Volume 43 of The Collected Letters of Thomas and Jane Welsh Carlyle sees the end of the epistolary relationship of Jane Welsh Carlyle and Thomas Carlyle that has been traced through all the preceding volumes. This volume covers the last winter and spring of their life together, from October 1865 to JWC’s death in April 1866. It continues through the aftermath of her death with TC’s shock at her loss, covering May through June 1866, when TC was preoccupied with writing his reminiscences of JWC. There are 114 of TC’s letters, 65 of JWC’s, and one written for her by Margaret Welsh. There are also two letters written by Margaret Welsh and three by John A. Carlyle on TC’s behalf. This volume is the last to have JWC’s letters placed chronologically with TC’s letters.
div1.q:
It made me laugh, Dear, that Edinr notion that because Mr C had been made Rector of the University, an office purely honorary; we should immediately proceed to tear ourselves up by the roots, and transplant
ourselves there! After thirty years of London, and with such society as we have in London to bundle ourselves off to Edinr to live out the poor remnant of our lives, in a new and perfectly uncongenial sphere; with no consolations that I know of but your three selves—and dear old Betty—! … And for Edinr people!— Those that I knew are mostly dead and gone—and the new ones would astonish me much if they afforded any shadow of compensation for the people I should leave here! No! my Dear we shall certainly not go “to live in Edinr,” I only wish Mr C hadn’t to go to deliver a speech in it; for it will tear him to tatters. (JWC to GW, 23 Jan. 1866 )
div1.p: Once the decision was taken about when the inaugural was to be held, TC moved into an unusually calm state of mind:
div1.q: This Rectorial Office is beginning to promise being a highly pacific one; and has already shifted itself to a corner of the mind where I seldom remember it, and never almost with anything of anxiety or displeasure. When the time for speeching approaches, I shall have to bethink me a little, & be bothered & tumbled abt for a week or so; but that done, I hope, essentially all will be done. (TC to JAC, 21 Dec. 1865 )
div1.p: TC was correct in that his winter continued pleasantly with no particular agitation until shortly before his departure, late March 1866, for Lord Houghton’s house, Fryston, Yorkshire, on his way to Edinburgh and the address itself. William Brookfield, an old friend of both Carlyles, wrote to Lady Ashburton describing a February visit: “I have seen the Carlyles pretty recently. She invalided a good deal—but still not set aside from human life— no less agreeable than ever; He—now that Frederick is finished, is more amenable to social intercourse than I have known him for long” (WB to Lady A, 21 Feb. 1866; MS: NLS Acc. 11388.62). During TC’s journey north, he was expressing himself in his more customarily agitated way at the prospect of travel, people, and public speaking, changing his mind about his plans, and arguing with other guests at Fryston. But John Tyndall successfully shepherded him through the visit at Fryston and all the subsequent drama of the events surrounding the inaugural. JWC, undoubtedly preferring to stay in London in an active social whirl, finally acknowledged in letters that her health did not allow her to accompany him; she wrote a dramatic account to TC of the imagined giving of his lecture:
div1.q:
What I have been suffering, vicariously, of late days, is not to be told! If you had been to be hanged, I don’t see that I could have taken it more to heart! This morning, after about two hours of off-and-on sleep, I awoke—long before daylight—to sleep no more! While drinking a glass 
of wine and eating a biscuit at five in the morning; it came into my mind what is He doing, I wonder, at this moment? and then instead of picturing you sitting smoking, up the stranger chimney, or anything else that was likely to be; I found myself always dropping off into details of a regular execution! now they will be telling him it is time! now they will be pinioning his arms! and saying last words! Oh mercy! was I dreaming or waking? was I mad or sane?—Upon my word I hardly know now! … My “Imagination” has gone the length of representing you getting up to speak before an awful crowd of people; and what with fuss and “bad air” and confusion dropping down dead!—Why on Earth did you ever get into this galley! (
  JWC to TC, 2 April 1866
  
)
div1.p: She used this trope of TC being hanged in other letters; it undoubtedly entertained her, but it also expressed an anxiety about her own health as well as about TC’s capacity to survive his own challenging situation. The irony for later readers is, of course, that it was she herself who was to drop dead, not TC.
div1.q:
Mrs Carlyle always when she was alarmed or agitated had a great sudden pain in her Back wh took her breath for the moment she used to say her mother had it & that some day it would kill her—well on Saturday she had put her little dog out of the carriage to run by the side a little A carriage drove over it poor thing & she sprang out of the carriage to take it up— took it in her arms & got in again— then in a little while the driver of the carriage was surprised not to have orders to go home
as it was her time— then they found she was dead— now she lies in her Coffin upstairs looking as tho’ she were asleep. ( GEJ to BB, 23 April 1866
; Appendix 260)
div1.p: Her sense of herself this winter may have been that of a woman back from the brink of death after her illness of 1864; she also wrote to contrast her ill-health during the summer of 1865 (particularly neuralgia in her arm) with her current comparative good health:

Another of her tropes this winter was to describe herself as a “Living Miracle,” using it both to express her sense of astonishment that she was still alive and to justify not traveling to Edinburgh with TC. She wrote an expressive letter of justification to Henry Inglis, an old Edinburgh friend:

TC’s insistence that JWC have a carriage at her disposal for a daily drive out meant that she was mobile during this winter in pursuit of friends and social events. Her latest (and last) protégée was Maria Price, the daughter of a tailor, hence “Sartorina,” who wrote a letter of admiration to TC and was astonished about six months later to receive a visit from JWC in her home above her father’s shop, October 1865. Price described her adoption into JWC’s circle in her “Recollections of Thomas Carlyle” (Blackwood’s Edinburgh Magazine, Jan. 1896), where she gave as many recollections of JWC as of TC in the detailed narrative of their contact between October 1865 and Spring 1866. Price’s first contact with the Carlyles was described briefly by JWC:

JWC included Maria in social gatherings at Cheyne Row and called on her often during her daily carriage rides. Maria Price’s recollections provide a record by a bright young woman from outside the Carlyles’ usual social and intellectual milieu that confirms the impression given by JWC’s letters as to how busy socially this last winter and spring were. After JWC died, Saturday 21 April the news was “gently broken” to Maria the next day by James Aitken, TC’s nephew, who had recently met her at a tea party (he also notified the Dilberoglues [see Appendix 258]). The speed and kindness of this shows the extent to which she had taken on an important role in these last months in the Carlyle household. Maria Price continued to see TC before and after her marriage and retained her admiration for him and his works. But it was JWC that she called the “sun of my little world” (Price, “Recollections” 35).

TC’s and JWC’s activities in her last three weeks can be quickly summarized. For his rectorial address, TC stayed in as private a space as he could find in Edinburgh, the back bedroom of Thomas Erskine’s house. TC was fÊted in Edinburgh, about which he wrote to JWC, 4 April: “am like a man
killed with kindness;—ah me, all the world coming tumbling on ‘Do me this, see me that; above all, dine, dine!’—Two days of it still remain to me; Friday morng, Friday or at latest Saturday, I am off to Scotsbrig; there to cool down, and be silent, dumb as stones.” At Scotsbrig he proofread the account of his rectorial address for its official publication (an unauthorized pamphlet was also soon to circulate). A sprained ankle slowed him down. JWC stayed with Margaret Oliphant at Windsor, 6–8 April. Oliphant wrote later about this visit, reminding us of the forensic skill in storytelling and gossip that JWC possessed: “[She was] looking very feeble and picturesque, and as amusing as ever, and naturally has been taking away everybody’s character, or perhaps I ought to say throwing light upon the domestic relations of the distinguished people of the period” (Oliphant, Autobiography and Letters 209); for a supreme example of gossip relayed by JWC, see the “London Scandal” relayed to Mary Russell (JWC to MR, [26 Jan. 1866]). On her return to Chelsea, she visited Lady William Russell, 8 April, and had Maria Price, Count von Reichenbach, and James Aitken to a tea party in Cheyne Row, 9 April. She sent TC a copy of Punch with its cartoon of TC and John Bright, “Wisdom and Wind-bag.” TC wrote JWC the last letter she was to read from him, 19 April, announcing he would go to Dumfries to stay with Jean Aitken, before leaving for London, Monday 23 April. JWC drove to Richmond with Sarah Dilberoglue, Thursday 19 April to see Margaret Welsh (on whose head a heavy wooden shutter had fallen); she called on Maria Price during her Friday 20 April drive to show her the Punch cartoon. TC’s letter of 20 April to JWC arrived after her death. In her last letter to TC, Saturday 21 April JWC wrote about her planned party for that evening, which was to include Margaret Oliphant, Geraldine Jewsbury, the Froudes, Professor Tulloch, Jane Tulloch, the Tullochs’ two daughters, Charlotte Williams Wynn, and the Spottiswoodes; she also planned a tea-party for James Aitken to meet the Dilberoglues on Sunday 22 April (see Appendix 258). She went for lunch with the Forsters and was then driven around her usual route, jumping out at Victoria Gate to retrieve her little dog Tiny (inherited from Clara Chapman) whose paw had been run over by a passing carriage; she died in the carriage sometime during several turns around Hyde Park, and her body was taken to St. George’s Hospital, near Hyde Park Corner. There is no possibility of knowing exactly from what JWC died as Forster organized (in the belief that it was essential for TC’s well-being) the avoidance of a postmortem, customary after a sudden death. Jewsbury’s reporting (see above) that JWC connected the pain in her back with something her mother suffered from and that “some day it would kill her” seems to confirm it was probably a stroke, Grace Welsh having died in 1842 of a stroke (CL 14:27–28). John A. Carlyle wrote that it was from “disease of the brain or spine,” but Sarah Dilberoglue reported that “we all believe it was an apoplexy” (Appendix 255 and 258). JWC had last consulted
Dr. Richard Quain early June 1865 and he was able to provide the certificate (noting the cause of death as “paralysis”) that prevented a postmortem. Her body was taken home to Cheyne Row to await TC’s arrival, Monday 23 April; she was then transported north to Haddington, Wednesday 25 April with TC, Forster, and John A. Carlyle in attendance, to be buried beside her father in St. Mary’s Church choir, Thursday 26 April.

TC interspersed his reminiscences of JWC with dated comments on his feelings and noting visitors to Cheyne Row; these have led commentators to interpret these reminiscences as being centered more on himself than her, foregrounding his own grief rather than her life. But reading them now in the context of TC’s circumstances immediately after JWC’s death, these interjections read more like a record of a life being lived as he wrote his memorial to JWC’s life, giving them the feel of a man struggling with grief and loss of purpose, rather than any attempt at self-centered self-justification. As he wrote so few letters in the months of May and June, the first two months of his writing of the reminiscences, we have inserted these dated entries into the notes to give as full a record as possible of how he was feeling day by day and who was visiting him. The final month of his writing JWC’s reminiscences, ending 31 July 1866, will introduce volume 44. During these weeks after JWC’s death, Maggie continued to organize the sorting and disposal of JWC’s belongings, but she probably also gathered JWC’s letters to TC. TC mentioned, 5 July: “Her Letters must be got sorted up and (approximately) dated and put in order,” as though they had already been brought together. By 8 July, he noted that the “collection of all her Letters now discoverable (by Maggie Welsh and me)” was nearly complete (Carlyle, Reminiscences 158, 160). TC wrote in acknowledgment of Maggie’s help just before she left in August; he also described to Lady Ashburton his own tasks of the preceding months:
div1.q:
Miss Welsh … is really a well-bred, correct, attentive & honourable creature … always cheerful, punctual & helpful. Has done me a great deal of good in searching thro’ the affairs of the Past. I have been at that, day after day, all summer; at all hours, in a sacred, sad & quasi-religious kind of company with Her who has left me forever: this has been the far best solace I have had; and with it, in genl, I have preferred to be left alone when permitted. I still look out into the future, asking if any work remains to me? ( TC to Lady A, 8 Aug. 1866
; vol. 44)
div1.p: At least part of the work that remained for TC became the collecting and editing of JWC’s letters for publication after his death, and this was the task he was to undertake over the next years. He wrote later about JWC’s last letter to him as he ended the self-imposed task:
div1.q:
The last words her hand ever wrote. Why should I tear my heart by reading them so often? They reached me at Dumfries, Sunday, April 22, fifteen hours after the fatal telegram had come. … I am at Addiscombe … day and house altogether silent, Thursday August 5, 1869. while I
finish this unspeakable revisal (reperusal and study of all her letters left to me). Task of about eleven months, and sad and strange as a pilgrimage through Hades.—T.C. (TC’s note to JWC to TC, 21 April 1866
; Froude, LM 3:335).
div1.p: The roots of all the controversies that raged after TC’s death, February 1881, over Froude’s publication of TC’s Reminiscences (1881), JWC’s letters (1883), and his life of TC (1882, 1884), lie within these weeks of work by TC after JWC’s death. But what also came from this work was the recognition of JWC’s talents as a writer. In her own life she was noted for wit, sarcasm, and comic narratives; but the collecting, then publishing of her letters, placing them in the public domain, led to recognition of her position as one of the supreme nineteenth-century letter writers and provided the basis for the twentieth- and twenty-first-century publication of her complete letters as part of the Duke-Edinburgh edition of The Collected Letters of Thomas and Jane Welsh Carlyle. In his introduction to its first volume, Richard Sanders, originator of this edition, acknowledged both JWC’s talents and TC’s recognition of them: “Carlyle may be heavy-handed at times in his books and at times even in his letters, but he sensed and fully appreciated the qualities in Jane Welsh Carlyle’s letters which were not only most compatible with her own unique genius but which indicate that she had much in common with the other great letter writers of literature” (CL 1:xviii). This volume completing the main publication of her letters now allows for the widest consideration of these talents.

JWC’s attitudes were resolutely un- or antisentimental, while TC, after her death, fell at times into an unrealistic and somewhat sentimentalized picture of her. As an antidote to any temptation to sentimentalize JWC, it seems appropriate to include reference to the Eyre controversy. This became one of TC’s preoccupations after August 1866 (see vol. 44) when his involvement in the Eyre Defence Committee undermined his public reputation both at the time and later. But the events began in October 1865 with the riots in Jamaica, Governor Eyre’s declaration of martial law, and executions. TC commented then: “What a shriekery is rising abt the ‘Jamaica Massacre,’—from a few throats, I can remark, but of choicest folly” ( TC to Lady L, 2 Dec. 1865
. But JWC reminds us in one of her late letters to TC that she could be as intemperate in her holding of unpleasant opinions as TC, when provoked by liberal expressions of support for the opposing view: “He [Abraham Hayward] told me women might patronize Eyre—that women were naturally cruel, and rather liked to look on while horrors were perpetrated. But no man living could stand up for Eyre now! ‘I hope Mr Carlyle does, I said, I haven’t had an opportunity of asking him, but I should be surprised and grieved if I found him sentimentalizing over a pack of black brutes’!” But, ensuring that TC
would hear a joke against himself, she included Hayward’s riposte that TC’s “great aim and philosophy of Life” was “‘the smallest happiness of the fewest number’!” ( JWC to TC, [10 April 1866] ). TC replied to this with a comment that epitomizes his own extremism in this area: “Nay (privately very!) if Eyre had shot the whole Nigger populatn, & flung them into the sea, wd it probably have been much harm even to them, not to speak of us? I really calculate, from the aspects & horoscopes, not. Blockheads black, & do white!” ( TC to JWC, 11 April 1866
). His “privately very” indicates that he was at least partly aware of the unpopularity and inappropriateness of these views.

JWC returned in this last volume of her letters to writing expansively detailed letters, to TC, to particular friends such as Mary Russell, Lady Ashburton, and the young Lady Amberley (previously Kate Stanley). Mostly she was concerned with telling her stories, but on occasion she did comment on her own letter writing, particularly when it provided an elegant excuse for tardiness:

This provides a commentary on the cultural change of the increasingly efficient provision of postal services and its effect on the writing of long letters, while providing an amusing excuse to Mary Craik by illustrating the way JWC’s long letters emerge from her upbringing and times. It is these long letters upon which most of our knowledge of her writing skills rests. In the twentieth- and twenty-first-century, as when they were first published, the range and accomplishment of her epistolary achievements have led to an assumption that she was somehow a “missing novelist,” rather than a supreme letter writer. The root for this assumption may rest with a mischievous comment in one of her letters this winter; after much description (in several
letters) of her new triumph over the threat to their quiet from neighbor noise, she concluded:
She clearly repeated this novel-writing trope to Charles Dickens; Forster described their last meeting, 3 April 1866:
div1.q: Among other things she gave Dickens the subject for a novel, from what she had herself observed at the outside of a house in her street … and the subtle serious humour of it all, the truth in trifling bits of character, and the gradual progress into a half-romantic interest, had enchanted the skilled novelist. She was well into the second volume of her small romance before she left, being as far as her observation then had taken her; but in a few days exciting incidents were expected, the denouement could not be far off, and Dickens was to have it when they met again. (Forster, Life of Dickens [1874] 3:277)

div1.p: October 1865-June 1866

October . TC writes to Lady Ashburton (4) of his and JWC’s anxiety about her coach accident in the Alps, late Sept. JWC and Geraldine Jewsbury visit Queen Emma of the Sandwich Islands; she has read some of TC’s works. TC acknowledges arrival of a barrel of provisions from Scotsbrig (10). JWC visits Maria Price in Camberwell, and invites her to Cheyne Row where she takes tea with the Carlyles and John Ruskin. JWC cautiously welcomes Jessie Hiddleston from Thornhill as a servant, and Sarah Warren is an efficient housekeeper, but the two servants do not get on well. TC is becoming hypersensitive to railway whistles. JWC is at a loss to find a doctor to replace Dr. Herbert Barnes who d. late Sept. She writes affectionately to Betty Braid in Edinburgh and refers to her cousin Jackie Welsh’s estate (27). JWC calls on Maria Price and takes her for a drive.

November . JWC sees Lord and Lady Russell at Henry Taylor’s “the other day” and is visited by Caroline Davenport Bromley “till eleven at night” (7); Col. Stanley takes TC for a tour of the London slums (7), and JWC goes to see Chang the giant (for the second time) with Miss Bromley (8). TC, “idle as possible” is reading widely including Richter and Plutarch. Froude tells him of Gladstone’s completion of his term as rector of Edinburgh Univ. (6); TC tells John A. Carlyle he has agreed, reluctantly, to accept the rectorship (7); John Stuart Blackie writes telling TC his majority is 347 (11), and TC replies (13) asking for help and advice. TC formally accepts the office (14) and asks David Laing (16 [15]) to be his assessor on the University Court. Many letters arrive congratulating him, including one from his early friend Thomas Murray (17). Laing accepts ([20]), and the formal address is discussed; eventually TC decides on giving it in April 1866 (24). He declines an immediate invitation to Fryston from Lord Houghton, but hopes he can visit on his way to Edinburgh in April (23). TC and JWC attend a dinner at the Pollocks (24). JWC has to devise methods for deadening outdoor sounds while still admitting fresh air to 5 Cheyne Row, along with suppression of poultry noises from new neighbors next door (28). While her horse, Bellona, is in the stables after an accident to her hoof, JWC nervously rides an omnibus with TC, the first time since her accident ([29]). TC accepts the formal Senatus invitation from Edinburgh Univ. but holds out for an April inauguration (29). TC acknowledges gift of A. H. Clough’s Letters and Remains from Blanche Clough, who was its ed. (30).

December . TC thanks Lady Lothian for the gift of a wild turkey, sent from their estate at Blickling Hall, Norfolk (2). He mentions for the first time the insurrection in Jamaica in Oct. and Governor Eyre’s response (2). Tennyson visits Chelsea (3). TC and JWC spend an evening at the Forsters’ to celebrate TC’s 70th birthday (4) with Robert Browning. Maria Price, invited (3) to visit JWC (6), also sees TC on his return from seeing Chang the giant with Tyndall and another friend. The Carlyles dine at the Froudes’, along with the Milmans and the Brookfields (8). JWC sleeps poorly: “Thick skinned people haven’t a conception of what we thin-skinned individuals have to endure!” ([10]). She writes affectionately to Lady Ashburton, regretting that she is to stay abroad for the winter ([ca. 12]). JWC acknowledges receipt of a hamper (including eggs and whisky) from the Russells at Holmhill, Thornhill ([16]). TC mentions interest in buying a house in Jean Aitken’s neighborhood “even at this late date” (16). Ruskin calls at Cheyne Row (16); TC praises Ruskin’s Ethics of the Dust as “a most shining performance” (20). Seasonal gifts from Jean Aitken arrive (24), including a cape and whisky, and TC writes James Carlyle Jr. to praise the changes he has made at Craigenputtoch (25). The Carlyles go to Christmas day dinner with the Forsters (25). JWC writes affectionately to Charlotte Southam (26) and to Betty Braid, telling Betty she has a cold and about her cousin Robert Welsh dying (in Liverpool) of tuberculosis, like his sisters before him (28). JWC sends money for old servants and acquaintances for Mary Russell to disburse ([30]).

January . TC writes to his brother John that he is improving in both health and mobility; the maids now sleep in the old attic study, from which the books have been moved to his working room downstairs. He sees Anthony Sterling. JWC, though suffering from a cold, manages still to make visits (1). A week later TC is complaining of lack of sleep, “nerves shivery” and “spots … a kind of red eruption” on his side (9). JWC writes Geraldine Jewsbury (“my dear young Woman!”) telling her she misses her ([12]); she also misses Lady Ashburton and Miss Bromley, both away from London (16). Weather is bad; TC tells John A. Carlyle he is feeling “weak, languid, ineffectual” (22 [24]). To her aunt Grace Welsh, JWC dismisses as ridiculous the idea that she and TC would move to Edinburgh on his being made rector (23).

February . TC thanks David Laing for his preparatory work in Edinburgh for the rectorial address (14). He resumes his old dream of a quiet Scottish retreat if his relatives could find him one, asking Jean Aitken to “take a little peep” at an old cottage, for himself or brother John (21).

March . JWC writes Frederic Chapman (2) on the death of his wife, Clara (28 Feb.). She has decided not to accompany TC to Edinburgh (2); she tells Henry Inglis (3) that TC is putting off all the arrangements as long as he can.
He accepts Lord Houghton’s invitation to visit Fryston on his way to Scotland (10). He writes to John Stuart Mill (13) in friendly terms. JWC writes David Aitken (15) to decline an invitation for them both to stay with the Aitkens, while TC writes Laing (15) to fix 2 April as the date of his address. Tiny, Clara Chapman’s dog, joins the Carlyle household; Jane tells Lady Airlie ([16]): “my little dog is turning out all that could be wished.” JWC invites herself to visit Margaret Oliphant during TC’s absence ([17]). She sends her Edinburgh aunts tickets for TC’s address ([26]), while TC addresses handwritten tickets of admission to various friends. TC is to stay with Thomas Erskine in Edinburgh, and JWC writes (28) to Erskine to arrange for TC to see Betty Braid. TC leaves for Fryston (28), and Maggie Welsh arrives to stay in Chelsea for a few days; James Aitken is also staying, while looking for lodgings. TC, after a fractious start, seems to enjoy his time in Fryston with Lord Houghton and John Tyndall.

April . TC in Edinburgh is feeling less nervous about the address (1), while JWC in London feels “if you had been to be hanged, I don’t see that I could have taken it more to heart!” (2). Tyndall wires that the address is “a perfect triumph” (2); JWC, Dickens, and others celebrate at John Forster’s birthday party (2); TC has to endure various dinners, including the Senatus dinner (3), Erskine’s (4), and Masson’s (5). Maggie returns to Liverpool ([3]). JWC writes to TC: “I wish you had been coming straight back—for it would be so quiet for you here just now” (4), while TC writes: “two days of it still remain to me … at latest Saturday, I am off to Scotsbrig; there to cool down, and be silent, dumb as stones” (4). He reaches Scotsbrig (7) and begins to proofread (8–15) the account of his rectorial address for publication. He sprains his ankle (9), which slows him down. JWC stays with Margaret Oliphant at Windsor (6–8). On her return, she visits Lady William Russell (8); she has Maria Price, Count Reichenbach, and James Aitken to a tea party in Cheyne Row (9). She sends TC a copy of Punch ([11]) with a cartoon of him and John Bright, “Wisdom and Wind-bag.” TC can walk again with care (15), and enjoys Scotsbrig’s calm and good food. JWC writes affectionately to Lady Ashburton (15), and reports on her busy social life. TC’s sister Jean Aitken arrives in Scotsbrig (16), and Mary Austin returns to The Gill. TC writes to thank Thomas Erskine for his hospitality (17), and sends both JWC and John A. Carlyle copies of the published rectorial address; as soon as his ankle allows, he is for “Dumfries & home!” (17). JWC calls on Tyndall (16) to hear his account of the rectorial address. TC writes JWC (19) the last letter she was to read from him; he announces he will go to Dumfries (20) to stay with Jean Aitken, before leaving for London. JWC drives to Richmond with Sarah Dilberoglue to see Margaret Welsh (19), a day earlier than planned, as she has had “an ugly accident” (a shutter fell on her head). During her drive (20),
JWC calls on Maria Price to show her the Punch cartoon of TC. JWC also saw both Jewsbury and Erasmus Darwin during Friday (20), probably in the evening; Darwin found her “extra well.” TC’s last letter to JWC (20) arrives after her death. In her last letter to TC (21), JWC writes about her planned party for that evening, comprising Margaret Oliphant, Geraldine Jewsbury, James and Henrietta Froude, John and Jane Tulloch and their daughters Sarah and Isabella, William and Eliza Spottiswoode, and Charlotte Williams Wynn. She goes for lunch with the Forsters and is then driven around Hyde Park, jumping out at Victoria Gate to retrieve the dog, Tiny, who had been hurt by a passing carriage; she dies in the carriage, and her body is taken to the nearby St. George’s Hospital (21). TC writes Forster (22) from Dumfries that he and his brother John will arrive in London the following day and asks him to make arrangements for JWC’s funeral, 26 April: “Do this for me, dear F,—and for her.” He also writes to William Dods, asking him to make the necessary arrangements in Haddington. Maggie Welsh comes to London to help TC. TC, John A. Carlyle, Forster, and Edward Twisleton travel to Haddington where JWC is buried next to her father within the walls of the unroofed choir of St. Mary’s Church (26). TC travels home overnight (26–27); Emilie Venturi calls on him shortly after.

May . Maggie Welsh continues sorting JWC’s belongings. TC replies personally to messages of condolence from Lady Augusta Stanley on Queen Victoria’s behalf (1), Erskine (1), Betty Braid (2), Ruskin (10), and Lady Ashburton (20), while between them John A. Carlyle and Maggie Welsh write to others. Henry Taylor, Arthur and Laura Russell call, and Forster comes to take TC for a walk (13). Froude and Emilie Venturi call (15). TC writes to Geraldine Jewsbury commenting on her notebook of JWC’s anecdotes (22). He begins writing his own reminiscences of JWC in response to Jewsbury’s notebook (25).

June . Mazzini calls (3). Lord Houghton visits (9). TC writing his reminiscences of JWC: “Ought I to quit this ‘work’ here, which I feel to be very idleness?” (10). John A. Carlyle goes to Jersey (20), and TC walks “abt, a good deal, silent,—especially on long walk towards midnight, along a range of solitary streets” (21). The inscription for JWC’s memorial tablet is carved in London, then sent from London to Haddington (23); its attachment to John Welsh’s tombstone is organized by William Dods. TC writes Mary Craik (29) on the news of her father’s death (25); John A. Carlyle returns from Jersey (30). TC writes to Eliza Snowden with whose family he and JWC first lodged in London (30).

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], 4 Oct. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p:
We were sadly shocked, last week, by news of yr dangerous accidt amid the Alpine precipices,Lady Ashburton was hurt in a carriage accident in the mountains on her way from Vevey, Switzerland, to Aosta late Sept.; see 42:227 TC to JAC, 29 Sept. 1865
, and see JWC to MR, [16 Oct.]. She replied, 7 Oct.: “I shd have got dear Emilia Bunsen to have written to you from Aosta but I didn’t want to make you both needlessly anxious & rather hoped you wd hear nothing of the accident till I cd tell you I was all right. We went to look at the place by daylight where the accident happened— only wondered that we hadn’t been killed on the spot. It was on the slope of a steep hill into a deep ditch & against a wall that the carriage upset.” Aosta, Italian city, apparently about 8 mi. (13 km.) from the scene of the accident.—such one figures them, ignorant otherwise of the exact localities and circumstances. It is a miserable adventure; & has raised among us, as you may image, no end of speculatns and alarming consideratns,—especially of anxieties to know how howWord repeated. you are going on after it. I in vain suggest to my poor Wife that it might have been far worse; she dwells upon the fact that it is itself far too bad, thinks “all the neuralgia will settle on that hurt shoulder,” and dares not wholly believe the favourable accts there since are;—in short, dear Wounded One, you perceive we are in great perplexity abt you; and cd never worse than now afford to be left in the dark as well! And it is principally in the hope of getting some authentic word, if not from yr own hand (whh, alas, is probably impossible), at least from yr own honest self,—who are earnestly petitioned hereby to tell us the exact truth, no better and no worse than it actually is,—that I now write. My own greatest anxiety is, to know whether that shoulder is completely well set (whh you will now be able to judge of); whether yr Italian Surgeon altogether knew his busss? I persuade myself there wd not be much complexity in the Operatn: but great trouble, pain & damage are often enough incurred by a mistake in that preliminary point.Lady Ashburton replied: “altho the Italian doctor assured that the arm was set & wd soon be quite well—his words proved false as I have had to have it set again & it is now tightly tied up & it will be some days before I know whether this performance has been any better than the other. If, as I hope, it turns out well done, the first use of my right arm shall be to write to you. I need scarcely say how much I value yr kind words & quite feel with you how thankful I shd be that it is only the shoulder & still more that my dearest little child was not with me. She was here with my kind friends the Bunsens”; surgeon unidentified further. Please send us a word, never so short! If that poor shoulder is the left one, perhaps you can now write agn,—tho’ I hardly hope it! At any rate, Fraulein von BunsenLady Ashburton’s letter was written by either Frances Helen (b. 1826) or Emilia Bunsen (b. 1827), das. of Frances Bunsen, b. Waddington (1791–1876; ODNB) and Christian Karl Josias von Bunsen (1791–1860; ODNB), Prussian ambassador to Britain 1841–54, known to TC since 1839; see 11:29 TC to JCA, 13 Feb. 1839
. Frances Bunsen and her family lived at Carlsruhe, but spent the summer and autumn of 1865 in Vevey. She wrote from Château de Blonay, Vevey, to Heinrich Akenen, 12 July: “I hasten delightfully to announce myself as quartered here for the summer, with Frances [and] Emilia” (Augustus J. C. Hare, Life and Letters of Frances, Baroness Bunsen [1879] 2:351); see also Surtees, Ludovisi 117. or some charitable soul will send us a line or two
of yr dictatn. Oh dear, oh dear, what a ride that must have been, to Aosta from the place where the mischief happened! But agn, as I reflect, how easily might it have been the head instead of the shoulder!—

I have been here, as you know, since the last days of Augt;TC spent the summer in Scotland, staying with various friends and relations, returning to Chelsea 28 Aug. but, except that the weather has been burning hot, I have no record to give of myself or others. No mortal has been idler than unworthy I, all summer, and till now; still witht the least symptom of change for the better. I had, of course therefore, a gloomy time in Scotland, and still have here; and shall, it is like, continue to have,—if I never do find any faculty of work agn, so long as I live! Nor have I the least prospect that way hitherto; feeling myself entirely broken down and “done for”; so heavy have the roads been, the miles so many. I intend to be very quiet, however, and will say no more of all that.

After 3 days of the Erskines, we went round by Keir (my Brother & I), and spent 3 days there. Stirling was the kindest of landlords; kind too, and good & simple, was his new “Lady Anna,”TC and his brother John A. Carlyle stayed with Thomas Erskine and his sisters at Linlathen, Dundee, 15–19 Aug., and then with Sir William Stirling Maxwell and his new wife, Anna Maria, at Keir, 3 mi. (5 km.) NW of Stirling, 19–22 Aug.; see 42:197 TC to LLA, 18 Aug.
; 201–3 TC to JWC, 21 Aug.
; and 201–3 TC to JWC, 22 Aug.
surely an importt conquest to him: and his House—never saw such a House like a Palace of the Incas; with ornaments preciosities and curiosities, enough to fit out three Houses: “most expensive!” as an old Scotch maidCoterie speech; phrase of Helen Mitchell’s, servant at Cheyne Row Dec. 1837–Nov. 1846 and Oct. 1848–Feb. 1849. of ours used to say on great occasions. I hardly staid above a fortnight in Edinr; made no other visits, or none to speak of. The place was nearly empty to me; much changed, I did not think for the better. London too has been “empty” thus far,—nay I surmise quietly it will never agn be very full! Yet it will grow fuller a little! Ruskin we saw the other night: “going to have something out abt Xmas”John Ruskin, The Ethics of the Dust: Ten Lectures to Little Housewives on the Elements of Crystallization (1866), which was to come out in Dec.; see TC to JRU, 20 Dec.
(really). “And when is Lady Ashbn coming home?” Yes, when?Lady Ashburton replied: “About my return: it depends upon this arm—except for you & the dear wife London wd look wholly ‘empty’ to me. I can’t believe it is the same place I used to be so happy in with him. I sometimes think it might be best for Mary’s future that I staid abroad to economize till Melchet is finished—but I haven’t quite settled anything”; Melchet Court, Hampshire; for work on the house, see Surtees, Ludovisi 122. That is it.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-EW [EWEL], [9? Oct.]. MS: NLS 609.754. Pbd: Froude, LM 289–91 inc. Dated approximately by reference to cooler weather, and the visit to Queen Emma. JWC dated the letter “Monday” but also referred to “tomorrow” being “Wednesday”; she may have written over two days; it may also be dated a week earlier.
div3.head: JWC TO ELIZABETH WELSH

docBody.p:
I am very glad indeed of the Photograph and grateful to you for having had it done at last!JWC had asked Elizabeth Welsh to have another photograph taken Nov. 1864; see 41:111 JWC to AW, [30 Nov. 1864] ; for earlier photographs of the aunts, see 38:76 TC to GWE, [2 March 1863] , for Grace; 41:108 JWC to AW, [30 Nov. 1864] for Ann and Elizabeth.
knowing how all such little operations bore you! It is very satisfactory as a portrait too;—very like and a pleasant likeness! “handsome and Ladylike”—(the epithets that used to be bestowed on you in old times). Photography is apt to be cruel on women out of their teens! but this one is neither old looking nor cross looking. So thank you again with all my heart.

We have had a severe time of it with heatMuch of September had been very hot; see 42:216 TC to JCA, 10 Sept.
since our return to London. Plenty of people found it “delicious”; but Mr C and I—and indeed the whole household not excepting the cat, suffered in our stomachs and even more in our tempers. It was quite curious to hear the cat—squabbling with her cat-companions in the garden just as the Cook and HousemaidThe cook-housekeeper, Sarah Warren, and the maid, Jessie Hiddleston. squabbled in the kitchen, or Mr C and I in the ‘Up stairs.’ A general overflow of Bile producing the usual results of irritability and disagreement! Now, the weather is again favourable to the growth of the domestic virtues, and also, sad to say, to the development of rheumatism.

I asked in my last letter if you knew anything of Mrs George?Margaret Welsh, widow of JWC’s paternal uncle George. I drove to Richmond the day after with Mr C to call for the Chadwicks;Edwin Chadwick (1800–1890; ODNB), social reformer and retired civil servant, and his wife, Rachel, b. Kennedy (1802–91); known to the Carlyles since the early 1840s, now living at 5 Montague Villas, Richmond. where Mrs George visits and is regarded as a woman of quite superior qualities. And Mrs Chadwick informed me that She and “Mrs Welsh” had settled to pay me a visit on Wednesday (tomorrow) “Was Mrs Welsh at Richmond then”? “Oh yes! she had been home for a month”!! “In her own house?” “Yes—in her own house”!— — I had understood the House to be let for another yearUnexplained further.—didn’t you?— There she is however, and coming tomorrow

I paid a visit the other day—which interested me—to “Queen Emma”Emma (1836–1885), queen consort of King Kamehameha IV (1834–63) of the Sandwich Isles (now Hawaii) from 1856 to his death; she stayed with Lady Franklin from Aug.; see 42:178 JWC to LLA, 8 Aug.
; for her portrait, see 42:179
JWC to LLA, 8 Aug. [1865] .—
She is still in the House of Lady Franklin (the widow of that “Sir John”—that everybody used to sail away to “seek”)Jane Franklin, b. Griffin (1792–1875; ODNB), traveler, widow of Sir John Franklin (1786–1847; ODNB), arctic explorer. She lived at 2 Upper Gore, Kensington. Sir John Franklin disappeared in 1845, during his last voyage, in search of the North-west Passage; more than 30 expeditions went to look for him, 1847–1859, some sponsored by Lady Franklin; according to a note left by Francis Rawdon Moira Crozier (1796–1848; ODNB), Franklin’s 2d in command, Sir John d. 11 June 1847, his body apparently buried in the ice; the remains of some of his crew were found on King William Island in the Canadian Arctic Archipelago; all the others also perished, some after struggling to the Adelaide peninsula, effectively finding the North-west Passage. When Lady Franklin made a journey to the Sandwich Islands amongst other out of the way places she was received with great kindness by “the royal Family”—and is now repaying it by having “The Queen” and her retinue to live with her; tho’ our Queen has placed her apartments at Claridge’s Hotel at the Sandwich Islands Queen’s disposition.The Times reported, 14 Sept., “Her Majesty’s Government have placed at the disposal of Queen Emma … and her attendants, the rooms at Claridge’s Hotel, Brook-street, which are usually occupied by such Royal personages as are received as guests in this country.” We (Geraldine Jewsbury and I) were taken by Lady Franklin into the Garden where The Queen was sitting writing; and “much scandalized to receive us “in a little hat, instead of her widows cap!” which she offered to go in and put on! She is a charming young woman—in spite of the tinge of black—or rather of green. Large black beautiful eyes, a lovely smile, great intelligence both of face and manner, a musical, true voice, a perfect English accent. Lady Franklin introduced me as “the wife of Mr Carlyle, a celebrated Author of our country”— “I know him I have read all about him, and read things he has written”! answered the Queen of the Sandwich Islands!!! In fact the Young Woman seemed remarkably well-informed on “Things in General”!Coterie speech; see Carlyle, Sartor 14.
The funniest part of the interview, for me, was to hear Geraldine addressing Queen Emma, always, as “your Majesty”; in a tone as free and easy as one would have adopted to one’s cat!

Do you remember Joseph Turner who was deaf & dumb— I saw him on the Platform at Dumfries and spoke to him and he has written me such a nice letter. I will send it when I have answered it. I cannot conceive how he should have known my Father—he was too young.Joseph Turner (ca. 1798–1872), deaf and dumb teacher in Dumfries; for their meeting at Dumfries Station, see 42:96 JWC to TC, [28 June] ; Turner was about three years older than JWC. TC wrote later (ca. 15 June 1866) in his reminiscences of JWC: “(Deaf-and-dumb ‘Mr. Turner,’ an old Strathmilligan acquaintance, recognised by her in the Dumfries Railway Station, and made to speak by paper and pencil, I writing for her because she could not,—oh me, oh me, where is now that summer Evening, so beautiful, so infinitely sad and strange! The train rolled off with her, to Thornhill, Holm Hill, and that too, with its setting Sun, is gone)” (Carlyle, Reminiscences 127).

I hope Ann has gone or is going to Dumfriesshire It always does her good that trip.Elizabeth’s sister Ann; she enjoyed traveling; see 39:66 JWC to JAD, 21 Feb. [1863]
. And many people are glad of her coming.

I saw her old friend Mrs Gilchrist at Thornhill. How changed from the time when she helped me to make woolen mattrasses and moreen bed-curtains at Craigenputtoch!Probably Jane Gilchrist, b. Kellock (ca. 1785–1866), widow of James Gilchrist (d. ca. 1851), sheriff’s officer at Thornhill; for moreen curtains at Craigenputtoch, see 4:393 JWC to TC, [19 Aug. 1828] .— The history she gave me of her accidents was most pitiful! I didnt like the DaughtersJane Gilchrist (ca. 1839–1904), seamstress; it is likely her mother was also a seamstress. looks much—but she had the room as clean as a pin and spoke kindly enough tho’ roughly to her Mother.

closer.salute: Good by dear Elizabeth / yours affly /

div3.sourceNote: TC-JC Jr. [JACA], 10 Oct. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JAMES CARLYLE JR.

docBody.p:
You expect to hear of the opening of the Barrel,TC wrote to Scotsbrig, 26 Sept., asking for oatmeal; see 42:225 TC to JCA, 27 Sept.
yesterday having hastily apprised you that it had at length got to hand. The poor chickens were nearly altogether ruined,—not quite altogether, for I dined yesterday on part of one (a safe part, and as good a chicken as I have seen), and I believe portions of the others are still to be extricated, and put to use,—better use than that of being dog’s meat; small thanks to our railway friends! But, on the whole, this is all the damage; everything else is right & successful. Meal unsurpassable (part of it appeared as cakes at dinner yesterday, such the impatience of a certn person); not one egg was broken or hurt; ham, butter & the rest, of course cd shift for themselves. So that all we can do at prest is to thank you all for yr great & unvaried kindness to us, whh, I fear no degree of “thanking” will ever fully repay!—— I fancy these railway carriers have a kind of tendency to take Saty night for their luggages & goods? Such was the roaring we used to hear far-off abt the edge of Sunday on solitary Middlebie Rig.Middlebie Rig, ½ mi. (1 km.) NW of Scotsbrig.— If so we shall know again.

I am very glad to hear of yr progress at Craigenpk: pray persist till you have got everything completed to yr own satisfactn, and in yr own way; to whh I entirely trust in this matter. If there is anything to be done just now as to the replanting &c, I wish you to do it, whenever suitablest. In short to take
charge of the thing, on the basis I repeatedly explained to you when we talked together.— I shd like very well to hear of that mile of Galloway road being rendered reasonable;James Carlyle Jr. wrote, 3 Nov.: “I am sorry to say that the piece of Road is only likely to get a partial repair after all. The Surveyor & Clerk to Trustees have stumbled on the only argument they have against us vizt that we do not pay them (Stewartry) … any Road money & consequently cannot compel them to repair that piece of road principally used by the tenant of Craigenputtock. The Surveyor estimates the cost of a thorough repair at £30 and offers to see the work properly done and pay the half, provided the Proprietor of Craigenputtock will pay the other half I cannot recommend you to do this; and in the meantime I will urge the moral obligation and try for all that can be got out of them.” but I doubt it may take some time still: all you can do, pray do it. Are you to proceed by private offer on Octr 20; or will there be an Auctn (Roup) after that, if have got no offer that pleases you?The Dumfries Courier advertised, 10 Oct.: “LARCH WOOD FOR SALE. On the Estate of Craigenputtock in the parish of Dunscore and County of Dumfries. About 1000 Trees of old Larch Wood, 12 inches and under in diameter. Offers may be sent to Mr James Carlyle, Junior, Scotsbridge, Ecclefechan till 20th October curt.” James Carlyle also sent TC his account for Craigenputtoch, 3 Nov.; see TC to JACA, 6 Nov.
Once more, I have no doubt you will do the wisest;—and so I leave it.

We are tolerably well here, especially yr Aunt, who is wonderfully so, for her; pray Heaven it only last! I myself am not very flourishing,—especially since last week when, by a kind of accidt, I fell into quarrelling with the railways here (as I did at Scotsbrig, to yr sad knowledge) and starting at them in my bed! I am “putting up curtains” &c, really with effect; & hope to be finally victors, & have done with that foolish strife, in a day or two now.— Aunt Jean told us poor Jenny was ailing rather;James’s sister, Jenny; her first child had been born in July; see 42:174 TC to AC, 6 Aug.
Aunt Jean was Jean Carlyle Aitken. whh we were grieved to hear: pray mentn her when you next write.

I am very anxious abt—abt many things, in my prest (ill-sleeping) mood!— will add only that I faithfully participate in yr Father’s anxiety abt the New Lease of Scotsbrig,See TC to JC, 18 Oct.
and whether he is to go or not to go! I think it wd be very wise wise Word repeated with a line over it at turn of page. if he went or consulted Mr Edwd HogganEdward Hoggan (1793–1867); factor of the Waterside estate, which included Scotsbrig; see 40:205–6 JWC to TC, [24 Aug. 1864] . (as the Dr John A. Carlyle. writes me this day he was talking of doing): but you are to tell him from me that, tho’ I wish he might get Scotsbrig on terms that pleased him, and not be driven to lift anchor after 40 years of quiet stay: yet that if he miss, there will be other resources; and, for one example, there will be a stroke at Craigenpk open for him if he still like it! That is certn enough. But I add not another word today; except my love to him & to all of you,—and my desire to be informed
abt this consultatn at Waterside or what comes of it; especially abt the fate of “Scotsbrig Tak,” so soon as that is settled;—and remain always,

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MCA, [11 Oct.]. MS: NLS Acc. 7864. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:291–93. Quot: Hansons, NE 535.
div3.head:
JWC
TO MARY CARLYLE AUSTIN

docBody.p:
It is “a black and a burning shame”Coterie speech; see 12:304 JWC to FW, [28 Oct. 1840] . that I should not have told you before now that the butter is good—very good! and Mr C eats it to his oatcakes in preference to the Addiscombe fresh butter which is the best in the world. The Girl—or I should say young woman (her age being thirty) whom I brought from Thornhill is an admirable hand at oat-cakes; and is fond of being praised—as most of us are when we can get it; so is willing to do the cake-making of the family tho’ it isn’t “in her work.” And I seldom eat “loaf bread” now; having taken it into my head that the oat cakes do instead of rhubarb pills— She is a capital Servant that Jessie; and pleases Mr Carlyle supremely attending to all his little “fykes & manouvres” (as she calls it in her private mind) with a zeal and punctuality—that leaves him nothing to wish! But to me she leaves a good deal to wish! not in her work. She is clever and active and has an excellent memory. But as a woman I might wish her different in some respects! with a face that captivates every one by its “brightness and sweetness” she is, I find, what the clergyman at Morton,John Murray (1798–1882), minister of Morton, 3 mi. (5 km.) N of Thornhill, 1839–82; see 14:59–60 TC to JWC, 7 March 1842
. who had known her from a child, told me she was and I wouldn’t believe him till I tried, “a—vixen” And when Mrs Russell told me she was—“Oh—Well!—about that, I should say she was as truthful——as the generality of servants—nowadays”!— Even that mild account was stretching a point in her favour I think. But so long as Mr C find her all right, the rest dont signify. He has been off his Sleep again; listening for “railway whistles” which have been just audible—nothing more—for years back, but he never discovered them till his experiences at Dumfries made him morbidly sensitive to that soundTC suffered from the noise of the railways in Dumfriesshire, both at The Gill and at Scotsbrig; see 42:66 TC to JWC, 7 June
, and 193 TC to JWC, 17 Aug.
—the last week he has slept better. And in other respects he is better I think than before he went to Scotland—can walk further and looks stronger. For me; my neuralgia continues
in abeyance—no pain in my arm or hand or anywhere— And tho a certain stiffness remains I can do my self, without help almost everything I need to do and some things not needed! For example, I made myself yesterday a lovely Bonnet! My sleep has been greatly improved ever since my return from Scotland for the bad nights I have had lately were not my own fault but induced by listening to Mr C jumping up to smoke, to thump at his bed and so on“Alas, alas; watchful for two! How sad, sad that now is to me!” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:293).—
God bless you Dear kind regards to them all

signed.name: Jane W CarlyleReginald Blunt noted later: “Mrs. Carlyle returned to Chelsea [summer 1865 ]; and my mother [Frances Mary Blunt] and she saw a good deal of each other; and in the autumn, when Carlyle came back, she was busy, with my father’s help [Gerald Blunt], in arranging the rescue from the workhouse, and establishing, in tiny quarters of her own, of their old laundress, the faithful Mrs. Cook” (Blunt, Memoirs of Gerald Blunt 90). For more details about the settling of Mrs. Cook (b. ca. 1785), see Carlyle, Reminiscences 186.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 12 Oct. MS: NLS 526.32. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head:
TC
TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Your last Note was peculiarly welcome to me, and did me good in more than one way. It is longer than yr Letters usually are, lets one into some of yr feelings, thus awakening ones kindly sympathies, and interesting one in a wholesome human manner. Such a thing was very welcome to me at the moment!

For above a week past, I have been in deadly quarrel with the railway whistles hereabouts; sometimes had no right sleep at all,—only a 4, 3 or 2 hours of broken do; in such sad, shivering and ghastly humour as that always brings with it thro’ the day too;—and, in fact, till last night when I had an excellt real & healthy sleep, I cd not be said, with all my industries, to have seen my way to speedy victory in the busss. It is a most unfortunate “quarrel,” and a most unexpected. The railways are exactly what they were when I left them in May; but at that time I heed them no more than the wind; nor for a month after my return did I notice them with the least criticism; and yet, on slight cause, since 10 days ago it has come to this! One cannot escape from railways; all over habitable England & Scotland that Scream extends its fitful dissonances, making night hideous if you have disordered nerves: it has given me many reflexns, perhaps monitions and lessons that may be useful,
during this last week of battle. Enough of it at prest. I have hung up an ingenious curtain (and have more in reserve if necessary); I believe I shall have to introduce a ventilator going topway, ample & effectual like that at Dumfries;See 42:39 TC to JWC, 25 May
, and 47 TC to JWC, 28 May
. and, in bad times, shut my windows altogether if I like. During all this, what is matter of hearty thankfulness, Jane sleeps what we count “well,”—i.e. as well as for years back; and has no pain in her right arm, and some use of her hand, tho’ it has yet little strength. Daily drive of 3 hours is the life of her, poor little soul; & she is very punctual and careful. Item let me add that, tho’ it seems very sad to have acquired in Scotland, with so much trouble to myself and others, merely a “sensibility to railways,” this is by no means my only conquest, as I surmise. My strength, for walking &cis certainly a little increased; my feet too, in the skin part, are greatly improved (corns almost in abeyance);—and, in short, perhaps all these shiverings and nervous horrors were perhaps needed to awaken me into a healthier state than that enchanted one of the 12 years past. Esperons,Coterie speech. faisons effort
[let us hope, let us make an effort]!

Thank Jean very much for her Sunday Letters; and bid her continue them. Tell her, James junr has yet sent me no whisper of ansr;TC presumably had offered James Aitken Jr. vols. 8–13 of the Leipzig edn. of Frederick; see 42:225 TC to JCA, 27 Sept.
Bernhard Tauchnitz, publisher of the Leipzig edn., wrote to TC, 13 Nov.: “It is a particular pleasure to me, to send you, according to your wishes, 3 complete copies of your Frederick and 2 copies of vol. 8–13.” for whh I am waiting. James Senior’s BookTC had offered Jean’s husband, James Aitken, a copy of John Pinkerton, Modern Geography; a description of the Empires, states, and colonies, with the oceans, seas and islands in all parts of the World, 2 vols. (1802); see 42:225 TC to JCA, 27 Sept.
will arrive by railway, I think, within a week now: it goes in the same box with—what think you?—a cast of Woolner’s Bust; whh I myself don’t much like;Presumably a plaster cast of Thomas Woolner’s bust of TC; for a photograph of the bust, see 42:18 TC to JCA, 12 May
; for TC’s dislike of the bust, see 42:69 TC to JWC, 8 June
. but whh whhWord repeated at turn of page, with a line over it. I know well Jean will be well pleased to possess, & joyfully find a bracket (James & she) in some luminous part of that fine staircase. I was shocked and astonished to find what price (£5) Woolner puts upon it; but me it costs nothing, this one copy, & we don’t want it here. I must end, paper having ended.

signed.name: T. CarlyleJohn A. Carlyle, who was living at The Hill, Dumfries, with Jean and James Aitken, wrote to TC, 25 Oct., about his winter plans: “Some days ago I wrote to Miss Orrock that I dont mean to be in Edinr at the usual time this year, & that she need not keep any rooms for me. I came to this resolution the more easily, as none of her rooms (except the upstairs ones which you know & which would not do at all for the winter) are other than strange to me, & I don’t know how I should be able to train myself to them. The old ones in Hanover Street had become tolerable to me only by long usage, & my stay in them was frequently dreary enough. If I find Dumfries wearisome in the winter I can leave it whenever I may think fit; & meanwhile I have books about me & make plenty of work for myself.” Miss Orrock was probably Agnes, the older sister; John had lodged with Agnes and Elizabeth Orrock in Edinburgh for many years. They had recently moved from 67 Hanover St. to 73 George St.

postscript.p: (read the enclosed two, & burn)Two enclosures unidentified.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 14 Oct. MS: NLS 518.12. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p:
I wrote to the Dr yesterday; & have not the least more of news to tell you today. But as one of those inclosed PiecesSee TC to JAC, 12 Oct.
may have had something of not intelligible to you, I forward this supplementary one (from a difft quarter, on the same most small subject),Unidentified. whh has just arrived this morning, with a Book accompanying. How “idle of wark”Coterie speech; see 9:161 JWC to JWE, 4 March [1837]
. must parts of mankind be, to get into rippling & motioning on the fall of nothing better than an honest pebble or bigger than a pea!— The Book seems not quite bad; if it keep up promise, I will send it you by and by. Please return the little Newspaper Clipping; Jane may possibly want it.

I hope you are writing to me at the very time this arrives! Yr salutatns on the monday morning, are a welcome phenomenon to me as I step down stairs to begin a new Week. Never after 9 a.m. now; we have changed our Postman here; the last oneThe new Chelsea postman unidentified; the previous one was John Bullock (1815–90); see 42:231 42:biographical notes . used to keep us waiting sometimes for an hour longer.

The Dumfries shoe-ties,TC had asked Jean to buy shoelaces for him from William Nibloe (1815–89), Dumfries shoemaker; see 42:129 TC to JAC, 15 July
. tape kind & string kind, are a great “temporal blessing,”—perfect both kinds of them.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JMM, 16 Oct. Addr: 6 Torriano Villas / Kentish Town. MS: Strouse. Hitherto unpbd. John Macrae Moir (1827–81), journalist and lawyer, sec. (1862–81) of the Royal Scottish Hospital, also known as the Scottish Corporation, a charitable institution for impoverished Scots in London; see TC to UC, 6 May 1861 .
div3.head: TC TO J. MACRAE MOIR

docBody.p: I reflect that it is not proper to waste yr time in suspense; and that I ought at once (such are the medical aspects this morning) to decide, whh I do with regret and reluctance, that I must decline the great honour you have offered me.The Royal Scottish Hospital held an annual St. Andrews Day Festival, 30 Nov., to which eminent Scots were invited as speakers; Moir presumably asked TC to speak. And you can assure yrself, and especially the Gentlemen who deputed you, that I do esteem it a distinguished honour, and shall always thankfully remember it as such, tho’ forbidden in my present state of health to answer otherwise than as now.
Believe me /

postscript.p: J. M. Moir Esq
Secry &c

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, 16 Oct. Addr: Holmhill / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire / N.B. PM: London, 19 Oct. 1865. MS: NLS 609.755. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NLM 2:337–39 inc.
div3.head:
JWC
TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p:
Well, Dear,
are you home again? And have you found the dear Doctor all right! not broken in health or spirits by being left to his own shifts and “the mercy of servants” for a few days! I heard of him in your absence as not only alive, and “looking well” but as “remarkably agreeable”! Depend upon it we are not so indespensable to these men of ours as we are apt to flatter ourselves! Any one would have sworn beforehand, that my Husband, could not have survived six months of house-keeping on his own basis, he being, as my scotch HelenHelen Mitchell; see TC to LLA, 4 Oct.
said of him, “one that could do nothing i’ the worl for hisell, and had no turn for taking up wi other women”! but he did, and survived it very well too! doing his own work all the while, without a day wasted in conjugal regrets! You might have done as I wanted you to do in summer, and taken the holyday I had schemed out for you, and found the Dr on your return nothing worse than very glad to get you back!
It was from Mrs EwartAlicia Ewart. I heard of your being in Glasgow. Such a long nice letter she sent me! How anybody can keep up such a Spirit at eighty exceeds my comprehension!

I also received a nice note from Mrs Macgowan!Mrs. McGowan, unidentified further. in which she spoke enthusiasticly of the Dr’s kindness in some illness she had had. I am sure if being looked up to as a benefactor by a whole countryside can make one happy; Dr Russell must live in a sort of inward Heaven.

What is to become of me for a Dr when next I need one? I was so satisfied with Herbert BarnesDr. Herbert Sedgwick Barnes d. 26 Sept. last winter, when I had conquered my prejudices against having a Dr under thirty, who wore a glass in his eye! He treated me most skillfully; and was so gentlemanly and kind and I had been quite at ease as to what I should do next time. I was saying to Mrs Warren one night, what a comfort that was. And went down stairs after to receive the Rectors Wife,Frances Blunt. who looked anxious and flurried, and bit by bit told me the astounding fact that Herbert Barnes was dead!Reginald Blunt later recalled: “Mrs. Carlyle’s doctor, Herbert Barnes, upon whose visits she had relied greatly during this last year of weakness and prostration, died suddenly; and my mother, hearing the news, and fearing that Mrs. Carlyle might be greatly shocked if the intelligence reached her abruptly, at once went over to Cheyne Row, and broke the tidings quietly to her” (Blunt, Memoirs of Gerald Blunt 90). He had become a great favorite with his Fathers Patients, and is much lamented. The poor old Father took the news like a child; crying one moment and forgetting the next!Dr. Alfred Brooke Barnes, physician, was JWC’s doctor until he became ill (see 40:123 TC to LLA, 28 June 1864
; 198 TC to JWC, 22 Aug. 1864
; and 224 40:biographical notes ).

I know of no other Dr in Chelsea that I could trust myself or any belonging to me to, without a shudder! though there are some scores of them! And Dr Quain is at such a distance; besides the delicacy about sending for him; when he absolutely refuses his fee!Dr. Quain treated JWC during her illness, winter 1863–64; see 41:104 JWC to MC, 28 Nov. [1864]
. Clearly I ought to take no other business in hand, till I have made a choice; for illness may come; and the want make itself felt when I am powerless to supply it.

In the meantime, I go on famously without doctoring; even of my own! The wonderful improvement on my sleep has continued, and the cessation of all pain in my arm and hand has continued There is still stiffness enough. But that too wears off by degrees, and has already ceased to be much of an inconvenience. I have just made myself a bonnet! black silk and ermine and little feathers!— Indeed can put the hand to anything needed! only I cant raise it to the crown of my head. In the winter weather I suppose it will make itself felt
again—that “gout” or whatever it was; but there is a good old proverb “afraid of the day one is never to see”! I don’t do that much.

I have various things to tell—in the small talk line. About Queen Emma,—the Chinese Giant,Chang Woo Gow (ca. 1846–93), known as the Chinese giant, about 7 ft. 8 ins. (2.34 m.) tall, according to the Illustrated London New s
, 30 Sept., was “lately arrived in London for the purpose of displaying his wonderful stature to us little people, at the Egyptian Hall.” The Times announced, 5 Oct.: “CHANG, the Great Fychow Giant, and Suite.—FOUR LEVEES daily, at the Egyptian-hall, Piccadilly. Afternoon, 3 o’clock and 4 o’clock. Evening 8 o’clock and 9 o’clock. Admission 1s. and 2s. 6d.” For the drawing (pbd. ILN 30 Sept.
) of Chang, his “wife” who performed as “King-Foo,” and Chung “who stands but 3 ft. high,” see 12 above
.—Bedlam (!)Unexplained further; JWC may have been using the term metaphorically, or she may have visited the Bethlem Royal Hospital for the treatment of mental illness, at St. George’s Fields, Southwark. and so on! But all that had better be kept to put in the letter to Mrs Ewart, which I shall be writing one of these days. and you will get it all indirectly.

figure.p:
Illustrated London News
, 30 September 1865

docBody.p:
Lady Ashburton is still at Vevay; detained there by an accident which nearly cost Her her Life, and did cost her a dislocated shoulder.See TC to LLA, 4 Oct.
A carriage drawn by mules in which she was crossing the Alps got overturned, on the brink of a precipice! She had to travel eight miles in agony, before it could be got set; and then it was ill set
and had to be all done over again! She talks of wintering abroad which will be a great loss to me.

Jessey is well, and continues to be an active and punctual Servant. Mr C is immensely pleased with her. and has reason to be. I think she must have her mother’s preference for the male sex!Jessie’s mother, Margaret Hiddleston, had been servant to JWC’s mother; see vol. 14; her “preference for the male sex” is unmentioned elsewhere. for she never exhibits any ill temper with Mr C but is ready to fly at his word. Perhaps one reason why she is better for him than for the rest of us, is, that He never pays the slightest regard to a servants humours; remaining sublimely unconscious of them! So long as he gets his bidding done! She has had the “young man that neighboured her at Closeburn manse”Unidentified further; Closeburn, village and parish 2½ mi. (4 km.) SE of Thornhill. to visit her; indeed is not at all so ill off for visitors as she led me to expect. With Mrs Warren she seems to fight less than at first; but still they are by no means cordial. I kept them under silent but watchful observations for a while, to find out where the fault lay; and so far as I could discover, Jessey’s passionateness, and suspiciousness, and quarrelsomeness
was chiefly in fault. The Proverb says; “where two quarrel the right is with him who says least.” By this rule; the right is with Mrs Warren, who has never spoken of Jessey at all beyond once, asking me, “if the friends from whom I had got Jessey had not told me what a dreadful temper she had. I said, several people had spoken of her temper being sharp. “Oh well! that’s all right, she said, but I thought it strange, if taking her among your own people none of them should have told you that”—and then she spoke of something else. Whereas Jessey is never weary of complaining of Mrs Warren, and saying things of her which I know to be untrue. “Im a good servant! I have had plenty of experience! I know my work—better than Mrs Warren can tell me! and I’ll not let her take any authority over me! One Mistress is plenty! And if Mrs Warren pretended to be my Mistress I wouldn’t stay!”— That is the style!— To me she puts a certain restraint on her tempers, feels, I believe, that it is better. But it worrys me a good deal, to think it is not because I am kind to her and because she likes me in return, that she behaves with tolerable respectfulness to me; but merely because she knows and feels that I should tolerate no incivility! I thought her so loveable looking! and could have, for her looks sake and other sakes have liked her dearly! but there is that about her that perpetually warns me, (as you did) “not to make too much of Jessey.” Please say nothing of this—and dont leave my letter about. It wouldn’t improve her temper to have it come round that I had complained of it. What of yours? Does the Dairy Maid continue good? and Catherine? As for little Mary she will be always goodMary Russell’s servants; JWC was particularly fond of Mary; see 41:57 JWC to TC, 29 Sept. [1864]
. and there till she marries
Kindest love to the Dr—

signed.name:
Jane CarlyleFor a photograph of Mary Russell, see 15 above>
; it was taken by R. Wilson, Dumfries, at the same time as the photograph of JWC (see frontispiece.), presumably at Holmhill. Another photograph, of John, one of the Russells’ servants, was taken at the same time; see 16 above>
. The photographs, all with the same backdrop, were presumably taken during JWC’s last visits to Holmhill, 17 June–3 July and 16–24 July 1865.

figure.p: Mary Russell, [1865]

div3.sourceNote: TC-JC, 18 Oct. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JAMES CARLYLE

docBody.p:
I this morning have a Letter from James junr, in regard to Craigenputtock & its larches, roads &c.See TC to JACA, 10 Oct.
concerning whh you are to tell him that the whole
of it is comfortable & satisfactory; and that he is simply to go on in the same business-like style till the thing be completed according to his mind. To his mind, by all I can judge, will likely be to mine also.

You are abt offering for Scotsbrig, I perceive; and of course will be in considerable dubiety, till you resolve what it is really worth, and also what it is not worth to you. These points once settled, you will be on a firm basis. I am of course anxious enough for a right decisn to you; but, alas, can give you little or no assistance. One thing I write to day agn to repeat to yrself, as it may be of some small weight in the matter: namely, that Craigenpk shall be at yr refusal, if you like; and certainly no tenant shall be preferred to you at a given rent whh I can reckon fair! Adamson’s idea was that a Valuer (“Hardgrove,”Samuel Adamson, agent for British Linen Co., Dumfries; valuer, unidentified further. I think he suggested) shd be got to name a probable rent for the place, and that then we shd advertise. You will believe I do not want more than a just rent from anybody whatever; least of all from you or yours! And, I find, it wd perhaps satisfy me best, if in this, the last transactn I can expect to have abt poor Puttock, I shd happen to leave it comfortably in the hands of one of yr Boys. Know this privately always, & say nothing abt it. This is all Jane is well; and I am very glad yr Jenny is.See TC to JACA, 10 Oct.
For myself, I ought not to complain either, tho’ the struggle abt sleep is not even yet quite ended,—nor will be, I begin to perceive, till some far deeper and more profitable questions are better settled than they are!

div3.sourceNote: TC-HA, 19 Oct. MS: Hornel. Hitherto unpbd. Henry Attwell (ca. 1834–1901), teacher, author, translator, and botanist.
div3.head: TC TO HENRY ATTWELL

docBody.p: Thanks for the Papers, botanical and other, whh you took the trouble of sending.Unidentified further; Attwell was a prolific author of works on various subjects. I have been proposing to my Wife to drive me out to Barnes, some day, for the sake of a glance into yr schoolrooms and operatns there;Attwell ran a school at Nassau House in Barnes, a London suburb S of the Thames. but the weather and other poor impediments have stood in the way hitherto.
Believe me, /

postscript.p: Profr Hy Attwell
&c&c

div3.sourceNote: TC-CAW, 21 Oct. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO Charles A. WARD

docBody.p:
Many thanks for yr new fruits of the earth,Ward wrote, 20 Oct.: “The waning year brings in its periodicity old recollections with a desire to commemorate. This makes me again call upon you to receive fruits of the sunny south, in token of goodfellowship & old memory.” Ward often sent the Carlyles gifts of fruit or vegetables; see 41:17 TC to CAW, 11 Sept. 1864
. TC wrote on Ward’s envelope: “Octr 1865 / with ‘fruits of the earth,’ & first meeting afrds.” Ward concluded his letter: “Enclosed is the track it has fallen to me to be busy in”; Ward had presumably been busy with his wine business. whh the revolving year and your continued kindness brings round to me. In the turbid ever-whirling vortex of things, it is good that here and there a clear and pleast thing drop down upon us, to redeem a little the ugly lot, and remind us that there is a sky ever-bright, above all that!—

I am now an idle man, or one striving to be honestly idle (whh is not quite so easy); and have remembered often enough that a bit of personal acquaintance with you was one of the satisfactions I had long anticipated. Now that I know you at hand,Ward lived at 1 Chapel St. West, Mayfair. I say Let there by no farther delay. Call any day here abt 2 p.m. (say, some day early next week), and we will have a little talk together.Ward enclosed a card with his name and address; TC wrote on it: “end of Octr 1865 (interview).” Ward wrote again, 30 Oct.: “I must not let the week round without saying how great was the gratification I experienced from the kind indulgence you granted me of listening to you for an hour or more.”

div3.head: TC TO RICHARD CHENEVIX TRENCH

docBody.p:
Your kind little mementoUnidentified; Trench published prolifically on the subject of language. is very welcome to me, not on the philological side alone! For the rest, I have no doubt you are right in regard to that of “amuse”; and I have corrected accordingly. The verb, in that sense, is still common in Military Writings,In military terms “amuse” meant to divert the attention of the enemy from one’s real designs. TC’s correction unexplained.—or at least was, in those of last century; as I have had sad reason to know, since we used to meet from time to time!Trench had been part of the Ashburton circle that used to meet often at The Grange; see 38:50 TC to LS, [31 January] 1862
. For the photograph taken by Vernon Heath (ca. 1819–95; ODNB), Oct. 1863, of TC, Louisa Baring, Lady Ashburton, and JWC “sitting about on the steps of one of the Porticos” of The Grange, see above; see also 38:241 JWC to MR, 21 Oct. [1862]
, where it was previously referred to and identified only tentatively as of this date.—

“The Grange” is gone,After Lord Ashburton’s death, 1864, The Grange passed to his heir, Francis Baring, 3d Lord Ashburton. —alas, yes: how that bright bit of Earth, with all the sunny Figures in it, noble some of them like few, has vanished from us, like the baseless fabric of a vision; melted into air forever!

figure.p: Thomas Carlyle, Louisa Baring, Lady Ashburton, and Jane Welsh Carlyle at The Grange, [1863]

p.hi: Courtesy of Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University

docBody.p: For those of us who still remain in this world, it is sad we shd never meet. But you come to Town now and then,—perhaps this very winter, you are coming? Have the charity to call on me, at any time; or give me some notice, and I will find you out. I am now idle enough; with little prospect but that of continuing so for the remainder of my appointed days.

With many kind regards to Madam,Frances Mary Trench (1809–90), m. 1832, with whom he had 12 children. if she will accept them; and with all
manner of good wishes to you both, in yr new and eminent sphere of activity,Presumably this was TC’s first contact with Trench since he became archbishop of Dublin, 1 Jan. 1864. I remain

div3.sourceNote: TC-MW [MEW], 24 Oct. MS: NLS Acc. 9207. Pbd: Eugen Oswald, Das Magazin fürdie Litteratur des In- und Auslandes No. 17 (24 April, 1886): 259–62. Meta Wellmer (1826–89), German writer, teacher, feminist, vegetarian, and spiritualist.
div3.head: TC TO META WELLMER

docBody.p: I have received yr gentle and graceful Letter, and yr little BookPossibly Meta Wellmer, Theophile: eine Erzählung (Halle, 1862). which is of the same character; also the Jean-PaulJean Paul Richter (1763–1825), novelist and humorist, whose work TC had translated; see Carlyle, Works 22:117–332. Autographs, whh latter I now return,—with many thanks for yr goodness to me, and for the pleasure I have had in all that. The Jean-Pauls I had to get copied into roman hand (his cursive-schrift being too abstruse for me); and have found them altogether Jean-Paulish; very pretty, especially that to Keul,Unidentified further. and altogether curious and interesting to me,—with their old Postmark of “Baireut” coming to hand, after 40 years,Richter lived in Bayreuth from 1804 until his death, 14 Nov. 1825. by the singular route of “Donaghadee”!Small town in County Down, Ireland, 18 mi. (29 km.) E of Belfast, where presumably Wellmer was living. The Note to yr late FatherUnidentified further. ought to be bound up with some Copy of his Book;Unidentified. both Notes you will no doubt carefully keep.

I can only hope and wish that you may be prospering in your new position, in your new country; and believe that, in Ireland as elsewhere, goodness can produce only good to yrself and others. With many thanks, I remain,

div3.sourceNote: JWC-BB, 27 Oct. MS: NLS 609.756. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NLM 2:340–41 inc.
div3.head:
JWC
TO BETTY BRAID

docBody.p:
My darling Betty!
When I was lying, unable to sleep, in my bed last night it suddenly went thro’ me, like a knife, that your dear last letter was still unanswered! I sometimes intend so certainly to write a letter, that the intention imposes on my own mind for an accomplished fact; and it is only when some chance has put me on cross questioning my own memory, that the truth comes out, that I had not written, but only positively meant to write!
Now that I have realized my neglegence, I hasten to repair it.

I was much amused by your account of the visit from Anne and Grace.Ann and Grace Welsh, JWC’s aunts, living in Edinburgh. It was full late I think!
