Grace wrote to me after having seen you; taking credit to herself for the “great effort”(!) and telling me particulars of very old date now, as if I had been left in ignorance about you till it pleased them to give me your news. I replied that “I was obliged to them for their details but that these had been all communicated to me at the time by Mr Erskine of Linlathen who had a great respect and regard for Betty, and had gone to see her and sympathize with her on the first opportunity”Erskine visited Betty Braid after the death of her son George who d. 10 Feb.; Erskine wrote to JWC of his visit by 12 March; see 41:187 JWC to BB, 12 March [1865]
. And that you yourself, under whatever difficulties of sorrow or weakness, never neglected me—as they did!

They never alluded to the subject of Jackie Welsh’s moneyJohn Amelia (“Jackie”) Welsh, JWC’s cousin, d. 28 March 1864. Her estate was valued (26 May 1864) at £404 1s 8d. in that last letter. A long time ago ElizabethElizabeth Welsh, sister of Ann and Grace. wrote suggesting that i should write to John FermeJohn Ferme (b. ca. 1797), Writer to the Signet, JWC’s childhood Haddington friend; see 37:33 JWC to WDO, [31 Oct.? 1860] . about it! I answered, that “considering the smallness of the gain to each of us, when divided; I didn’t see it was worth showing oneself anxious and greedy about it”!It is unclear among whom Jackie Welsh’s estate was to be divided; she had lived in Haddington with her aunt Jane Scott and her mother, Elizabeth Scott, who was still alive in May 1863, when she was “frail and stupefied” (39:135), but presumably was now also dead. Poor Jackie, she is a loss to me! besides having a sincere regard for me, naturally; since I was the only one of her father’s name that recognised her existence;Jackie Welsh was the illegitimate da. of JWC’s uncle William Welsh. she used to keep me up with all the affairs of Haddington. And dull, gossipping, lowmin[d]ed place as it has become (if indeed it ever was otherwise), I was always interested to hear who had died, or been married
or been born in it! Now I am quite cut off from it. Especially since the loss of poor General Veitch (Hamilton—the youngest and best Veitch)Hamilton Veitch, JWC’s schoolfellow and old friend. who was always, when not in India, flying between London and East Lothian like a weaver’s shuttle!

I continue free of my Neuralgia; tho the wet weather we have had is very trying for that sort of illness. My arm and hand are still stiff—but I don’t mind that when the pain is gone—and I can do mostly every thing for myself that I need to do—and even some things that neednt be done by myself! For instance I made myself a beautiful bonnet the other day!

Only think I get my pills—ever since I was in Scotland—from Duncan & FlockhartDuncan, Flockhart & Co., Edinburgh pharmacists; see 38:186 JWC to TC, 2 Sept. 1862
.—and I am sure they suit me better than any other physic. I have been sleeping much better latterly, and every thing turns on that with me! On the whole, after all these horrors I have come thro’, and in spite of the stiffness which makes walking too difficult; I am really in better health I think, than when you saw me last at Stenhouse!JWC had last visited Betty Braid Sept. 1862; see 38:192–93 JWC to TC, [4 Sept. 1862] . Suppose I send you my likenessPossibly the photograph of JWC taken in Holmhill, June or July; see frontis.; or a carte-de-visite of one of the photographs taken by John Watkins and by Elliott & Fry, April 1865; see 41:217 JWC to JW, [25 April] , and 42:48 TC to JWC, 29 May
; and 49
.—that you may see how I look after having come thro nervous torments enough to drive me mad—if I had had any madness in my blood!JWC was seriously frightened that she would go mad during her illness, Nov. 1863–Aug. 1864; see 40:xii 40:introduction and 171 JWC to TC, [5 Aug. 1864] .

But it the photograph will be too small for your eyes, without my large magnifying glass which always reminds me of old Mrs ScottFriend of JWC’s mother; see 14:89 TC to JWC, 25 March 1842
; possibly Mrs. Mary Scott (b. ca. 1777) of Court St., Haddington; otherwise unidentified further. at Haddington who used to read her Psalm-book with just such a glass. I wish I had you here to make you look thro’ it. How do your spectacles hold out? Be sure and tell me if you need a stronger pair.
God bless you dearest Betty— My kind remembrance to your Husband.Alexander Braid.

div3.sourceNote: TC-AT [ATT], 30 [28] Oct. Addr: 96, Richmond Road / Hackney / N.E. PM: London, 28 Oct. 1865. MS: Hilles. Hitherto unpbd. Alexander Thomas Taetgen (1843–1927), author, poet, and musicologist; he was staying in the John Stables Lodging House, 96 Richmond Rd., Barnsbury, Hackney. TC misdated; dated by postmark.
div3.head: TC TO ALEXANDER T. TAETGEN

docBody.p: You are perfectly at liberty to publish that little Piece called Adieu,TC’s poem “Adieu,” first pbd. in 2d edn. of Critical and Miscellaneous Essays (1840); see Carlyle, Works 26:473–74. The poem was widely anthologized, although Taetgen’s publication of the poem is untraced. For commentary on the poem, see The Collected Poems of Thomas and Jane Welsh Carlyle, ed. Rodger L. Tarr and Fleming McClelland (Greenwood, FL, 1986) 172–73. in what way you like.

postscript.p: Alexr T. Taetgen Esqr

div3.sourceNote: TC-JC Jr. [JACA], 6 Nov. 1865. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JAMES CARLYLE JR.

docBody.p:
I meant to ansr yr Note on Saturday,Sat. was 4 Nov. James Carlyle Jr. wrote, 3 Nov., reporting expenses in relation to the selling of wood at Craigenputtoch. TC wrote on James’s envelope in blue pencil: “4 Novr 1865 / Wood sold at Craigk.” See also TC to JACA, 10 Oct.
the day it came; but time & hurry wd not then allow. Today too, by mismanaget and foolish accidt, I have to write in great hurry: but the essential is capable of being very easily said.

I think you have managed to perfection at Craigenpk, in all respects; and that nobody cd have done it better. With punctuality, with profit, without loss of time, or of any chance or advantage you had! The sum realised is far beyond what I ever cd have expected;James Carlyle Jr. wrote: “I beg to enclose a/c of my intromissions since I have been in charge of Craigenputtock Woods. I trouble you only with an abstract and preserve the detailed statement in my books here. I enclose also a deposit receipt for one hundred and forty-five £s Stg (£145).” The woods raised £169 10s 3d before expenses; see opp. and nobody cd have picked it out of the affair more succinctly than you have done. I am very much obliged;—and have only to leave the whole remaining matter, road,The approach road to Craigenputtoch; see TC to JACA, 10 Oct.
replanting, &c&c, confidently in yr hand. Permit me also to insinuate into you the inclosed bit of greenback,TC noted in his checkbook: “6 Novr 1865 / to Jas Carlyle junr (for Craigenpk woods &c) / £10 .. 0 .. 0” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753).—
not as payment, for such zeal & skill wd be difficult to pay;—but in testimony of my thanks, and as a solacement to myself in the matter. And that is all, for the prest.

figure.p: Accounts for Craigenputtoch, October 1865

p.hi: Courtesy of the National Libraryof Scotland

docBody.p:
We hoped secretly, yr Father being at BromwichamOlder form of Birmingham, possibly Saxon; see 30:126 TC to LOA, 29 Nov. 1855
. might have taken a return ticket on Saturday and have had a look at London and us agn.James Carlyle visited Cheyne Row 1–2 Dec. 1863; see 39:255 TC to JC, 6 Dec. 1863
. But he never stirred. I tried all I cd to recollect his Birminghm Address, any Birmm address;James’s da., Jenny, and her husband, William Scott, lived in Birmingham. but it was quite gone. One of these days, perhaps this very day, he will be off to Waterside on an importt errand:To consult Edward Hoggan about renewing the lease for Scotsbrig; see TC to JC, 10 Oct.
Hoggan had been shooting near Scotsbrig while James Carlyle was away; James Carlyle Jr. reported that his father was to “go up to Mr Hoggan’s place before the bargain of Scotsbrig can be settled. I judge, from what Mr Hoggan said to my brother and myself, the case is hopeful and we may continue to live at Scotsbrig at a considerably higher rent than hitherto.” I can only wish it may speed with him to the full;—that he may not offer too much more rent, and that he may get repair of Houses, Offices & whatever is reasonable out of those poor complex people. No doubt you have all considered & consulted abt it along with him; & have fixed upon your No, where you decided to stop,—I hope not
far away from the real mark of the thing as it actually stands. I shall long to hear, so soon as possible, how matters end.John A. Carlyle wrote to TC, 9 Nov.: “You will have heard that [yesterday] the two Jamies of Scotsbrig … succeeded in getting a new lease of Scotsbrig.”

We are pretty well here; that is, no worse than usual. The sad glarry weather (wetter in late weeks than I had ever seen in London) has seemingly given me some flying rheumatism &c, but that amounts to little. I am still rather skittish as to sleep, but not so ill as I was in that way;—for the rest “idle utterly,” idle as a dry bone and do not yet trace the smallest appetite for work. I gave yr Aunt her message;James Carlyle Jr. wrote: “Will you please say to my Aunt Mrs Carlyle that the tea … is a great favourite here. Since the 15th June last I have ordered 120lbs.” she is now out driving thro’ the world, & I ought to be on foot before now. With love to everybody.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady Am [KST], 7 and 8 Nov. MS: NLS 1808.106. Pbd: Amberley Papers 1:426–48. Quot: Fielding and Sorensen 305–6; David Southern, “Jane Welsh Carlyle’s Last Protégée,” Carlyle Studies Annual 23 (2007): 191–92. Lady Amberley was JWC’s friend Kate Stanley, now married to Lord Amberley.
div3.head:
JWC
TO LADY AMBERLEY

docBody.p: “Hope I don’t mind your writing to me?!”— Oh you bewitching little Darling! I do “mind” it though!—very much! Only—there are two ways of minding; and my way of minding any token of kind remembrance from you is not to be hoped against! Won’t I be glad to see you, when you come? and your “Boy”!Lady Amberley’s son, John Francis Stanley, b. 12 Aug. To you who have come by natural course into this possession, there may be nothing to confuse your soul in it; but to me, who have hardly seen you, since the time when your maternal instincts were fully occupied in hatching canaries!Kate Stanley gave JWC one of her canaries in 1862; see 36:214–15 JWC to LST, [30 Aug. 1860] , and 225 JWC to KST, [5 Sept. 1860] . The idea of a Baby Boy of your own is an idea to stand amazed before, “as in presence of the Infinite”!Coterie speech; see 33:74 JWC to TC, [6 Sept. 1857] .— I must see Him before I shall be able to clearly believe in Him, as an accomplis[h]ed fact! And then—if He be really so like his Mother—I think I should like to—eat Him! He must be so nice!

What a mercy you found out that OgresseDavies, the baby’s nurse; for her cruelty to the child, see Amberley Papers 1:413–16. before she had done any irreperable mischief! Poor little Child! I can especially sympathize with him under the Gin; for my own NurseUnidentified further. used to put me into dead sleep with whisky, when she had assignations outside! And my Mother was always of opinion that my
sleeplessness in after Life was owing to having been drunk so often as a Baby!! I privately believed, it was owing rather to the interminable lessons I had to learn! You won’t over-excite the Brain of your little one with “Lessons,” will you? when the time comes? There are more ways than one of “making little Children pass thro’ the fire to Moloch,”Moloch, a god worshipped by the Phoenicians and Canaanites, to whom parents sacrificed their children; see Lev. 18:21. and that of making them prodigies of Instruction at the cost of their bits of nervous systems seems to me sadder than any other way; for is it not a sort of “seething of the kid in its mother’s milk”?See Exod. 23:19.—And after all, teach and teach what you will; what Gibbon said remains true, that “Instruction is hardly of any use except in cases where it is almost superfluous”!Edward Gibbon (1737–94; ODNB), historian, Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire (1776–88), ch. 4.

I have seen such a curious example lately of the superfluousness of Teachers, where there is capacity to be taught! Some months ago Mr C got a letter from a girl, giving her opinion of himself and his BooksMaria Price wrote later about first reading TC’s works: “As time went on, quite a passion of gratitude and admiration for this new teacher, this great genius, filled my heart to overflowing” (Price, “Recollections” 31).—with considerable enthusiasm of—what shall I say?Coterie speech; see 17:36 JWC to TC, [11 Aug. 1843] .— admiration?— I did not feel sure whether it was admiration or love; but anyhow she expressed herself with an elegance, and eloquence, and real understanding of the subject, that excited my interest in her, and deserved, I thought some answer. So, as Mr C can never be moved to answer unknown adorers, especially unknown female adorers; one day that I had nothing to do, good or bad, I drove to Camberwell to find the “Maria Price” of the Letter. Heavens and Earth! The address she had given was a Tailor’s shop!Maria Price’s father, Joseph Price, was a tailor; in the 1861 census, Price was listed as a master tailor, employing three men, at 10 Church St., Lambeth, with his three das. and a governess also recorded at that address. He had possibly moved to smaller premises in Camberwell. Not a rich Tailor’s like Nichols, whose wifeHarvey Nichols, linen drapers and clothiers, Knightsbridge. Originally opened in 1831 by Benjamin Harvey (d. 1850); James Nichols from Oxfordshire, employed 1841, became a manager 1845; he m. Harvey’s niece Anne Beale (b. 1816), 1848; Nichols then became a partner with Anne Harvey (Benjamin’s widow), 1850, creating Harvey Nichols & Co. goes to court in Diamonds, and tears Lady Downshire’s lace flounces;Lady Caroline Frances Hill (1815–93), marchioness of Downshire; m., 1837, to Arthur Blundell Sandys Trumbull Hill (1812–68), 4th marquess of Downshire; known to the Carlyles since the mid-1850s; see 37:266 37:biographical notes ; the event is untraced. but a Tailor represented by one waistcoat and one pair of trowsers, in one small window! For one moment my heart failed me, and I was near driving
away re infecta [with the business unfinished]. Then I said to myself; is not she the more, not the less worth seeing, for having had no “advantages” in making herself what she is? So I asked if Miss Maria Price was within, and was shown up the smallest stair ever seen, not belonging to a hen roost How there came to me a little creature, looking eleven years old, but in reality six and twenty; how she blushed and flashed into sudden beauty, (like one of Balzac’sHonoré de Balzac (1799–1850), French novelist and playwright. colourless Heroines) at Mr Carlyle’s name; How sweetly she looked and spoke, with what modesty and good breeding;Maria Price later wrote: “one never-to-be-forgotten day in October 1865 (just about six months after my letter), I was told a lady had called to see me, and on entering the room I saw a lady indeed, but a perfect stranger, who told me that she was Mrs Carlyle. Overwhelmed by this announcement I sank into the nearest chair; but the beautiful eyes and kind smile soon reassured me, so that I was quite at my ease” (Price, “Recollections” 31). how I invited her to Cheyne Row, and how she came, and how Ruskin took her home in his carriage!Price wrote about the visit: “Knowing nothing of Chelsea, in my ignorance of the locality I took a train to Victoria, then walked to Cheyne Row. … I saw Mrs Carlyle on a sofa at the farther end, who started up with both hands outstretched in welcome. … Not long after this Mr Ruskin was announced, and we were all three soon engaged in animated conversation. … At last Mr Carlyle came in, erect and tall.” Price sat between TC and JWC at tea, and John Ruskin sat opposite: “Of the conversation I took no notes, but I remember that we talked of many things—of John Sterling, of Edward Irving, of Mrs Oliphant’s Life of the latter, and Mrs Carlyle’s own early days.” TC gave Price (signing each vol. for her) a 2-vol. copy of Wilhelm Meister; Ruskin gave her a lift home in his carriage; they had a discussion (“I had almost said a dispute”) “as to the relative beauty of sunlight or moonlight … but Mr Ruskin’s amused sense of the unsuitability of ‘Wilhelm Meister’ to a girl was still uppermost” (Price, “Recollections” 32–33). In about a fortnight, JWC called on Price in her carriage (with one of the Reichenbach das.) and took her for a drive: “She was full of interest and curiosity as to how Mr Ruskin and I had got on together, teasing me not a little about my having to write a critique on ‘Meister’” (Price, “Recollections” 33). and how she is turning out the most comfortable protégée that I ever fell into—! About all that and much more, I will tell you if you like, when you come— In writing it would be too tedious!

When I told Lord HoughtonRichard Monckton Milnes, Lord Houghton. the other day at “Lady William’s”Lady William Russell. that I had “discovered a Genius,” he threw his arms up wildly and exclaimed “Oh God forbid”! But I assured him my Genius wanted nothing of anybody not even a subscription to a Book of Poems! When I asked her had she ever thought of writing a book herself she answered, like the wise little woman she is. “Oh Dear! no! I have read far too many good Books to think of writing a bad one”!

Where on earth, or under it, do you imagine Mr Carlyle is going this evening? First he is to dine with your Brother (Colonel Stanley) at The Travellers
Club, and then to be conducted by him all thro’ the Slums!!John Stanley, lt.-col., Grenadier Guards; the Travellers Club, 106 Pall Mall, London. Lord Stanley wrote to Lady Stanley, 11 Nov.: “Johnny has been taking Carlyle a tour among his thieves & robbers . … He had given Carlyle a dinner before at the Travellers & I cannot think what could have possessed Carlyle to make such an expedition, I suppose however it amused him” (Mitford, The Stanleys of Alderley 569–70). The event was also mentioned by John Reuben Thompson (1823–73, pro-Confederate U.S. poet and journalist; see 41:75–76 JWC to MR, [17 Oct. 1864] ) in his diary; visiting TC, 15 Nov., he reported: “Carlyle gave us a graphic account of a visit to the thieves’ quarter in Whitechapel” (Gerald M. Garmon, John Reuben Thompson [Boston, 1979] 124). and no further gone than last Friday (I think it was) He was dining with your Brother “On guard”!!Presumably dining in the officers’ mess. People who hear of this intimacy predict from it precious humanizing results for Mr C!

I saw Lord Russell and Lady,Lord John and Lady Frances Russell, Lady Amberley’s parents-in-law. at Henry Taylor’sHenry Taylor (1800–86; ODNB), poet and public servant, friend of the Carlyles since the 1830s; see 6:40 TC to MAC, 10 Nov. 1831
. He m., 1839, Theodosia Alice, b. Spring Rice (1818–91); they lived at Sheen Common, nr. Richmond. the other day. Lady Russell told me they were going to you,The Amberleys lived at Rodborough Manor, near Stroud, in Gloucestershire. took three steps forward to say that! And I instantly set her down in my mind for a good, kind woman! It is curious what trifles will give one the most conclusive impression for or against a person at a first interview! And still more curious; how right these first impressions generally are, even in the minds of Blockheads!
I began this letter yesterday; but Miss Davenport BromleyCaroline Davenport Bromley. came, from Ripple (!) Court (a House she has taken near Dover), and I was talking with her till eleven at night.
I am now going off to chaperon her to the Chinese Giant’s whom I have seen already,Chang; see JWC to MR, [16 Oct.] . but could look at every day. He is so sublimely beautiful!

closer.salute: God bless you, Darling! I am always affectionately / yours

signed.name: Jane W CarlyleJWC took Margaret Oliphant for a drive in her carriage around this time; Oliphant wrote to William Blackwood (1836–1912; ODNB), literary ed. and publisher, 13 Nov.: “I was rather amused to find that I had been at the door of your Heros house the other day in Mrs. Carlyles little brougham leaving a card for an American Southern companion of his who helps him with his English” (MS: NLS 4102); John Reuben Thompson was helping J. A. H. Heros von Borcke (1835–95), German cavalry officer, write his memoirs; they were being serialized in Blackwood’s Edinburgh Magazine. Heros von Borcke had fought in the American Civil War and been chief of staff to Gen. J. E. B. Stuart (1833–64), of the Confederate Army.

postscript.p:
I went to the Study to ask Mr C if he had any message to you— “Well!—
Oh— Yes—give Her my kindest regards.”— “No!— I said—if a Man of Genius like you has nothing more original than that to say, it isn’t worth sending!”— As I went upstairs he opened his door and called after me— “My Dear!— I’ll tell you what you can say! that she is a bonnie Woman”!

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 7 Nov. MS: NLS 526.33. Quot: Froude, Carlyle 4:296.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: I am very sorry for yr fit of illness; but hope it is now quite over, and console myself by the thot that perhaps good results may follow from it, as they often do in such cases. You shd get yrself a warm wrappage, plaid, cape (that is a very nice thing, handy, effectual), and never go out in cold weather as lightly clad as you generally are. Remember, you too, how many years you now count!John A. Carlyle was now 65. And be careful, as everybody should.

I am going along here in the old crawling way; idle as possible, with little to enjoy, except the gloomy luxury of my own thots (if that be a luxury!)—but with nothing special to complain of, and witht the faintest trace of a desire or a capability for new work. That latter is somewhat a novelty with me. I read in all vacant hours (whh are few): Ancient Histy, Middleton’s Cicero,Conyers Middleton, The History of the Life of Marcus Tullius Cicero, 2 vols. (Dublin, 1741). Ferguson Possibly Adam Ferguson, The History of the Progress and Termination of the Roman Republic, 3 vols. (Edinburgh, 1783).
(really a good Book), Plutarch (poor Clough’s excellt American Editn), Plutarch’s Lives: the Translation Called Dryden’s. Corrected from the Greek and Revised by A.H. Clough, 5 vols. (Boston, 1857). —latterly I have sat almost a week, enchanted and yet often disapproving, over Jean Paul’s Hesperus (baddish American Translatn), Hesperus, or Forty-Five Dog-Post-Days. A Biography from the German of Jean Paul Richte, trans. Charles Timothy Brooks, 2 vols. (Boston, 1865). Charles Timothy Brooks (1813–83), minister and translator. In London around this time, Brooks visited TC twice, reporting in his journal: “Found him at breakfast. … [A] voice as familiar as if I had heard it from childhood bade me walk through, and there sate the great man munching his toast before the fire,—a little, wizened-faced, Irish-looking man, with a cheek like a frozen apple, and eyes bright as the cauld blue north. With what a queer smile he greeted me! … Then he showed me two autographs of Jean Paul [see TC to MW, 24 Oct.
]. Had I seen Emerson? Yes, two days before I sailed. At this ‘the creatur’ gave an eldritch grin’—lsquo;to think of seeing Emerson in the flesh,’ and afterwards, upstairs … ‘Wife, here is a man who has seen Emerson in the flesh!’ ‘A nice man, Emerson,’ he then said, very quietly and respectfully, but couldn’t make out the secret of his notions about our country. … [H]e took me up to see his wife. … She wore a sad smile, and seemed a woman of small health and few words. But [Moncure] Conway says she talks fast enough when Carlyle is away” (Charles T. Brooks, Poems, Original and Translated, with a memoir by Charles W. Wendte [Boston, 1885] 64–66). In 1863 Brooks sent TC a copy of his translation of Jean Paul Richter, Titan: A Romance, 2 vols. (Boston, 1862); when thanking him for it, TC suggested that he next translate Hesperus; see 39:88–89 . never in the world before
or since was there a mad Book written with such redeeming qualities! Yesternight I took to my Plutarch agn. Cui bono [to whose advantage], I might ask always, but seldom do.— Poor Jane is well hitherto; better than in past winters, if it only hold! I have still some botheratn with my sleep; but little or nothing of the old ghastly misery and terror; for whh be Heaven thanked.

FroudeJames Anthony Froude. was here yesterday; and gave me a long narration abt Edinr: all very lively there for the time being; Gladstone mellifluous & melodious, to a miracle, for two hours long, but without sound meaning in him,—had ended his RectorateWilliam Ewart Gladstone, appointed Lord Rector of Edinburgh Univ. 1860, then re-elected 1862. His statutory three-year term of office expired 1 Nov. Gladstone delivered his valedictory address, “The Place of Greece in the Providential Order of the World,” 3 Nov., at the Edinburgh Music Hall. The Times reported: “The Rector’s reception was most enthusiastic. The … address … took two hours and a quarter in delivery” (4 Nov.). by a job (or quasi-job, that of the music chair, for whh Hullah among others applied in vain).One of Gladstone’s final tasks as rector was to supervise the election among members of the University Court for the Reid professor of the theory of music, a position which had become vacant as a result of the death of John Donaldson (1789/90–1865; ODNB) on 12 Aug. The two leading candidates were John Pyke Hullah (1812–84; ODNB) and Michael Stanley OakeleyHerbert Stanley Oakeley (1830–1903; ODNB). The Times reported: “When the Court met on Thursday to elect, Mr. Gladstone took the chair, and all the members (eight in number) were present. … [O]n a vote being taken the election of Mr. Oakeley was carried by five to three. … The friends of Mr. Hullah and of the other early candidates were naturally greatly disappointed with the result, and were scarcely satisfied with the solatium contained in the minute of the Court, which acknowledged the great amount of ‘genius, knowledge, experience, power of performance, and general reputation’ of the rejected candidates” (6 Nov.). My Rectorate, it seems, is a thing “settled”;As a consequence of reforms implemented under the Universities (Scotland) Act, 1858, the rector was to be elected by the matriculated students, and the position was open to anyone who did not hold a teaching position at Edinburgh Univ. The rector was to preside over the University Court, which consisted of the principal and assessors appointed by the chancellor, the Senatus Academicus, and the Council of Graduates. In late October the univ. announced that the election to fill the place left by Gladstone would be held on Sat. 11 Nov. The Edinburgh Caledonian Mercury reported, 2 Nov., that the University Students’ Conservative Club had met on the previous afternoon to propose Benjamin Disraeli (1804–81; ODNB), politician and novelist, as a candidate. In a second report, the paper noted that a “very large and enthusiastic Liberal meeting” had been held the same evening to nominate an alternative candidate: “Mr Thomas Carlyle was the first candidate proposed. His name was received with great applause and waving of hats. Sir R. Murchison, the Lord Advocate, Mr John S. Mill, and Sir Robert M’Neill [sic], were also proposed. Mr Carlyle and Mr Mill were the most popular, the other three having very few supporters. When it became evident that Mr Carlyle had the majority in his favour, the movers and seconders of the other motions gracefully withdrew their opposition and joined the committee which was formed to secure his election. It has been a matter of anxiety among the students whether Mr Carlyle would accept of the rectorship. We can state on good authority that Mr Carlyle will accept of the office.” The Scotsman reported, 2 Nov.: “The Candidates nominated were Mr. Thomas Carlyle, Mr. John Stuart Mill, MP, Sir Roderick Murchison, The Lord Advocate, and the Lord President of the Court of Session”; Sir Roderick Impey Murchison (1792–1871; ODNB), geologist and geographer; James Wellwood Moncrieff (1811–95; ODNB), Scottish lawyer and politician, the current Lord Advocate (until July 1866); Duncan McNeill (1793–1874; ODNB), lawyer and politician, lord president of the court of session, 1852–67, appointed a law lord, Baron Colonsay and Oronsay, 1867. The campaign was vigorously contested by the two committees, with satires and parodies being widely circulated; see K. J. Fielding and Heather Henderson, “Carlyle and the Rectorial Election of 1865 including the campaign parodies ‘Artemus Ward Esq., at the Edenberry Yewniversetty,’” Carlyle Pamphlets 1 (Edinburgh, 1980). TC’s assumption that his election was “settled” was possibly based on a report in the Times, 6 Nov. : “The likelihood is that Mr. Carlyle, being, as it may be said, the nominee of the Liberal party, generally the strongest in Edinburgh University, will poll the majority of the students’ votes.”
whh by no means oversets my composure with joy! A young Edinr manUnidentified further, unless A. H. Burgess who reported TC’s previous refusal to stand; see next note. came here two weeks ago to remind that, last time, in flatly refusing, I had partly promised for this, if my work were done;TC was invited to stand for the rectorship in 1862 but refused on the grounds that he was too busy with Frederick, implying that once that was finished he might be interested; see 38:262 TC to CAW, 11 Nov. 1862
. I objected to the Speech &c, he declared that to be a thing they wd dispense with: “Well, if so—!” I concluded; but do not yet entirely see my way thro’ that latter clause, whh is the sore one. Indeed I have yet heard nothing of official upon it; and did not even see the Newspr Paragrh till yesterday. Hat gar wenig zu bedeuten [It means little], one way or the other. I cd not read Gladstone, shuddered even from trying it; have read Froude in yr Newspr Froude’s lecture, “The Influence of the Reformation on Scottish Character,” which he delivered, 3 Nov., to the Edinburgh Philosophical Institution. The lecture, pbd. in the Scotsman, 4 Nov., defended John Knox and his campaign against Mary Queen of Scots: “He only, in this wild crisis, saved the Kirk which he had founded, and saved with it Scottish and English freedom.” While acknowledging that the Kirk had engaged in acts of fanaticism, such as burning witches and heretics, Froude argued that the men of the time “did not know that the instincts of humanity were more sacred than the logic of theology. … We should not attempt to apologise for these things, still less to forget them.” The paper reported that “[t]he lecture was frequently and loudly applauded during its delivery, and Mr Froude resumed his seat amid general cheering.” John A. Carlyle later reported to TC, 22 Nov.: “I thought Froude’s lecture in Edinr, excellent as it was, showed that he knew what kind of people he had to speak to, & the violent blockheads amongst them would be much in the dark as to the real significance of his words.” with much assent and pleasure,—shall make him very happy by reading (audibly) what you say of
it the first time we meet.— I went to Hy Taylor’s the other day, to prepare him for Kirkpatrick,Possibly either Thomas Kirkpatrick (1839–80) or James Kirkpatrick (1841–99), the two eldest sons of Sir Charles Sharpe Kirkpatrick (1811–67), 6th bart. of Closeburn, Dumfriesshire, and Helen Stuart Kirkpatrick, b. Kirk (1814–77); John A. Carlyle and TC had previously tried to help him to find work; see 41:148–49 TC to JAC, 16 Jan. 1865
. John Carlyle replied to TC, 9 Nov.: “Thanks for what you have done in favour of Kirkpatrick. He has at present enough of private teaching in Edinr—at least four hours daily at 5/ per hour. I will write to him & say what you have done.” who I suppose will be coming. Nothing they can do for him (if it prove anything!) will be wanting, I perceived; & they seem to augur well. Little Earl Russell & SpouseLord John and Lady Frances Russell. came in before we left; brisk he, kindly huming, & busy as the little bee. To a certain Lady Wm Russell, a Sister-in-law of his, who has many friends, I intend speaking abt Kirkpk (“private teaching” &c) before this week end;— that, I am sorry to say is pretty much all I can do for him. London will yield, no doubt; but sometimes it vult expecteri [needs to be waited for]. My blessing to Jean, James & Household.

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], 7 Nov. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: I have just wrapt up for despatch to you in Karlsruhe, the Mémoires of Wilhelma, Mémoires de Frédérique Sophie Wilhelmine de Prusse, margravede Bareith, 2 vols. (Paris, 1811); see Carlyle, Works 12:320. 2 voll.—with a slight American thing,Unidentified. whh has just come to hand, and whh you may either read or burn; it will not take you long in either case! In fact, I am sadly apprehensive you will be disappointed in the noble Wilhelmina too; her accounts are so embroiled, wandering, dateless,—not to be understood witht much commentary, by a stranger to the scene and time. However, you must do yr best. You have asked for her; and yr word is a law to me. The Wife undertakes to find out today from some competent authority, what is the right, sure and swift, conveyance, and to set the Package under way herself before returning home to me.— She is well, very well for her; drives daily 3 hours; and defies the ugly muddy weather we have had. The other night abt 10 o’clock yr Letter came to her: what a pleasant visitor, breaking the solitude so beautifully; but ending in such a dismal manner for us!The news that Lady Ashburton intended to stay on in Germany; see Surtees, Ludovisi 117.

There is but one cry and shriek here among all yr friends; cry of grief and of unanimous dissent, for their own sake and for yours, upon this same busss of the “House in Karl’sruhe for 8 months”; how much more, upon the wild project of quitting England and living abroad for 3 or 4 years. Disapproval, not approval, is the voice of all! I myself say little; but, so far as I yet see, have as deep a dissent as any, perhaps a deeper,—and this not for my own interests alone, whh are deeply wounded by this turn of affairs, but for yours too and yr bonny little Mary’s,Mary Florence Baring, Lady Ashburton’s da. as I construe them. “To fly one’s country for a parcel of paltry Gossips!”Several members of the Baring family were unhappy with the terms of Lord Ashburton’s will (see 40:113–14 TC to LLA, 5 June 1864
); Lady Ashburton found their enmity upsetting and apparently feared that the will might be contested; see Surtees, Ludovisi 117. exclaims Miss Bromley in her last Note to Jane. Depend upon it, You ought not to make yr little Girl a Foreigner, to entwine her beautiful first feelings (whh are the root of all that follow) round German, Swiss, Italian or other such objects,—far from it;—nor are, or were, you yourself expected to become a Foreigner and a Wanderer, No, indeed no. Believe me yr course is, to come and plant yrself down in the Home provided for you, amid the high and difficult duties that have devolved on you; and to set yourself, stedfastly, and with exclusive interest, to the discharging of them; as if these (whh they are) were the one interest you had in the world. I conceive very well how sore and sad the malice of tongues at MelchetMelchet Court in Hampshire, bought for Lady Ashburton by Lord Ashburton shortly before his death (see 38:8 JWC to LLA, [11 Nov. 1861] ), was specifically left to her in his will; see 40:114 TC to LLA, 5 June 1864
. or elsewhere may be to a high and delicate female soul: but there is only one course with such bare lies and misbeliefs; not that of flying from them, but that of disregarding them, as at once contemptible, and of quietly living them down. As one always does, even in this poor stupid world! For everybody has such things in his degree; and I have noticed that everybody at length is found out to to Word repeated with a line over it at turn of page. be what he approximately is. Yes; and all the sooner, if he can keep never mindingCoterie speech; see 22:161 TC to JF, 18 Nov. 1847
. the foul blacks of the atmosphereSoot; used metaphorically. that are falling round him, but minds wholly his own work, and tries to do that better and better. Oh how I wish I cd persuade you! But you are so warm, so headlong, hasty; the wild Highland heart!Although Lady Ashburton was b. in Seaforth Lodge, Isle of Lewis, Western Isles, much of her childhood and young adulthood was spent at Brahan Castle, Ross-shire, in the Highlands; see 33:83 TC to LOA, 15 Sept. 1857
, and 36:161 TC to JWC, 6 Aug. 1860
.— Come to us any way, “end of Novr:” that is the one bright point.—

div3.sourceNote: TC-JSB, 13 Nov. MS: NLS 2626.283. Pbd: Anna M. Stoddart, John Stuart Blackie. A Biography, 2 vols. (Edinburgh and London, 1895) 2:18. Quot: Ian Campbell and K. J. Fielding, “New Carlyle Letters,” Carlyle Newsletter 8 (1987): 37.
div3.head:
TC
TO JOHN STUART BLACKIE

docBody.salute: Dear Blackie,Blackie wrote, 11 Nov.: “I have the pleasure of learning that you are elected our Magnificent Rector by a majority of 347 declared this moment. God bless your reign!—Watchword / NO SHAM!”
docBody.p: I am thinking seriously abt the Assessorship;Blackie wrote: “You will have to look out for an Assessor—who ought to be a man of sense, who … is independent of the petty local cliques and parties of this place. Excuse me if I suggest that you can select no more satisfactory man than your brother the Doctor.” TC noted beneath this on MS: “my Brother won’t go;—and is even forbidden on the face of him by his being my Brother!” The assessor was chosen by the rector to be his representative on the University Court. John A. Carlyle wrote, 12 Nov.: “I hardly know what to say about that Rectorship, but on the whole it afflicts me to think that you are pestered with it at all. The duties of it you might perform well enough if it were worth your while to try; but Edinburgh has now become a narrow & illiterate arena for any one; & all your habits stand opposed to public speaking & minute discussions, especially before such men as have to do with Edinburgh University. I can only wish that you may be guided to a wise & effectual decision in the matter!”—also abt shirking the Installatn Speech,Blackie replied, 14 Nov.: “My dear Prophet! / By this time … you will have received the official notice of your dignity. … As to the speech, you can in no wise shirk it … of course you need not make a speech unless you please; but you must speak. You ought to thank God that you live in an age when there is much to speak about; specially in the Educational world. Here, as in the church, we are living too much upon dead traditions. We do not look nature directly in the face. We move in a groove of books. I have a strong faith in you, that you will speak out the word that the time requires. Only in God’s name, do not be too violent, or you will ruin all. The stupid world requires a qualification—half a dozen sometimes; they do not understand your method of swinging about with a club.” John A. Carlyle agreed, 14 Nov.: “No hurry about Installation. Some speech will be indispensable at the outset, some address to the Students who have chosen you & to them mainly; & you will have no difficulty in giving them sound & good advice. Any extraneous eloquence like Gladstone’s would be out of place & disorderly—calculated to do no good at all.” if that be at all feasible? Assist me in that if you humanly can!

From Sir D. BrewsterSir David Brewster, principal and vice-chancellor of Edinburgh Univ. I have a Note, brief as yr own, and touching on the same topics? Is that to be the announcement to me of this fine Dignity; or am I to expect something more formally Official?TC received a telegram, sent 11 Nov., from Mr. Donald of Edinburgh Univ.: “You have this day been elected Rector of Edinbo University by a Large Majority / Charge to pay 3d.” For the official announcement, see TC to PK, 14 Nov.
The Times gave a detailed report of the election: “The polling took place between 10 and 12 o’clock on Saturday [11 Nov.], in the different class-rooms, the professors acting as poll sheriffs. Of a constituency of 1,288 only 967 voted. … About half-past 12 the numbers were exhibited from a balcony to a great assemblage in the quadrangle, the following being the results:—For Mr. Carlyle … 657 / For Mr. Disraeli … 310 / Majority for Carlyle … 347. The announcement was received with tremendous cheering on the one side, and an almost silent disappointment on the other” (13 Nov.).

div3.sourceNote: TC-PK, 14 Nov. Addr: Edinburgh. PM: London, 14 Nov. 1865. MS: NLS 2883.241; copy: Edinburgh Univ. Senatus Minutes, 1865–68. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO PHILIP KELLAND

docBody.dateline: 5 Grt Cheyne Row, Chelsea London, 14 Novr 1865
docBody.p: I have the pleasure to receive your official announcementLetter untraced, but TC apparently sent it to John A. Carlyle as he replied, 15 Nov., “I have put Kelland’s letter along with the others.” that, by vote of the matriculated Students of Edinburgh University, I am appointed Rector: and in reply I will now beg you to make known to those Gentlemen and others concerned that I am very sensible of the great honour done me, that I cheerfully accept the Office, and will to the best of my ability endeavour to discharge the same.Peter Kelland wrote to Alexander Gibson, chairman of the committee for TC’s election, quoting this letter: “20 Clarendon Crescent [printed] / Mr Carlyle desires it to be made known to the Electors and others concerned that he is very sensible of the great honour done him, that he cheerfully accepts the office of Rector, and will, to the best of his ability endeavour to discharge the same” (MS: EUL draft; pbd: Caledonian Mercury, 17 Nov.).

The choosing of an Assessor occupies me at this moment;TC had already written to John A. Carlyle discussing the choice of an assessor as John replied, 14 Nov.: “The main thing is to get an Assessor of good quality. I agree with you in thinking it would not do at all to appoint me even if I were much better qualified than I am for the office: such appointment wd look too like a job at the very outset.” He then discussed various candidates, continuing: “David Laing is all that you say. He has no talent for public speaking, but can write rapidly enough & sensibly, & is well liked by many in Edinr, & wd be very zealous for improvements of all kinds & entirely faithful & loyal. Perhaps you should try him … first. I know of no other as well qualified … Laing might perhaps suit you best.” and I expect, in a few days, to offer you one who will not be unwelcome, nor prove unsatisfactory.

In regard to the subsequent necessary steps, you will perhaps have the goodness to give me some intimations from time to time. I remain, meanwhile,—with the sincerest thanks to my too friendly Electors,—

postscript.p: To Professor Kelland, Secy &c&c

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady L [LLO], 16 [15] Nov. Addr: Newbattle / Dalkeith / N.B. PM: London, 15 Nov. 1865. MS: EUL. Hitherto unpbd. TC misdated.
div3.head: TC TO LADY LOTHIAN

docBody.p: I was much pleased yesterday morning, on sight of the Cromwell Letters (whh arrived quite safe, tho’ they had needed to be “sealed in the Edinr Post-Office”); and still better pleased on sight of the more modern Letter, whh testified that you still remembered me with the old kindness.Lady Lothian wrote, 12 Nov.: “These letters have been ready for you for a long time, but I unfortunately forgot altogether about sending them. They have been copied under the superintendance of Mr David Laing, & may therefore be relied upon for correctness. Lord Lothian has been rejoicing at the decision of his compatriots about the Rectorship & trusts it may give him an opportunity of seeing you again. We trust that when you do come to Edinburgh you will not risk quarrelling with us, by shunning a visit here— The little visit you did pay has been something pleasant to think about. I trust Mrs Carlyle is feeling stronger. May I ask to be brought to her recollection.” I had heard of you all, a few days ago, from Mrs Gladstone, whose Husband I had gone to have a few words with on this extraordinary Rector business.Catherine Gladstone; TC called Sat. 11 Nov.; Gladstone noted only: “Saw Mr. Carlyle” (The Gladstone Diaries, ed. H. C. G. Matthews [Oxford, 1978] 6:396). The Lady staid with us not above 3 minutes; but was eloquent upon Lord Lothian’s “beauty,” among other qualities; and had nothing at least that was bad news to tell me of you.

I cannot well make out hitherto what this Rectorate of mine will amount to,—not quite to nothing, it wd seem; but then to what kind of something? For one thing, I do fear there will be journey to Edinr before long, and a certain necessity of opening one’s lips more or less, in public; whh in itself, to say nothing of the 800 miles of railway, is abundantly horrible to me!Coterie speech; see 18:83 JWC to TC, [25 June 1844] . The round trip is about 800 mi. (1287 km.). I must try and discover what is really proper to be done, and when and how.

If I have to come to Edinr, you need not fear but I shall appear punctually at Newbattle,Newbattle Abbey, the Lothians’ estate, about 7 mi. (11 km.) SE of Edinburgh. —nay perhaps (but this I don’t know yet) come begging Lodging from you for a night or two! One of my constant miseries (whh are manifold, and make me shudder at the thot of railway or other travel) being that of inability to sleep in the noisy and otherwise inhuman dormitories usually provided for one!— We shall see.

My Wife, with many thanks & regards to Newbattle, is decidedly better for the prest than when we last spoke of her; in fact she drives abt at a considerable rate, and seems fully stronger & hopefuller than for several years back;—if only the winter don’t crush us down! I myself am not better than I was on sight;TC visited the Lothians 23 Aug.; see 42:210–11 TC to JWC, 25 Aug.
often enough I think rather worse,—tho’ perhaps it is only the
dispiriting muddiness of earth and of sky, and the fact that I have altogether ceased riding; having, after abt 30,000 miles of it, as I count in the last 12 years, among these abominable London purlieus, grown utterly to abominate it. In fact London Town grows more & more disagreeable;—we are besung all night, for instance, by the yell of railways, quite a novelty, whh I can hardly by best contrivance keep out of my bedroom here, the more is my sorrow!—

I read Lord Lothian’s Book,William Schomberg Robert Kerr, 8th marquess of Lothian, The Confederate Secession (London and Edinburgh, 1864); see 42:211 TC to JWC, 25 Aug.
in Annandale; & found it full of lively expressn, and of just and ingenious ideas; none the less true for the turn events have taken latterly. “Events” are not all done, by any means! With many respects & regards to his Lordp & you,

div3.sourceNote: TC-DL, 16 [15] Nov. MS: EUL. Hitherto unpbd. TC misdated.
div3.head: TC TO DAVID LAING

docBody.p: You know they have elected me Rector of the University; and that, as the preliminary of all else, I want an Assessor. Contrary to first notions I find that there are real duties, apart from the honorary, connected with this appointt; & that for these, as for all others whatsoever, real qualities will be required,—three in particular: perfect integrity, sound judgement, and compatibility on fair terms; whh three, indeed, are everywhere available in this world!—

The first man I thot of was you; and after considerable reflexion and comparison, you still appear to me clearly the eligible. If there is any honour in the thing, you are he who have deserved it; you will be welcome to Edinr; and your fidelity, in peaceable form but solid as the rocks, to all interests of the University, is a thing we can depend upon.— Say only, on consideratn, “I will,” and the matter is settled.Laing replied, 16 Nov.: “My Dear Lord Rector / I was no less surprised this morning than honoured, to receive your very flattering letter. On referring to the University Calendar, I see that you have the benefit of only one Assessor, and that the duties are such as might well make one hesitate to undertake them, even if an aversion to public notoriety did not exist. It occurred to me moreover, that not being qualified to have my name enrolled as one of the Council, there might be more serious objection to your proposal which might throw me ‘out of Court.’ / As this might apply to others as well as myself, I went down to the College to enquire. It seems however that any one may be appointed excepting the Principal or a Professor in one of our Universities. / Now seriously speaking, I would much rather that you should nominate some one else. But if you are inclined to give me the preference, remember—I will not engage (much as I may wish it for the sake of harmony) to concur in all the views you may take in matters coming under the special jurisdiction of the University Court.”

A refusal will much grieve me; nor in fact do I seriously anticipate refusal;—perhaps you are even bound not to refuse, if you reflect well? At all events, please let me know by return of post, for the people seem to be impatient for a sight of their man.
Expecting much comfort from you for myself, too, in these to me uncertain and untrodden regions, I remain

postscript.p: David Laing Esq / &c&c

div3.sourceNote: TC-TM, 17 Nov. MS: NLS 8992. Hitherto unpbd. Thomas Murray (1792–1872; ODNB), printer and misc. writer. His printing business, Murray & Gibb, was in N.E. Thistle St. Lane, Edinburgh; he lived in St. Anne’s Mount, Lasswade, Midlothian.
div3.head: TC TO THOMAS MURRAY

docBody.p:
I am glad at the sight of yr old handwriting agn, whh I have known so well these 50 years back & more!Murray was TC’s friend and fellow student in Edinburgh; see 1:3–5 TC to TM, 24 June 1813
. Many thanks for yr friendly feelings to me; flourishing in old age as they did in youth; memorable to me across the wrecks of so many years.

It is impossible to wish quite deliberately this Electn had gone otherwise than it did: but the Office, thus far, does threaten to involve me in infinite small trouble and botheratn—me, who perhaps of all her majesty’s subjects most needed & affected absolute rest at this point of time. But there is no help just yet. Nay before very long, it wd appear, I have a journey to Edinr ahead, with &c&cof a painful & most unwelcome complexion:—in the course of whh one bit of consolatn will be that of seeing an old friend’s face agn, whh surely will not prove unmanageable.

I found the Colinton Book in an Annandale Library last summer; and read it, both it and the Hume,Thomas Murray, Biographical Annals of the Parish of Colinton (Edinburgh, 1863); Letters of David Hume, and Extracts from Letters Referring to Him, ed. Thomas Murray (Edinburgh, 1841). with true satisfaction. Many thanks for the Copy you have sent and inscribed.

With best regards to Mrs MurrayJanet, b. Murray (1799—post-1872), m. 1826; see 2:411 TC to TM, 8 Aug. 1823
. and you, I remain,—expressly, what in silence I have always been,—

div3.sourceNote: TC-DL, 17 Nov. MS: EUL. Hitherto unbpd.
div3.head: TC TO DAVID LAING

docBody.p:
You are not in the least bound to “concur” with me,Laing had made the point that he would not always agree with TC; see TC to DL, 16 [15] Nov.
or with anybody; you are an independt seventh part of The University Court; elected (on such method as there was) by all Edinr, and all Scotland for that matter, to do what you can for the University, according to yr own judgement and conscience. No more hesitatn, therefore; I accept yr conditional consent as a complete one;—and write, by this post, to Profr Kelland, Secrety of the Senatus, that you are the man. Well convinced that I might go farther and fare worse!—

Of course if you were madly to refuse after all, you still can: walk across to Profr Kelland directly on sight of this, and announce that you will not accept:—but I am far from anticipating such a step; and confidently flatter myself that I have got the matter finished; all the more, as this (I recollect) is the last available Post-day of the Week,TC wrote on Friday. and I cannot hear even from yourself till Monday morning.

Supposing this all settled, and no more writing or thinking needed from me on the subject, the next helpful thing you can do is to ascertain for me from the proper sources, When first there is to be, or can be made to be, any real or considerable business before the University Court?—inasmuch as that wd be the good time for my appearing in Edinr, with some kind of Inauguratn Speech (whh I much abhor, but it seems cannot avoid), after a railway journey of that length (whh I ditto do)! My own choice, whh they say may extend over all the months of the Session, wd decidedly be, “The sooner we have done with it, the better.” Please settle all this for me, on the above terms,—and with either no farther writing &cfrom me abt it, or with the minimum possible. I am perfectly worn out with the shovelfuls of empty Letters that have been flying abt me all week; one in ten of whh (very unwillingly) I have been compelled to write abt in return.
And so Heaven speed you; and grant us a happy Rectorate:—of refusal I will hear nothing!

div3.sourceNote: JWC-WHB, [17 Nov.]. Pbd: Brookfield, Circle 2:516. Dated after TC’s rectorial election.
div3.head:
JWC
TO William H. BROOKFIELD

docBody.p: Would you like to know what Mr. Carlyle said on reading your letter? What he said was this:

“Well! Upwards of a bushel of letters,—I should say a bushel and a half have come within the last week to ‘congratulate’ on this most deplorable event, and the only really pretty one of them all is Brookfield’s! a really, friendly, graceful letter as a man could wish to receive.”

For me, as a solitary Individual,Coterie speech; see 18:308 JWC to MR, [30] December [1844]
. what I said was, “Oh, what a blessing if more people would write as legibly as that!” Can’t you come in this evening, Miss—I have referred to your letter and perceive you are not in London),The dash indicated a pause as JWC realized that an invitation to Brookfield to meet the unidentified “Miss” that evening was redundant as he was not in London. but as soon as you can come you know we are always glad to see you.
I am sadly afraid “Jock”Possibly Caroline Davenport Bromley’s dog Jocky; see 42:154 JWC to TC, [27 July] . is dying of the distemper.

closer.salute: Yours kindly, / The Rectorium.The house or office of the rector.

div3.sourceNote: TC-DL, 20 Nov. MS: EUL. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO DAVID LAING

docBody.p:
Dear Laing,—I am much satisfied to have you as Assessor; and believe that I have managed this, the first and probably the most importt part of my Office, in a way that will be satisfactory to the Public as it is to myself. It is not to be expected my own Official activity, at a distance of 400 miles, in such a state of health, and with such a horror railwaying &c, shd be in the least considerable: but I shall always have a solidly faithful and discerning Substitute on the spot; and shall be able to promise that no dishonesty at least, or misconduct shall be practiced or countenanced either by him or by me. In regard to the next grand step, for whh you propose the “Month of April,” Sir David Brewster has already suggested that, as a favour to me, “it might be delayed till january”;—my present wish being that I had it over (hateful and horrible as it is to me) as soon as possible,—that then I might hope to be in statu quo agn, & left mainly in silence unless where the contrary was indispensable! For
the rest, I am willing to conform to whatever is judged best for both parties; since, truly, except to the imaginatn, the matter is not great; and either April or December, whichever way Sir David & the rest of you may decide, ought to be nearly indifft to me. Say only that I do want to have it off my hands, there is no other point of preference.
Please try to get this decided for me.—
I remain always

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, [20 Nov.]. MS: NLS 518.17. Hitherto unpbd. Dated Mon. 20 Nov. by TC’s receipt of Laing’s letter of Sat., 18 Nov., and John A. Carlyle’s letter, 19 Nov.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: My dear Brother,—Thanks for yr Note; thanks for writg to Blackie, who is good but goosish.In his letter of 14 Nov., Blackie invited TC to stay while in Edinburgh: “When you come down, will you take lodgment under our humble roof?— We will esteem it an honour; and you may do what you please, and eschew all bother. I have a profound respect for the liberty of an individual.” TC wrote at the end of Blackie’s letter: “cackle-cackle / goosey-goose: But will you perhaps thank him for his offer of Lodging?” and sent it to John A. Carlyle. John wrote to Blackie, 18 Nov.: “This morning my brother has forwarded your letter, requesting me to thank you and Mrs Blackie for your very kind offer of receiving him in your house when he comes for the Installation; & I now do so most heartily both on his part & my own. But I rather think your house is too much exposed to noises that might hinder him from getting sleep, as he had difficulty even in the quiet back rooms of George St when we were there in August” (MS: NLS 2626.284). Laing accepts, as you see;Laing wrote, 18 Nov.: “If I had taken a day to think over your proposal, I would have declined accepting—but as I hate indecision, in reply to a note from Profr Kelland this forenoon I have intimated my acceptance, & will do what I can to be useful. … When you as Rector, make your appearance to give the Students &c. an Address, this necessarily must be a very public affair—and what I have to suggest is, not to be too anxious in the matter, but to write to Sir David Brewster, asking him his advice, & whether it would not be proper to delay this till the close of the Session next April? Our chief reason for suggesting any delay is, to avoid following close on the heels of your predecessor, who delivered his elaborate Address at the beginning of this month. / Moreover it might save you a journey in the middle of Winter,—and there is now at that time a large assemblage usually an occasion of conferring Honorary Degrees, and there could be no fitter time for you to make an appearance. / I cannot conclude without offering you my hearty thanks for the honour conferred on me.” and in spite of his grunting way will do, I believe with you, perfectly well. I send you all my Notes (except one of Saty, recomendg you for self, but David Aitken or John Stoddart on hint from others; Note lost, & of no use whatever): keep Laing’s;John A. Carlyle replied, 21 Nov.: “You have forgotten to enclose Laing’s letter of acceptance which you tell me to keep.” the others are merely to shew you where I am, and to light yr pipe.

My problem at prest is to know when the Speech had best be. Ld Houghton (Milnes) invites us for 10 days in the early pt of Decr (very sulky that I refused all his dinners, other invitns &c&c); his house is on the Edinr rail, half way;Lord Houghton lived at Fryston Hall in Yorkshire. and wd be handy for resting at, if the time were “Decr before Xmas.” Laing votes for April; Brewster you might notice said Jany. Except that I wish rather to have it off my hands, I am myself nearly indifft. But think you of it; and try if you can see what really is the right time, and help to get it settled for me. The others (Laing & Brewstr) I have already told as above my desire (not too strong) abt speed & my indiffce otherwise;—and will not write to agn, if I can help it, except to name a day. Think & survey for me.
Thanks to Jean;Jean Aitken wrote to TC every Sunday. I have no more time (3½ p.m. & the shades sinking). Yesterday was wet; today is half do. I am better than when I wrote last; but not well ah me!

div3.sourceNote: TC-FC, 22 Nov. MS: John Work Garret Lib., Johns Hopkins Univ. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO FREDERIC CHAPMAN

docBody.p:
Here are two Books, a set of Foreign Biographies (Leibnitz &c)William Maccall’s Foreign Biographies (see below, notes 2, 4, and 6) included one of Gottfried Wilhelm von Leibniz (1646–1715; see 38:114 JWC to TC, [2 July 1862] ), German philosopher and mathematician. Maccall was to note in his preface that they had all been previously pbd., “chiefly in the Gentleman’s Magazine.” Maccall’s biography of Leibniz, dated July 1852, was to be at 2:1–66. and a Swedish Novel,William Maccall’s trans. of Marie Sophie Schwartz, Mannen af börd och qvinnan af folket (Gottenberg, 1858); M. S. Schwartz (1819–94), Swedish writer and feminist. come to you for judgt. “To be or not to be.”Cf. Hamlet 3.1. I have myself had nothing in either of them, and can only testify that the Author & translator (“W. Maccall Esq. Bexley Heath Kent”) is an earnest, studious, and highly respectable man,—who very much desires that yr “Examiners wd really examine his Ms.,”William Maccall, known to TC since 1848; see 23:89–90 TC to JWP, 5 Aug. 1848
, and TC to WM, 5 Aug. 1848
. He had previously applied several times to TC for help with selling his work; see 42:28 TC to JCA, 18 May
. and say Yes or No. In the event of Yes, a little money wd by expected and necessary; a little, and not much.

Do me the favour & [affirm?]Word unclear in MS. him, by the above address, as soon as you can, that yr Examiners have done their duty, and what the result is.Neither work was pbd. by Chapman. Both were pbd. later: William Maccall, Foreign Biographies, 2 vols. (1873), by Tinsley Brothers; Marie Sophie Schwartz, The Man of Birth and the Woman of the People, 3 vols., trans. William Maccall (1868), was pbd. by Strahan.
Am I to have the [Envilotus? Invitations?]Word unclear in MS. shortly?—

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 22 Nov. MS: NLS 518.13. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head:
TC
TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
My dear Brother,
—It was very stupid of me to forget Laing’s Letter, tho’ I sent you the contents of it. Here it is;—nothing more from him, or Edinr, since,—except only a University Calendar (as announced by him), of whh I have now two Copies; and will send you one, if you are not otherwise provided.

The questn of the time is so nearly insignifict to me, that I decide for the prest to lie on my oars, & wait till Edinr do something towards a decisn. April, Decr , early in Jany : each has its pros & contras: in April or end of March, there will be more quietness, this whole hurlyburly sunk agn forever; in Decr or Jany, “better to have it over soon,” yes truly, but then at prest I am so feeble, nervous, bilious &cas I almost never was, and it will be better to try for a little amendt first:—on the whole we will lie on our oars, and try to keep never minding,Coterie speech; see 13:85 JWC to TC, [9 April 1841] . in the interim. If you hear anything from Brown,Dr. John Brown (1810–82; ODNB), Edinburgh physician and author; he had been Gladstone’s assessor. John A. Carlyle reported, 21 Nov., that Brown thought “the earlier the better” for the speech. from GordonJohn Gordon (1797–1882), inspector of schools in Scotland, old friend of TC; see 4:201 TC to AC, 19 March 1827
, and 29:115 TC to LA, 10 June 1854
; according to John A. Carlyle, 21 Nov., Gordon “spoke of April.” &c(of their own accord, n.b.), tell it me; but otherwise never mind, you either. What is the amount of it all? A mighty small matter. I can “speak” to them a few of my silences (since compelled to it) at any time; & my one interest in it ought to be, Not to speak any lies to them, or totally unsuitable truths to them, when I do. Inanitas inanitatum [vanity of vanities],See Eccles. 1:2. botheratio botherat ns
!”— I send you Spedding’sThomas Story Spedding. little Note of this morng (the only rational one of the 2 or 3 score lately); & Blackie’s as a lost babblet found agn.John A. Carlyle replied, 23 Nov.: “Spedding’s letter is very good & I keep it too along with the rest. Blackie’s last I have burnt as useless.”

Milnes (Houghton), hardly legible, sends Jane & me an Invitatn for “the
12 first days of Decr,” nobody to be there but Miss WynneCharlotte Williams Wynn. and us (good Heavens),—whh I design to refuse in some mild way tomorrow. He will be very surly;—and perhaps reject the “Halfway-house scheme for Easter following” (whh might have a perceptible use for me then).— — Jane has lost all sleep last night (poor little soul,—gone out all the same!)—weather a tempest from s.w. from s.w.,Phrase repeated with a line over it at turn of page. with blusts of wild rain, but fine bits of sky too, and a temperature inconvently warm. Our room is empty here, you know; & 3 curtains go up before yr advent: but quietness is best!

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lord H [RMM], 23 Nov. MS: Crewe House. Pbd: Reid, RMM 2:144–45. MS torn and stained; words in sq. br. from Reid.
div3.head: TC TO LORD HOUGHTON

docBody.p: I will see Fryston agn, one day, and bring my Wife, unless fate itself have forbidden! But, for the prest, all the indicatns are that it actually will not do. We are both as weak as possible (I, you wd almost say, the weaker—sleepless, catarrhal &c&c),—nor is this the sole consideratn, tho’ I think it really might be the suffict one.

But the truth withal is, ever since I saw you,Presumably they met in early Nov.; see JWC to Lady Am [KST], 7 and 8 Nov.
I have been endeavouring to combine a visit to Fryston with that “Inauguratn Journey to Edinr (whh it does appear I am bound to,—[sorrow]Word assumed to be “sorrow” as someone (not Lord Houghton, perhaps Reid) has written on MS: “In reply to invitation. / That inauguration Journey to Edinbro’ / Sorrow on it!” on it!)—and for that latter the choice hangs, for a ten days past, betn “the week before Xmas” just coming, and “the first week of April” next,—whh I believe will be Easter time,Easter Sunday was 1 April 1866. when Fryston may agn be alive with yr presence?

Easter, I find, for many reasons, will probably suit me best; and tho’ the decisn is not quite irrevocable, I believe it will fall that way, and Edinr, in a day or two, hear that it is so. Edinr is sorrowfully indis[tinct] hitherto, talks of “early in jany,” and other dates: but I must settle it myself, and on strict survey cannot well otherwise than as above. Pity me; don’t be angry [at] me, and fancy I care nothing for you,—hardly ever in the world were you more mistaken!

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 23 Nov. MS: NLS 518.14. Quot: A. Carlyle, NL 2:232.
div3.head:
TC
TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
Thanks, dear Brother,
for yr patient and carefully considered Letter of this morning. My mind more and more inclines to “first week of April” for a good few reason.Thus in MS. First
the whole matter will be quiet agn, fallen dead & silent, nothing to rekindle but my bit of speech. Secondly I may be better (let us hope so, for at prest I am oftenest truly helpless, weak as a sparrow, liver & nerves deeply wrong,—12 years of that kind give one a right thrashing, especially when 70 is within a fortnight!)TC was 70 on 4 Dec. —at any rate I shall have better weather; shall see the matter more clearly from such distance, &c&cIn short, on Saturday or Monday next (if Edinr say nothing and you say Yes) I believe I shall decide it that way;— then kick the affair mainly out of doors for a good while!— I have rejected the Houghton scheme (whh at any rate had no charm); but have left Easter delicately hanging open to the Hospitable Lord, if he [like; if]Gap in MS where the corner was torn off. he don’t—well still.

This is one of the finest days; Jane just gone out, I just going. Need enough, the last two or three days have been such tearers, such splashers! I have flying bits of rheumatism, and a hareskin at the Baltic bosom busss,TC had a “hareskin breastplate” made for him by his sister Jean (see 36:24 TC to JCA, 10 Dec. 1859
) that he wore to alleviate the rheumatic pain he believed he had caught bathing in the Baltic in 1858 (see 34:170 TC to JWC, 5 Sept. 1858
); see also 37:248 TC to JCA, 17 Oct. 1861
. item
a sore toe (hope it is getting better), have no strength in my limbs (except now & then), and am reduced to Omnibuses, and can’t sleep—in short, am a very crazy article just now, to have nothing seriously wrong abt me. I believe the want of the horse is hurtful;TC gave his horse Noggs to Henry Inglis in the summer; see 42:188 TC to JWC, 14 Aug.
but my horror of riding here is not in the least abated.TC had come to hate riding in London, partly because of the continual noise of construction, and partly because he associated it with working on Frederick; see 41:154 TC to JCA, 4 Feb. 1865
. Don’t make yrselves uneasy abt me: I have known from of old how tedious any recovery always is with me; and what a job it is re-ascending out of such a bottomless Slough of DespondCf. John Bunyan, Pilgrim’s Progress. as that was

You amuse me by yr acct of Deucher;Probably Robert Deuchar (1794–1867), retired Edinburgh solicitor, living at Jordan Cottage, Morningside. John A. Carlyle wrote, 21 Nov.: “That S.S.C. is not known to me personally at all. In 1817 I see he became a Solicitor, so that he must be old now. He seems to be one of the narrow, violent & prescriptive sectarians that are peculiar to Edinr & hardly thrive anywhere else.” He wrote again, 22 Nov.: “I keep R. Deuchar’s letter as a curiosity peculiar to Edinr. He is evidently quite in earnest. His mixture of money (£100,000 to be gained, if he had your talent along with his own opinions) & the defence of Christianity is very characteristic.” TC apparently did reply to him, as John A. Carlyle wrote to TC, 7 Dec.: “I am glad you sent a small reply in kind terms to old Deuchar. With all his faults he evidently respects you & wishes to avoid offence.” whom I didn’t read. Kelland 
(inclosed)Kelland wrote to Laing, 18 Nov., after receiving TC’s official acceptance (
  TC to PK, 14 Nov.
  
): “I have this morning received a letter from Mr Carlyle intimating his appointment of you as his Assessor in the University Court. I shall be glad to get your acceptance of this appointment that I may intimate the same to Mr Carlyle & to the Secretary for the University Court” (MS: EUL). Either Kelland’s letter to TC was written after Laing’s formal acceptance, or was simply a reply to TC’s acceptance letter. was forgotten twice, & is now superfluous;—as is the illegible Ld Hn’s, just ansd.

My love to Jean & the rest of them; nothing can repay their kindness. Above a week ago there came a Canada [News]pr from [Jen]ny,Their sister Jenny Hanning in Ontario. whh I forgot to mentn. Good b’ye.

closer.salute: Yrs everCorner of letter was torn off, possibly for the signature.

div3.sourceNote: TC-DL, 24 Nov. MS: EUL. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO DAVID LAING

docBody.p: April will be better; let us say April, as you advise,—“first week of April” or so, if that will suit. But please ascertain first, in yr Almanac, What time the “Easter Holidays” of these southern parts will fall, and the Parliamt be in vacatn;The Houses of Parliament were in recess 23 March–9 April 1866; TC wanted to stay with Lord Houghton on his way to Edinburgh, and as a member of the House of Lords, Lord Houghton would be in London while Parliament was sitting.—and let my Edinr Expedition come within that limit. One need not yet fix the day; but do, at yr convenience, settle all the rest for me, and put it to quiescence.

I got yr University Calendar; and have been searching abt in it;—many thanks. Believe me I am well satisfied to have you as my Substitute on the field yonder, and to depend on yr faithful keeping of the same. I am always

postscript.p: David Laing Esqr
&c&c

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 24 Nov. MS: NLS 526.34. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Along with yr Letter has come the inclosed, from Laing—mitstimend [unanimous] in all points. I have written to Laing, accordingly; settling for April, “first week or so,”—but it is to be some time in the “Easter Holidays” (to give a chance of halfway rest, if that occur);—and he is to fix it so far, and put it to sleep for the next 4 months. I like Laing well; and think of him, so far as I have got to know, quite as you do.— The University Calendar comes for you,John A. Carlyle wrote, 23 Nov.: “I have ordered a copy of this year’s University Calendar, which I thought of sending to you, but it has not yet come & I will countermand it today; so please send me one of your two copies if you still have them both.” by this same post,—unless they please to veto at the Office.

I made a violent attempt at a “long walk” yesterday while the weather was so fine; & I did, by dint of stubbornness, keep on foot for above 2 hours, and made 3 calls (all out, or invisible) before I returned. John Chorley,John Rutter Chorley. ill of sciatica, feverish &c, & quite invisible these some weeks, was my first call; 2d was Coll Sir Anthony Stirlg,Sir Anthony Coningham Sterling.—who I heard had taken to daily riding at a mighty rate (to keep down fat):—“gone riding, Sir; out always at 2, home a little after 4,” said his Butler,Possibly Charles Sears (b. ca. 1821); otherwise unidentified. a serene steel-grey old gentn with perfectly official air. Twisleton,Edward Boyd Twisleton, who lived very near Stirling. nearby was, also out; whereupon I took to the Park,Hyde Park. and kindled a cigar; slowly meditative, & indeed much inclined for an omnibus at He Pk Corner,—whh however I magnansly declined, after all. Today is blustery agn & showery; poor Jane is below par today,—and we have to go out in the evg (Fredc Pollock’s,Frederick Pollock. a most anct promise, and to me not a welcome this day), but such things, Jane says, always do her good. Jean will write on Sunday; but I think, from me there can’t well be anythg!

postscript.p:
At night I read Plutarch (Clough’s)See TC to JAC, 7 Nov.
whh is really capital of its kind. Morng I am on Chronology (“World-Eras” chiefly for dates to my Plutarch), & such poor stuff, poor but honest!—

div3.sourceNote:
TC-JAC, 28 [27] Nov. MS: NLS 518.15. Hitherto unpbd. TC misdated; he wrote this letter before TC to LLO, 28 [27] Nov.
; that letter was postmarked London, 27 Nov.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
Dear Brother,—Here is a new burble abt “the time”!David Masson, recently appointed professor of rhetoric and English literature at Edinburgh Univ. (for which position TC recommended him in Aug.; see 42:195 TC to JWC, 18 Aug. [1865]
), wrote, 26 Nov.: “At a meeting of the Senatus yesterday there was some talk on the subject of your Rectorial visit. I was not able to be present at the beginning of the meeting—when this subject came on; but I had conveyed … my impression, from your letter, that, although you would not object to April, yet, on the whole, it would be as agreeable to you to have the matter over sooner. It was resolved, I believe, to ask you whether the first or second week of January would suit your convenience. It was thought that your coming then, when the students will have all reassembled after the Christmas vacation, would be particularly good for the University.” He added: “We were both gratified by your truly kind letter, received on Tuesday last; and my wife means to follow your advice as regards the managing of her new element. She has always had a liking for Edinburgh, and there is abundant disposition to be kind to us.” Masson asked TC to come and stay when in Edinburgh: “The competition for you will be great; and, of course, I could not stand in the way of others. … But might not you come to us first, use our house as your own to arrive at & recur to as you chose, & radiate from it as much or as little as you found suitable? Not even this would I ask, if I were not sure that you would be less put about with us than anywhere else. There shall be a supply of the true Glasgow pipes, and of the right tobacco, snugly at hand, but without obtrusion; and we will in all ways consult your wishes. In short, you shall be Rector within 3 Roseberry Crescent as well as without; and, if Mrs Carlyle is with you, she shall reign too—as my wife means to assure her.” TC wrote a note on Masson’s letter: “very kind: accept so far as Glasgow Pipes &c,—if only the time were fixed! (Return this; I may want the Address).” John replied, 28 Nov.: “Masson’s letter is very kind indeed, & it seems to me that in his house … you would be freer & feel more at home than anywhere else.” I however still incline to what was fixed, to April namely; but will say nothing at all till Tomorrow, when official Senatus Letter will probably come,—whh I mean to remit to Laing, with instructn to fix for me; ascertaining first (what I suspect) that the Senatus has no real interest involved, but has merely wished to oblige me, and then, declaring “April” as before to be the time. Ohe, jam satis [Now, that is enough]!—Thanks for the clipping:John A. Carlyle sent, 24 Nov., a clipping from the Edinburgh Evening Courant. Laing is all right as choice.— I believe I shd to Lady Lothian at once; a hospitable Marchioness ought not to be kept waiting!For Lady Lothian’s invitation, see TC to LLO, 16 Nov.
TC wrote next to Lady Lothian, also misdating; see TC to LLO, 28 [27] Nov.
Their House seemed to me, next to La Trappe,Site of the first Trappist monastery; TC’s metaphor for silence. the quietest in the world.

We are a little off hinge here,—not very much, I hope. But the Pollock Dinner was dreary and unwholesome, and instead of mending Jane (as these things often seem to do) cut off her sleep altogether; and now, adding this to other dirty little sundries, she fears there is cold upon her, and is decidedly
below par, tho’ in good spirits still. I myself am free of the dinner (& shan’t have another,—Plutarch how preferable!)—but am sadly shattery and feeble in genl at this hollow of the Year. 70 of them due upon me this week withal!— — Jean’s narrative of the poor Clart of a Girl, caught in the toils of despair in that manner, fills me with pity & sorrow for poor human nature as well as “Marion.”Unidentified further. Pooh, pooh!—

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady L [LLO], 28 [27] Nov. Addr: Newbattle / Dalkeith / N.B. PM: London, 27 Nov. 1865. MS: EUL. Hitherto unpbd. TC misdated.
div3.head: TC TO LADY LOTHIAN

docBody.p: The “Inauguration” Business (blessings on it!), whh on Saturday seemed to be fixed for “April next,” has agn this morning come to hang betn that date and the “second week of Jany,”—not quite certain whh, for 3 or 4 days yet; tho’ I still think April the likelier. In whh latter case, my poor wife intends to come with me if she can!—

And whichever the date may be, what can we do but embrace with our best thanks yr benignant, invitatn,See TC to LLO, 16 [15] Nov.
—my Wife with not less pleasure than myself; nay almost with more, being a Physiognomist &c, and having taken a considerable loyalty already to Two Noble Persons, especially to a certain Noble Lady whom as yet she has little more than seen! This is literally true; and I forbid you to think it improbable.
You shall hear, I hope before this week end, how the date fixes itself; and then, apart from contingencies, we will if yr Ladyship permits hold the bargain settled.
With my kindest regards to the Ld Marquis, to whom may the Winter be gentle,—
