div3.sourceNote: JWC-MC [MCR], 28 Nov. Addr: care of Professor Craik / Chlorine Place ? [JWC’s question mark] / Belfast. PM: London, 29 Nov. 1865. MS: Strouse. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head:
JWC
TO MARY CRAIK

docBody.p:
Oh my little Woman! my little Woman!
Were it another than you, I shouldn’t have the face to write to you at all,—now,—at this date!! But you yourself
have been guilty of similar shameful silences! and so; must be able to understand and pardon, me. Who is it—George Sand?George Sand, pseud. of Amandine Lucile Aurore Dupin (1804–76), French novelist. who says “To understand all would be to pardon all”!French proverb, “Tout comprendre c’est tout pardonner”; Sand used a variant in Corinne, bk. 18, chap. 5.— Perhaps!—and certainly so far a truth, that I may rely on a little dear Woman, who has shown the profoundest understanding of that bad spell on ones power of writing, to pardon it to a person so otherwise exemplary as myself! So let us kiss and be friends!

The fact is my Dear, I should need to be born over again, into the Time of Penny Post!The penny post was introduced in 1840. My actual BirthJWC was born in 1801. occurred when postage was at a shilling and there-abouts, and it was a natural consequence that people should make their letters long and deliberate, to be worth the money they would cost. Now, one’s letter costs a penny and the penny paid by oneself; and the nicest conscience neednt trouble itself how few lines, and how offhand the lines, that go to a letter on the present terms of postage. Your modern Lady-letter may be written at any moment under any distractions! but as I have said, I was born too far back to adopt this free and easy little-note style—having been early used to filling big square sheets when I wrote at all. Now, I put off and put off always for “some reasonably good leisure”Coterie speech; see 24:104 JWC to TC, [7 July 1849] . and that being a condition rarely vouchsafed me, with one devilry and another; it happens——as it has happened in your case, that I often give myself the airs of a Brute, without being brutal the least in the world!Coterie speech; see 38:132 JWC to TC, [12 Aug. 1862] .

But if anything is more stupid than leaving a dear friends letters unanswered; it is answering then with a cart load of apologies. Let us “come out of that”Coterie speech; see 24:89 JWC to TC, [1 and 2 July 1849
.—

When Georgina saw me,Georgiana Craik, Mary’s sister; her meeting with JWC is unrecorded, but was presumably in May or June 1865 when JWC’s arm was very painful. I was wild with pain in my arm and hand, and I could not write, with the right hand—could not cut my food, nor sup my soup nor do any one earthly thing with it. After my return from Scotland in August, the pain went away all in a moment, and has never come back!! And tho’ the stiffness remained behind, that also has gradually lessened—till I have recovered such power in my hand that, the other day, I made myself a —— Bonnet!! which has been twice mistaken for one of Elise’s!Madame Elise, dressmaker; for a photograph of her, see 41:130 JWC to MR, [19 Dec. 1864] . And I can play on the piano!—and it would be difficult to say what female thing I could not do—if I tried!—

When we were both settled at home again—to all outward appearance at ease—with a certain dignity! the same “highly respectable” Cook and HousekeeperSarah Warren. who replaced the perfidious little Brute of a Mary, still saving me all trouble with my House; and a new Housemaid,Jessie Hiddleston. brought back with me from Scotland saving me all trouble with Mr Carlyle—a vixen, between ourselves (she)—if that signified much—but it doesn’t!—the time had come one would have said for settling up my letter-accounts. But no!— Mr C had got during his stay in Scotland a new idea! He had had his ears and his senses opened to the nuisance of railway whistles!—and no bribing no diplomacy could put down that; you know! So we had nights and days like those at MarinaMary Craik stayed with JWC and TC at 117 Marina, St. Leonards, May–July 1864; see 40:103 TC to HL, [21 May 1864] . with the cocks! minus hope—all hope of buying off the railway crowing! The problem now given me to solve was neither more nor less than this—to find some means of excluding sound, while giving the freest admission to air!!— Wide open windows, together with “something to keep the sound out”! “my”! (as the American Ambassador’s Daughter says)Presumably Mary Adams (1845–1928), younger da. of Charles Francis Adams (1807–86), American minister to the Court of St. James, 1861–68, and Abigail Brown, b. Brooks (1808–89). that I had no thought to spare for anything else while this problem remained on my mind, you will understand you! who had once the St Leonard cocks on your mind!JWC and TC both slept badly at Marina, but did not specifically mention cocks; see 40:122 TC to LLA, 25 June 1864
, and 126 TC to JN, 3 July [1864]
. At length, after weeks of experimenting on the principle that while air can circulate; sound goes straight; an apparatus of successive curtains was put up which served the end in view! and now I was about to “thank god and write to my friends”; when—oh Heaven! one morning I was waked by the crow—of—a—Cock, sounding almost in the same room!— I sprang out of bed—rushed to my dressing room window—and beheld—a sight for sore eyes indeed!—beheld a hen-hutch, that had been erected over night! in the nearest garden! and in front of the inelegant structure were pasturing much at their ease nine large hens and a magnificent cock!!! Oh my Dear had I been ever in my days given to fainting I should have—dropt on the spot! For the owner of this house is no longer Larkin,Henry and Louisa Larkin lived at 6 Cheyne Row until 1864. who could be acted upon; but a woman“A mysterious dressmaker”; see JWC to BB, [10 Dec.] ; unidentified further. whom ever since she came—eight months ago, we have suspected of——“many things” (as Mr C might say! For a week Mr C never observed this poultry so near him! was never awaked by the crowing!! The railway whistles being what now he
listened
for. But I who forsaw a terrible future when the discovery should be made! who went about with a terrible secret in my breast! I could “sleep no more”!See Macbeth 2.1.— Night after night I lay listening for that feathered Demon which was soon to drive Mr C mad; if not poisoned or otherwise disposed of! My head was full of strickxnyneJWC’s “x” over “stricknyne.” (I cant spell it), County Courts, coroners inquests! I lay awake meditating murder, till nature gave way and a terrible sick headache which I had not had the like of for many years laid me on my back for two days—and left me as if I had been getting a few turns on the rack! It was the first time I had intermitted my daily three hours drive since I came from Scotland! Two days ago, I had arranged a plan of operations—too long to enter upon now—but the result was what my dear old Edinr BettyBetty Braid. would call “perfect pis [peace]”! The Poultry is to be carried off bodily about Xmas, and meanwhile the cock is shut up in a dark cellar (whence no cheap of him can reach us)—from darkening till after our breakfast. In return for this heavenly deliverance, I give a lesson—in “syllables of two letters”—three time a week to a small Irish boy!Unidentified further.—

I never spoke of the new poultry to Mr C, until they were disposed of—and then I found he had been aware of them just two days, and had made up his mind to go to ask TyndalJohn Tyndall, physicist. for some—stricknine A fine mess he would have made of that line of action. The final scene was touching, sure that, tho’ he had said nothing, he must know about the cock, when the affair was all settled I rushed to his study and said “it is all right”!— “The cocks? said he, You have done for them”? “Yes the cock! you knew then?—” —“Oh if I knew!—I have been in despair! had no hope but in you”! Then he caught me in his arms and called me his “Guardian Angel” &c&c— But I must stop—I was amazed at your Father finding the photographPossibly JWC sent a copy of the Elliott & Fry photograph (taken April), which TC labeled “an unfavourable likeness”; see 42:48–49 TC to JWC, 29 May
. I sent suffering looking I had picked out the very brightest ask him how he likes the enclosed done about the same time—one day when I was weariedJohn Watkins also photographed JWC in April; see 41:210 JWC to MR, [14 April 1865] . None of these have been traced unless the photograph TC labeled “the worst” (reproduced by Kaplan 453) was by Watkins. She was also photographed at Holmhill, June or July; see frontis. piece. — That you can tell him is how I looked when you saw me! Give him my Love

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MCA, [29 Nov.]. MS: NLS Acc. 7864 and Acc. 7988. Hitherto unpbd. Dated by the Pollock dinner, 24 Nov.
div3.head:
JWC
TO MARY CARLYLE AUSTIN

docBody.p:
Oh my Dear!
I am so vexed that you should not have had your kind Sending acknowledged sooner.

It arrived when I was under a cloud—last Saturday, confined to bed in a perfect agony of sick headache! I had had nothing of that sort for many years, and it was really strange to me, the thought, how many such days I had passed formerly without being killed by them! But I am sure I couldnt live thro’ many such at the present date! The Headache and sickness lasted only one day and night— But the effects of it have not yet passed. I am as weak and nervous as if I had just come thro’ a course of mercury! And that is why I have let several posts pass without returning you our Thanks; but expressing them meanwhile in an approving consumption of the eggs and fowls— One was boiled on Monday (excellent!) the other is to be roasted today—according to my views about variety of food being requisite to the welfare of the human stomach. a consideration which Mr C makes light of but exemplifysThus in MS. in his own person, very convincingly the truth of—

One morning when I looked out of my dressing room window to see what sort of day it was; imagine the spectacle that met my eyes—a rubbishy hen-hutch—erected over night, in the garden next to ours—next! think of that! and nine large hens and one very large cock sauntering under our windows!!! I should have fainted where I stood, had I been in the habit of fainting but that I never was. As Mr C said nothing, I could not guess whether he had made the discovery or not— The crowing which occurred several times during the night as well as abundantly in the morning certainly did not awake him—his mind being at present intent on “Railway whistles”— But when he should have once opened his eyes to the thing and as the days should lengthen the crowning would increase—Ah—My Heaven what then?— no wonder that I lay awake thinking “what then!”— I have notMS Acc.7864 ends here; the letter continues on MS Acc. 7988. time to give a detailed account of all that followed Enough to say the poultry is all to evacuate the premises at Xmas and meanwhile the cock is shut up in a dark cellar from darkening till after our breakfast. And Mr C clasped me in his arms and called me his “Guardian Angel”“Some wretched people who had settled next door had brought poultry and other base disturbances; against which, for my sake, the noble soul heroically started up (not to be forbidden), and with all her old skill and energy gained victory, complete once more. For me—for me! and it was her last. The thought is cuttingly painful while I live” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:293). and all I have to pay for this restoration of peace and quietness, is giving a lesson three times a week in “Syllables of two Letters”—to a small Irish Boy!! rhyme that if you can!
Excuse this illwritten letter— I am not quite recovered from the crush of that poultry affair on my mind—altho the secret load is removed.
I will write soon when more up to writing— This is merely thanks and a kiss for the fowls and eggs— Oh if one never saw a fowl but like these—dead!
Love to them all—

postscript.p: Jessie—the Thornhill Girl is going on quite satisfactorily since I ceased treating her too kindly—snubbing, and riding with a curb bridle is what she needs. All her former Mistresses warned me of that; but I wouldnt believe them the Girl looked so sweet and affectionate, the humbug!

Mercifully Mr C sees no fault in her.TC later wrote on the reverse of the final sheet in blue pencil: “(1865, (the Hens &cat N 6: alas, alas))”; and then later has overwritten in ink: “Complete / (Spring, 1865) / (I remember it well).”

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 29 Nov. MS: NLS 518.16. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
Inclosed is my Ansr (barring maculae [marks, spots, blemishes]) to Profr Kelland;TC refers to the crossings out on his draft that he enclosed with this letter, writing at the end: “Copy (burn)—” (MS: NLS 518.36); see above and opp. For the final letter, see TC to PK, 29 Nov.
—bad luck to all this botheratn of botheratns abt nothing at all! To Laing I cd not prevail on myself to write farther on the point. I conclude that Kelland & he will decide to let it stand, “beging of April”; and that I shall have leave to dismiss it for some months!—— —— We are getting better agn: Jane
is out driving with Miss BromelyCaroline Davenport Bromley. in Miss B.’s brougham; yesterday she did not drive at all,—her own horse got a slight hurt near the hoof the other night (a furious cart, either run away with, or driven by fellows drunk, coming madly near collisn), and is not to yoke agn till abt Friday. We have, meanwhile, given up all dinners &c:—only FuzJohn Forster. for Xmas day, if we be able. The day is muddy: vernal sunshine & winter wet & darkness strangely alternate. Kindest regards to James, Jean & all the rest

div3.sourceNote: TC-PK, 29 Nov. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO PHILIP KELLAND

docBody.p: Be pleased to offer my best thanks to The Senatus, and express the sense I have of their courtesy and goodness to me.

Originally I had been desirous that the Installation shd take place “before the Xmas Holidays”; but finding, by what evidence I cd gather, that this wd not be suitable, and that on various grounds the early days of April (“first week or so,”) wd be the fit time, I lately settled it that way—or empowered Mr Laing my Assessor so to settle it for me.

figure.p: Draft of Thomas Carlyle to Peter Kelland, 29 November 1865 page 1

p.hi: Courtesy of the National Library of Scotland

figure.p: Draft of Thomas Carlyle to Peter Kelland, 29 November 1865, page 2

p.hi: Courtesy of the National Library of Scotland

docBody.p: If it be the least an object to the Senatus, or involve at all the interests of the University, we will still change to “the early part of january”: but if otherwise (and it be perhaps only a polite indulgence to myself, as I can surmise), I shd then a little prefer to abide by the settlet already made,—whh I had announced to my Assessor and some others.

May I ask you to be so kind as communicate with Mr Laing,Philip Kelland wrote to David Laing, 29 [30] Nov.: “The Senatus had assumed that Mr Carlyle was coming down in January, but it appears that he had previously arranged with you to come in April, as it was stated in the Newspapers. / He requests me to consult with you as to the desirableness of adhering to this or otherwise. Perhaps it would be inconvenient for him to come down in Jany. I think the students would somewhat prefer it, but it would be unfair to bring him down when it would be inconvenient for himself” (MS: EUL). —on the understanding that whatever you and he judge best, I intend to adopt as the practical decision, and so save farther trouble on this preliminary point. I remain always

postscript.p: Professor Kelland &c&c

div3.sourceNote: TC-BC, 30 Nov. MS: Bodleian Lib. Copy. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO BLANCHE CLOUGH

docBody.p:
I have rec’d, and read with unusual interest, the beautiful and pious memorial to your late Husband,Arthur Hugh Clough; see TC to JAC, 7 Nov.
Arthur Hugh Clough, Letters and Remains (1865), ed. and privately pbd. by Blanche Clough. my ever-regretted Friend. To those who knew him in life, it is like his very image bro’t back in glory. So wise, so clear, so cheerful, faithful, bright and pious a soul I have not often known in this world!

You have done your task in a very graceful and intelligent manner; your
matinalsTC possibly meant her introductory material. too were excellent. I am very much indebted for your gift to me of a copy; and will keep it among my preciosities, with a feeling far from common in such cases. Alas, alas!

There were one or two very nice Notes to myself from New Engl’d; which I now cannot find, after not a little searching; but if I ever do, they shall be sent you at once.Arthur Clough traveled to New England Oct. 1852–July 1853, and wrote to TC from there; Blanche Clough asked TC about these letters, 1862, but he was unable to find them; they were later discovered, and included in The Correspondence of Arthur Hugh Clough, ed. Frederick L. Mulhauser, 2 vols. (Oxford, 1957) 2:342–44; see 38:70–71 TC to BC, 9 March 1862
. Only parts of them could have gone into this Book; and many others, still more valuable, must, I suppose, have been lost. Dipsychus with his Easter etc. pleases me extremely, even in this ragged and incipient stage;The book included the poems “Easter Day” (1849) and “Dipsychus” (1850), in which the character Dipsychus refers to “Easter Day” as his poem. “Dipsychus” is a dialogue between a tormented young man and a spirit who discuss the conflict between the impossible Romantic ideal of a world of goodness and purity, and the realism of living in the world as it is. The poem was unfinished and in draft form; for a discussion of it, including its similarity to Sartor, see Clyde de L. Ryals, “An Interpretation of Clough’s ‘Dipsychus,’” Victorian Poetry 1 (Aug. 1963):182–88. nowhere in English writing has a talent like that of Faust Johann Wolfgang von Goethe (1749–1832), German writer; his “Faust” takes the form of a similar dialogue between a man and a spirit. (truly cognate, and yet so divine) looked out on me as there.

We have had a good deal of distress since you saw us last; but, thank Heaven, my wife is now much better, indeed as well as had been usual to her. We should be very glad to see you and Miss CloughAnne Jemima Clough (1820–92; ODNB), women’s educator, Arthur Clough’s sister, who had been living with Blanche Clough since 1862 helping her with the children. again when in our neighbourhood.

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady L [LLO], 2 Dec. Addr: Newbattle / Dalkeith / N.B. PM: London, 2 Dec. 1865. MS: NLS Acc. 11439. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head:
TC
TO LADY LOTHIAN

docBody.p: It is not yet quite settled, at least not yet announced to me (for I have left it with Mr Laing & the Professors), what time my Edinr adventure is to be; but I suppose the old date, “beginning of April,” will be allowed to hold:—at any rate, yr hospitable Ladyship shall hear if there is any material alteratn.

Meanwhile I have to record the arrival, night before last,—duly heralded from the woods of Blickling (in a fine hand of whh I cannot read the signature),—of a magnifict Wild Turkey; the like of whh I did not know to inhabit this side of the Atlantic,—and whose personal acquaintance we were, on various grounds, very proud to make. A magnanimous russet-coloured fellow,—still in perfect order, I am assured; and who will this day fulfill his destiny, let us not doubt, in a credible and benefict way! Many thanks for this pretty remembrance of us, thanks from Wife & self.

I know not if Lord Lothian takes any interest in these Workmen--Master Controversies that are getting so rife in late times, and are likely to grow louder and louder till they get upon the way of settlement.TC was referring to labor disputes which had been continuing since the spring, in ironworks and collieries, throughout the midlands and north of England. The Times reported: “The North Staffordshire Coal and Iron Masters’ Defence Fund, recently established to support employers in resisting strikes of the men for enforcing unjust demands, is now in operation. … The strike at Mr. Williamson’s colliery at Tunstall, which has now continued for 12 weeks, came under the consideration of the meeting, and it was ordered that full compensation be made to Mr. Williamson from the commencement of the strike, and that the amount due to him for 12 weeks be paid forthwith” (11 Nov.). Mr. Williamson was Hugh Henshall Williamson (1785–1867), land and property owner (1861 census); his brother Robert (b. ca. 1781), listed in the 1851 census as a coal mine owner but not listed in the 1861 census, was presumably d.; they were both mine owners, presumably including in the Tunstall area. The Times then reported: “The colliers working in the South Yorkshire coalfield met in their thousands on Monday last, at Wombwell, Yorkshire, to take the final step as regards their demand for an advance of 10 per cent. upon the wages at present paid by their masters. … [T]he meeting pledged itself not to rest satisfied until this, in its opinion, just demand was conceded. From present appearances there is likely to be a long struggle. … There will not, however, be a general strike on the part of the men, nor yet a general lock-out on the part of the masters, judging from the present phase of the dispute” (15 Nov.). In the Nov. issue of Macmillan’s Magazine, Thomas Hughes (1822–96; ODNB), MP for Lambeth and a novelist influenced by TC’s writings, wrote: “For years past there has been an uneasy feeling throughout the country at the frequent recurrence of strikes and locksout in one branch or another of our great productive industries. … When a local dispute between the masters and men of a small district can lighten up in a few days into a blaze over the whole north and centre of England, paralyze the most flourishing of our trades, and threaten some quarter of a million people with utter destitution, it is no longer the question of a section of the nation: our own houses are in danger” (“Trades’ Unions, Strikes, and Co-operation,” Macmillan’s Magazine 13 [Nov. 1865]: 75). I fear “Cassell and Co”Cassell, Petter, & Galpin, publishers, La Belle Sauvage Yard, 38 Ludgate Hill. The firm was founded by John Cassell (1817–65; ODNB), self-taught political radical and temperance advocate, with the purpose of advancing the moral and social well-being of the working classes. Due to financial difficulties the firm was taken over, 1855, by two printers, Thomas Dixon Galpin (1828–1910) and George William Petter (1823–88); they reinstated Cassell as a co-partner. They published several magazines, including the weekly Cassell’s Illustrated Family Paper, aimed particularly at the middle and working classes. won’t do much that way; but I have consented to see their EditorPossibly Thomas Frost; otherwise unidentified.
for a few minutes. As Great Britn is growing more and more into one universal, sooty, most unlovely Blacksmith’s Shop, this questn is evidtly the most importt of all.—— What a shriekery is ris- is risingRepeated at turn of page. abt the “Jamaica Massacre,”Reports were published in British newspapers from mid-Nov. about the insurrection in Jamaica, then a British colony. The immediate cause of the uprising was the trial of a Jamaican for trespass on an abandoned plantation. A group led by Paul Bogle (ca. 1820–65), deacon of Stony Cut Baptist Church, protested the proceedings; one of them was arrested and violence followed after the protesters rescued their colleague. On 11 Oct. when around 300 Jamaicans attacked the Court House in Morant Bay, the Custos (chief magistrate) assembled a small group of volunteer militia outside the building, and read the riot act to the assembled crowd. Hostilities ensued, resulting in deaths on both sides. The British governor of Jamaica, Edward John Eyre, concluded that the rebellion was aimed at exterminating the white population of the island. He believed that Bogle had been encouraged by George William Gordon (ca. 1820–65; ODNB), b. Jamaica; his father, Joseph Gordon, was a wealthy white sugar planter and his mother an unnamed slave; George Gordon was a Baptist preacher, a delegate to the House of Assembly, and a fierce critic of Eyre’s governorship; although Gordon was in Kingston, a town under civil jurisdiction, Eyre had him transferred to Morant Bay, where martial law had been declared. Gordon was charged with high treason and sedition and hanged, 25 Oct. More than 400 suspected rebels were shot or hanged, about 600 flogged, and 1,000 had their homes burnt. The controversy centered on whether or not Eyre’s actions were excessive, not on any question of the possible justice of the insurgents’ cause. The view of the Times editorial, 2 Dec., was that “[t]he importance of the events in Jamaica, and the intense interest which has been excited by them in this country, make it incumbent on the Government to give to the public at once the means of forming an accurate opinion. The English Press has no correspondents in the island, and for anything like trustworthy intelligence must be dependent on official documents or the chance letters of respectable private persons. We have not thought it necessary or right to publish the absurd and incoherent accounts from the Jamaica papers that came to hand by the last mail, bearing as they did the marks of enormous exaggeration. … On the one hand, we find the Governor of Jamaica, a man of long experience and most honourable character, with all the authorities, military and civil, of the island, declaring that the colony had been in the greatest danger, and could only have been saved by the prompt and severe measures which have been taken; on the other hand, there is a strong party at home which asserts that these people have, under the influence of rage or fear, or political hatred, indulged in a cruel massacre. For the sake of those who are thus assailed, as well as for the general satisfaction of the country, we trust that the Government will give the earliest publicity to everything that may be received from either the civil or military authorities. The executions have been numerous; it may be that some at least were unnecessary; but both soldiers and civilians on the other side of the ocean were of opinion that the danger was great, and the Legislature of the island has agreed with them.”—from a few throats, I can remark, but of choicest folly.—

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 2 Dec. MS: NLS 526.35. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
My dear Brother,—Except the inclosed from Mr MuirJohn Muir, an assessor to the General Council of Edinburgh Univ. John A. Carlyle wrote, 19 Nov.: “Your other correspondent, Muir … founded the Sanscrit Professorship (giving £4,000) three years ago. He is a very good man in his way & very courteous—formerly the Civil Service of India—perhaps rather too much set on giving & getting money for university as the main thing.” I have had nothing from Edinr;—“time of Installatn” still schwebend (hovering); and shall for me “hover,” much luck to it the while!— — I am not worse in health, better if anything, being very punctual in regr regimen &c; Jane the like, tho’ her horse still stands vacant: I have had to employ one of Silvester’sJohn Silvester, Chelsea livery stables. for a day or two, to avoid worse losses.— — Nothing else worth mentn has occurred,—except what you will see indicated in the Froude & StephenJames Fitzjames Stephen. Letters, if you read them before burning. The Stephen Review of me in Fraser James Fitzjames Stephen, “Mr. Carlyle,” Fraser’s Magazine 72 (Dec. 1865): 778–810. In a balanced and detailed assessment of TC’s writings, Stephen classified him as a “Transcendentalist” adamantly opposed to “Benthamism and Democracy”; he rejected the assumption that Carlyle was a misguided “visionary”: “To those who not merely defend, but admire Mr. Carlyle, his practical sagacity will probably appear one of the most characteristic features of his character. It is entirely in harmony with the whole of his philosophy, which might almost be described as fact-worship” (787). His “strange language” was the result of his need to “express the extreme depth, earnestness, and vivacity of his own feelings. … It is only by the use of humour and paradox that he can give full scope to his feelings” (786). According to Stephen, TC’s support of slavery betrayed a lapse of historical understanding: “Abolish slavery says [the British nation]—reform it says [Mr. Carlyle]. [He] entirely omits to notice the fact that it was precisely because long experience and repeated trials showed that it could not possibly be reformed that it was at last abolished” (794). is really goodish; thinking you wd wish perhaps to read it, Jean & you, I mean to despatch it on Monday,—you to forward it to Walter Welsh,Rev. Walter Welsh, JWC’s cousin at Auchtertool, Fife. John A. Carlyle replied, 7 Dec.: “Jean & I read the Article in Fraser with great interest, & liked it well; & the magazine was sent off to Auchtertool yesterday.” at yr leisure. Stephen is the late Sir James Stn’s Sir James Stephen. eldest Son; a rising Lawyer, and really an honest intelligt kind of man. Instead of ansr, I bade Froude (before I saw the “Article”) bring him down for a walk with me Tomorrow.In his memoir of his brother, Leslie Stephen recalled: “Fitzjames, on his first call, had been received by Mrs. Carlyle, who ordered him off the premises on suspicion of being an American celebrity hunter. He submitted so peacefully that she relented; called him back, and, discovering his name, apologised for her wrath. I cannot fix the dates, but during these years Fitzjames gradually came to be very intimate with her husband” (Leslie Stephen, The Life of Sir James Fitzjames Stephen [1895] 201). Bother, Bother! But Froude’s
nr neighbourhd Froude had recently moved from Clifton Place, Hyde Park, to 5 Onslow Gdns., S. Kensington, a short walk from Cheyne Row. is rather a convenience to me. Ld Lothian’s Norfolk GamekeeperProbably Henry Butler (b. ca. 1845), gamekeeper at Blickling Hall, Norfolk. sends us a “Wild Turkey” (strange big russet-coloured flatch),—whh we instantly despatch for Dr Quain’s eating. An Irish-Yankee Editr Possibly John Louis O’Sullivan (1813–95), Irish American cofounder and editor of the United States Magazine and Democratic Review (1837–59). At the outbreak of the American Civil War, he declared himself a Confederate sympathizer and supporter of slavery; he spent much of the war publishing and lecturing in London. (from Emerson) is to call; &c&c! Chorley is still invisible, but said to be recovering.John Rutter Chorley, ill with sciatica; see TC to JAC, 24 Nov.
You don’t want me to stay in-doors too long, for such causes.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MP, [3 Dec.]. MS: Harry Ransom Center, Univ. of Texas. Pbd: Price, “Recollections” 34. Dated by the injury to Bellona’s hoof, late Nov.
div3.head: JWC TO MARIA PRICE

docBody.p: I have ever so many times thought of going to you in these weeks. But—“the Pigs have run thro”!Coterie speech; see 23:205JWC to HW, [20 Jan. 1849]. My carriage horse has had a bad foot, and is still in the hands of “the Doctor.”TC recorded in his checkbook: “2 Dec r 1865 / to Silvester (Horse &clame) / £9 .. 18 .. 2” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). I myself have been off my sleep, and besides, “troubled about many things”See Luke 10:41. and so—and so——!
Would you come to me? Would you mind the long road back—with no Mr Ruskin to take you?See JWC to Lady Am [KST], 7 and 8 Nov.

I have a charming friend coming to keep me company on Wednesday next, in Mr Carlyle’s absencePossibly one of the Reichenbach das., Elisabeth or Hedwig. When Maria Price described the evening, she did not identify the friend but later referred to meeting “Count R[eichenbach], the father of the young German lady I had seen”: “Of course the invitation was joyfully accepted, and we three dined together. Mrs Carlyle was dressed in black velvet. She had a pale blue ribbon round her neck, to which was attached a large gold cross; she also wore a brooch which had been given to her by Goethe. One of her bracelets (a very pretty one, pebbles of different colours, and beautifully cut, polished, and set in silver), she told the lady I had been invited to meet, was a present from the same great man” (Price, “Recollections” 35 and 34).— Would you come and make her acquaintance?—
in spite of there being no Mr C? If so, let me see you to dinner between five and six oclock—on Wednesday 6th— Perhaps you may get a glimpse of Mr C before you need to leaveAfter dinner TC returned: “Mrs Carlyle gave me a mischievous smile as Mr Carlyle followed by two gentlemen, entered the room. They were all in high spirits, and had been to see ‘Chang,’ the Chinese giant. … I … was sufficiently interested in listening to the brilliant, clever talk. One of these gentlemen was Professor Tyndall, the other I did not recognise. The Professor gave me my tea, and talked to me a little, but I preferred listening,—keeping well in Mrs Carlyle’s shadow, and slipping quietly away when it grew late” (Price, “Recollections” 34).—
One of my Servants could take you to an Omnibus—if you liked!

div3.sourceNote: TC-MW [MEW], 4 Dec. MS: NLS Acc. 9207. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO META WELLMER

docBody.p:
I received duly your graceful little Gift of the Jean-Paul Autograph;Wellmer had sent TC two Jean Paul Richter autographs for him to copy, duly returned by TC; see TC to MEW, 24 Oct.
Presumably Wellmer had now sent him one as a gift. whh I prize very much, and will take good care of: I ought, in conscience, to have thanked you for it, weeks ago; and indeed, in a silent way, have been doing so, but cd not in words till now,—it wd seem! The truth is, I am, of late, considerably overburdened with affairs, bigger and less; and my health is always rather feeble. No doubt you excuse me.
May all good be with you, dear young Lady: continue yr kind feeling towards me so long as it will last;—and if you ever come where I am, by all means apply for a “sight of me,” shd you still wish!

div3.sourceNote: TC-[TD] [TDI], 4 Dec. MS: EUL. Quot: Sotheby’s Catalog, 21 Dec. 1965.
div3.head: TC TO [THOMAS DIXON]

docBody.p:
I have just recd the Bewick’s Book of Birds;Thomas Bewick (1753–1828; ODNB), Bewick’s Birds, 2 vols. (Newcastle, 1797 and 1804). whh you, and my other Friends not named, but all thanked very heartily, have been so kind as send me. The
Book is one I have long known, and loved as an excellt and noble one; but of whh I had no Copy. Bewick is an honour to Northumberland and to the world; and shall henceforth be more than ever a possession to me,—acquired in altogether a welcome and pretty kind of way. Better Gift you cd not have chosen for me; and the feeling on yr parts that brings it to me may well make it still more valuable. I beg you will thank my little group of considerate Northumbrian FriendsAlthough Dixon did not apparently name his friends with this gift, when he sent TC a gift for his 71st birthday, he added at the end of his letter of 3 Dec. 1866 (vol. 44): “I give you slight sketches of the friends beside their Autographs in the other page” (MS: NLS 1768.196A). They were William Crosby, artist; W. Rutledge, wood carver; James Taylor, watch maker; Samuel Westness, wood carver; W. Henry Hill, bookseller and printer; William Pae, artist; and Jane Bewick (1787–1881; ODNB), da. of Thomas Bewick. very expressly all round; and tell them I find their Gift a finely human thing, and will try to keep it in a human manner.

No doubt you have seen this Prospectus; one of the ManagersProspectus and manager unidentified further. was here an hour ago, and I have some hopes he too may do a little good. With many cordial acknowledgts of yr & yr comrades’ kind feeling towards me,

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 5 Dec. MS: NLS 518.18. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NL 2:232–33 inc.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
Today no more than yesterday brings me any word from Laing or Kelland; the time of my Edinr Journey still an unfixed quantity. A thing not entirely pleasant; yet a thing, on the whole, whh I will not write farther abt if I can help. Patience: one must even put up with all these empty botheratns,—since one did not at first (as might have been better) pitch the whole busss into the cesspool!— I enclose Muir’s Letter;See TC to JAC, 2 Dec.
except the trish-trash of Letters (continually flowing in, and all abt other people’s busss and interests!) specimens of whh I inclose for yr burning, I have, as it were, no other news.

Last night, very much agt my will, we had to go to Forster’s; F. himself ill of gout wd take no denial: “Yr birthday, Carlyle!” To set abt rejoicing because one’s 70 th year is done wd not have occurred to myself by any means: ah me, ah me! However, the thing went well enough, foolish as it was; and did not break my sleep. BrowningRobert Browning. was there, and one Dyce (an Aberdeen Ex-shovelhat, huge grey man, very good-natured) who lives upon Shakspeare;Alexander Dyce (1798–1869; ODNB), literary scholar and editor; he spent his childhood in Aberdeen, and was ordained into the Church of England, 1823, hence the epithet “shovel-hat,” after the stiff, broad-brimmed, low-crowned hat worn by English clergymen (see 13:115 TC to RMM, 25 April 1841
, and later vols.); he published a 6-vol. edn. of Shakespeare in 1857, and between 1863 and 1867 was working on a revised 9-vol. edn. no other except ourselves,Forster hosted a similar dinner party, March 1864, with TC, Browning, and Dyce; see 40:36 TC to JWC, 21 March 1864
.—poor Jane says she always sleeps better after such a thing! On friday (no help for that either!) we are to go to the Froudes:James and Henrietta Froude. after whh—except Fuz’s Xmas (fixed, weeks ago) let us hope there is nothing of that kind farther in store!Jessie Hiddleston later remembered that TC “dined out seldom, and usually at John Forster’s. She [JWC] had to coax him and settle the thing at least a week in advance, and even then he would seem uncertain about going and ready to change his mind at the last moment and not go; but in general she had promised him, and took him, even although he had said ‘no’ when the thing was first mentioned. / Mrs. Carlyle was different—dined out very often, nearly every night, returning home at midnight or later” (Wilson, Carlyle 6:38). I am not worse in health than I was; and I cd digest my own gloom well enough, if well let alone,Coterie speech; see 18:231 JWC to HW, [7 Oct. 1844] .—whh I hardly am! Most dull, wearisome and unprofitable most people are to me; hardly above one or two whose talk is worth the breath it costs: but that is the rule of things.

On Sunday Alfred Tennyson was here; had a dilapidated kind of look, but in talk was cheerful of tone; Woolner is his host: Woolner & he, with Froude & Stephen (meeting at the door, I suppose) were all here together; and I hastened to get them out into the Park muddy & clamy as that was.Woolner wrote to Lady Ashburton, 9 Dec.: “I took the Bard [Tennyson] to call on Carlyle last Sunday calling on Froude by the way; we all took a ramble together in Hyde Park and enjoyed it exceedingly. It rejoices me to see the quiet (for him) state of mind the beloved old philosopher is in now; for he seems to me to be really tasting the pleasure of quietude, after his 50 years of grim battle with the kings of darkness” (MS: NLS Acc. 11388). Neuberg came in the evg; first time for many weeks: he is much older since you saw him last, and considbly deaf. “Two years” yet of Translatn ahead!Joseph Neuberg was working on a translation of Frederick; he d., 1867, before he was finished; it was completed by Friedrich Althaus (1829–97), biographer.— Chorley is still perdu [hidden]. “Professor Tyndall” (a great admirer, if you ever heard of him) has appeared agn of late; really a cheery thoroughgoing man, & perfect in the newest news of the Chemical & Physical world. Our Stephen I think must be the elder (a big heavy man of perhaps 33):James Fitzjames Stephen was the elder brother of Leslie Stephen; John A. Carlyle replied, 7 Dec.: “The Stephen I saw at Cambridge is the younger brother of your reviewer. … The elder (Fitzjames) apparently practises in the Ecclesiastical Courts. … His differences with you in regard to Slavery & the negroes are honest & sincere. … I think his review very good indeed & at the same time perfectly fair & even kind from his point of view.” the Dickens PaperCharles Dickens’s weekly magazine, All the Year Round. sent to Jean yesterday was one of 2 copies that had come.— Oh, I ought to have mentioned that a certn Cork-cutter Thomas Dixon. at Sunderland, “combining with a few other Working Men,” sent me yesterday a fair enough copy of Bewick’s Birds, “in honr of my 70th birthday,”—poor souls, after all!Coterie speech; see 1:211 TC to AC, 15 Dec. 1819
.

closer.salute: Adieu, dr Brother, dr Friends all.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady S [LST], 9 Dec. MS: Duke. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head:
JWC
TO LADY STANLEY

docBody.p:
We should have liked it so much! “if it had not been entirely out of the question; under the circumstances”! If you care to know what “the circumstances” are—“circumstances over which I, alas, for one, “have no control”Cf. Dickens, Bleak House (1853), chap. 55.—they are somewhat of the nature of the Lilliputian Pack threads, cobwebish enough
separately but binding by their number!For the tying down of Gulliver with hundreds of web like ropes by the tiny Lilliputians, see Jonathan Swift, Gulliver’s Travels (1726) part I; for an illustration by Thomas Morten in the new edn. by John Francis Waller, 1865, reprinted in the 1867 edn., see above. Thomas Morten (1836–66; ODNB) killed himself, Sept. 1866, because of financial difficulties.

figure.p: “Lilliputian Pack threads,” illustration by Thomas Morten

Gulliver’s Travels
(Cassell, Peter & Galpin, 1867)

p.hi: Courtesy of the National Library of Scotland

docBody.p:
First; “it is so terrible a thought,Coterie speech; see 17:173 JWC to JW, [12 Nov. 1843] . that of plashing four hundred miles thro’ the dark winter!— Besides You (meaning me) couldn’t do it, without bringing down ruin on yourself! And another journey, double the distance, that must be taken in March! And Milnes?— What could you make of that”? (Lord Houghton had invited us so pressingly! and almost quarrelled with Mr C for again refusing!) “No! it can’t be done! You may tell them truly; that there is nowhere I like better to stay than at Alderley!—few people—in fact, nobody, that I like better to talk with than Lord Stanley! I have always found him &c&c&c—!— And I cannot but say (why shouldn’t he?) that Lady Stanley showed a sort of appreciation
of me, when there wasn’t much of that going! And has been always a kind woman to me! and a nice (?) one!—when one can get any talk with her alone!! But she is always swamped in young people now—when one goes to see her.”— Ach!

I wish he had been feeling more up to travelling. He really has not got over the reaction of his ten years labours yet!— I, as a solitary individual,Coterie speech; see 19:108 JWC to TC, [25 July 1845] . would have risked the “ruin.”

And He has to go to Edinr the last week of March—to deliver that vexatious “address.” Which he shudders to think of! Not being so fond of speechifying as Mr Gladstone. If the weather then and my neuralgia permit, I shall go with him to keep up his heart. I was not dreaming of such a thing till Lady Lothian put it in my head, by pressing me to accompany him to Newbattle Abbey. for the time of his stay in Edinr

I called at Airlie Lodge yesterday but the LadiesMaude Stanley and Lady Airlie who wrote, 4 Dec.: “I am come to town for my confinement & I long to see you before it comes off Shall we that is Maude & myself find you in the afternoon after four oclock— I hope you are pretty well & not in the country.” Her da. Griselda was b., 20 Dec., at Airlie Lodge, Kensington; the Lodge was previously owned by Thomas Babington Macaulay (1800–1859; ODNB), Baron Macaulay; he d. there 28 Dec. 1859; Lord Airlie then bought it. It had been called (and was later renamed) Holly Lodge; for a later photograph, see 69. were “out in the carriage.”

figure.p: Airlie Lodge, Kensington

Courtesy of the National Library of Scotland

div3.sourceNote: TC-DL, 9 Dec. MS: EUL. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO DAVID LAING

docBody.p: I had written yesterday to Profr Kelland, offering the Senatus (what yr Letter of this morning is a welcome confirmation of) the choice of “Last week in March,” if they thot it preferable to First in April. I hope they will decide that way; but probably there is no need of my troubling you farther on that subject. I am also glad you have explained to me what “Second Week of January” meant.David Laing wrote, 8 Dec.: “At the College yesterday I was told Profr Kelland had written to you wishing on the part of the Senate that you should fix January for your Address. Asking why that month should be thought of, it seems the Professors have an Annual dinner at which they would like to have you present. Further if delayed till April many of the Medical Students might be absent from Edinr after the 1st of that month. All this I hold to be of no great importance. Perhaps the last week of March might obviate this objection.”

I cannot see any daylight thro’ Mr Thorburn’s grand Project;Rev. David Thorburn (1805–93), minister of South Leith Free Church of Scotland, was prominently involved in the Scottish Universities and Educational Association that had the aim of obtaining better endowments for the universities of Scotland; he had written a pamphlet on the subject, The Endowment of the Universities of Scotland an Object of National Importance (Edinburgh, 1863); at a meeting of the association, 5 Dec., he submitted a paper outlining his proposals for funding more teaching positions, scholarships, and accommodation for both teachers and students in all Scottish universities (later pbd. as The University Endowment Movement: Memorandum Relative Thereto [Edinburgh, 1866]), and a provisional committee was set up to look into this. Laing wrote, 8 Dec.: “His scheme may be thought Utopian, but it would not commit you to allow your name to appear, as he wishes, as one of the Provisional Committee.” TC’s name did not appear as one of the provisional committee. and must content myself with wishing it well from the distance. I have already joined Mr Muir’s “Association”;John Muir was the secretary of the Association for the Better Endowment of the University of Edinburgh; TC recorded in his checkbook: “2 decr 1865 / to John Muir Esq (Edinr University ‘Associatn’—blessings on it!) / £10 .. 0 .. 0” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). whh is enough of Terra Incognita [unknown land] to me in that directn.

Not long since, I learned that the University had done itself the credit of constituting you L.L.D.: I know not if you adopt the well-earned Title; but shall learn by and by, and conform to usage.Laing was awarded the honorary degree of LL.D. (Doctor of Laws) in 1864. Laing replied, 13 Dec.: “I don’t take the title of Doctor, (which I heartily detest) but in a matter connected with the College, it may be proper to add LL.D. to my name.” Meanwhile I seem to feel you not a whit less valuable to me, almost more, under the old form:—and remain as always

div3.sourceNote: JWC-BB, [10 Dec.]. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd. Dated by the arrival of the hens and a cock at No. 6, and TC’s recent birthday.
div3.head:
JWC
TO BESSIE BLAKISTON

docBody.p:
Oh my darling Bessey! Please don’t
!— It frightens me so when you dream about me, or have presentiments about me!— If I am not ill, I fall to fancying I am about to be!— But indeed you are generally right in your divinations; and when you divine there is something amiss with me, something is already amiss!— So, this time; I have not been, to say ill exactly; but I have been off my sleep again,—the first time since I returned from Scotland and took that
miraculous doze of Morphia which, twenty four hours after taking it, gave me a sleep so deep and so long, that when I awoke from it, I hadn’t an atom of recollection who I was! was clear about nothing but only that “it couldn’t be me who had had that nice sleep”!!For JWC’s deep sleep on returning from Scotland, July 1865, see 42:151 JWC to MR, [26 July] . Ever since then, I had slept; better and worse; but always some; till three weeks ago, when I was worried into my old sad habit of lying awake all night long! with a pertinacity which even Morphia could not overcome! It is a terrible misfortune really to have been born with a natural affinity to Worry! Thick skinned people haven’t a conception what we thin-skinned individuals have to endure!— Not one in a thousand could understand how my Sleep should have been driven a hundred miles off, and darkness should have descended on the face of my soul, and all the blood in my heart should have rushed up to my head, at the innocent—rather Arcadian spectacle that met my eyes, on looking out from my dressing room window, some three weeks ago, into the nearest garden!

No. six
has been tenanted for a year back by a very mysterious “Dressmaker,” who takes in very mysterious Lodgers,Unidentified further. the latest, a Lady, who came with two van-loads of furniture, which being all carried in, the shutters of the lower room were closed, and have never been opened since!! In the garden however, a waste bit of ground this long while, Phenomena presented themselves from which we could infer—several things! For example, an excessively bad old rocking horse, with a tattered side-saddle, indicated the neighbourhood of a female child.—who, added to the solitary little Boy of the Dressmaker, very quiet Boy hitherto, might get up more noise than Mr C would like! Then, an enormous brasswired cage, taken out to be cleaned, left me no doubt of——a parrot! Good God! there was a prospect for us when the fine weather came, and this cursed Bird should be hung outside to make the horriblest sounds!

But one thing I noticed that I couldnt make head or tail of—a great number of green spars of unequal lengths, mixed up with mats and wicker-boxes!— Were they going to make these things into a little play-house for the children?—or a rabbit House perhaps?— Strange! that with all my horrible experiences, it never occurred to me, till I looked out that morning and saw the accomplished fact, that what they were going to make was a——hen-house!!! just under Mr C’s bed-room window! and just under my own bed-room window; for that matter! But, what made me all but burst a blood vessel on the spot,—what would have made me drop down in a faint—if I had ever fainted in my life! was the recollections that rushed thro’ me, all in a heap, of the nights that Mr C had wandered about, sleepless and near mad; with cocks!
and the days laden with discord and dispair—about cocks; following naturally on such nights! and of all the dirt I had been made to eat in negociating with the Cock-owners, and begging or buying their removal.See 28:350–51 JWC to CR, 25 Dec. 1853
. Was that sort of thing to begin again, now that I had neither the strength nor the Spirit for it? Now that the first interview I sought with the cock-owner I was sure to take a pain like a knife-stab at the bottom of my back; that would take my breath away, and leave me gaspingFor TC’s later comment on JWC’s back pain and loss of breath, see JWC to DA, 15 March 1866
.—like an idiot?

I counted the hens airing themselves in the garden, there were nine of them, and one magnificent cock! who bewildered by the novelty of his position, maintained a golden silence! But I knew whether that was likely to last! Next night I went to bed all in a flutter with the evil discovery of the day; was at last falling asleep, when a loud crow seemed to issue from under my bed!! This was at three of the morning; the crow was repeated three times! the same performance came off at four, and again at five! Mr C sleeping soundly thro it all! and I, with my heart thumping,—listening not for the crowing only—but far worse—for Mr C’s step on the floor overhead, telling that he had been disturbed and would make everybody know he had! Oh my Heavens! For a week I kept this bad secret in my breast; all that time Mr C never discovering it for himself! But my sleep had gone. and I had to take to bed at last with sick headache. Now I used to find, when addicted to sick headache (It is years since I had one) that I always came out of it with my wits unusually clear! and this time also, I got up out of my agony, with a clear insight into the course to be followed with this cock and a determination to follow it forthwith. Just in time! For Mr C had seen the Cock and was going mad about him, the very day that I brought my operations to a triumphant close—had got the Cock utterly extinguished from three in the afternoon till ten in the morning; and the whole bad lot to be removed from the Premises at Xmas. And didn’t Mr C catch me in his arms, and kiss me wildly, and call me his “guardian Angel” and every denomination of Angel!— And scenes in which one figures as “angel” are not good for the nervous subject either!—anything but soporific they are!— So the sleep that had been worried away didn’t come back all at once, when the worry had ceased—is only coming back slowly, and with difficulty—now!

For the rest of my neuralgia keeps in abeyance. and tho’ my right arm continues stiff I can do wonderful things with the hand! For example I made Mr C two beautiful black stocks, for a Birthday present.

What a tiresome Boy that “Charlie”Charles Bally (b. ca. 1846), known to Peyton Blakiston since childhood; Charles (age five) was staying with Blakiston during the 1851 census count; presumably related to Blakiston’s da.-in-law, Annie, whose maiden name was Bally. is! He called at last, the other day, and
chose the time of day when every body is out driving, and left a card without a vestige of address on it! I shouldn’t even have known who owned the name on the card, having never heard him called anything else but “Charlie,” if it hadn’t been the notice in your last letter that he would call, and the Servants description of him, “a slim genteel young gentleman who had come to inquire how I was! I mightn’t have guessed the identity of “Mr Charles Bally” When you write tell me his address in case he can’t persuade himself to come again soon of his own accord
God Bless you Darling (It is you Bessey I am writing to this time) with a dozen kisses

div3.sourceNote:
JWC-Lady A [LLA], [ca. 12 Dec.]. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Pbd: Hansons, NE 535–36 and 537 inc. Dated approximately by the dinner with the Froudes “a few days ago,” 8 Dec. (see TC to JAC, 5 Dec.
) and by its similarity in tone and content to JWC to BB, [10 Dec.] . By 16 Dec., JWC lacked the energy to write long letters; see JWC to MR, 16 Dec.
div3.head: JWC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: It would not be true to say, that ever since I received your dear letter I had been too unwell to answer it; but at least this much is quite true, I have been all the while feeling too unwell to answer it as I wished; longly and pleasantly. and so, have delayed writing from day to day, hoping always the night would bring sleep—at last; and the morrow a consequent lightening of the inward Clouds!— Today, finally, I find myself at, not the beginning of my recovered sleep, but the end of my expectations of it,—for the present: which comes to, practically, much the same!— So here I am writing a consciously dull letter; trusting to your divining out of the dullness love enough to supply the place of wit.

So it is all certain! you will not come home to brighten the darkness of our winter!Lady Ashburton had decided to stay in Germany indefinitely; see TC to LLA, 7 Nov.
Very dark it looks to me in prospect! almost as if you had died; so little definiteness there is in my hopes of seeing you and kissing your dear face again! If you had only named as probable a time for your return! If your return were not postponed quite far away into the vague! Oh I do hate the vague! It has a natural affinity, in my Imagination, to all sorts of mischances, and miseries! We dined at the Froudes the other day, and met, amongst others
the MilmansRev. Henry Hart Milman (1791–1868; ODNB; see 30:282 30:biographical notes ), dean of St. Paul’s, poet, and historian; known to the Carlyles since at least 1840, although TC sent JBW a book of Milman’s poems as early as 1822 (see 2:155 TC to JBW, [9 Aug. 1822] ). His wife, m. 1824, was Mary Ann, b. Cockell (d. 1871). Possibly this dinner was the occasion of an anecdote reported to Milman’s son Arthur (1829–1913) by a “Miss Elliot” about a dinner at which she sat next to TC: “Carlyle began to grumble, looking across at Froude: ‘There is a man who tries to whitewash and excuse a tyrant. You cannot improve them and you cannot alter them by telling soft lies about them. They are cruel, wicked men, and God lets them gang their ain gait.’ My father. … called out: ‘Listen, Froude—listen: here is Mr. Carlyle denouncing you for making Henry VIII. a hero and a great king. Won’t you remind him of Frederick the Great?’ Carlyle looked in great dudgeon for about half a minute, and then burst out into a guffaw of laughter” (Arthur Milman, Henry Hart Milman, D.D. Dean of St. Paul’s. A Biographical Sketch [1900] 211). and the Brookfields,William and Jane Brookfield. and it seemed as if the only topic under Heaven they could find, one of them after another, to talk to me about was the probable length of your absence, and the reasons for it. I grew so cross, and so like to cry! all this questioning in a spirit of idle curiosity so jarred my own heart-soreness! what I should have liked would have been to vanish out of the midst of them in a clap of thunder, leaving a strong odour of brimstone— Ah you needn’t keep away to put an end to their talking! They will talk about you wherever you are, so long as you are in every way so superior to themselves!

But I do like to talk about you with Miss Bromley. She has a Sister’s love for you, and her love is worth having. If it were not that you have laid so many obligations on me, that it feels absurd to specify any one in particular, I might thank you with all my heart for that friend—the only one that comes near yourself in my regard; of all living women! Oh my Darling my Darling! How good and kind you have been to me from first to last! And I can do nothing for You but love you, with all my soul and all my strength!—as I do!

If you were here beside me, with your beautiful sympathetic eyes; I should have a rare lot of little troubles to tell you; all converging into one great trouble, a protracted fit of sleeplessness! How long I shall be able to hold out under the fatigues of these terribly restless nights, I can’t guess; only I know I am running down towards “immortal smash.”!Coterie speech; see 14:210 TC to TSS, 26 June 1842
.

Imagine the situation! You have heard, I think, of our troubles in long past years from neighbouring Cocks! How I had to rush about to one and another Householder, going down on my knees, and tearing my hair (figuratively speaking); to obtain the silence of these feathered Demons, that broke Mr C’s Sleep, with their least, croupy crow; when you might have fired a pistol at his ear without waking him! Thro’ efforts that I still shudder at the recollection of, the neighbouring gardens were quite cleared of Cocks; and Mr C forgetting all the woe they had wrought him has been free, latterly, to
devote his exclusive attention to—Railway whistles!! Bearing this in mind; be so good as imagine my sensations, one morning about a month ago, on being startled awake, before day-light, with the loud crowing of a full-grown Cock, from under my very bed (as it seemed in the bewilderment of the first moments)!— I sprang to the floor with my heart in my mouth, ran to my dressing closet window and looked out! but it was too dark to see anything; only the crowing, which continued like mad, sounded just underneath! I went back to bed, and lay with my heart thumping, till it was light enough to see; and then I reconoitred the ground; and just below Mr C’s bedroom window and my own, behold! an ill-conditioned Hen-House had been erected over night, and I counted nine hens and a Splendid Cock in quest of the early worm!!! If I had ever fainted in my Life, I must have fainted at that sight! I no longer felt in myself strength or Spirit to enter upon the old hand to hand battle with Cocks and Hens! I could have taken a good cry,Coterie speech; see 17:19 . in prospect of Mr C’s nervous terrors and rage when he should have discovered his little feathered neighbours! And me with such a sharp pain always at the bottom of my back, taking away the very breath of me at thought of presenting myself before the people at No 6, with “complaints of nuisance &c”—!

For a whole week I carried the bad secret in my own breast! Thanks to the prepossession of the Railway Whistles, Mr C never heard the crowing under his nose! But night after night I expected to hear his foot descend on the floor over head, with the old frantic stamp,—“preluding Much”! (as himself might say). Sleep, difficult for me in the best of circumstances, was in these circumstances simply impossible! And at the weeks end I had to take to bed with a sick headache— Now; nothing clears the brain so much as a good spell of sick headache; I find!— Accordingly I came out of this bout with a plan of operations in regard to the poultry, and a modest determination to “carry it out.” The result of which appeared next day in Golden Silence on the part of the Cock; and in raptures on the part of Mr C, who had discovered his Enemy the very day that he was delivered from him, when he “was just going off to Tyndall to beg him to supply him privately with some strychnine”!! a fine course that would have been! But now there was no poisoning needed! and so he clasped me in his arms, and assured me over and over that I was his “Guardian Angel!” Humph! It is no sinecure!

And one night, when doing a bit of amiability (that sort of thing never prospers for me!) I was run into by a mad cart! and my poor Bellona (the Black Mare), had her foot so bruised that till yesterday I had not driven her for—three weeks! Nothing goes always well with me but my flowers!Flowers were often sent with the regular hamper of produce from Addiscombe; see JWC to JC, 29 Dec.
When I have
arranged any particular vaseful to my mind I say “Oh if She could but see that”! When Miss Bromley was staying at that dingy HotelProbably Mrs. Vivian’s, where Bromley stayed, Nov. 1863, while her house at 32 Grosvenor St. was being painted; JWC mentioned then that Lady Ashburton had showered her with flowers while on she was on her sick bed; see 39:231 JWC to LAI, 2 Nov. [1863]
. Or possibly an unidentified hotel this winter when the house was also being repainted; JWC mentioned that Bromley “was in the Country till the new-paint smell should have gone out of her house”; see JWC to GW, 23 Jan. 1866
. I gave Her some! To think of my being able to give flowers to Miss Bromley!

I dont think I was ever more relieved in my life than when the theThus in MS. letter came—saying the wee DarlingLady Ashburton’s da., Mary Florence. was better. I had been in such a fright that I couldnt write to you! Miss Bromley sent me word the minute she had read the letter. Mine came some days later—
Mr C would send love if he werent asleep

div3.sourceNote: TC-DL, 13 Dec. MS: EUL. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO DAVID LAING

docBody.p: Inclosed is yr credential Note, as required.Laing wrote to TC, 13 [12] Dec.: “I did not mean to trouble you so soon with further letter-writing—but I have just received the notice of a Meeting of the University Court next Monday—accompanied with a note stating that ‘all appointments to the University Court are required to be in writing. It will be necessary for you … to send to me … a written appointment as Rector’s Assessor.’”

The importt busss this time, I observe, will be the appointt of the “Three Curators”;—but for the prest, I suppose, they will only be named or proposed, so that one will have an opportunity of voting on them, if needful, when the day comes? I am extremely in the dark as to forms of procedures, as to persons, circumstances & conditns, in this new element; & must depend on you for the needful light. The smallest contribution gratefully received! For example, do you preside instead of me; or who presides?Laing replied, 19 Dec.: “In your absence, the Principal, (as a matter of course), took the Chair, although the new Lord Provost looked as if he would willingly have done so. / Having now got a little insight into the business of the Univty Court, I may mention that the Rector is Chairman in virtue of his office and has both a deliberative and casting vote in case of equality.” He then mentioned some of the business of the meeting, including “the appointing of three Curators. … These Curators, with the Four from the Town Council have the important duty of exercising the patronage formerly vested in the Town Council in case of vacant Chairs.” By the Universities (Scotland) Act of 1858, the rector of Edinburgh Univ. was appointed president of the University Court. Sir David Brewster was the principal; William Chambers (1800–1883; ODNB; see 7:132 TC to JHLH, 18 April 1834
), publisher, was lord provost of Edinburgh 1865–69. &c&c&c

Our Secy mentions five heads of “business”: 1o Curators, 5o something abt “Music-Lectures”;The University Court was responsible for the patronage of seventeen academic chairs. Responsibility for appointments was assigned to seven curators, three of whom were nominated by the Court, and four of whom were nominated by Edinburgh town council. In addition, the curators had a share in the patronage of five other academic chairs: humanities, agriculture, civil law, law of Scotland, and conveyancing. The University Court also held the patronage of the chair of music. —on all the intermediate 3 questions I appoint you my absolute Proxy and Alter Ego; knowing nothing whatever abt them.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 13 Dec. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd. TC wrote the letter on the reverse of David Laing to TC, 13 [12] Dec.
div3.head:
TC
TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
Dear Brother,
—I am in the usual way;—imagined yesterday I was getting visibly better (weather being fine); but had, unexpectedly, an ugly troubling night,—owing I think to something at dinner. Superficially I seem to have been growing steadily worse (worse in spirits, in rheumatm, catarrhs, especially in nervous irritability); yet substantially I do rather believe that something of strength, purity of blood &cmay be slowly returning to me.

Monday last Blackie himself sent me the Courant The Edinburgh Evening Courant, 9 Dec., pbd. a letter from John Stuart Blackie on the subject of the univ. curriculum and the system of remuneration of professors; Blackie believed that the univ. was old-fashioned in its practices and needed to move with the times; see also TC to JSB, 13 Nov.
you had clipt from; his poor Note is here. Nothing else till, this morning, the Two officialities inclosed,—whh I have done for— I am reading (nearly done with it) Life of Genl Wm Napier (given me by Author); Life of General SirWilliam Napier
, ed. H. A. Bruce, 2 vols. (1864); see TC to JAC, 9 Jan. 1866
. Henry Austin Bruce (1815–95; ODNB), lawyer, liberal M.P. for Merthyr Tydfil, Glamorganshire, 1852–68; he and TC met in 1856, and through him Sir William Francis Patrick Napier (1785–1860; ODNB), army officer and writer, gave TC his History of Sir Charles Napier’s Administration of Scinde
(1854); see 31:67–68 TC to HAB, 12 April 1856
. Bruce was m. to Napier’s da. Nora (1827–97). and like it so well, I think of trying Peninsular WarW. F. P. Napier, History of the War in the Peninsula ... 1807–1814 (1828–40). next.— I am sorry Jim junr is on the causeway agn;“Jim” was their nephew James Aitken, who had been working in Liverpool, but was now apparently out of work (see TC to JCA, 16 Dec.
); presumably TC was speaking metaphorically, with Jim “on the causeway” looking for work. but it could not be helped.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 16 Dec. MS: NLS 531.5. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head:
TC
TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p:
Dear Jean,
—The Sun (or what we consider to be he, for the Sun Proper has not shewn himself all day) is in the act of sinking, and I ought to be half-way to Charing-Cross by this time: hardly one word for ansr to you, tho’ the monday Letters are always so welcome! I will at least return the poor WolverhamptonUnidentified correspondent; possibly connected to “Marion” mentioned in TC to JAC, 28 [27] Nov.
Letter lest it be lost.

We have no actual frost yet; but every day drawing nearer it; cold & colder days, often enough sunless; but dry, clearly wholesome days, very pensive to me in their quiet grey costumes. Jane still keeps on foot (i.e. on axle), tho’ sometimes threatening to fail. This morng I had the Dr’s Note; my thanks to him. For the last 3 days, almost with that exceptn only, no Letter,—a welcome thing agn! I am very quiet; perhaps—slowly, slowly,—making a leetle progress towards better health. But I don’t know;—nor indeed do I nearly so much care as I was wont. I do long for quiet; the incesst discordant noises of this Babylon grow more & more disgusting to me. If there ever turn up a House for sale in yr neighbd (with a hill betn it & railways), I shd be strongly tempted to buy! Really even at this late date.— If Jim have to visit London on inquiry &c,Jean’s son James Aitken, now looking for work. send him here to lodge.

signed.name: T. CarlyleTC may have met, 14 Dec., Adam White (1817–78; ODNB), naturalist, as White wrote, 29 Dec., from Edinburgh: “How I have to thank you for the few delightful minutes spent with you on Dec. 14. I thought, how much good a perfect rest would be to you amidst moors and hills & green lanes, for Lanes are green at this time of year with various mosses. I believe, the refreshing effect of the simple looking at the objects beneath your feet & getting some one, who knew a little about them, to interest you in these objects individually & as species, would be of the utmost advantage to your bodily health. … I am going to take the liberty of sending to you one of the books for young people, which I edited. ‘The Instructive Picture Book.’ The book is badly printed, it was sent to Wirtenburg for cheapness, & is printed & spelt at times in the queerest way. … Excuse my liberty in sending so simple a book to one so great as a writer. / But it may please you, after all, in so far as it is natural.” White worked in the Dept. of Natural History, British Museum, 1835–63. He pbd. The Instructive Picture Book (1857) with R. M. Stark; by 1877 it had reached a 10th edn.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [16 Dec.]. Addr: Holmhill / Thornhill / Dumfries N.B. PM: London, 16 Dec. 1865; Dumfries, 17 Dec. 1865; Thornhill, 18 Dec. 1865. MS: NLS 609.758. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p: I began a letter to you on this sheet of paper, last Tuesday— But was interrupted, and have never had a fair chance at writing a reasonably long letter since. In fact I have been very poorly, and had no heart in me to do battle with the smallest Lion in the way! It has been mere commonplace illness however—produced quite naturally by want of sleep, and the want of sleep was produced as naturally by worry! What the worry was produced by would take longer to tell than there is time for just now—nothing to do with JessyJessie Hiddleston. —all right in that direction— But I will tell you all about every thing, so soon as I can.

This is only an acknowledgement of the the JWC’s repetition. hamper that came yesterday when I was out driving—not a penny to pay for it!! I never understand how you manage that—for on all other packages that come there is always at least porterage from the Station to pay! Every thing inside in perfect condition not one egg cracked! How kind you are! and the Whisky! I was just near the end of the last of the bottles—I brought home with me.JWC left Holmhill for London, 24 July; see 42:148 JWC to TC, 25 July
. Nothing could come more opportunely!—
A thousand thanks—and kisses ad libitum

Two LadiesPossibly Caroline and Frances Macmillan; see JWC to MCR, 26 March
1866 ; otherwise unidentified. are sitting staring at me and the carriage awaiting me in the Street! J C
I will write in a day or two—

div3.sourceNote: TC-JR [JRU], 20 Dec. Pbd: W. G. Collingwood, Ruskin 2:51–52. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 6:40.
div3.head:
TC
TO JOHN RUSKIN

docBody.p:
Don’t mind the Bewick; the indefatigable Dixon has sent me, yesterday, the Bewick’s “Life”Thomas Bewick, A Memoir of Thomas Bewick, written by Himself
, ed. Jane Bewick, 2 vols. (Newcastle and London, 1862). as well (hunted it up from the “Misses Bewick”Jane Bewick and Isabella Bewick (1790–1883; ODNB) together preserved their father’s drawings and writings and supervised posthumous publications of his work. or somebody,
and threatens to involve me in still farther bother about nothing)—and I read the greater part of it last night before going to bed. Peace to Bewick: not a great man at all; but a very true of his sort, a well completed, and a very enviable,—living there in communion with the skies and woods and brooks, not here in do with the London Fogs, the roaring witchmongeries and railway yellings and howlings.

The “Ethics of the Dust,”John Ruskin, The Ethics of the Dust. Ten Lectures to Little Housewives on the Elements of Crystallisation (1866); pbd. in Dec., with the publication date of 1866. In the preface Ruskin explained that the work originated in a series of lectures delivered at a girls’ school. “The Lectures always fell more or less into the form of fragmentary answers to questions; and they are allowed to retain that form, as, on the whole, likely to be more interesting than the symmetries of a continuous treatise” (Ruskin, Ethics vii). whh I devoured witht pause, and intend to look at agn, is a most shining Performance! Not for a long while have I read anything tenth-part so radiant with talent, ingenuity, lambent fire (sheet—and other lightnings) of all commendable kinds! Never was such a lecture on Crystallography before, had there been nothing else in it,—and there are all manner of things. In power of expression I pronounce it to be supreme; never did anybody who had such things to explain explain them better. And the bit of Egyptn mythology, the cunning Dreams abt Pthah, Neith,The two Egyptian gods appear to Ruskin in a dream in “Lecture II. The Pyramid Builders” (Ruskin, Ethics 27–36); according to Ruskin, Pthah represents “the formative power of order and measurement” and is known as the Lord of truth (Ruskin, Ethics 237), while Neith is the “Egyptian spirit of divine wisdom” (Ruskin, Ethics 239). &c, apart from their elucidative quality, whh is exquisite, have in them a poetry that might fill any Tennyson with despair. You are very dramatic too; nothing wanting in the stage-directns, in the pretty little indicatns: a very pretty stage and dramatis personae altogethr.Ruskin’s book takes the form of a play, the dramatis personae consisting of an old lecturer, and 12 girls aged between 9 and 20. According to Collingwood: “The Real Little Housewives, to whom the book was dedicated, were not quite delighted … at the portraits drawn of them, in their pinafores … with some little hints at failings and faults which they recognised through the mask of dramatis personae” (W. G. Collingwood, Ruskin 2:52). Such is my first feeling abt yr Book, dear R.— Come soon, and I will tell you all the faults of it, if I gradually discover a great many.At the end of his preface, Ruskin wrote: “this poor little book will sufficiently have done its work … if it engages any of its young readers in study which may enable them to despise it for its shortcomings” (Ruskin, Ethics ix). In fact, come at any rate!Ruskin probably visited, Sat. 16 Dec., delivering TC’s copy of Ethics, as he wrote to JWC, Wed. [13 Dec.]: “Indeed it is long—but I have just done a little bit of work which needed me to keep quietly at it; and I was ill in the middle of it which threw all back. / And I thought Mr Carlyle would have enough to do, & be bothered—and now it is all right, and I hope to bring him my bit of a book on Saturday, if I may come. / Don’t write if I may, only if I mayn’t.”

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 21 Dec. MS: NLS 526.36. Pbd: Froude, Carlyle 4:298 inc. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 6:40.
div3.head:
TC
TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
My dear Brother,
—Here is a very harmless Letter whh (with a Newspaper alluded to) has just come from Laing: you may read it, and then add it to the other bag of Rectorial Nothings. I forward the “Newspr” also, whh is one I had never heard of before.David Laing wrote, 19 Dec., with a report of the meeting of the University Court, 18 Dec.; see TC to DL, 13 Dec.
Among matters dealt with was “An Appeal by Medical Students against a decision of the Senatus, complaining of not enjoying like other Students, the full Christmas holidays. The conclusion we came to, you will see in the Newspaper sent with this”; the newspaper is unidentified. This Rectorial Office is beginning to promise being a highly pacific one; and has already shifted itself to a corner of the mind where I seldom remember it, and never almost with anything of anxiety or displeasure. When the time for speeching approaches, I shall have to bethink me a little, & be bothered & tumbled abt for a week or so; but that done, I hope, essentially all will be done.— The Lothians, Marquis & Marchness, I understand to be in Town this day (and am to call at the Shrewsbury House,Shrewsbury House, 36 Belgrave Sq., London home of Lady Lothian’s parents, earl and countess of Shrewsbury. just opposite the Buccleugh one, in Belgrave Square,The duke of Buccleuch’s London home was 37 Belgrave Sq., a detached house at the E corner of the square, while Shrewsbury House was at the end of the SE terrace. Walter Francis Montagu-Douglas-Scott (1806–84; ODNB), 5th duke of Buccleuch, was Lord Lothian’s brother’s father-in-law. as I go up today!) “To see Doctors,” it wd appear.See also JWC to HI, [ca. 3 March 1866] . Alas, what a journey! The Lady writes to us, soliciting an Evg visit,—whh of course will have to be; all the more as it is very easy, and not to be called disagreeable at all.

I have been reading a strange little Xmas Book of Ruskin’s called The Ethics of the Dust: it is all abt Chrystallography; and seems to be, or is, geologically well-informed & correct; but it twists symbollically, in the strangest way, all its Geology into Morality, Theology, Egyptian Mythology (with fiery cuts at Political Economy &c!)—pretending not to know whether the forces & destinies & behaviours of Crystals are not very like those of Men! Wonderful to behold. Apart from this sad weakness of backbone, the Book is full of admirable talent; with such a faculty of expression in it (or of picturing out what is meant) as beats all living rivals. If you wd like to read it, let me hear by & by.
Jane’s mare is brisk agn;Bellona had been injured almost a month before; see TC to JAC, 29 Nov.
—has just rolled away with her since I began. The shortest day of the Year, and a temperature like that of Septr! Are you thinking of Londn at all?— My blessing to everybody.
