signed.name: T.C.Lady Ashburton’s friend, Lady Marian Alford (1817–88; ODNB), Viscountess Alford, wrote, 20 Dec., thanking TC for some family information about the Comptons (her father was Spencer Joshua Alwynne Compton [1790–1851; ODNB], 2d marquess of Northampton).

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JR [DRJR], [22 Dec.]. Addr: Holmhill / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire / NB. PM: London, 22 Dec. 1865. MS: NLS 609.759. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO DR. JAMES RUSSELL

docBody.p: It was very kind of your Wife to bid you write to me—and—so far as my observation of Husbands goes—it was superhumanly kind of you to do her bidding!—and if it bothered you, you have this comfort; to know that whatever advice you give me is always conscientiously and gratefully attended to. I think that on the whole I am a good Patient; certainly I am a good Patient to you; for I never doubt the correctness of your views; and I follow your prescriptions to the letterFor JWC’s appreciation of Dr. Russell’s prescriptions during her stay at Holmhill, July–Sept. 1864, see 40:149 JWC to TC, [25 July 1864] , to 41:60 JWC to MR, [3 Oct. 1864] .—in spite of all traditional or femenineThus in MS. fancies!

Accordingly within an hour your Prescription was sent to be made upPresumably to Charles Rowett Quiller, pharmacist, 15 Sloane Sq.— But I judged it wise, and also conformable to your advice to preface the Tonic with a doze of Castor oil! And it is in the valley of the ShadowCoterie speech; cf. Ps. 23:4. of this most abominable Thing that I am here writing—our General Post leaves at half past four; the carriage comes to take me for my Drive at one— Half the hours till then have gone in being helplessly sick! and the rest must be given to finishing the packing up of some Books &cthat were meant to reach you on Xmas.
So I write just two lines to promise again a deliberate letter—thanking you most cordially in the mean time for that “clap on ma heed.”

How Mrs Russell came to know I was poorly, I wonder! for, I only said that I was off my sleep—and that I knew why—at least that is my impression of what I said! I think she must, like Mrs Blackiston, have a “Blue Bird”Cf. “L’oiseau bleu” from Madame d’Aulnoy, Les Contes de Fées (Paris, 1697). who whispers to her things hidden or future. She, her Husband wrote, had been
wanting to be off on two several days to look at me, being sure from a presentiment that I was ill— I hadnt written to her at all—nor had my silence been unusually long.

closer.salute: God bless you both / Affectionately yours

postscript.p: Expect a decent letter presently

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 25 Dec. MS: NLS 518.19. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p:
Yesterday (Sunday, the better day the better deed!)See Thomas Middleton, Michaelmas Term (1604) 3.1. abt noon a wagon stopt at this door, and handed me in the Dumfries Parcel, all in order and perfectly safe: carriage 2s 8d + 6d= 3s 2d;—whh paid, the interior was with all rapidity laid bare. Excellt throughout; and worth many acknowledgts! I really feel quite ashamed of the endless trouble you take with me; who am so little worthy of it, all things considered. The Cape is quite superlative; worth both the others at their best; cloth so feel and soft; will be full of warmth too (especially in a carriage), and will be well worth its little superiority of weight, in comparison to the great do of heat for the walker on a frosty day. The only imaginable fault it has is to be remedied tomorrow; that of the two pockets on the outside (tomorrow they shall go to the inside, and then be of some use,—for holding a pocket handkf, a ’bacco-box &chandy!)—whh I wd not have mentioned at all, except for the Dfrs Tailor’sProbably William Boyd (1811–90), master tailor at Cummertrees; see 42:53 TC to JWC, 31 May
. sake, whom it wd be charity to advise Never in any sane man’s case to put a pair of pockets outside a Cape, where of all places they are the least attainable, the unsafest and the most useless! Tailor herePossibly John and George Sampson, tailors and drapers, 2 Princes St., Leicester Sq.; see 42:109 TC to JWC, 5 July
. shall slit off these cloth-plates, & sewing them on directly oppose, make inside pouches & all right. This Cape, I calculate, will keep me warm as long as I live. Many thanks to the kind Sister that sends it.

Jane is very glad to see herself so stored with whiskey for a long time. Two points only: 1o You must tell me what the price of that was; 2o What you exactly mean by “unta’en-down,”“Unta’en-doon,” “untaken down,” undiluted. i.e. whether there is any water to be added (and if so how much!) before drinking?— The bosom-friend is to have a small button added at the right point, & to go on this very night: I am wearing an old hareskin of yr making, whh fairly ought to be relieved.A hare-skin chest covering; see TC to JAC, 23 Nov.
— Jane is to have the
Cap; and give it away (the cheat!) as her own work. The DoctorTheir brother John A. Carlyle. was right abt it; all the more as I have another of the same type (only ½ an inch deeper, and rather roundish at the corner), whh I have already worn sometimes. And so, once more, thanks many; and may never waur be among us,Proverb; see 15:178 TC to AC, 13 Nov. 1842
. dear Sister!

I am sorry to hear yr account of the Dr’s last ways of health,—tho’ as I judge it will be but temporary, there is for the time no such torment known to me as that of undue sensibility to sound. Cannot you push him off hither for a change? We are as quiet as possible at this season; & there shall be 3 curtns for his room whenr I hear of him.— Nothing from Edinr, tell him; only the inclosed scrap, whh is accurately zero to me. I have in good part ceased thinking abt Edinr (Intolerable paper; whh I have tried with 3 pens,—all alike futile!) We are to dine at Forster’s today; nothing of a party,—Fr himself recovering from gout! You may examine those anonyms Papers; and see whether they are not by yr little Schoolmaster Nisbet:Unidentified further; see also TC to JAC, 1 Jan. 1866
. —I think they had Kinross for Postmark. My scandalous materials, were there nothing more invite me to finish.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JC Jr. [JACA], 25 Dec. MS: NLS Acc. 7988. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head:
TC
TO JAMES CARLYLE JR.

docBody.p:
I approve all you have done at Craigenputtock; and am glad to know you so alert and decisive in tying up the disorderly lumber into some kind of coherence there, and sweeping the slutteries away. Go on with the woods;James Carlyle Jr. wrote, 23 Dec.: “It is now necessary that I should report progress at Craigenputtock. On the 24th Novr last I sold a portion of the wood on the Estate which brought two hundred and eighty five £s Sterling. This sum has been deposited at interest with the Royal Bank of Scotland at Ecclefechan in the meantime; and when the days grow longer and the weather more suitable I purpose commencing operations of draining the plantation from which the wood has been cut, rebuilding the fences and other necessary work towards the replanting of the ground which cannot be done before the early part of 1868, as an insect which is bred in the old roots would attack the plants if put into the ground within two years from the time of its being cleared of the old wood.” I trust entirely to yr insight into the matter; I have myself no real judgt in the matter; but you know well enough what my ideas and intention were. It is a comfort to me to get those abominable slidders of broken dikes (round stone walls gone all to that state) out of my head agn; whh have lain there too as a kind of pollution, ever since I saw them last autumn! Of the Road also I am very
glad;—and the terms seem abundtly economic. An effectual running ditch on the north side will be quite a saving clause to whatever repairs: 30 cubic yds of broken whinstone in the worst places, & some coating of the till—gravel whh is in every hillock close by; this I can fancy to myself as a really fairish road,—and an immense improvt over what we saw!James Carlyle Jr. continued, 23 Dec.: “On Thursday last I had a meeting, at Craigenputtock, with the Road Surveyor for Kirkcudbright and we have arranged to expend a sum of £10 upon the piece of road from Castramon to the turn for Craigenputtock. A drain will be made on the south side of the road throughout its entire length and fifty cubic yards of broken stones will be put upon it. I have agreed, on your part, to pay for breaking thirty yards of these stones and Mr Common will lend his horses to cart them. In the coming summer, if it is your wish to have the road made an entirely superior one, when a further sum will be set aside for it by the Road Trustees,—I could have it pared on the sides and rounded up on the middle with gravel by making a small addition to the allowance of the Trustees. The cost of breaking the thirty yards of Stones will be something under £3.” TC wrote on James Carlyle Jr.’s envelope: “Craigenpk Woods (£285), & Road (24 Decr 1865).” “All right,”Coterie speech. therefore; that is all I will say to you at prest.

We are in our usual way here; rather better hitherto, if anything. We have the finest Xmas weather ever seen; no frost, no rain, fine sharp dry weather,—tho’ no doubt things will alter before long. The “Cattle Pest”An outbreak of rinderpest, cattle plague, was traced to a shipment of oxen and sheep that had arrived in Britain, 29 May, from eastern Europe; it spread throughout the country, and was not eradicated until Sept. 1867. A royal commission, appointed late Sept., published its first report 31 Oct. The commission called for strict regulations for the movement of cattle and the slaughter of diseased animals, although this was not implemented till Feb. 1866. John A. Carlyle wrote to James Carlyle Jr., 9 Dec.: “You will see that the Times &chas begun to agitate for government compensation in regard to the Rinderpest, & I think it will come to that ere long if the disease continues to spread” (MS: NLS Acc. 9086). seems to be a great botheratn with you, as with us (in another form) & everywhere else. Not the least thing known of it, or how to help it; & stupid justices sitting everywhere, tormenting the poor people who have charge! “See that yr cattle are kept comfortable, and so in the best state of general health
you can”: this is pretty much all that human wisdom can do, as I imagine. The poor beasts well fed, well aired, accurately clean (I sometimes think I wd curry-comb them all, like horses, for they are equally fond of it, & the skin is a very fountn of health or disease),—in this state they will clearly be ablest to front whatr is coming on them, Pest or otherwise!— — My best love to yr Father & JohnJames Carlyle Jr.’s brother.—

div3.sourceNote: TC-WA, 25 Dec. MS: NLS 3823.131. Pbd: H. Allingham and E. Williams, eds. Letters to William Allingham (1911) 136–38. William Allingham (1824–89; ODNB), Irish poet; he worked in the Customs Service 1846–70, currently at Lymington, Hampshire; friendly with TC since the early 1850s.
div3.head: TC TO WILLIAM ALLINGHAM

docBody.p:
I will stand to whatever I may have said abt the Ballyshannon Almanac; I thot, and think, the Introductn there shewed a very pretty talent, and remarkable diligence in investigating,—to whh add patience, sagacity, sobriety in ditto, and you have the basis of all talent for History.Allingham wrote to TC, 17 Dec., referring to TC’s letter of appreciation of his introduction to the Ballyshannon Almanac (Dublin, 1862); see 38:66–67 TC to WA, 3 March 1862
. He wrote: “I was very glad to hear a good account of you, and of Mrs Carlyle also, from Woolner. He came over here to me for a day … & [we] talked incessantly. / In the talk came up a scheme or dream of mine, how if I could get away from the Customs’ service after 20 years employment, with some small annual sum, I would wish to apply myself to a careful study of Irish affairs, examining libraries records & places with this view, & in the hope of doing something useful.” I did then expect from you in course of time something quite superior on the History of Ireland; but you pulled up yr tether agn, took to shifting abt agn; & I suppose there is nothing done.Allingham continued: “I did (as you well know) a foolish thing in resigning my place in the Customs once on a time, and again did an injudicious or unlucky thing in exchanging to London.” You have no idea how much a man loses by tumbling up his locatn, and getting into a totally new environment of his commonplace conditns of existence, time after time.

What chance you may have to get this increase of Pension &c&c(in short, this total abolition of “tether”!)Allingham continued: “My total income, including the recent literary pension of £60, is about £150 a year; & what is sought is that I might be set free at the end of 20 years’ service with this sum in all, or something not very much less; with a reasonable expectation of my proving worth more to the country in the next 20 years as student of Irish history than as Coast Officer.” Allingham was awarded a pension of £60, 1864, for his contributions to poetry and literature, but his application for an increase was denied. I do not know at all: but I must candidly tell you I have great doubts whether it wd do you anything but mischief,—whether you are not even now better situated for working out some History of Ireland than you cd anywhere else be, for the next ten or twenty years! You will not the least believe me; but, before you have spent that length of time, perhaps you will! I know nothing you can get by “searching Libraries,” one reads Books nowhere except in silent seclusion at home, and Books can always be bought by one in yr circumstances. The great thing requisite (and that is inexorably so) will be to meditate in yr own unwearied thot, month after month & year after year, the riddles, obscurities & contradictns whh
Books offer, and never rest till you have overcome them.Allingham replied, 27 Jan. 1866: “Best thanks for your kind & welcome letter, & also for the advice—good & excellent in itself, yet not (really not!) applicable in my precise case. ‘Sense of permanence’ I long for & have longed for. It is just what I cannot have as Officer of Customs. … You only know of my voluntary moves. I have been moved in Bank and Customs service, involuntarily & often against my will, over & over & over again. … Besides, the business tho’ trivial is incessant. … I doubt if you can fully conceive the impossibility (to me at least) of applying oneself in such circumstances to continuous literary work.” By far the richest “Irish Library” (Froude has taught us) is the State-Paper Office here:Froude’s History of England (1856–70) quoted extensively from documents in the State Paper Office, for its chapters on Irish history as much as English. much nearer you at prest than when you have gone a-roving, with yr tether annihilated!—— In short, my dear Allm, if the Officials altogether refuse you, I shall be sorry for yr disappointed humour; but I shall think the chance of an Irish History (whh you cd indeed do better than anybody, if the Devil didn’t hinder) is improved for us thereby!—

By all means come & see us when you are here on holiday.Allingham ended his letter of 17 Dec.: “If in London for two days at Christmas, I hope to call at your house”; but, 27 Jan., he wrote: “I did not visit London at Christmas.”
(In great haste, with paper and pen extremely detestable)

postscript.p: I commissioned Woolner to write to you; but have found yr Letter agn, & do it myself

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, 25 Dec. Addr: Holmhill / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 26 Dec. 1865. MS: NLS 609.760A. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:297–304 inc. Quot: Ireland, JWC 298; Wilson, Carlyle 6:40; Bliss, JWC 326–27; Ashton 440–41. TC later wrote: “Nothing nobler was ever done to me in my life than the unseen nobleness recorded in this letter. When I look out on that garden, all so trim and quiet now (old rubbish tenants gone for ever), and think what she looked out on, and resolved to do—oh, these are facts that go beyond words! Praise to thee, darling! praise in my heart at least, so long as I continue to exist.— T.C.” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:297).
div3.head:
JWC
TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p:
Dearest Mary!
I was unwilling to leave your Husband’s letter unanswered for a single day; or I wouldn’t have chosen Friday morning for writing to him, when I was busy packing your box, and had besides to write a business letter to the Haddington Lawyer,“About some trifle of legacy from poor ‘Jackie Welsh,’ I think (supra)” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:298); John Richardson (ca. 1800–67) and his son Robert Richardson (1836–70), Writers to the Signet; see JWC to BB, 27 Oct.
and to give a lesson in syllables of two letters to
a small Boy!!“Part of her task with those new neighbours and their noises and paltrinesses. Good Heaven!” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:298).—all before one o’clock, when I should go for my drive! After my return between four and five there is no time to catch the General Post, which closes for Chelsea at half past four. So having so much to do in haste, I could only do it all badly. For example the explanatory list which should have been put in the box was forgotten, also the buttons of the Garibaldi.Blouse or tunic modeled after the red shirt of the Italian patriot, Giuseppe Garibaldi (1807–82).— If, as the Clerk at the Railway office told me, the parcel would reach you the very next morning (I dont believe him) you would wonder having a half-worn Garibaldi,—pieced in the sleeves, offered for your acceptance! The meaning thereof was two-fold;—first to prevent the things in the box from being shaken about—second to furnish you with what I have several times heard you expressing a wish for, the pattern
of a Garibaldi! You might wear
this of mine, if you thought it still worth wearing; but—it was not sent you to wear, only for the modest reasons I have said. Thus much in extenuation!

The buttons I will inclose in case. The little trays don’t need any apology; for they are real Japanese and I flatter myself you will like them. There is also a Japanese Fire-screen in shape of a fan. If I didn’t tell you the use, you might fancy you were expected to use it as a fan, which would be hard on you; it is so heavy! The other two pairs of fire screens are light enough,—also from Japan,—and of no value, only curious! If you think one pair of them worth taking in your hand to Mrs EwartAlicia Ewart. please do! There are two books for her. I think I wrote her name on them outside. I am sure I wrote the Dr’s name on the largest Book. Then you may be perplexed by the four pieces of cork! my Dear! Mr Carlyle has admirers of all sorts of trades; and one of them, a very ardent admirer indeed, is, by trade a Cork-cutter,Thomas Dixon; see TC to TDI, 4 Dec.
and he sent me, as a tribute of admiration, a box containing some dozens of bottle corks large and small, and half a dozen pairs of cork soles, to put into my shoes, when shaped with a sharp knife! It is not many or any chances that I have to wet my feet; so there is small generosity in bestowing two pairs on you or the Dr!

I hope you read that Tale going on in the Fortnightly—The Belton Estate (by Anthony Trollope).Trollope’s novel, The Belton Estate (1866), was being pbd. in installments in the Fortnightly Review, a new literary magazine, 15 May 1865 to 1 Jan. 1866. It is charming, like all he writes, I quite weary for the next number—for the sake of that one thing; the rest is wonderfully stupid.

When I wrote to the Dr, “my Interior” (as Mr C would say) was in wild agitation! from a doze of Castor-oil, which I had taken, rightly or wrongly, to allay certain pains—not severe—but annoying—and reminding me of the
Inflamatory attack I had last winter.— Nevertheless, I took my daily three hours drive, and some tea after, and put on my black velvet gown and went to “Lady Williams”“Lady William Russell, who much liked and admired her” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:299). eight o’clock dinner!! I hadn’t dined with Her for some three weeks—so I must be getting better when I could muster spirit for such a thing! Rolled up in fur, and both windows up, and warm water to my feet, I caught no cold, and it is always pleasant there! And I always sleep well after! I met the man who is said to have made the Crimean War—Lord Stratford de RedcliffeStratford Canning (1786–1880; ODNB), Viscount Stratford de Redcliffe, diplomat, British ambassador in Constantinople at the outbreak of the Crimean War, Oct. 1853.—and found him a most just looking, courteous, agreeable white headed old Gentleman!
When I told you I had been off my sleep; I told you did I not that I had been worried, off it? Better when one can put one’s finger on the cause of one’s sleeplessness!

The cause this time—or rather the causes—were first a bilious fit on the part of Mr Carlyle! who was for some days “neither to hold nor to bind,”Cf. 30:208 JWC’s Journal, 31 Oct. 1855
. a condition of things which keeps my heart jumping into my mouth when it should be composing itself to rest! Then it happened that in these nervous days I had Agnes Veitch, my old Haddington playmate (Mrs Grahame)Agnes Graham, b. Veitch. coming to dinner! and seeing that he had made up his mind to find her dreadfully in his way; I ordered my Brougham at eight oclock, to take her home to St John’s wood;About 5 mi. (8 km.) NW of Chelsea. and that she mightn’t think it was sending her off too early I went along with her, to give her another hour of my company! Prettily imagined you will allow! Having deposited her safely at her own door, I was on my way back, crossing Oxford Street, when I saw a mad or drunk cart, bearing down upon me, at a furious rate and swerving from side to side, so that there was no escaping! My old CoachmanJohn Silvester. is a most cautious as well as skillful Driver! but this was too much! I shut my eyes and crossed my arms tight, and awaited the Collision! Instead of, as I expected, running into the carriage, the Wild Thing ran into the Black Mare! threw her round with a jerk that broke part of her harness, and then rushed on! Men gathered round, and Silvester descended from his box, to knot up the broken straps my beautiful Bellona (so named, for her imputed warlike dispositions) standing the while as quiet as a lamb! Then we went on our way again, thanking God it was no worse. But it was found on reaching the Stables that poor Bellona had got her foot badly hurt! the mad wheel seemed to have bruised it and snipped out a piece of
skin. She was not at all lame and was quite willing to go out with me next day; but the next again, her leg was much swelled, and for more than a fortnight she had to be attended by the Vetrinary Surgeon,Unidentified further. who forbid her going out, and said if the bruise had been an inch nearer the hoof, she would have been a ruined Bellona!— also he said “a more sweet natured horse he had never handled.” After much poulticing, the inward suppuration came outward—and she is now all right, being of an admirable constitution this one! never, even thro’ the poulticing time loosing her excellent appetite and excellent spirits. But it was worrying to not know when she could be taken out—and meanwhile to be putting Mr C to the cost of a livery-horse as well!TC recorded in his checkbook: “2 Decr 1865 to Silvester (Horse &clame) £9 .. 18 .. 2” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). But the grand worry of all—that which perfected my sleeplessness, was an importation of nine hens and a magnificent Cock (!!!) into the adjoining garden! For years back there had reigned over all these Gardens a heavenly quiet! thanks to my heroic exertions in exterminating nuisances of every description! But I no longer felt the hope or the energy in me requisite for such achievements! Figure then my horror, my despair, on being waked one dark morning with the crowing of a Cock—that seemed to issue from under my bed! I leapt up, and rushed to my dressing room window; but it was still all darkness! I lay with my heart in my mouth, listening to the Cock, crowing hoarsely from time to time, and listening for Mr C’s foot stamping frantically, as of old, on the floor above!— But strangely enough, He gave no sign of having heard his Enemy!—his whole attentions, having been, ever since his visit to Mrs Aitkens, morbidly devoted to—Railway whistles!TC suffered from the noise of railway whistles “at all hours & subject to no rule” while staying with Jean Aitken in Dumfries, 22–31 May 1865; see 42:62 TC to JWC, 5 June 1865
.

So soon as it was daylight I looked out again, and there was a sight to see!—a ragged irish looking hen-house, run up over night; and, sauntering to and fro, nine godly hens, and a stunning Cock!— I didn’t know whether Mr C remained really deaf as well as well asThus in MS. blind to the new neighbours; or whether he was only magnanimously resolved to observe silence about them; but it is a fact, that for a whole week he said no word to enlighten me—while I expected and expected the crisis which would surely come! and shuddered at every Cock-Crow, and counted the number of times he crowed in a night! at two! at three! at four! at five! at six! oh terribly at seven!— For a whole week I bore my hideous secret in my breast! and slept none to speak of! At the weeks end I fell into one of my old sick headaches. I used always to find a sick headache had a fine effect in clearing the wits! So, even this time, I rose from a day’s
agony with a scheme of operation in my head, and a sense of ability to “carry it out”! It would be too long to go into details, enough to say, my negociations with “Next door” ended in an agreement that the Cock should be shut up in a cellar inside the owner’s own house—from three in the afternoon till ten in the morning! and in return I give the small boy of the house a lesson every morning in his Reading made Easy!! The small Boy being “too excitable” for being sent to school!— It is a house full of Misteries No 6! I have thoughts of writing a novel about it. Meanwhile Mr C declares me to be his “Guardian Angel”!— No sinecure I can tell him!
So I might fall to sleeping again—if I could! But I couldn’t all at once! Getting back to even that much sleep I had been having must be gradual—like the building of Rome!

Jessy is going on quite well since I decided to take the upper hand with her and keep it! I don’t think Mrs Warren likes her any better; but I ask no questions. Best “let sleeping dogs lie”! She (Jessy) is much more attentive to me, since I showed myself quite indifferent to her attentions, and particular only as to the performance of her work. She is even kindly and sensitive with me occasionally. But she can’t come over me ever again with that dodge! She let me see too clearly into her hard, vain nature that I should place reliance or affection on her again! I do not regret having taken her—not at all! As a Servant she is better than the average, as a woman I do not think ill of her; but I mistook her entirely at the first. and see less good in her than perhaps there is, because I began by seeing far more good in her than she had the least pretention to! At my age and with my experience, it would have well beseemed me to be less romantic! I have paid for it in the disappointment of the heartfelt hopes I had invested in my hereditary Housemaid!Jessie’s mother, Margaret Hiddleston, had been housemaid to JWC’s mother, Grace Welsh, and her grandfather had been a servant to JWC’s maternal grandfather, Walter Welsh; see 42:21 JWC to JHI, 15 May [1865]
.
Good by Dear /

div3.sourceNote: JWC-CS [CSO], 26 Dec. PM: 27 Dec. 1865. MS: Chelsea Public Lib. Pbd: Blunt, “CLC” 419–20.
div3.head:
JWC
TO CHARLOTTE SOUTHAM

docBody.p: I have been literally drowned in letters, for some weeks back; and off my sleep at the same time, which makes my head not worth twopence for writing with.

This—and not neglectfulness of you, has been the reason I did not thank you sooner for that other and better photograph of yourself. Even this one does you no justice—at least does you no justice when you are good
. But—I have seen you sufficiently like it when the Devil had got into you, and spread a sort of cloud of sullenness over your naturally kind and intelligent look! Oh yes! When I first knew you, and for long after, you were the nicest, brightest looking creature, one could wish to see!— Pity one can’t keep always young!—
I am not well, ever, but I have not been positively ill this long time.

Except one day that I was in bed with sick headache, I have been out in my Brougham from three to four hours every day of my life since I returned from Scotland!! and I go out to dinner occasionally even in this winter weather!

Poor Mr BarlowPresumably Rev. John Barlow (ca. 1799–1869), clergyman and scientist, who sent Charlotte Southam a valentine card, 14 Feb. 1860; see 36:70–71 JWC to WDJD, 15 Feb. 1860
, and 276 36:biographical notes . hangs on to Life, as helpless and patient as ever— All the other people who came about in your time still come about—little changed except in the colour of their hair.

Mr C is much in his usual health—taking his fill of idleness,—if reading all day long can be called idleness! He will have to go to Edinr to make a Speech the last week of March—if the weather keeps favourable and my health ditto, I shall perhaps accompany him.

Mrs Warren continues to be a great comfort to me; and I brought with me from Dumfriesshire, a capital housemaid—whose Mother and Grandfather were servants to my Mother and Grandfather—so the House goes on without any bother to me, and at no greater expense than when I did half the work myself, and had to teach the other half! But with all her cleverness, and nice looks, I have none of the love for Jessy I had for you! No servant has ever been for me the sort of adopted Child that you were!
I send you a Book for a Xmas present— I haven’t seen your MotherElizabeth Southam, who lived nearby. for long. I never go out on foot in the cold!

div3.sourceNote: JWC-BB, 28 and 30 Dec. MS: NLS 609.757. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NLM 2:341–44 inc.
div3.head:
JWC
TO BETTY BRAID

docBody.p:
I have been looking forward to writing you a nice long comfortable letter for your newyears day! How many of them have we seen together on this Earth, you and I?— Glad Newyears days! and sad Newyears days!—oh so
very sad some that we have seen! But the wonder to me is, that for all the sufferings I have gone thro’, of one sort and another, I am still in the upper light; with my heart unchanged in its old affections—especially its affection for you my “Haddington Betty”!

But I was beginning to say, that I would not put off my letter to you, until the post before Newyears day—in case the last day should find me unable to sit up! I am taking (what my little cousinsProbably JWC’s Liverpool cousins, children of her maternal uncle, John Welsh; otherwise unidentified. used to call) “a heavy cold.” I don’t know when I caught it, nor how; it has been hanging about me, making me feel all nohow for days back. Tonight my throat is sore, and I am sick; and shall most likely be “worse before I am better”!— Don’t be uneasy about me! Colds are not the formidable things for me that they used to be; when I couldn’t cough a dozen times together, without my dear Mother setting me down for far gone in Consumption! The only inference to be drawn from my present discomfort is, that nothing that can be done today should be put off till tomorrow!

One shouldn’t however talk lightly of consumption in our family! Oh is it not sad? the last surviving Welsh whom one looked to for continuing my Fathers name and blood, is going the way of all my Uncle Robert’s family!JWC’s cousin Robert Welsh, son of her paternal uncle Robert Welsh; see 39:75 JWC to GWE, [2 March 1863] . He returned from his last voyage, coughing, emaciated,—with all the symptoms of the Disease that carried off his four Sisters!Elizabeth, Sarah, Annabella, and Grace Welsh; the latter three died of pulmonary consumption. He was in a lodging at Liverpool when my AuntsJWC’s paternal aunts, Ann, Elizabeth, and Grace Welsh, living in Edinburgh. wrote to me about him. His mother “Mrs Robert”Mary Welsh. is very deaf—and does not see well, and said—“if she went to him, she would be no help”—! All her life that woman could take things so coolly!— Fancy yourself in her place!— I think if You had been stone-deaf, and stone-blind you wouldn’t have kept away from George;Betty’s son, George, who d. Feb. 1865. had you known of him dangerously ill—in a lodging—at no greater distance than from Hull to Liverpool!— His SisterMary May Craven, wife of Dr. Robert Martin Craven, a doctor in Hull; see 34:46 JWC to TC, 15 July 1858
; presumably her mother now lived with them. Hull is 127 mi. (205 km.) E of Liverpool. too! the only one surviving out of six! married to a flourishing Dr at Hull, wrote to my Aunt Anne, in a letter which I saw, that they “did not press him to come to Hull—because he would just have had to stay in a Lodging there, the same as in Liverpool! and would be just as comfortable with his Liverpool Landlady as beside them!” “them” being his own Mother and own Sister!— I am very sorry about the poor young man, altho’ I never saw him
with my eyes. But I have heard of him from John Welsh (George’s son)John Welsh, son of JWC’s paternal uncle George Welsh. who died, and whose opinion was to be relied on; as being more like my Uncle Robert than any of the others, and a most upright, industrious, creature, who was very little cared for by the rest—because he was less pretentious—

I had a visit lately from Agnes Veitch of Hawthorn Bank—(Mrs Thomas Grahame) She is such a queer, little, old, white haired, fairy-grown! but as fond of me as when we were play fellows at home! I felt ashamed of myself that I couldn’t feel so glad over her as she seemed to be over me! I felt to have gone so far, far away from her! into spheres of thought and action so different from the narrow monotonous sphere in which she had lived, and turned grey! But I tried to not show that she rather wearied me! that at least I owed to her long regard. By way of being very kind indeed, I took her home, to a distant part of the Town, after dark, in my Brougham, the day she dined here; and this act of amicability cost me no end of vexation; For; on my way home, after having deposited her safe; a drunk or mad cart drove against my beautiful Black Mare, and burst her harness and bruised her foot, so that she was in the hands of the Vetrinary Surgeon for three weeks and couldn’t be put to any use.

Mr Carlyle has settled to go to Edinr, to deliver that “Address” expected of him, in the last week of March— If the weather happened to be remarkably mild, and if I happened to be remarkably well, I should like to go with him, and possibly may! Tho’ my Aunts have given me no invitation, I should be at no loss for good quarters to stay at, and the warmest welcome! But of all the invitations we have we are likely, and have indeed engaged to accept the one that came first—from the Marchioness of Lothian at Newbattle Abbey— They are nice people—and live very quietly—the poor young Marquis being paralized in his lower limbs. They are in London now, consulting Drs

I had to stop in the last sheet; I was so sick! it is two days since then, and meanwhile my cold has reached its climax, and I expect to be in what poor Jackie Welsh used to call my “frail ordinar,”Coterie speech; see 36:18 JWC to LAI, [28 November or 5 December 1859
. before the new year set in.
I beg to be your “first foot” in the shape of a post office order for a Sovereign. Ah my Dear if I could but give you a kiss along with it— Kind regards to your husbandAlexander Braid.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JC [JOCO], 29 Dec. Addr: Melchet Park / Romsey / Hants. PM: London, 29 Dec. 1865. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd. Joseph Cross (b. ca. 1830) was Lady Ashburton’s head gardener.
div3.head:
JWC
TO JOSEPH CROSS

docBody.p:
I am sure Mr Cross you will think me lost to a sense of my own interest when you find the purport of this note is to prohibit the hamper!Joseph Cross previously sent hampers of farm produce from the Ashburton farm at Addiscombe; see 40:75 JWC to JOCO, [9] 11 Sept. [1865]
. He was apparently now at Melchet Court, Hampshire.—at least partially; that is, two weeks out of the three!

If I had unlimited shillings (as many people have) I should think those flowers, alone; so beautiful, and in such perfect preservation, well worth the passage of the whole hamper, which has grown to be from four to five shillings a time! But as it is; I feel that hamper, just now, a sort of luxury that I ought not to indulge myself in!

For you see; the flowers are “all to myself”Coterie speech; see 13:284 JWC to TCH, [22 Oct.? 1841] . (as the children say). Mr C has no taste for them—does not know a myrtle from a nettle! And is constantly assuring me when he sees me arranging them that he “wouldn’t give a brass farthing for a whole cartload of them!!!”

Of the vegetables I may almost say the same—that these too are “all to myself”! Now that Mr C had got old potatoes again, he will eat no other vegetables whatever!TC believed that new potatoes upset his stomach; see 41:3 TC to JWC, 1 Sept. 1864
. So all these heaps of vegetables are for my individual benefit! and I, tho’ I am up to eating large quantities of every sort of garden stuff—would take a long time to eat my way thro’ one of these hampers!

So I have been considering that a hamper now and then—say once in the three weeks—would be a more economical arrangement, and would still keep me well supplied— The hard vegetables, and the apples would keep that long and even the flowers I can keep alive amazingly long—when I am put to it. I have at this moment a vaseful perfectly fresh of those that came in the former hamper.

closer.salute: Wishing you a good new year, your obliged /

div3.sourceNote: TC-JR [JRU], 30 Dec. MS: Serendipity Books, 1790 Shattuck Ave., Berkeley, CA. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN RUSKIN

docBody.p: Wd you now, like a good Ruskin as you are, put an Inscriptn, and despatch the Book by post, addressed (n. b.!) “Dr Carlyle / The Hill / Dumfries N.B.”—by whh route it will arrive here safely, some day next week,TC offered to lend the book to his brother John A. Carlyle, who replied, 29 Dec.: “When you have quite done with that book of [Ruskin’s] I should be glad to see it & return it punctually & soon.” and (in manner whh there is no time to explain) have killed two birds, instead of one! Do this & love me (tho’ in haste),

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [30 Dec.]. MS: NLS 609.760B. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:304–5.
div3.head:
JWC
TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p: Just a line Dearest to enclose the poor little money order—I have no time for a letter—indeed my hurry is indiscribable—for I have been fit for nothing this week, and all my newyear writing is choked into the last day of it

Wrap up five shillings, please, and address it to John HiddlestoneJohn Hiddleston (b. ca. 1806); possibly Jessie’s uncle; listed in 1861 census for Morton, Dumfriesshire, as “lab. in garden.” and give it or transmit it to MargaretMargaret McCaig, Jessie’s sister. who will save you the trouble of seeking out himself.

And you remember there was to be five shillings to that unlucky Mrs GilchristJane Gilchrist; see JWC to EWEL [2 or 9 Oct.] . into her own hand
!? The other ten shillings please give where you see it most needed. A woman who had had something from me, thro you—(an old Postwoman,Unidentified further. Jessie said) came to Jessie when she was coming away and begged her to tell me that “she had been sometimes at Templand! and had
once taken tea with Mrs Welsh in her own parlour”! and if I would do something more for her that being the case!!
Jessie had properly told her that it was no business of hers to interfere. And she could tell myself!— No! I do not recognise the claim! Let her have what she has been used to have but no more.
She ought to have appealed to me thro’ you, not thro my prospective Servant!

My sickness and my sleeplessness have culminated in a violent cold or Influenza! Blue pill, Castor-oil, Morphia, I have not been idle I assure you!— And now the evil thing is blowing over; and I expect to be able to keep my engagement to dine with Dr QuainDr. Richard Quain. on the 3d of January!!!
I hope you got my long letter;—that it was not confiscated for the sake of the buttons!

Will
you tell me how you manage to get baskets all the way to our door without a farthing to pay? Nobody else can manage it! Even when the carriage is paid; there is still porterage from the Station to the place of delivery—which cannot be prepaid—six pence or eight pence or a shilling according to the bulk—I really want to understand? Had you any porterage from the Station to Holmhill to pay for my box? A good new year to the Dr— I would be his “first foot” if I had a wishing Carpet Cf. Arabian Nights’ Entertainments.
Tell me how poor little Mrs Ewart is?

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JS [JRS], 30 Dec. MS: NLS Acc. 7012. Pbd: E. B. Chalmers, “Mrs Carlyle’s Letters to John Stodart,” TLS, 25 June 1971, p. 739.
div3.head: JWC TO JOHN STODART

docBody.p: I was meaning to write you a long, kind, charming letter, for your New Years morning; since, having no Wishing Cap, nor Flying Carpet Cf. Arabian Nights’ Entertainments. I could not well go myself to be your First Foot! But my amiable intentions are always overruled by Perverse Fate! My evil ones, I have observed succeed perfectly! Pity! But who can help it?

You see I went out to dinner on Xmas day!Christmas dinner at the Forsters’ was “(fixed, weeks ago)”; see TC to JCA, 25 Dec.
That I couldn’t help either
under the circumstances! And I caught a violent cold or Influenza, from sitting amongst a lot of Jew-Germans,Unidentified; possibly well-off relatives of Count von Reichenbach who was German Jewish but not rich himself. “immensely rich, and “prodigiously munificent”! I dont mean that the people were damp; so far as I know! But they were awful heavy and depressed my system so that it could make no resistanceThus in MS. to the “inclemency of the season! Ever since, I have been a wretched little Woman! what with face-ache and headache and aches all over! And my new-years letters have got postponed to the last day!— And I am writing them in a head-over-heels fashion that takes away my breath!
But I would just say; Good New Year to you dear John!

I am not such an idiot as to wish you in the usual phraseology “a happy one”! That being entirely out of the question at our age—when Youth and Strength and Health and Hope have all “been left behind—for some one else to find”!See 38:158–59 JWC to TC, [22 Aug. 1862] . Nothing left to be happy at, but—our virtues! And these, I take it won’t carry us far towards Elysium! wherever else!
God bless you all the same, truest hearted Friend!

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 1 Jan. MS: NLS 518.20. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC to John A. Carlyle

docBody.p: Here is a Newyear come upon us; may it be good for us all,—“happy” we dare not ask it to be; the chaceThus in MS. of “happiness” having gone quite over the horizon so long ago! I am sorry you scunner at the front-room here: we might be all snug enough, with a little exercise of practical philosophy; the rather as I am now “bone-idle” (dry bone), ready for any little bit of locomotion, and perhaps slightly improving in my faculty of walking. The maids now sleep in my old garret; except Jane, the whole household is now aloft, and there is no special nicety required in sliding to bed and out of it. Our weather, I believe, is on the average superior to yours; today agn is bright with sun, after an abundt clash of rain with loudish wind for many hours agn.John A. Carlyle wrote, 29 Dec.: “As to going to London, I should like much to be near you again for a time, but I doubt very much whether I should be able to sleep at all in that front room—quiet as it is—for I got my nerves shaken much when I was last there, especially when we used to be going upstairs to bed late, & afraid of disturbing Jane.”

I had, before finishing Frh, discovered that abt the Keiths;John A. Carlyle wrote: “I have been reading Memoirs of Sir R. M. Keith, with interest, tho’ the book is feeble & long-winded. It appears the name of his father was Robert Keith. In next edition of Frederick one or two corrections wd be desirable as you may see by the enclosed scrap”; the enclosed scrap dealt with various details about the Keiths. but did not know what a blunder Larkin had accomplished in the Index! That is in the way of getting rectified;In the index to the 1st edn. of Frederick (6:750–51), Larkin had confused Sir Robert Murray Keith (1730–95; ODNB), army officer and diplomat, with his father, Robert Keith (ca. 1697–1774; ODNB); Frederick was apparently being revised; Chapman & Hall pbd. a new edn., 1869, where “Keith, Excellency Sir Robert Murray” was correctly identified as “son of the foregoing” “Keith, Excellency Robert” (Frederick [1869] 7:310; Carlyle, Works 19:361). that at any rate: the others too I will doctor before quitting. The “Mrs Gillespie,” I learned, was a natl Daughter of the Sir R.M.K.,—certainly one of the most ignorant of writing women (lived or lives in Edinr, I have heard): her first editn was not called “Romance of Diplcy,”Amelia Gillespie Smyth (1788—post-1871), possibly Sir Robert Murray Keith’s illegitimate daughter. She edited Memoirs and Correspondence (official and familiar) of Sir Robert Murray Keith ... With a Memoir of Queen Caroline Matilda of Denmark, 2 vols. (1849), which TC consulted while writing Frederick, and The Romance of Diplomacy: historical memoir of Queen Carolina Matilda of Denmark .... With memoir, and a selection from the correspondence (official and familiar) of Sir R.M. Keith (2d edn., slightly abridged), 2 vols. (1861); this was the edn. John A. Carlyle was reading. —does she give, in that second, any acct of Qun Matilda’s affair? Any Despatch upon it? In the first, nothing on that head was our allowance, and her own knowledge abt Struensee &cappeared to be nearly zero.Caroline Matilda (1751–75; ODNB), sister of George III (1738–1820; ODNB), king of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland; she m., 1766, Christian VII (1749–1808), king of Denmark and Norway, who suffered from mental illness. By 1769 she was presumed to be having an affair with Johann Friedrich Struensee (1737–72), royal physician and politician. After Struensee’s execution, 1772, her husband divorced her, and she was rescued by Sir Robert Murray Keith, then British minister at Dresden; see Carlyle, Works 19:167. Smyth does not refer to Queen Caroline Matilda’s affair in either edn.; see also 28:229–30 TC to JN, 28 July 1853
, where TC describes Smyth as “a fool.” No matter at all, at all!—

We had a copy (or Jane had) of the Ruskin Book in hand here; and there was another due “with an Inscriptn on it.” The first was voluntarily carried off to the Lord-Lothian people (who are here, “consulting Doctors” &c): so, on Saty, I wrote to Ruskin, bidding him forward copy2 & 1Inscriptn TC wrote “2” above “copy” and “1” above “Inscriptn,” presumably to indicate order of words. to yr Address (when it will arrive perhaps along with this, or the day following: read, at yr leisure quite, & then return hither.John A. Carlyle wrote to Ruskin, 4 Jan.: “By this day’s post I have received your most welcome gift of a copy of your Ethics of the Dust, & I beg leave to thank you most cordially for sending it to me. I read nearly all of it yesterday, my brother having lent me a copy which I shall send back to Chelsea today. … I entirely agree with you in regard to all the things you teach in it, & admire the correct, easy & graceful style of the little book. It is one of the very best I have ever read” (Cate 114); see also TC to JRU, 30 Dec. 1865
.— Tell Jean I have sent for two Books (Sartor
& Life of Sterling) for the Birminghm Cousins:Thomas (b. 1815) and John (b. 1818) Carlyle, sons of TC’s uncle Francis Carlyle (1761–1819) and aunt Elizabeth, b. Bell (1783–1842); see 37:219–20 TC to JCA, 25 Aug. 1861
.—Jean must directly send me the Address agn (for it has gone by mistake into the fire!) & say what are the Cousins’ names, and whether Tom or John is the elder. Then it will do. And let the Jenny-spinnerSee Carlyle, Reminiscences 70. Nisbet, poor wretch, rest on the tub-edge forev[er]more,—with my blessing!—

Anthony Sterling I saw yesterday, after the rain: he rides daily for some months past; ordered by the Doctors for fat;—has already got 11 lb down since we saw him;TC and John last saw Anthony Sterling together Aug. 1865 when they were all staying with Sir William Stirling Maxwell; see 42:201–2 TC to JWC, 21 Aug. 1865
. ohe pinguis [ho! fat]! On the other hand, Wm Stirling, I heard some weeks ago, is in Town with his Wife—in demand of some Locock’s help!Sir Charles Locock (1799–1875; ODNB), gynecologist and obstetrician; for TC’s opinion of him, see 32:106 TC to JAC, 21 March 1857
. The Stirling Maxwells’ first son, John, was b. 6 June. There is for you!— I had more to say, but am driven out of it; I will write soon agn.— Dear Brother consider seriously the questn of Flannel Shirts; I am persuaded they wd do you sensible good! For my own part, I am sure I shd perish in yr clothes, very soon. Think of it.

postscript.p: Jane’s cold goes to & fro; is not away yet,—tho’ she keeps the road, poor soul; & is going out to be “first foot,” &c

div3.sourceNote: TC-CAW, 2 Jan. Addr: 1. Chapel Street / Mayfair. PM: London, 2 Jan. 1866. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO CHARLES A. WARD

docBody.p:
You are always very kind and mindful! Accept many thanks for the pretty Strasburg Pot; reputed acme of the culinary art,Presumably goose paté; paté de foie gras was known as Strasbourg pie or paté, Strasbourg being the chief source at the time. and dear inexpressibly to “those who,” as the French Editor has said, “se dévoient à la carrière des indigestions [succumb to a career of overindulgence].”TC possibly refers to the death of Julian Offray de La Mettrie (1709–51), French physician, philosopher, and hedonist; his death, apparently from overeating pheasant pie, is recounted by Frederick the Great; see Carlyle, Works 16:331–33. Materially speaking, we here must not try to eat it; nevertheless, to us also, no part of it or of its savoury qualities has been lost;—and on the spiritual palate it has a taste far
finer than the vulgar Strasburg one, far more lasting, too, and perfectly wholesome! I can only wish you many New Years: that they may all be for good to yrself and others.

I continue perfectly idle here, merely reading &c&c; and feel disappointed that you have never come back to me yet. I am almost always here till after 2 p.m.; daily, towards 3, I have to sally out for a walk; and cd with pleasure escort you up to Town agn. So it stands at prest; so it will not always stand.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 9 Jan. MS: NLS 518.21. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NL 2:234 inc.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
I recd yr Sentimental journey;Laurence Sterne, A Sentimental Journey Through France and Italy by Mr. Yorick (Dublin, 1768). The work is referred to often by both TC and JWC; see, for example, 2:303 and 12:100. many thanks. It will fill up some gap in the heavy Napier;W. F. P. Napier, History of the War in the Peninsula; see TC to JAC, 13 Dec. 1865
. —Jane too talks of reading it for auld lang-syne; but her powers in that way, poor little soul, are greatly limited at prest!

I am very sorry to report that the Fraser
Fraser’s Magazine. went away several days ago! I had no suspicn you wd care for anything in it (and indeed I myself found as good as nothing that now stays with me); otherwise it wd have been so easy and even so agreeable to halt & salute:—but next time if we are all right, I will do it witht being asked; neither need you stint yrselves to “2 hours,” nor to 24, in forwarding: WalterRev. Walter Welsh; see also TC to JAC, 2 Dec. 1865
. is not used to it till abt the 5th or 6th if I recollect.

Napier is clumsy as you say; very heavy-hoofed, & slow, slow. But he is well-informed, credible on every point (whh I never knew till now); and there is a fine fire of soldierhood in him,—tho’ little culture that way in comparison to what I have been used to lately. He understands abt fighting of Battles (what they call “tactic”) well enough; but his notions upon strategy (or the planning and handling, or campaigning part) are good for little,—Napoleon such a god to him. His endless details abt Spaniard people and their fatuities I try all I can to skip (but cannot yet): in fact he knows still less abt “Literature” than abt Strategy; and is not quite steady in gramar even. But I mean to read him all, finding him true. By the bye there has a Life of him (2 voll. smallish 8vo) come out lately by his Son-in-law Bruce M.P.See TC to JAC, 13 Dec. 1865
. —not bad at all; whh I have wholly: yours next, if you like to say a word.

For some days back I have occasionally been below par, a small way, in point of health; sleeping inferior, nerves shivery even beyond wont:—within the last 2 days there is coming out, in spots, on the right loin (betn back-bone & edge of pelvis) a kind of red eruption, whh is not itchy at all but seems rather blabby & soft, but whh as you may fancy is fasheous with my belt &cin that part. I am for a go of castor tomorrow: that first of all! I am quite heart-whole (eat &cas usual): so you needn’t bother abt me.

My regards to IrmaIrma Otthenin (1838–97; see 42:236 42:biographical notes ) who lived in Edinburgh; presumably John A. Carlyle visited there during the winter although he was still based with the Aitkens in Dumfries. when you go walking agn. Kind love to everybody.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-GEJ, [12 Jan.]. MS: Berg. Pbd: Ireland 299–300. Dated by report of “heavy fall of snow in London on Thurs. morning” (11 Jan.), Illustrated London News, 13 Jan.
div3.head: JWC TO GERALDINE E. JEWSBURY

docBody.p: Oh my dear young Woman! For goodness gracious’s sake dont be outstaying your time by ever so long! You “are wanted”—not by the Police but by me! I want you every day and all! for I have no resource in myself at present! am indeed an unmitagatedThus in MS. nuisance to myself! and for any comfort that lies in “Others”—such others as are getatable—! Ach!—
Since we parted I cannot boast of one moment of wellness, day or night! There is nothing serious the matter with me, so far as I know— It is just that

When Jessie was mending the fire yesterday, she suddenly addressed me, “D’ye ken mam I miss Miss Jewsbury.” “Impossible!” I answered, for I thought she had said “D’ye ken mam I met Miss Jewsbury.” She stared and said, “but it is the truth”—“Perfectly impossible I repeated—Miss Jewsbury is not in London, she is in Manchester.”Jewsbury was visiting her brother Frank (1819–78) and his wife, Emily, b. Vandeburgh, m. 1853, who lived in Manchester. “I ken that fu weel, said she snappishly, and that’s just the reason I miss her.” Then I saw my mistake. It was the only good sentiment I had heard out of the young woman’s head for some time! I am so disappointed in that “hereditary Housemaid”! Being human of course she would have faults, and I should find them out in time. But when found out they prove her in all the most important things the very opposite of what I took her for! and that is humiliating for me as well as vexatious She lies like an Irishwoman—is secretive and decitfulThus in MS. as a Welshwoman; is heartless and ungrateful as well as extremely bad tempered and all the while such a sweet open countenance! and, when she likes, fascinating manners!

Mrs Frank (my kind regards to her) may console herself under Her household troubles with the same consolation which alone makes it possible for one to bear up against old age and Death! that it is the universal doom!
Mrs Warren has had a sort of Influenza, which kept her in a cloud of blue devils for a fortnight But now she is all right again.
Pray write and fix the time of your return—and keep it! I have hundreds of things to tell you!

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady T [LT], 16 Jan. MS: Trevelyan Papers, Robinson Lib., Newcastle Univ. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO LADY TREVELYAN

docBody.p:
Oh my dear Lady Trevelyan! Have you had much to do with Cold in the Head?— Have you had occasion to know that there is nothing more sodden and abject than a woman with a cold in her head, unless, perhaps, a man similarly afflicted! For the last three or four weeks, I have felt to be hearing
and seeing and speaking and thinking “thro’ wool! to be living and having my Being in Wool! I have a cold in my head, and this is the sad result, that I am choked full,—especially the head of me—with (figurative) Wool! If You, with your little, diamond-clear brain, ever tried writing a letter thro’ wool, you will understand without further apology why there has been any delay at all in my answering your dear kind letter!

I was real glad of it! it was so long that you had never written to me! I feared you had clean forgotten me! And then your cards with no address on them—no penciled word—(looked at woolily too, even then,—) I didn’t find much satisfaction therein! But you might have said a few words about your own health! Might have told me whether the dear wee arm had gained any roundness! I ask about your healthLady Trevelyan suffered continual ill-health; JWC last mentioned seeing her in May 1865; see 42:40 JWC to LLA, [25 May 1865] . as often as there is any chance of learning; but the accounts are so contradictory that I might as well be left wholly without news of you And my best source of information has thrown us all over; and wandered away into a Bunsenland Lady Ashburton had been visiting the Bunsens in Carlsruhe; see TC to Lady A, 4 Oct. 1865
; JWC was possibly also using it to mean “Germany.” where even my imagination cannot follow! Poor empty Seaton! Poor empty Bath House!Two of Lady Ashburton’s houses, Seaforth House, Seaton, Devon, and Bath House, London. People generally know their own affairs best, and “the heart knoweth its own bitterness”See Prov. 14:10. best! but I cannot console myself for my own loss, with any feeling of assurance, that in thus turning her back on friends and enemies she is doing the best for herself and the wee Darling. Thank God they are away from Carlsruhe however! So long as little one Lady Ashburton’s da., Mary Florence. was there “the coldest place in Germany[”] even Germans tell me, I was in continual apprehension of great calamity!

Miss Bromley is coming back to Grosvenor Street this week, I am happy to think! My two dearest Friends away all these dull months, and a cold in my head, in permanence, have made this winter so far very dreary for me!

We met Sir Walter’s nephew (or Cousin is he?)First cousin once removed; George Otto Trevelyan (1838–1928; ODNB) was the son of Sir Charles Edward Trevelyan (1807–86; ODNB), Sir Walter Calverley Trevelyan’s cousin, and Charles Edward’s wife, Hannah More, b. Macaulay (1810–73), sister of T. B. Macaulay. at Mr Froude’s, at dinner and he sent Mr Carlyle his Cawnpore George Otto Trevelyan, Cawnpore (1865), an account of the Cawnpore massacre during the Indian rebellion, 1857; see 33:14–15 JWC to TC, [10 Aug. 1857] . JWC began referring to George Otto as “Cawnpore”; see JWC to LLA, 15 April
. next day. Mr C said it, the Book, beat all the sensational novels of the day!

Oh you Dear! I should so like a long talk with you! But writing I am downright
stupid at just now! And I should like to have TinyApparently Lady Trevelyan’s dog was called Tiny; JWC acquired another dog called Tiny in March; see JWC to LLA, [16 March] . in my lap, and to show him that I have not forgotten the trick of his lip!

Mr C has to go to Edinr the last week of March to deliver that horrid “address.” A long journey and a speech! just the two things in the world he most detests! If the weather prove superhumanly fine then, and my cold has got subdued, I have some idea that perhaps I shall accompany him. I have no neuralgia at present. and have the use of both my arms!!— But— But— it is a terrible way off!

Do write to me again when you have leisure—and tell me about your health And, as my old nurse in Edinr writes to me, “Oh my Dear! excoos all my rongs”!Coterie speech; Betty Braid’s saying; see 40:218 JWC to TC, [30 Aug. 1864] .
Kind remembrance to Sir Walter

div3.sourceNote: TC-UYW [UC], 21 [Jan.?]. Pbd: Conway, Carlyle 217–19; Wilson, Carlyle 6:109–10. The letter was given to Conway by an acquaintance: “It was written to a lady of my acquaintance when she was quite a young girl. She had passed into a somewhat morbid state of mind and feeling about herself, and wrote to the man who appeared to her almost a prophet” (Conway, Carlyle 217); it was only dated “21st” and 1866; placed tentatively in Jan. as a month when TC was relaxed enough to have time to write kindly.
div3.head:
TC
TO AN UNIDENTIFIED CORRESPONDENT

docBody.p:
Dear young Lady,
—Your appeal to me is very touching, and I am heartily sorry for you, if I could but help at all. In very great want of time, among other higher requisites, I write a few words, which, I hope, may at least do no harm, if they can do little good. Herein, as in many other cases, the ‘patient must minister unto himself;’ no best of doctors can do much. The grand remedy against such spiritual maladies and torments is to rise upon them vigorously from without, in the way of practical work and performance. Our thoughts, good or bad, are not in our command, but every one of us has at all hours duties to do, and these he can do negligently, like a slave; or faithfully, like a true servant. ‘Do the duty that is nearest thee’Goethe’s expression in Wilhelm Meister; see 6:122 TC to JAC, 16 Feb. 1832
, and Carlyle, Sartor 145.—that first, and that well; all the rest will disclose themselves with increasing clearness, and make their successive demand. Were your duties never so small, I advise you, set yourself with double and treble energy and punctuality to do them, hour after hour,
day after day, in spite of the devil’s teeth! That is our one answer to all inward devils, as they used to be called. ‘This I can do, O Devil, and I do it, thou seest, in the name of God.’ It is astonishing and beautiful what swift exorcism lies in this course of proceeding, and how at the first real glimpse of it all foul spirits and sickly torments prepare to vanish.

I hope you will not often have experience of this, poor child. And don’t object that your duties are so insignificant; they are to be reckoned of infinite significance and alone important to you. Were it but the more perfect regulation of your apartments, the sorting-away of your clothes and trinkets, the arranging of your papers—‘Whatsoever thy hand findeth to do, do it with all thy might,’See Eccles. 9:10. and all thy worth and constancy. Much more, if your duties are of evidently higher, wider scope; if you have brothers, sisters, a father, a mother, weigh earnestly what claim does lie upon you, on behalf of each, and consider it as the one thing needful, to pay them more and more honestly and nobly what you owe. What matter how miserable one is, if one can do that? That is the sure and steady disconnection and extinction of whatsoever miseries one has in this world. Other spiritual medicine I never do discover; neither, I believe, does other exist, or need to exist.

For the rest, dear child, you are evidently too severe upon yourself; these bad thoughts don’t make you a ‘wicked girl,’ not until you yield to them; the excess of your remorse and self-abhorrence is itself proof of some height of nobleness in you. We have all of us to be taught by stripes,That is, by being beaten; cf. Luke 10:47–48. by sufferings—won’t learn otherwise. Courage, courage! As to fasting, penance, etc., that is all become a ghastly matter; have nothing to do with that; work, work, and be careful about nothing else. Choose with your utmost skill among your companions and coevals some real associates; be not too much alone with your thoughts, which are by nature bottomless. Finally, be careful of your health; bodily ill-health, unknown to your inexperience, may have much to do with the miseries.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JD [JAD], 22 Jan. MS: NLS 1797.106. Pbd: Fielding and Sorensen 308–10 inc.
div3.head:
JWC
TO JANE DODS

docBody.p:
I have written no letters that I could avoid since new year time, when I had a surfeit of letterwriting, complicated with a cold in the head—lasting (the
cold) I cant say how long; for it is not yet done with! Now, a cold in the head is hardly an indisposition “to speak of”!Coterie speech; see Dickens, Martin Chuzzlewit, ch. 8. Nobody dies of it, and nobody pities it—much!—nevertheless it makes one very sodden and abject!—gives one the feeling of being crammed full of Wool! especeally one’s head! So that to think with it, or do anything with it besides just blowing its nose seems out of the question! If you have had any experience of this fuzzy condition, you will at once understand and excuse my delay in answering your welcome letter; and will appreciate the willingness of the Spirit which is able to overcome the Weakness of the FleshCf. Matt. 26:41. at even this late date!

If this wonderful temperature would last a while, one might hope to bloom up again like the green things in the Garden. The Laburnum and Hawthorn which your Husband once sent me from Sunny BankIn 1860, William Dods sent slips of fuschia and laburnum (which JWC thought were dead in 1861), a little fir tree, and a slip of hawthorn; see 37:3–4 JWC to WDO, 6? Oct. 1860
, and 149 JWC to WDO, [ca. 15 April 1861] ; Sunny Bank (Tenterfield), home of the deceased Donaldson sisters in Haddington; see 37:265 37:biographical notes . are actually budding! and all the bits of flowers and weeds brought from my different far away Homes are shooting out of the ground.In 1856, JWC gathered from her father’s grave in Haddington an unidentified plant (which turned out to be a gooseberry) and a nettle from Crawfurd; see 32:28 JWC to MR, [5 Nov. 1856] , and 39:135–36 JWC to BB, 22 May [1863]
. In 1862, she gathered a Templand daisy and ivy, and a Strathmilligan woodruff from near Holmhill; see 38:159 JWC to TC, [22 Aug. 1862] , and 221 JWC to MR, [21 Sept. 1862] . Not one day since I returned from Folkstone in SeptemberJWC stayed in Folkestone 14–28 Aug. 1865; see 42:212
TC to EWA, 27 Aug. 1865 , and 42:212
JWC to EWA, [27 Aug. 1865]. have I failed to drive out for some three hours, except the two days of the Snow a fortnight ago, when the very Omnibuses stuck up. What the present fine weather may bode for the end of March; who can tell? And supposing the end of March to be propitious as to weather; there are other things, still doubtful, which will determine whether or no I go to Edinr with Mr C! But this much is certain, as far as anything can be certain under Heaven! If I go to Edinr, I will go to Haddington and, on the strength of your kind invitation, make your House my resting place for the brief time I may have to spare! I should like to look about in the dear old place again, and at the few known faces remaining to me! I used to feel, after Sunny Bank fell desolate, that I could not face so many graves and empty Houses (empty for me)JWC refers to her family home off Lodge St., to Sunny Bank, and to the graves of her father and of the Donaldson sisters in St. Mary’s churchyard, all in Haddington. ever more! But since my terrible, long, and painful illness, strange to say, my nerves are much stronger than they were before! Or is it, that they are only deadened? Any how, I feel now that I could look at my old Home without crying myself to Death.

It was a most provoking disappointment to me, missing you and your Husband
when you called here. I say provoking because of the wilful mismanagement!! Why on Earth, if you were so pushed for time did you not send me one line by post to warn me of your coming? or, when you found I was out, why did you not write on your card where you would be till you left London. I could hardly take off my things, and sit down, after coming in and seeing your card! I wanted to drive off again, to find you—anywhere!— If I had only known the where!

I continued to be vexed and angry with you for ever so long! And would have put these sentiments in a letter, following you home; but for the good reason, that then, and for four or five months after, I had no use of my right hand and arm!Jane and William Dods’s call on Cheyne Row is untraced, presumably Feb. or March 1865, as JWC dated her painful arm from early March; see 42:212 JWC to MR, 4 May [1865]
. couldnt so much as feed myself therewith! My meat had to be cut for me as for a Baby! I had to learn to make strange writing with my left hand, and to do with my left hand everything that absolutely must not be left undone! This was the style of thing thro’out!JWC wrote this sentence with her left hand. The Doctors ordered me back to Dumfrieshire which had done me so much good the year before. I stayed there six weeks without any perceptible benefit, and returned home in the worst spirits. The night after my return, being dead weary, I fell into such a long deep sleep, that, when I awoke, I had not only forgotten where I was! but forgotten utterly who I was!! I remember maundering to myself; “It can’t be me who has had this nice long sleep! who am I, I wonder”!!See 42:154 JWC to TC, [27 July 1865] . I had not had such a nights rest, poor wretch! for two years! and to complete the miracle the neuralgia had gone out of my hand and arm entirely and has never returned to this hour! Yes! if it hadn’t been for the pain in my arm you would have got a thundering scold from me for that stupid business.

Such a nice clearly written letter dear old Mrs DavidsonJanet Davidson. sent me! She does not seem at all fallen off since I had last heard of her. How in the world does old MaryMary Jeffreys (b. ca. 1790), Janet Davidson’s servant; see 32:196–97 JWC to TC, [23 July 1857] . go on? Is there any affectual creature to attend to them both?
My faithful love to William Dods! I hope tho’ he ‘makes no sign’See Henry VI part 2, 3.3. that he remembers me as kindly as I do him Do please write to me sometimes

div3.sourceNote: TC-JC, 22 Jan. MS: NLS Acc. 7988. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JAMES CARLYLE

docBody.p:
Here a two Sovereigns whh you will get from the Bank,TC recorded in his checkbook: “22 jany1866 / to Brr James Carlyle / (for 2 poor women) £2 .. 0 .. 6” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). and whh I wish you to give, one to Babby Moffat, the other to Jenny Ker,Barbara Irving, b. Moffat (ca. 1791–1873), widow and dressmaker (1861 census); Jenny Halliday, b. Ker (b. ca. 1787), m., 1817, Tom Halliday (b. 1789). —two poor old women, almost the only contemporaries of mine now left in the village of Ecclefechan. Babby you know where to find: Jenny Ker also I think you know, and once pointed out to me; she lives abt the first of the Hagheads somewhere, was once married to a fellow called Tom Halliday (son of old Jamie, the Joiner),James Halliday (b. ca. 1767); see 3:434 TC to JAC, 15 Dec. 1825
. and is daughter to an old “Mrs Ker”For a family of Kers, masons in Annan, see 7:232 TC to JCA, 6 July 1834
. whom you may remember from yr boyhood. Poor old creatures; terribly reduced by the cruelty of Time & Fortune; slip the coins into their old hands, with a minimum of words, hardly saying from whom (not at all saying, unless necessary), and it will be a kind of small satisfactn to me.

We are haggling along here, on the old terms; not worse than we were, & hardly much better: Jane still keeps the road (out driving at this moment); it seems to me her poor vehicle is really the staff of life to her, for she cannot walk half a furlong at her best, and wd have to go witht exercise, society or amusement, if it were not for help of this “clatch”The Carlyles’ word for an old gig; see 6:193 TC to JAC, 31 July 1832
, and 34:202 JWC to MCA, [25 Sept. 1858] . whh supplies them all. I am myself a very feckless creature ever since you saw me,—“worse than ever,” I often feel; tho’ in better moments I seem to trace some beginnings of possible improvet to a slight degree. Early in April I hope to see you all agn,—my chief profit from that grand Edinr “Rectorship,” whh was so admirable to toWord repeated at turn of page. mankind!— I am often anxious abt that “Cattle-pest”For the cattle pest or rinderpest, see TC to JC Jr., 25 Dec. 1865
. affair; & sorry above all for the sad botheratn official & other, whh you have upon it. Let us hope it may omit you, after all. My affecte regards to the Two Boys.James’s sons, James Jr. and John Carlyle.

div3.head:
JWC
TO GRACE WELSH

docBody.p:
Have you any more news of Robert?“Uncle Robert’s only surviving son, who had returned from sea in a dangerous state of health” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:306). I weary to hear how he is; tho’ without hope of hearing he is better! From the first mention of his illness I have felt that it was all over with the poor Lad for this Life!— one thinks it so sad that one’s Family should die out! And yet, perhaps it is best—(nay, of course it is best, since God has so ordered it)—that a Family lying under the Doom of a hereditary, deadly maladyConsumption; see JWC to BB, 28 and 30 Dec. 1865
. should
die out! and leave its room in the universe to healthier and happier People!— But, again, hereditary maladies are not the only maladies that kill! and plenty of Mothers have, like Mrs George and Mrs Robert,Margaret Welsh, mother of JWC’s cousin John, the meteorologist, who d. of consumption, 1859; see 35:94 TC to JN, 14 May 1859
; Mary Welsh, mother of Robert. seen their children, one after another, swept from the Earth, without Consumption having any thing to do with it! It is hard, hard to tell by what death, slow or swift, one would prefer to lose one’s dearest ones; when lose them one must!

Figure what has just befallen that dear kind Dr Blakiston, who saved my Life (I shall always consider) by taking me under his care at St Leonards.JWC visited the Blakistons in St. Leonards, June 1863 (vol. 39), and then Dr. Peyton Blakiston treated her at his home in St. Leonards, March–April 1864 (vol. 40). Of all his sons the most promising was Captain Peyton Blakiston—risen to be Naval Captain while still very young. Oh such a handsome, kindly gallant fellow! He had married a beautiful girl with a little fortune;Annie Blakiston. and they were the happiest pair! A year ago he was made ‘Commander’—a signal honour for so young a man! and just three weeks ago his wife was confined of her second BabyPeyton Blakiston, b. 20 Dec. 1865; he was her third child.—in her Mother’s houseSarah Ellen Bally. at St Leonards, The Captain being away to bring home a ship from somewhere in the West Indies— Well! four days ago, in reading his morning newspaper, Dr Blakiston read the “Death of that distinguished Officer Captain Peyton Blakistone, from fever—after three days
illness!”The Times reported, 20 Jan.: “Commander Peyton Blakiston, who went out by the last mail boat to take command of the steam screw vessel Sparrow, died of fever on board the Isis four hours after the departure of the homeward-bound mail boat.”— It is too terrible to try to conceive the feelings of a warmhearted, proud Father under a shock like that!— Not a word of warning! I think that going down of the London The Times reported, 18 Jan., that, 11 Jan., “[the] steamship the London had foundered in the Bay of Biscay with upwards of 200 souls on board. The fame this fine vessel had acquired as a passenger ship—partly owing to the fact of her last outward passage having been made in 59 days—was in itself calculated to dispel all anxiety on her behalf, even during the late tempestuous weather, and it is believed that her owners and the underwriters concerned were least of all prepared for the terrible disaster that has happened to her.” There were 19 survivors, who managed to get into a boat: “Scarcely had they gone 80 yards … when the fine steamer went down stern foremost with her crowd of human beings, from whom one confused cry of helpless terror arose, and all was silent for ever.”
has sent all the blood from my heart! Ever since I read its touching detail I have felt in a maze of sadness—have had no affinity for any but sorrowful things! And can find in my whole mind no morsel of cheerful news to tell you!— Perhaps I am even more stupid than sad; and no shame to me, with a cold in my head, dating from before Xmas! It is the only illness I have had to complain of this winter; and is no illness “to speak of”; but, none the less, it makes me very sodden and abject; and instead of having thoughts in my head, it (my head) feels to be filled with wool! Fuzzy is the word for how I feel, all thro’! But I continue to take my three hours drive daily, all the same. Since I returned from Folkstone in September, I have only missed two days! the days of the snow storm a fortnight ago; when it was so dangerous for horses to travel that the very Omnibuses struck work. And besides the forenoon drive, I occasionally, with this wool in my head go out to dinner!!! With a hot bottle at my feet, and wrapt in fur, I take no hurt, and the talk stirs me up. Dr Quain told me I “couldn’t take a better remedy, if only I drank plenty of Champagne,”—a condition which I for one, never find any difficulty in complying with!

My chief Intimates have been away all this winter, which has made my life less pleasant. Lady Ashburton on the Continent, and Miss Davenport Bromley waiting in the Country till the new-paint smell should have gone out of her house.Caroline Davenport Bromley was probably at Wootton Hall, Staffordshire; her London home was 32 Grosvenor St. She had been in London at the end of Nov. 1865 (see TC to JAC, 29 Nov. 1865
) and had returned by 26 Jan. (see JWC to MR, [26 Jan.] ). But there are always nice people to take the Place of those absent. It made me laugh, Dear, that Edinr notion that because Mr C had been made Rector of the University, an office purely honorary; we should immediately proceed to tear ourselves up by the roots, and transplant ourselves there! After thirty years of London, and with such society as we have in London to bundle ourselves off to Edinr to live out the poor remnant of our lives, in a
new and perfectly uncongenial sphere; with no consolations that I know of but your three selvesJWC’s irritation with her aunts’ religiosity (see 38:195 JWC to TC, [5 Sept. 1862] ) may also have contributed to her strong expressions against living in Edinburgh. Her friend David Davidson commented on her religious doubts and her aunts’ dislike of them: “However frank in other matters, Mrs. Carlyle was singularly reticent on the subject of religion; and I, in my desire not to offend, may have erred by going too far on the non-aggressive side. Her godly aunts were more venturesome, and latterly were more hopeful as to her attitude in regard to the most momentous subject. It is a pleasing fact that some of her dearest friends, and those on whose affection she relied with the greatest confidence, were decidedly serious people. … Thomas Erskine … and last, but not least, the faithful and godly Betty Braid. In my last letter to her, I pressed upon her as earnestly and affectionately as I could the importance of making sure work for eternity.
