I told her that in my dressing-room were hung portraits of many dear friends who had entered into their rest; and that the only ones that represented living friends were those of her husband and herself. And I added that, as I looked at hers, I was often filled with anxious thought as to what assurance I should have, if she were taken before me, that we should meet again in the happy land. That letter closed our earthly correspondence” (David Davidson, Memoirs of a Long Life
[Edinburgh, 1890] 317); Davidson’s last letter was possibly 1859; see 35:36 JWC to DD, 14 Feb. 1859
.—and dear old Betty—! Ach! “A Wishing Carpet” on which I could sit down, and be transported to Craigenvilla, for an hours talk with you all two or three times a week, and—back again!—would be a most welcome fairy gift to me!— But no “villa at Morningside” tempts me—except your villa! And for Edinr people!— Those I knew are mostly dead and gone—and the new ones would astonish me much if they afforded any shadow of compensation for the people I should leave here! No! my Dear we shall certainly not go “to live in Edinr,” I only wish Mr C hadn’t to go to deliver a speech in it; for it will tear him to tatters

div3.sourceNote: TC-[WD] [WHD], 23 Jan. MS: Duke. Hitherto unpbd. Recipient identified as William Henry Doeg (1836–1916), of Barlow Moor, Manchester, by the reference to Frederick’s autograph.
div3.head:
TC
TO [W. H. DOEG]

docBody.p: In remembrance of yr kindness with regard to Friedrich’s Autograph,In 1864, Doeg lent TC an autograph of Frederick the Great, which was reproduced in Frederick (Carlyle, Works 19:188); see 41:95 TC to WHD . I shd be very willing indeed to gratify you in this small matter. But I, like yrself, am totally in the dark as to everything concerned with it; my own privileges (if any), the place where, the time when (except that it is to be “in the final week of March”), all is entirely unknown to me at prest! So that I can, as matters stand, do nothing at all in the directn you indicate.
For the rest, I shd by no means advise such a journey as that to Edinr (were the ticket of admission never so read) for any Speech that is contemplated or can be possible, on such an occasion!

signed.name:
T. CarlyleTC sat, April–May 1865, for Thomas Woolner for a bust commissioned by Lady Ashburton; see 41:203 TC to JAC, 6 April 1865
. Walter White noted, 7 Dec. 1865: “Yesterday at Woolner’s. I saw his bust of Gladstone and the plaster model of Carlyle—both excellent. Both thoughtful, yet how different in the expression” (Journals of Walter White [1898] 195). Woolner corresponded with Lady Ashburton during the winter about the final marble bust; he wrote, 9 Dec. 1865: “Carlyle’s [bust] I hope to send to the Edinburgh Exhibition with Gladstone’s bust— The present and late Lord Rector of the University—if you have no objection to lend them the bust, and I am able to get it done in time” (MS: NLS Acc. 11388); he hoped, 14 Jan., that she would give permission for the completed marble bust to go to Edinburgh: “The burghers there are anxious to have it; and Carlyle himself wishes it to go to save himself from the attacks he will otherwise have made upon him to sit for busts and portraits” (MS: NLS Acc. 11388). On 23 Jan., he wrote: “I have great hopes of getting Carlyle done in time, but the labour is so great that I cannot really be sure” (MS: NLS Acc. 11388). In the event, it was the bust of TC and Woolner’s bust of Lord Ashburton that went to Edinburgh (see Surtees, Ludovisi 118); Alice Woolner wrote to Lady Ashburton, 24 Feb.: “Your two busts are gone to Edinburgh to the Scottish Academy, and have there been treated in a very honourable way. They have put them each on … pedestals, a distinction hitherto only granted to royal persons” (MS: NLS Acc. 11388). For a photograph of Woolner’s bust of TC, see 42:18 TC to JCA, 12 May 1865
.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-GLC, [24 Jan.]. Addr: 2 Chlorine Place / Belfast / Ireland. PM: London, 24 Jan. 1866. MS: Strouse. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO GEORGE LILLIE CRAIK

docBody.p: Your note looks in a hurry; so I answer it in a hurry; with my Brougham at the door, waiting to take me to Mrs Austin whom I have not seen these fifteen years!Sarah Austin lived in Weybridge, Surrey, about 15 mi. (24 km.) SW of Chelsea. JWC’s last recorded meeting with Austin was in Aug. 1850; see 25:149 JWC to TC, [10 Aug. 1850] .
Geraldine’s address is 43 Markham Square Chelsea—when she is at home. At this moment she is in Manchester; but coming back in a few days she told me.

I don’t know anything about the Review you mention—never heard of it—never see the Athenaeum newspaper! Cannot so much as guess whether Geraldine wrote it; as I dont know whether it is favourable or unfavourable; nor whether Geraldine liked the Book or not.Geraldine Jewsbury reviewed Georgiana Craik’s novel, Faith Unwin’s Ordeal, 2 vols. (1865), in the Athenaeum, 20 Jan.: “she is far too fond of epithets, making them do duty for thought, feeling, action—in short, making them save the trouble of work. Miss Craik knows little of life, and less of human nature, but she has a certain faculty for imagining things and people. … Miss Craik has talent, but she is … destitute of knowledge of life and of human nature, and so makes all her facts and her characters out of her own head.” An earlier critical review by Jewsbury of Georgiana Craik’s work, My First Journal (1860), was in the Athenaeum, 2 June 1860; see 36:139–40 JWC to GCMC, 18 June [1860]
. Craik’s novel, Winifred’s Wooing (1862), had also been reviewed in the Athenaeum, 18 Oct. 1862, by Lena Eden; see 38:239 JWC to GMC, 20 Oct. [1862]
. I only know that, as a general
Rule Geraldine Jewsbury writes the Reviews of novels, in the Athenaeum, unless the Novel be by some famed hand; when “Hap-worth” Dixon does it himself.William Hepworth Dixon (1821–79; ODNB), writer and journalist, ed. of the Athenaeum 1853 –69. For TC’s opinion of him, see 37:211 TC to JWC, 9 Aug. 1861
.

Why did Georgina address her book to Mr C instead of, as of old to myself? Mr C is notorious for never acknowledging the present of either a Novel or a Poem! From me she would have received thanks at least—
My love to dear wee Mary.Mary Craik.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 22 [24] Jan. MS: NLS 526.37. Hitherto unpbd. Dated 22 Jan. in error by TC, who wrote in reply to John A. Carlyle’s letter, 22 Jan., which arrived “yesterday,” 23 Jan.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
Yesterday morning, came yr Letter & Saga of Glum: The Viga Glum’s Saga—the Story of Viga-Glum, trans. and ed. by Sir Edmund Walker Head (1866). I intended writing to you yesterday at any rate; but impediments, not very strong tho too much so, proved invincible to the weak adversary! Indeed I have been altogether rather feckless, and oftenest below the mark, ever since I wrote last;—especially a great deal bothered with that 2 or 3 paltry specks of eruptn on my skin,See TC to JAC, 9 Jan.
on the most inconvenient part,—directly below the belt,Below the truss for his hernia (see 25:18 TC to JAC, 7 Feb. 1850
, and 34:69 TC to JWC, 23 July 1858
); see TC to JAC, 9 Jan.
namely, and on the side I have to sleep on! A shilling, or little more, wd have covered not only the biggest of them, but the whole sum of them; only there they were importt,—really very troublesome in the wild deluge of sleet, slush, glassy frost & bad weather we had. But I rallied upon the villains; and they are clearly on retreat, almost over the horizon agn,—and I have got two new belts by the job, not to speak of other conquests & profits!— The sober truth is, I am weak, languid,
ineffectual, quietly sombre to a degree; yet conscious now & then that something of clearness, of improvet from the horrible collapse of ruin I was in, does seem to be going on in a small way.

You also, I am sorry to learn, don’t seem to be very well.John A. Carlyle wrote, 22 Jan.: “[I] feel pretty well tho’ I often sleep rather badly.” Time, Time is very inexorable upon us all! It seems to me you ought to be far more warmly dressed than you are! Of course you understand best; but I always think so, knowing the benefit of “fleecy hosiery” in all forms.— I also think you ought to come up hither, and give yrself a doze of London agn. Our weather is getting quite pretty; in a week Parlt will be set,Parliament resumed 1 Feb. plenty of nonsense stirring for a quiet observer. You can be as quiet here as almost in any place: I go to bed abt 1 a.m., & for an hour & half before, cannot hear a sound (my very watch I have banished, so sensitive am I!) The front room shall have its 3 additl curtains the instant you say you will come:—or if you decidedly do prefer Brompton Cresct, that surely looks better than it used to do, not worse.John A. Carlyle replied, 25 Jan.: “I daresay a change to London for a short time might do me good, & at all events I shd see you there again. … Perhaps I might go first to Cheyne Row at least for some days, if I make up my mind for the journey, & then move if desirable to Brompton.” For many years John A. Carlyle lodged at 48 Brompton Row when in London; following recent changes to street names and numbers, this was now 174 Brompton Road; see 42:226 TC to JAC, 29 Sept. 1865
. In short I advise you to seriously turn over this thing. Wearied human nature does require variety; it is like turning to the other side (new & other) in the process of more or less uneasy sleep.— I hear nothing of Edinr (tant mieux, tant mieux [so much the better]!), but I shall require to be there at the time given. I totally ignore it in the meanwhile. The Lothians are still here; poor Ld Ln trying “electricity” for a remedy.See JWC to BB, 28 Dec. 1865
. “Both the medical literature on electrotherapy and its actual employment in medical practice expanded significantly in the second half of the nineteenth century. … Electricity could be applied to virtually any part of the body—head, neck, spine, abdomen, pelvis, and limbs were particular medical favorites. From the 1860s, electrical stimulation figured as a regular part of the physiotherapy offered at the national Hospital for the Paralysed and Epileptic” (Janet Oppenheim, Shattered Nerves (1991) 119–20). Perhaps they may not have returned to Newbattle by my time; never mind, never mind. Jane talks sometimes of going, but I think won’t. Froude do, Professor Tyndall do &c&c, strange but true! Chorley’s sciatica is very slowly withdrawing:See TC to JAC, 2 Dec.
; John A. Carlyle asked about Chorley in his letter of 22 Jan. I sometimes find him as lean & slippered pantaloonSee As You Like It 2.7. hirpling along in Eaton Sqre when it is sunny. Last night I read yr Glum’s Saga,—thanks for the treat;—Head is far more
of a scholar & gentn than poor pluffy Dasent:Sir Edmund Walker Head (1805–68; ODNB), scholar; previously governor-in-chief of British North America; George Webbe Dasent (1817–96; ODNB), Scandinavian scholar; TC had read several of Dasent’s translations of Norse and Icelandic sagas; see 42:85 TC to JCA, 15 June 1865
. you , I think withal, might do something on that matter much better than either of them;John A. Carlyle had recently been learning Danish, Swedish, and Icelandic; see 39:116 TC to JAC, 29 April 1863
. I actually do!

postscript.p:
We had never heard of Scott’s illness nor anything abt him, when this clipping of a Manchester Newspr suddenly came.The Manchester Courier and Lancashire General Advertiser announced Scott’s death, 19 Jan.: “For some years past the state of Mr. Scott’s health had caused grave apprehensions on the part of his colleagues and all his friends, and in the summer of 1865 he proceeded to Switzerland, in the hope that a year spent in a more equable and genial climate might send him back in the possession of restored health and vigour.” The Manchester Guardian and the Manchester Times both reprinted, 20 Jan., the obituary from the Scotsman, 19 Jan. John A. Carlyle replied, 25 Jan.: “Scott had been long ill before he went off to Switzerland. Last year, I heard … that he very often could not walk to his class. … Long ago he had symptoms of heart disease, & perhaps many of his changings & hesitations were due in some measure to physical causes. He must have had many sorrows to digest, & his wife was not able to give him much support or comfort under them, though always most zealous to do so.” Doubtless you have seen it; some Russell Possibly Francis Russell (1814–94), advocate, currently Sheriff-substitute for Roxburghshire (1861–86), living in Jedburgh, 47 mi. (76 km.) S of Edinburgh; an old friend of Scott’s, he wrote one of Scott’s testimonial letters, 27 May 1856; see 31:101 TC to AJS, 25 May 1856
; he is probably the Russell who accompanied Scott on his last visit to TC, rather than A. J. E. Russell identified there; see 38:140 TC to JWC, [14 Aug. 1862] . or so, I suppose, must have been the writer. I am much affected (considering) abt poor wandering, digging, boring, & fruitlessly striving Scott, who is now very seriously at rest!—

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MR, [26 Jan.]. Addr: Holm Hill / Thornhill / Dumfriesshire. PM: London, 29 Jan. 1866. MS: NLS 609.762. Quot: Froude, LM 3:309–11. Friday was 26 Jan.; it is possible that JWC wrote the letter over two days.
div3.head:
JWC
TO MARY RUSSELL

docBody.p: Let me instead of beginning with apologies, which you perhaps expect, begin with a piece of gossip which all Belgravia is ringing with! I heard it today when making calls, and might forget if I left it to the last page.

You have seen Dr Kitcheners cookery bookWilliam Kitchiner (1778–1827; ODNB), epicure and writer, author of the popular The Cook’s Oracle (1817). I dare say? He gave his well known name and a handsome fortune to a son who married a very lovely meek-looking LadyWilliam Brown Kitchiner (1804–61), m., 1828, Georgina Macdonell, b. Edgeworth (1808–79), da. of Thomas Edgeworth, major in the 35th Foot. whom I know—that is to say I have dined twice in company with her. He was a terrible Blackguard the younger Kitchener—squandered his money, ill used his wife—even to beating her, till old Kitchener took her away from him, and settled her in a small house in Belgravia with her two little girls.William B. Kitchiner did not marry until after his father’s death; it is probable JWC has confused Edgeworth’s own father with her husband’s father since Georgina Kitchiner lived at 14 Wilton Place, Knightsbridge, which was insured in 1837 by her father. In 1865 she changed her name back to Edgeworth. There were two das., Georgina Jemima Frances Edgeworth (b. ca. 1829), and a younger da., unidentified further. There she lived on, after old Kitcheners death, entirely separated from her Scamp of a Husband. People pitied her and liked her; talked a little scandal about a Mr ChisholmUnidentified further. (“The Chisholm”—the name he went by) making himself so much at home in her house, and acting as male to Protector to the family; and were sure The Chisholm would marry Mrs Kitchener if her Husband would only die.— but The Chisholm died instead; and, having no near relations, left all his Fortune to Mrs Kitchener. The Heir at Law disputed the will, but could make nothing of that! Mrs Kitchener entered into possession of a good fortune and has remained a popular woman in Belgravia up to the present time; her eldest Daughter being now well on to thirty.

The other morning—I think they said; four days ago— The footmanWilliam Johnson (b. ca. 1843). who was waiting at breakfast committed some stupidity which Mrs Kitchener reproved him for, and the man made her an insolent answer. Mrs K indignant said, she did not permit insolence from her servants that he must change
his tone or leave the House— He hadn’t the least objection he said. “Then said Mrs Kitchener you will give up the plate to the Housekeeper so soon as breakfast is over, and pack up your things and be off.”— “Oh with pleasure returned the Man when you have paid me my wages; but I will take my wife with me”!! “What have I to do with your wife” asked the Lady?— Whereupon the fellow turned round towards the young Lady sitting at the Breakfast table (Miss Kitchener) and said “Come along Georgie!—you hear?— Get ready your traps!” Mrs Kitchener could think nothing but that her footman had gone suddenly mad; and rushed out of the House, leaving the front door open, to a Street Sweeper who went messages; and implored him to run for the Police, that there was a mad man in the house! At which sight a mob began to collect about her door! The poor woman returned up stairs, and was met by the footman coming down followed by “Georgie,” with a bag in her hand!!! “I am going Mama, said the young Lady, with my Husband, we were married at —— church by Banns on Sunday gone a Fortnight.”William Johnson and Georgina Edgeworth m., 18 Jan., at Trinity Church, Marylebone. “Nothing wrong said the Footman to the people outside only be so good as call me a cab”! Mrs Kitchener didnt see her Daughter drive off with the footman; for at the girls first words she had fallen down in a dead faint!
“Did you—ever?” To complete the disgrace the footman is two or three and twenty and the young Lady near thirty!
There! all these pages filled with a London Scandal.
It is time to give you a few details, of myself, trusting that I am more interesting to you, than ever so many scandals

When you last heard from me I was badly off for sleep, and generally out of sorts; tho still quite free of neuralgia. It seemed a case for a tonic, and I had your Dr’sDr. James Russell. prescription made up, and persevered in taking it twice a day for a week. But the only effect I perceived from it was an ever increasing headache and sickness all the mornings—and a sort of sore throat like what I always got from trying cod liver oil! So at the end of a week I left it off on trial. I was immediately, almost, relieved from the headache and sickness but slept no better, and felt miserably low. After leaving off for a week I tried the iron again, and the very second day of it the headache and sickness returned to me, so I considered it a made out case that the iron did not agree with me, and left it off altogether! I am sure the Dr would have advised me to do so, if he had been near me to see! Since the weather has been so temperate, I have felt better, and had more sleep. Except the two days when London was so snowed up that the Omnibuses struck work; I have never omitted my daily drive; and have even continued to go out occasionally to dinner!! Dr Quain told me I “could do nothing more wholesome provided I drank plenty of Champagne.”
Easy to do that! and really it is a fact that the night after I have been at an eight o’clock dinner with plenty of talk going on, I always sleep sounder than on other nights!

The Town is no longer “empty.” All my most intimate friends are come back except Lady Ashburton, who alas will still remain on the Continent and give no certain promise of return— Her rheumatism is better; but there are family reasons for her avoiding England at present which she considers imperative,See TC to LLA, 7 Nov.
tho’ her friends find them chimerical enough— Miss Davenport Bromley is back— The Alderley Stanleys—the Airlies—The Froudes &c&c—

We were much surprised by the Lothians coming to London some two or three weeks ago.The Lothians had been in London for over a month; see TC to JAC, 21 Dec.
They had not stirred from Newbattle Abbey for two years! The poor young Marquis came the whole journey in one day.— Some hope of Electricity had been put into his head, and they have been trying it on him. He said he “did not think it had done him any harm as yet
; but that was the most he could say.” He is the saddest spectacle I have seen for long! His Body more than half dead, his face so worn with suffering; and the Soul looking out of him as bright as in his best days! I had not seen him since before my own illness, and I was shocked with the change—especially in his voice which from being most musical had become harsh and husky. She poor soul bears up wonderfully! But is so white and sad, that I cannot look at her without dreading for her the fate of her Mother!Lady Sarah Elizabeth Chetwynd-Talbot, countess of Shrewsbury; it is unclear if the countess was ill herself, or if she had to nurse her husband who d. 1868.

The House
(ours) goes on peaceably enough on the whole. Not without crisises of ill temper of course!— But I have got Jessy pretty well in hand now. It is mortifying after all my romantic hopes of her, to find that kindness goes for nothing, indeed for worse than nothing with her, and that she is only amenable to good sharp snubbing. Well! she shall have it! At the same time I make a point of being just to her and being kind to her As a Mistress to a
Servant! So she got the “nice dress” at Xmas,Traditionally female servants were given clothes as gifts at Christmas. JWC had once been insulted on being given a dress as a Christmas gift by the previous Lady Ashburton; see 30:152 TC to JAC, 30 Dec. 1855
. along with Mrs Warren, at the same time I put no affection into any thing I do for her and let her see that I dont.

It was a lucky Xmas for her! Mr Ruskin always gives my Servants a sovereign a-piece at that season! “The like never had happened to her before!” she was obliged to confess. She went to the Theatre one night with some FergusonsUnidentified further.—and has acquaintances enough— So I hope she is happy—tho i don’t
like her!! Has the Dr seen young Corson who had to leave Swan & EdgarWilliam Corson (b. ca. 1841), from Dabton, nr. Thornhill; JWC had met him when he worked at Swan & Edgar’s dept. store, Piccadilly, Feb. 1863; see 39:80
JWC to MR, [2 March 1863]. with a bad knee— He came here several times to see Jessy

closer.salute: Love to the Dr Yours ever

postscript.p: How is Mrs Ewart

div3.sourceNote: TC-BA [BAT], 2 Feb. Pbd: Blanche Atkinson, “My Four Letters From Carlyle,” Good Words 33 (1892): 459.
div3.head:
TC
TO BLANCHE ATKINSON

docBody.p:
Good young lady,
it is certain the greatest man’s “autograph” will do almost nothing for you.Blanche Atkinson, soon to be 19, later explained her request to TC: “In 1866 the passion for autograph collecting had seized me; and my most eager desire was to obtain the autograph of Thomas Carlyle. He was at that time my hero and spiritual master. ‘Sartor Resartus’ had lately fallen in my way, and wakened me to an entirely new world; and it was genuine enthusiasm for the teacher, not a mere idle wish to have a momento of a great man which prompted me, after long dubitation, to write and make my request to him. … So much has been written of his impatience and surliness, amounting to discourtesy, that it is time to give even this trifling proof of the other side of his character” (459). If, on the other hand, you can find anything of credibly wise in any of your great men, and will proceed and faithfully to put it in practice, how useful may not that be to yourself and him!

signed.name: T. Carlyle.Frances Bunsen wrote from Carlsruhe, 6 Feb., to Caroline Davenport Bromley, who was now back in London: “I like to think of your seeing the Carlyle’s. I wish you would remember me to each of them, for I think of them with interest, little as I ever saw of them. It was little, but not slight” (A. J. C. Hare, Life and Letters of Frances, Baroness Bunsen [1879] 2:356).

div3.sourceNote: TC-DL, 14 Feb. MS: EUL. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO DAVID LAING

docBody.p: I am very glad to have a word from you agn. It seems we cd not have made the least impression on that Conveyancer Electn:Laing wrote, 12 Feb., telling TC about the election by the University Court for the chair of conveyancing. so that it was just as well that I remained conscious of having no knowledge at all on that head, nor made the least effort to acquire any.

We are altogether pleased & grateful, both Wife & I, for yr offer abt quiet lodging,Laing continued: “I was told, you wished to be very quiet—and therefore you might have your heart’s wish if you would make your Assessor’s house your head-quarters. … [S]hould Mrs C be tempted to come so far North to see your Inauguration, my Sister would do her best to entertain her.” Laing’s youngest sister, Euphemia, lived with him as his housekeeper after the death of their mother, Helen. —an offer whh I can discern to be sincere, kind, & humanly hospitable, as perhaps not very many are;—nor will either of us forget to keep it in remembrance. There was a kind of engaget for Newbattle;The Lothians’ estate near Edinburgh; see TC to Lady L, 27 [28] Nov. 1865
. but as the Lordships are actually in London for 7 or 8 weeks back, and may not have returned when our day comes—— In short I will keep Joppa Laing lived at East Villa, 12 James St., Portobello, coastal village 4 mi. (6.5 km.) E of Edinburgh; Laing wrote: “Portobello is easy of access by omnibus or rail, at all reasonable hours.” Joppa is immediately E of Portobello. well in mind: and, on this occasn or some other, shd I live any time, it seems to me highly probable I shall find myself actually lodging under my excellt Assessor’s roof, lulled by the murmur of the sea, instead of driven mad by town noises & the shriekery of railways.

For the rest, if you cd, by degrees or at once, make out for me what the day of my Address ougt to be, and how the thing in genl is to be timed and ordered (on my side, & on its), I shd like to know a little more than appears to be yet fixed: “last week of March,” I once said,—thinking perhaps Saty 31 March might suit for the day;—but on all such points, I am perfectly flexible, & anxious to be convenient for neighbrs.— My Brother is here at prestt, & salutes you well.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JR [JRU], 14 Feb. MS: Strouse. Pbd: Cate 116. Quot: unidentified bookseller’s catalog.
div3.head:
TC
TO JOHN RUSKIN

docBody.p: You vanished in a moment, that Athenaeum night; & I had not once thanked you, for yr valiant punctuality both in signing and agn in voting.The Athenaeum Club records indicate that TC nominated John Rutter Chorley for membership, with the proposal seconded by Erasmus Darwin and supported by Ruskin. You are becoming a very evasive furtive kind of man; that night at Chelsea too, for instance, was not there a Box of distinguished Cigars, whh told a strange story of you? For shame!— Where will that end? In fact, I know not what to say of it.

At the Athenm we were blackballed, as you perhaps know; lost by one ball,
it appears.Athenaeum Club rules stipulated that the election process was confidential and that the names of the voters were not included in the minutes; the rules also stated that “one blackball in ten shall exclude.” The date 12 Feb. is entered in the “Not Elected” column. A base envious Plebs delights here & there to squirt a drop of dirty water in the face of betters: never mind it; it is the nature of the beast, and of the time it lives in.

Jane accepts you for Tuesday; and will this day warn the Photograph people,Possibly either Watkins or Elliott & Fry; see JWC to BB, 27 Oct. 1865
.—indeed, is on the road thither at this moment. As to the Lectures,Ruskin’s lecture “War,” later published as the third part of The Crown of Wild Olive (1866), was delivered, 16 Feb., at the Royal Military Academy, Woolwich; see Ruskin’s Works 18:459–93. of whh the Program is abundtly seductive to us all, I had to prohibit her altogether: not to be thot of in such danger from cold. My Brother & I are extremely desirous; but even for us, such the distance, such the lateness of hour, I do not yet see any good possibility. The difficulty is not that of dinner in the least; but that [of] getting home by abt 11 p.m. If you saw a practicable course in that partic[ular] and sent us tickets & indicatns (pla [ce]
&c) I almost believe we, even the far lazier of us, wd lift anchor and try.

Fair befal you in all your enterprises furtive & other.John Ruskin noted in his journal in May: “May 23rd Wednesday. interlachen, shop-lifting all day; spoons &c” (The Diaries of John Ruskin (1848–1873), eds. Joan Evans and J. H. Whitehouse [1958] 2:588).

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 21 Feb. MS: NLS 518.22. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p:
My dear Sister,—You are very good to keep so steadily writing me yr weekly bulletin,Jean Aitken’s bulletin, 28 Jan., expressed her irritation with John A. Carlyle: “He was very provoking yesterday just before starting, considering how patient I have been with him. ‘I’m going to London next week’ he said ‘there are noises and other things that annoy me here I must get a house of my own & not plague any of my friends. I have been a most reasonable man all my life & given little trouble to anybody. You wd be more comfortable in a small house but I suppose you can sell this house at any time (If I shd withdraw my custom clearly implied) I said little or nothing. I believe he will be the better of the change. … / I feel that I should not have plagued you with all my troubles but I could not help it.” John apparently stayed with Jean at The Hill, Dumfries, from late May 1865 (apart from occasional trips away) and may have irritated from the beginning as TC mentioned, June 1865, that “by his fidgeting & nig-nagging [he] become[s] very troublesome. … Jeans Letter of this morning … will shew you the interior there” ( 42:61–62 TC to JWC, 5 June 1865
). oftenest with nothing but a symbolical return. Today I will write you an express word; seizing a little minute there is.

John was very good while here, poor fellow;John A. Carlyle stayed at 5 Cheyne Row, 7 Feb.–17 Feb., after visiting friends in Warrington, then visiting his stepson Henry Watt and his wife, Jane, in Liverpool; he wrote, 29 Jan., about Jane Watt: “She is a very solid & faithful little woman, daughter of John Hunter of Craigcrook, & I should go fully as much for her sake as Henry’s.” While in Liverpool he had also dined with JWC’s cousin Alick Welsh and his family. perceptibly more staid, more sad, than in former times; and cheering me continually with something of affectionate, of tacitly cordial,—in a style almost pathetic to me. Some things were not as I wished them; but he accepted all with perfectlyThus in MS. loyalty, and seemed to wish no better. Saturday last at 2 p.m. I escorted him to the rail for Dale Park;To visit his friends Elizabeth and John Charles Fletcher, Dale Park, Arundel, Sussex; see 41:61 TC to JAC, 6 Oct. 1864
. I have since written, and have this morning had ansr (very brief); whh I meant to inclose, but it has unlucky fallen aside, & become unattainable on need rising. “All well” (birds singing, people kind, long walks &c), and “coming back soon after Monday” this was the substance of it. I rather believe he will go to his Lodging (in Brompton) on returning,John A. Carlyle apparently went to Brompton Rd., as TC forwarded Erskine’s letter, 26 Feb., to him; see TC to JAC, [28 Feb.] . & perhaps stay till my Edinburgh time; but he has yet said nothing positive. No doubt, barring accidts, the Excursion will do him good.

I very well recollect the building of that Cottage as seen from yr old windows years ago.Cottage unidentified further; presumably visible from Jean’s previous home in Assembly St., Dumfries. It must be a neat little habitatn, I can guess; and for the Dr’s sake or for mine, you might take a little peep into it (in a very silent way), find out what price &c, and see what at length becomes of it. John, I see, wishes some place,—“near Dumfries” is the readiest notion, of course, tho’ of definite there is as usual nothing hitherto. I too shd like much some rural shelter, when London grows intolerable and the kind summer is abroad;—but fear often, such are the conditns, of se [r] vants Letter omitted. &c&c, I shall hardly get one worth my while. But by far the most promising outlook, both for him & me, seems to be that little Patch of Property where Aird now lives;Thomas Aird (1802–76; ODNB; see 6:361 TC to JAC, 29 March 1833
), poet and editor of the Dumfriesshire and Galloway Herald 1835 –63. TC had visited Aird’s home, Mountain Hall, 2 mi. (3 km.) S of Dumfries, in May 1865; see 42:38 TC to JWC, 24 May 1865
. a place inaccessible to railway ragings, a place of many qualities! With the utmost silence, but with all constancy and ingenuity, keep yr eyes on that, if it do soon come to be open to
purchase. I know not myself whether that is any way likely, but you will; and yr James is a wise man in such things.

We have very crude & uncomfortable weather; insignificant frost, most of it rime, whh goes up in frozen vapour, keeping the air always damp &c at the freezing point. Very cruel to aged skins. Nevertheless we hold out,—I lazy as lazy can be; & no prophecy yet of work. Blessings on you all.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, [28 Feb.]. MS: NLS 1768.137. Hitherto unpbd. Written on the reverse of Thomas Erskine’s letter, 26 Feb., which presumably arrived 27 Feb.; TC sent it to John A. Carlyle the next day.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p:
Come tonight if you can; I cannot (Fredk Elliott, an old acquaintance has undertaken to call; he is a gleg, intelligt, official man,Thomas Frederick Elliot (1808–80; ODNB; see 10:106 TC to JOST, [18 June 1838] ), civil servant, assistant under-secretary of state for the colonies 1847–68; son of Hugh Elliot (1752–1830; ODNB), diplomat, whose papers TC had used while writing Frederick; see 36:100 TC to LS, 19 April 1860
. whom you wdn’t dislike);—if you can’t tonight, then come tomorrow before 2, for I am engaged that night also!— Bring Erskine back, for I haven’t ansd him.Erskine wrote from 11 Great Stuart St., Edinburgh, 26 Feb.: “It is a long time since you have looked on my handwriting—longer than I like or approve—but I am getting old & blind— any thing which is beyond daily habit & experience appears difficult. I write now, not merely for the pleasure of being in communication with you, which on the present occasion has overcome the power of inertia—but also with the hope of securing a day of you when you come to meet your young College electors. … / I hope that Mrs Carlyle is better— I have been meditating a letter to her—to tell her about the Braids where I visited a little while ago— I have heard that the Doctor has gone to London—we have missed his friendly presence very much this winter.”

div3.sourceNote: JWC-FC, 2 March. MS: Armstrong Browning. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO FREDERIC CHAPMAN

docBody.p:
Oh I am sorry for you, dear Mr Chapman! I have not words to say how sorry!— It is such a loss!The Morning Post, 3 March, reported the death of Clara Chapman: “On the 28th ult., at Bournemouth, Clara, wife of F. Chapman, Esq., of 193 Piccadilly, and North Lodge, Teddington, aged twenty-three.” She probably died from complications following the loss of a child several weeks before, although John A. Carlyle wrote to Alexander Carlyle, 3 May, that she d. of consumption (Marrs 751). — I can appreciate it; for the beauty of Her
Character had made a deep impression on me. She was so sweet, and simple, and unselfish! And so fond of you! and so grateful to you! and so fond of her Life, for your sake!— All that will make her loss the more cruel to you, at first! But after a time, it will be your best comfort to recall how happy you made Her while she was with you,—poor Dear! I wish you had heard all she said to me about you, the last day I saw her,—the last I was ever to see her sweet pretty face on this Earth.

Only a few days ago I made up my mind that I would not accompany Mr C to Edinr at the end of this month. And the first use I proposed to make of my freedom should be to go down to Bournemouth for a day; just to see how she looked, and to tell Her how much I cared for Her! I wanted Her to know!— And now—!

When you can; do come and see me; either in the evening, or in the morning before twelve. I know I shall not have courage to go to seek you at Piccadilly! I think you sincerely for telling me the manner of her Death! It seems to have been gentle as was her Life!— I am glad for you, that your last impressions of Her will remain sweet as Herself, thro’ all the Future you may have to spend without her.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-HI, [ca. 3] March. MS: NLS 1797.112. Pbd: Simpsons 280–81. Quot: Hansons, NE 540; Ashton 441.
div3.head:
JWC
TO HENRY INGLIS

docBody.p:
Dear “Henry Inglis”! That
is the name I knew you by, and have remembered you by, for the third part of a Century! that, and no other!— Mr MassonDavid Masson. asked me some days ago; “Wasn’t Mr Inglis a friend of mine?”— “Mr Inglis”? I repeated after reflection; and in the truthfulest ignorance, “No! I don’t know any Mr Inglis!” “Are you sure”? said Masson; “Your Husband knows him very Well! He staid at his house when he was in Edinr last summer.”— “Oh! Henry Inglis
you mean? I exclaimed enthusiasticly! Oh yes! of course I know Henry Inglis! Why; He baptized my Horse!—broke a cigar over his nose, and named him Harry—after himself”For Harry the horse, acquired by JWC Nov. 1828, see 4:421 TC to JAC, 26 Nov. 1828
, and 432 TCJWC to HI, 11 Dec. 1828
; see also 5:47 TC to HI, 21 Dec. [1829]
.

Mr Masson looked as grave as tho’ I had suggested that his next own Baby should be baptized after that fashion! “a rather strange one,” he remarked!Inglis replied, 5 March: “you must have astonished Mr Masson, with whom I have met only twice; under circumstances quite foreign to any such theological liberties, as you ascribed to me in the Craigenputtoch era.”
Well! but about coming— Indeed I should like to be beside you, long enough to make your acquaintance again! And I am glad—very—of your invitation even tho’ it lead to nothing beyond!

The nearer we get to the end of March, the more I shudder at a journey of eight hundred miles (there and back) and a Speech for object! I am not so strong as when galloping “Harry” over the Moors! In fact I am now, what is pleasantly called “a Living Miracle!”Inglis wrote: “In my latest Will and testament, I shall leave your letter to the British Museum. … There is no doubt that you are a ‘living miracle.’— What, or who else, could have produced such a resurrection of the past; which now, however, that it is narrated, comes before me as if it had occurred yesterday.”— That is a woman who ought in the course of Nature to have been dead and buried; but has come alive again; for some purpose;—what? one does not see!— But surely it could not have been for the purpose of killing myself after all, by outrageous fatigues and agitations, wilfully encountered—to hear my own Husband Speak!!

I did not answer your letter by return of post; because there was still enough of indecision in my mind, to make me pause before committing myself to let Mr C go alone but the frost and snow of the last day or two have chilled my spirit of enterprise into one lump of ice!The Times, 2 March, reported snow and a temperature of 26°F (-3°C) on 1 March. Inglis wrote: “I am very sorry that you are not coming here; but cannot blame you for declining to face such a frosty pilgrimage.” And now I have no hesitation about staying at home; as the suitablest place for Living Miracles!Reginald Blunt later recalled JWC at this time: “Though I was only a boy of eight, I can well remember the Mrs Carlyle of those last months, white and frail, almost as a wraith, but very kind and gentle, as other children than I had found her. Particularly I recollect the evenings when Carlyle came to the Rectory and the arrival of long delicate ‘churchwardens’ from Edinburgh, with green waxed ends, always provided for his smoke; and the great marmalade making in February 1866, which Mrs Carlyle herself came over to superintend in our big stone-flagged kitchen, according to her own delicious, but very elaborate, recipe” (Blunt, CR 170). For JWC’s previous marmalade making, see 33:194 TC to JAC, 26 March 1858
.
So, you see; i am done with! And if you are the Henry Inglis I cared for; you will not forget to come and see me next time you are in London!

For Mr C; I dont think he has taken a single detail of his visit to Edinr into his head yet! any more than a single head of his ‘Address.’— When I ask him anything, he merely says; “for God’s sake, my Dear, leave all that dreadful business lying over till the time comes”!

Lord Lothian is not worse, only not better—after all the attempts at curing
him by electricity! If they get home in time, Mr C will stay there, having promised from the very first If not; he has invitations to David Masson’s, to David Laing’s, not, I think absolutely refused; but the man he will go to, I will confide to you privately, will not be the man he likes best, but the man who lies furthest away from—“Railway Whistles”!Inglis wrote: “I still hope that Carlyle may prefer his old quarters at Torsonce; whence the railway whistle is far distant, and very occasional.” TC had stayed with Inglis at Torsonce House, Stow, 11–14 Aug. 1865; see 42:188 TC to JWC, 14 Aug. 1865
.
Most likely he will write himself and tell you all about it, when he has a plan—

div3.sourceNote: JWC-GLC, 4 March. MS: Strouse. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head:
JWC
TO GEORGE LILLIE CRAIK

docBody.p:
My dear, ever dear Friend!
MaryMary Craik. has transmitted your message,Presumably about Craik suffering a stroke in Feb.; he d. 25 June. which moved me to the very bottom of my heart!— I thank you for it, with a thankfulness too deep for words. And I thank you for being the good, brave man that you are! I am proud of my old friend, as well as grieved for Him and anxious about Him! And oh! I am pleased, to receive this assurance that he remains as affectionate for me amidst his own suffering and danger, as he showed himself, when the suffering and danger were mine!

I know, by experience, how illness, enough to bring one face to face with Death—to surround one as with an atmosphere of Death—how it tests the truth and strength of one’s sentiments! It is like living in a “Castle of Truth”Stéphanie Félicité Ducrest de Saint-Aubin (1746–1830), comtesse de Genlis, “The Palace of Truth,” Les Veillées du Château (Maestricht, 1784), included in Tales of the Castle, trans. Thomas Holcroft (1785) 5:129–261, describing a castle in which the inhabitants are obliged to speak the truth; see also 32:35 JWC to MR, [28 Nov. 1856] .— All one’s make-believe friendships are turned from with disgust; and the few real ones cleaved to with a passionate trust. So did I in my terrible trouble, cleave to You, when I asked you for your little Mary; sure that you would have taught her to care for me.For JWC’s earlier gratitude expressed to Craik for Mary Craik’s help, see 40:128 JWC to GLC, [9 July 1864] . and now You, in your sore trouble, send me that dear, loving message! God grant that we may yet talk over our experiences and sympathies!— There is no impossibility!— The Drs give good hopes!
And I am always recollecting about my Uncle in Liverpool,JWC’s maternal uncle, John Welsh. who had an attack precisely similar to this of yours, some fourteen years before he died; which required him, indeed, to live more carefully, and to be less diligent at his Counting House ever after, but, for the rest, did not destroy the health of either his body or mind.

When I read the account of your seizure, received from Dinah,Dinah Mulock Craik, m. to Craik’s nephew, George Lillie Craik. to my Cousin MaggieJohn Welsh’s da. Maggie Welsh. who is in London at present; She exclaimed fervently: “Oh Cousin! Isn’t that so like the way Papa was! and He got well!” I am not naturally hopeful; but somehow I feel we shall meet again! God grant it; And try,—You,—to believe it! at least try to hope it too! I need not say that Mr C is very anxious for more news.

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lord H [RMM], 10 March. MS: Trinity. Quot: Kaplan 463.
div3.head: TC TO LORD HOUGHTON

docBody.p: I think it will be serviceable, as certainly it will be pleasantest than any other thing of the sort can be, to stop a day or two at good old Fryston as I go northward. Days I have not fixed,—except that probably I ought to be in Edinr on the Friday Evg “previous” (Friday, 29 March, i.e.), whh may mean something like Wedny or Tuesday for Fryston. I am told no quick train nd Northward. stops at Knottingley;Knottingley, small station nr. Fryston, Yorkshire; the nearest main line station was PonteǨ, 3½ mi. (5.5 km.) from Knottingley. but doubtless you know how to manage that.

My Wife I find will be only too willing to come; but she stipulates for the clause “weather permitting,” as is nevertheless necessary to a strict degree. As fellow-guest yr BishopPossibly either Lord Houghton’s close friend Connop Thirlwall (1797–1875; ODNB), historian and bishop of St. David’s, or Samuel Wilberforce (1805–73; ODNB), bishop of Oxford; neither TC nor Lord Houghton mention a bishop being one of the guests while TC was at Fryston. is among the welcomest discoverable now in the world.
With best regards to Lady Houghton,

postscript.p:
n.b. I believe I am to stay with Thomas Erskine in Edinr Erskine was staying at 11 Gt. Stuart St. in the New Town of Edinburgh; he wrote, 26 Feb.: “I hope you will name a day, when you will dine with us, & I shall endeavor to collect a few friends who will thank me for bringing them in contact with you.” TC apparently replied 1 March, as Erskine’s sister Christian Stirling wrote, 3 March: “We were very glad to hear of you yesterday. … I have consulted my brother about offering you a room here if you will accept of one and he approves of me telling you what we have to offer” (see JWC to DA, 15 March
). She continued: “It would be a great pleasure to my brother & also to my self to have you with us,—and we would insist on having quietness secured for you, if you should feel unable to see visitors.” (shrunk out of railway noises &c&c),—and that the Wife will certainly not go farther north than Yorkshire.

div3.sourceNote: TC-WDC, [12 March]. MS: Strouse. Hitherto unpbd. TC noted: “recd 12 March . / T. Carlyle” at the top of the first page of George Scharf’s letter, 10 March; TC’s note to Christie was written on the reverse of Scharf’s letter. William Dougal Christie (1816–74; ODNB; see TC to WDC, [26 Feb. 1840], and TC to WDC, 2 June 1863 ), retired diplomat and author.
div3.head: TC TO WILLIAM DOUGAL CHRISTIE

docBody.p: Dear Christie,—I duly sent yr remonstrance upon DrydenChristie was preparing an edn. of the poetry of John Dryden (1631–1700; ODNB), poet, playwright, and critic, pbd. 1870; he had apparently written to TC about the National Portrait Gallery’s portrait of Dryden. to the proper Officer:George Scharf (1820–95; ODNB), sec. of the National Portrait Gallery. he has been to Wardr Strt A portrait of Dryden was presumably being sold by an art dealer in Wardour Street, Soho. in consequence;— the result, you see, is mere zero, as often enough happens.Scharf wrote: “Our small Dryden is only a stop-gap till we get a larger & more important picture. … I have just been to Wardour St. & looked at the picture mentioned in Mr. Christie’s letter. I had seen it before. It is not larger than our N.P.G. picture; not so old and, as a work of art, I would not desire to possess it.”

I have not myself any knowledge of the Affairs of Grt George Street;The National Portrait Gallery was at 29 Great George St., Westminster. having hardly been there once for the last 7 years, and indeed never above 3 or 4 times since my nominatn to that sublime office.TC was appointed a trustee of the National Portrait Gallery March 1857; see 32:100 TC to LA, 9 March 1857
.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-[JD] [JAD], 12 March. MS: NLS 1797.110. Quot: Hansons, NE 537; Ashton 442.
div3.head: JWC TO [JANE DODS]

docBody.p:
1000 thanks!— For it could be nobody but you, who sent me the newspaper with a “notice” of Mr Taits Picture!Robert Scott Tait’s painting A Chelsea Interior (1857–58; see 33:196–97 JWC to MR, 29 March [1858]
) was exhibited at the 40th exhibition of the Royal Scottish Academy, which opened in Edinburgh, 17 Feb. The “notice” is untraced. Robert Scott Tait (1816–97), portrait painter and photographer; see 41:237 41:biographical notes . There was the Haddington postmark; and if the handwriting wasn’t yours, whose else could it be?— I should say, the Critic had more knowledge of rhetoric than of art! and he has made a great, almost unpardonable omission, in failing to point out the Dog The painting included JWC’s dog, Nero. A reviewer in the Scotsman, 6 March, noted: “The minute detail of photography is equalled if not surpassed in the picture of ‘A Chelsea Interior in 1858’, by Robert Tait … containing portraits of Carlyle the celebrated historian, and his wife, in their own sanctum. The astonishing minuteness and high finish of this work, and its absolute truth, is a thing to be wondered at, and in the present case may be excused, from the interest which surrounds everything connected with a name so celebrated. But otherwise such an expenditure of time and talent on cabinetmaking and upholstery would seem to be a misapplication of art.” For Ruskin’s critique of the painting before completion, see 33:120 JWC to MR, [19 Nov. 1858] .—“thinking”!—thinking to most purpose of the three, it strikes me! Could anybody look in that dear little quadruped’s face; without seeing that he was thinking all this nonsense of keeping him motionless on a sofa-cushion,For the detail of Nero and his sofa cushion, see 33:235 TC to TWO, [3 June 1858] . to be painted, a great bore! and I’ll be hanged if either Mr C or I were thinking anything more profound!For JWC, see 33:17 TC to JAC, 11 Aug. 1857
; for TC, see 33:174 TC to JAC, 28 Jan. 1858
.

I was about writing to you at any rate; to tell you that the second of April (what luck it couldn’t be the first!) had been fixed for that weary “address,” which Mr C looks forward to with more horror than many a man feels at being hanged! And now it is so near, I have taken such fright at the eight hundred miles of railway (there and back), and at the fuss and ferment of the whole thing, that I have decided to stay at Home!— I dare say I shall get enough of it, and more than enough out of the newspapers!
But I hold you to your invitation! and when I am in Edinr,—under more auspicious circumstances,—(I do hope to be, before I die) I shall remind you of it!

I wonder if you will write to me some day? I miss poor Jackie WelshJWC’s cousin John Amelia “Jackie” Welsh who had d. 28 March 1864. who used to give me regular news of you all: always ending with assurance that “she was happy to say her Aunt and Mother were “in their frail ordinar”!Coterie speech; see 39:107 JWC to MR, [12 April 1863] . I
myself am in better than my ‘frail ordinar’ this winter. I have not been a day confined to the house, except for the two days of the snow storm, and these on my horse’s account, not on my own! and I have been to such a many dinner parties! Mr C said this morning “really my Dear I think it is time you drew bridle in this Career of Dissipation you have entered on!” But it helps me to— —sleep!

Give my kindest regards to Mrs David Davidson,—Janet Davidson; see JWC to JAD, 22 Jan.
to William Dods give—a box in the ear! He deserves nothing else—never taking the least notice of me more than if I didn’t exist, or had grown disagreeable old woman! old I am certainly! but—disagreeable? certainly not!
God bless him anyhow and you!

div3.sourceNote: TC-JSM, 13 March. Addr: House of Commons [scored through] / “Blackheath Park / Lewisham / SE” [added in another hand]. TC initialed the bottom left corner of the envelope. PM: London, 13 March 1866. MS: NLS 618.217. Pbd: A. Carlyle, CMSB 185–86.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN STUART MILL

docBody.p: Dr Löwe, a German political gentn of some eminence,Wilhelm Löwe (1814–86), German physician and liberal politician. whom I don’t myself know, but who is very favourably spoken of by others whom I trust,—desirous to translate, for behoof of his countrymen, yr Essay on Representative Govt;John Stuart Mill, Essay on Representative Government (1861). and applies to me, thro’ a Count ReichenbachCount Oskar von Reichenbach. a very estimable person, to ask in his name, If you will please to consent to that operatn?

Löwe was at one time Presidt of what they called the Frankfurt Parlt (where this Reichenbach sat as his colleague, and got ruined by the operantn); for years after that, Löwe too was an Exile in England, then in America; but has made matters good agn (witht any ratting or baseness, it wd seem), and is now agn a Prussian M.P.Löwe was elected vice-president of the Frankfurt parliament, 1848, and president of the radical Stuttgart rump parliament, 1849; he was then forced into exile; returning to Germany, 1861, he was elected to the Prussian House of Deputies, 1863. and even an Official of some kind,—Official and Journalist, “of superior credit,” and do talent, in both capacities, say the testimonies worthy of belief. My Wife, who used to see Löwe in society,JWC mentioned, 1853, having met Wilhelm Löwe; see 28:22 JWC to KS, [28 Jan. 1853] . considered him a solid honourable character, marked by ardour at once & by strength of intellect
& good sense:—in short I have practically little or no doubt but yr Book will be very well translated if you see good to proceed upon it.

For the rest, shd you incline otherwise for any reason, please to understand that I have no interest or wish abt it whatever, being myself totally a stranger, as above said; and that I will report yr No with perfect frankness, shd yr Yes (whh I can hardly anticipate) fail to be the answer.Mill replied, 11 April: “My answer to your note respecting Dr Löwe has been delayed by the necessity of finding time to rummage old papers in order to ascertain whether an impression I had of having already consented to a similar proposal from some other quarter, was well founded or not. I now find that in December 1861 I gave my assent to a translation of my book … by a Dr F. A. Wille who like Dr Löwe, had been engaged in the political events of 1848. … Dr Wille then informed me that his translation was partly printed & I am almost sure that it was published in the course of the following year.” François Arnold Wille (1811–96), Swiss-French editor, journalist, and translator; Betrachtungen über Repräsentativverfassung. Aus dem Englischen von F. A. Wille (Zurich and Stuttgart, 1862). If permitted, Dr Le himself will of course write to you before starting. I believe there is no pecuniary ever got or offered in these cases; but if one secure a goodish translatn instead of a bad, that too is something.

My Wife, who urges upon me the writing of this Note, and declares it will not be a trouble to you, bids me send her best regards, and testify her lively remembrance of old days, & the pleasure it wd give her to see you agn.Mill wrote: “Please thank Mrs Carlyle for her remembrance of me. I have been sorry to hear a rather poor account of her health.” In all whh you need not doubt but I, in my own way, cooperate with emphasis.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-DA, 15 March. MS: EUL. Pbd: Ritchie 326–28; Bliss, JWC 328–29. Quot: Hansons, NE 539.
div3.head:
JWC
TO DAVID AITKEN

docBody.p: Your kind letter made our Breakfast this morning quite pleasant! And, in cases of bad sleepers, it takes a good deal to do that; as you may perhaps know!

It was indeed a most agreeable surprise, to receive such a friendly letter from you and Eliza!Eliza Stodart Aitken; the Carlyles’ last recorded contact with the Aitkens was in 1858; see 34:33 JWC to TC, [11 July 1858] . The more shame to——which of us that it should have surprised as well as pleased? But there is no time to go into that, at the present writing!
That we cannot, either or both of us accept your friendly invitation, so cordially given, makes no difference in our gratification at receiving it.

Mr C has already engaged himself, it seem to me to five different places!! and lastly and most particularly to our old Friend Thomas Erskine. What reason he (Mr C) has for believing that he will be safer from railway whistles (!) in Mr Erskine’s house, than in any other in Edinr or about it, I really dont know, but that does seem to be the consideration which is directing his choice!TC was presumably influenced by Christian Stirling’s detailed description, 3 March, of possible rooms for him in 11 Gt. Stuart St.: “There is a very good small room unoccupied on the bed room floor: but it looks to the street which is very noisy, being a thoroughfare, both for carts, & carriages.— In the attic there is a very good room to the back—overlooking gardens, and with a view of the Fife hills—this room is high up, there being 71 Steps of Stairs between it & the dining room:—but, in it you could have plenty of air & tolerable quietness— We could also give you a sitting room on the same side of the house entirely to yourself.”
“What the eye sees not / the heart grieves not!”Proverbial.
So I mean to keep at a safe distance.

My kind love to Eliza whom I hope to see some day tho’ not just now. How I should like a long long talk with her about “dear old long ago”!Coterie speech; see 36:166 JWC to LST, 8 [9] Aug. [1860]
. What would she think of asking me in the warm weather? I am not bad at travelling now, in ordinary circumstances! indeed I have been better last winter
than for many preceding ones, tho—I couldn’t go to Miss RichardsonsPossibly Catherine Richardson, known to JBW (and probably to Eliza Stodart) in Haddington before they married; Richardson m., 1823, David Sherriff, lt. in the Bengal Lancers; see 2:279 JBW to EA, [21 Jan. 1823] ; otherwise unidentified. evening parties!

closer.salute: Yours affly with thanks and kind regards from Mr C

div3.sourceNote: TC-DL, 15 March. MS: EUL., Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO DAVID LAING

docBody.p: The Newspaper was quite sufficient on that occasion; and I pretty well guessed from what source it had come.Laing wrote, 14 March: “I delayed writing in answer to your last, in case anything requiring a special report should occur at the Meeting of the UC—but the Newspaper sent seemed to contain all that was requisite.”

April 2d is to be my day; I ought to arrive, I suppose, abt Friday or Saturday, 29 or 30 March,—and to make the briefest stay that will be handsomely possible.Laing wrote: “it is now all but officially stated, [the rectorial address] is to come off on Monday the 2d of April. On the previous Thursday we are to have a Public Fast for the Cattle Plague; and on the Good Friday I think there is no Railway travelling in England.” As to lodging,—with many kind thanks to hospitable friendly Portobello,Laing wrote: “I should like therefore to know your plans, taking it for granted that Portobello is to be your head-quarters.” and reference of it to a better time whh we hope is coming,—I find I must, at prest, reckon myself due to the Erskines of Linlathen (11. Grt Stuart Street), who promise to keep me very quiet &c&c, and are among the oldest friends I have in the world. As to Newbattle, there has been for many weeks, as you say, no questn:—Ld Lothian does not seem to be worse than usual; but I judge that they will not leave Town for a while yet, and that probably they will then go to NorfolkThe Lothians’ estate at Blickling Hall. before returning to Scotland.— My Wife dare not come with me in this inclement temperature; there was talk of her going to a place in Yorkshire,Fryston; see TC to RMM, 10 March
. & there waiting my return; but I privately rather think she will not stir from home at all. You are to offer many kind respects & hearty acknowledgts to the Lady of yr House for her gracious intentns,Laing wrote that his sister, Euphemia Laing, “also longs to hear that Mrs. C is to accompany you.” —
whh are not forgotten, nor likely to be, by either of us, tho’ this time they do not take effect.

I shd consider myself abundantly able to “read” the Address, if by good luck I had it, or any part of it, written:Laing wrote: “Then again as to the Address itself, if there was any chance of your self being able to read it … it may be a piece of impertinence on my part, to suggest you having it transcribed in a legible hand, or even printed before hand.” but, alas, that is not the case at all; and I fear I must depend on extempore speaking TC noted in May when writing his reminiscences of JWC: “as to Edinburgh, she said one day, ‘You are to speak extempore’ (this she more than once clearly advised, and with sound insight)” (Carlyle, Reminiscences 187–88). (taliter qualiter [for better or worse]),—whh can be all the briefer, if it succeed even worse than I expect! One way or other such a thing can be got thro’; and does not deserve beyond a certn quantity of botheratn from a poor old invalid like me.

I am busy on yr Dunbar, The Poems of William Dunbar, with Notes and a Memoir of his Life, ed. David Laing, 2 vols. (Edinburgh, 1834; supplement 1865). of late days; a most faithfully edited Book, tho’ the Glossary is now & then defective. That is a curious Letter indeed, that Spanish one abt James IV!Laing quoted from a letter written by the Spanish ambassador, Don Pedro de Ayala, to the king and queen of Castille, 25 July 1498, describing James IV (1473–1513; ODNB), king of Scotland, in glowing terms (Poems of William Dunbar 1:266–71). Froude has promised to get me, from Bergenroth,Laing quoted the letter from Calendar of Spanish Letters, Despatches, and State Papers Relating to the Negotiations Between England and Spain Preserved in the Archives at Simancas and Elsewhere, ed. G. A. Bergenroth (1862); Gustav Adolph Bergenroth (1813–69; ODNB), historian. the Spanish Copy in extenso [at length]; in whh, if he succeed, you shall certainly share.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady A [LAI], [16 March]. MS: NLS 20767.70. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO LADY AIRLIE

docBody.p: I am vexed that you can’t come tomorrow evening; for on Monday we are engaged.

Couldnt you bring your old ClergymanPossibly Rev. Robert Inglis (1803–76), minister of the Free Church of Scotland, Edzell, Synod of Angus and Mearns, 1843–76, near the Airlie estate at Cortachy Castle; he was a leading figure in the 1843 disruption of the Church of Scotland (see 16:28 TC to MAC, 20 Jan. 1843
) and an agricultural reformer; otherwise unidentified. in the morning any day—and I would show him Mr Carlyle.

I am ashamed of my mistake! I had got it in my head it was Monday I was to be at Watts’s,Possibly George Frederic Watts (1817–1904; ODNB), painter and sculptor, living at Little Holland House, Kensington; otherwise unidentified. before twelve. D V [Deo Volente: God willing] I shall not fail on Tuesday. But as Venables remarked; “there are two DsGod and the devil; George Stovin Venables was often credited by JWC with the joke; see 30:248 JWC’s Journal, 27 April 1856
.— So, if I don’t appear in time you will understand the wrong one has willed!

My little dog“Tiny,” bequeathed to JWC by Clara Chapman; John A. Carlyle wrote to his brother Alexander, 3 May: “A small terrier, left to her care by … Mrs Chapman who died latterly” (Marrs 751). is turning out all that could be wished. I have introduced her to Miss Bromley’s SparkFor a photograph of “Spark” taken in 1863, see 39:201 JWC to LLA, [22 Sept. 1863] . and he fell in love with her on the spot.

div3.sourceNote:
JWC-MO, [17] March. MS: NLS 23210. Hitherto unpbd. Dated by JWC’s decision not to go to Scotland with TC; see TC to DL, 15 March
.
div3.head:
JWC
TO MARGARET OLIPHANT

docBody.p: I wonder if it would be convenient that I should go and see youMargaret Oliphant moved, late 1865, from northern France to 6 Clarence Cres., Windsor. some day in Mr C’s absence (for I have decided to not accompany him)

I should have to stay all night you see! and if you are up to the ears in work—as I think is likelyOliphant was presumably working either on the closing chapters of Miss Marjoribanks, serially pbd. Blackwood’s Edinburgh Magazine, Feb.–Dec. 1865 and Feb.–May 1866, or on Madonna, serially pbd. Good Words, Jan.–Dec. 1866. it might bore you to have so much of me!
Tell the truth like the dear little woman you are!

signed.name: Jane CarlyleOliphant described a visit to the Carlyles around this time in a letter to her friend Jane Tulloch: “I spent an evening last week all alone with Thomas Carlyle and his wife. She has had a dreadful illness and looks like a weird shadow, not quite canny, but nothing could be kinder or nicer than both of them. She has to drive three hours every day, and has got a little brougham in which she performs that penance, making the best of it by driving her friends about. As for True Thomas himself, he expounded the Schleswig-Holstein business to me from a few hundred years before the beginning of it, to his wife’s intense horror. But notwithstanding this dull choice of a subject his talk is delightful” (Oliphant, Autobiography and Letters 207–8).

div3.sourceNote: TC-UC, 18 March. MS: NLS Acc. 9936. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO AN UNIDENTIFIED CORRESPONDENT

docBody.p:
Your Brother’s Paper is in the hands of Professor Masson, or of some of his subordinates; under examinatn for admittance into Macmillan’s Magazine;Although recently appointed prof. of rhetoric and English literature at Edinburgh Univ. (see TC to JAC, 28 [27] Nov. 1865
), David Masson continued editing Macmillan’s Magazine until 1868. with promises to be returned to you in case it is found unsuitable. I judged that to be the briefest way of coming at the essence of yr question, and giving you a practical instead of verbal ansr.

Mr Masson got the Paper from my own hand abt three weeks ago;Masson was in London late Feb.; see JWC to HI, [ca. 3] March
. if you have become, or shall become, impatt for an answer before the slow Editorial incubatn is spontaneously complete,—Professor Masson’s Address is,
“3 Roseberry Terrace / Edinburgh”;—and I believe the Paper is not corporeally there but in London.
My Brother, who perfectly remembers meeting you, is in London, for the prest week and part of next; his address 174. Brompton Road, Brompton.
In very great haste /

div3.sourceNote: TC-PK, 21 March. Copy: Edinburgh Univ. Senatus Minutes (1865–69) 131.
div3.head: TC TO PHILIP KELLAND

docBody.p: Dear Sir, I am infinitely obliged to the Senatus Academicus for this new mark of their favour,Kelland wrote, 17 March: “I am instructed by the Senatus Academicus to inform you that at their meeting this day they unanimously resolved to confer on you the Degree of LL.D.” TC wrote on Kelland’s envelope: “Profr Kelland: Doctorate (was refused, 21 March 1866).” so conspicuously honourable to me;—and shall have to add it in permanence to my pleasant recollection of their manifold and continual kindness ever since we came in contact.

The offer made, on such terms, from such a quarter, is one which no highest man need hesitate to accept, and to me surely it is a possession for the rest of my life: nevertheless I should say on consideration, I should say (if I might
without suspicion of unthankfulness, disrespect or affectation which are all very far from me on this matter) that I could wish it not to go farther, but to remain for me in that altogether pure condition. A feeling I have that there is something of incongruous between my past history and this new Dignity; that I have a Brother, an Edinr M.D. who would hereby cease to be “the Doctor” in our circle, after 30 or 40 years possession; that I should never know myself, or be at home in this dignity (even tho’ I kept it secret);—that, in short, this deliberate unanimous resolution of the Senatus is a great and signal favour, which I never shall forget, and which would not be enhanced, but the contrary, by going into actual fulfilment. Such accordingly is that practical decision I have had to form.

Have the goodness to indicate all this for me, to the Senatus, in the most respectful terms that can be chosen, and to say that I demand as another act of their kindness a generous interpretation of what is written here.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Mrs. S [MRSS], [23 March]. MS: Yale. Hitherto unpbd. Mrs. and Mr. Simpson are unidentified further. Dated by TC’s imminent departure, 28 March.
div3.head: JWC TO MRS. SIMPSON

docBody.p: I found your note on the breakfast table this morning, but was told it had lain in the letter-box all night, the Postman having failed to ring. So please excuse the hours lost in answering.

I am so sorry to have to decline your pleasant invitation. But Mr C will be starting for Fryston (the first stage on his road to Edinr) that very day or the day following. In no humour even now, already for dining, or doing anything but committing suicide!
I am sure many a man, with a good thick skin, has gone to be hanged more comfortable in his mind, than Mr C goes to make that tiresome Address

postscript.p: P S Mr C was greatly taken with your Husband I haven’t heard him say as many pretty things of any stranger for a long time

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lord H [RMM], [25 March]. MS: Trinity. Pbd: Reid, RMM 2:145–46; Simpsons 282–83 inc.
div3.head: JWC TO LORD HOUGHTON

docBody.p: I have been out in far worse winds than yesterday’s; since I came to depend on my drives for sleep! And I am not afraid of the journey to Fryston, nor of bodily fatigue, generally. For you see I am what is pleasantly called “A Living Miracle”! meaning—a woman who, according to Nature, should have been dead and buried away, two years ago, and is here still, going about in society alive and well! (To be sure both the aliveness and the wellness “may be strongly doubted,”Coterie speech; see 7:35 JWC to JCA, [ca. 18 Nov. 1833] . as they say in Edinr!)

What I am afraid of, and what has determined me against accompanying Mr C, on this “accursed adventure” (I don’t mean the Fryston part of it!) is the agitation that was getting hold of me about his agitation! I had visions of his breaking down in his “Address”! of his lying ill with fuss and dinners! of his going to wreck and ruin in every possible way! And I unable to do anything, now, for his furtherance, but just to take the terrible pain in my back which assails me under all violent emotion In intervals of good sense I perceived that my only chance of escaping an illness was to cut myself loose from him, till “the accursed affair” was over. “What the Eye sees not, the Heart grieves not!” When he is gone, out of my sight, I shall calm down! But if I should prolong the nervousness of these days, going with Him and the others to Fryston; I should get no good of Fryston, and risk a spell of illness— I want to go to Fryston (it would be the first time remember) in a state of mind that would not interfere with my enjoyment of it.

Mr C says he “cannot give me any advice—will not take the responsibility of my going; but if I dont think it wise to go with him now; I may say that I will come in the summer weather if you like and bring him along with me!” Will you let me come later? And will you believe how much I should like it in my normal state and how much I—like you
Lady Houghton too has written to me so kindly

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady H [LH], [25 March]. MS: Trinity. Pbd: Reid, RMM 2:146–47.
div3.head: JWC TO LADY HOUGHTON

docBody.p: You are kind, to write me a letter “all to myself” (as the Children say) about coming with Mr C to Fryston!— More than kind! it strikes me as almost heroic, to take graciously to the Bore of an extraneous Individual in one’s House; when one has just had a bad illness, and is still feeling ill.

I am afraid, however, that all in admiring your sweet nature, I should not have been unselfish enough to keep away, in the fear of being tiresome! Had not other quite selfish fears decided me to stay at home—while my Husband is away seeking—not a golden fleeceIn Greek mythology, Jason’s quest for the golden fleece was to reclaim his rightful kingdom. (it is to be feared.
I leave it to Ld Houghton to explain my ridiculous reasons and also to convey to you my hope that you will ask me another time—when we are all better!

div3.sourceNote: TC-JC, 26 March. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JAMES CARLYLE

docBody.p: Dear Jamie,— I shall hope to get a little glimpse of John & you, this day week:At his rectorial inauguration, 2 April. it is quite touching to me to think of yr coming to be prest in such a strange & vacant hurlyburly,—very strange to myself even!

But in any case I do trust to be down at Scotsbrig in a few days after the noise,—there to be left entirely alone, while I try to gather myself agn! Jean will come out from Dumfries (Mary I fancy being busy) & Cathne Mary’s da. Catherine Austin, housekeeper at Scotsbrig. & she will hold me up what they can.—— N.b. a screen round the foot of the bed: James knows the way to manage that,—and indeed I think it wd be permanently useful, and not diffict, with the aid of the Smith,Probably William Tait (b. ca. 1794) or his son, also William (b. ca. 1836), blacksmiths, 33 High St., Ecclefechan. in a good time!— John, I dimly guess, will go direct for Edinr from here.

div3.sourceNote: TC-MDC [MCON], 26 March. MS: Columbia. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO MONCURE D. CONWAY

docBody.p: Admit Mr M. D. Conway to the Rector’s Installatn Address, at Edinr, April 2.

postscript.p: (Chelsea 26 March 1866 )

div3.sourceNote: TC-AJS [AJSY], 26 March. MS: John Wilson, Oxford. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO A. J. SYMINGTON

docBody.p: Admit Mr Symington to the Rector’s Installatn Address, at Edinr, April 2.

postscript.p: (Chelsea, 26 March, 1866

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MC [MCR], 26 March. Addr: Chlorine Place / Belfast / Ireland. PM: London, 26 March 1866. MS: Strouse. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY CRAIK

docBody.p:
I have not been able to get out to Mrs CraikDinah Mulock Craik; see JWC to GLC, 4 March
. The Craiks were perhaps already living in Bromley, Kent, 10 mi. (16 km.) SE of Chelsea; they had a house built there, 1869. for news of you, all the last week. I have been so occupied with things to be written and done, preparatory to Mr C’s journey to Edinr—on his novel and hateful business of speech-making! I have not however been without news of your Father—less direct—coming indeed round by Edinr, to Arthur Helps.Arthur Helps (1813–75; ODNB), public servant and author; friend of the Carlyles since the early 1840s. You would be quite pleased with Arthur Helps, if you heard how he speaks of your Father! I don’t know if he have written to him; but I am very sure he has taken his illness to heart more than many who would have filled pages with words about it! He is the least demonstrative of men but faithful and kind—to the heart’s core! I think!

There!—I never sit down to write a letter I am wishful to write, but the Public bursts in! I have just had four Ladies here, and, two are here still—will stay till the carriage comes to take me for my drive—

(Mrs Alice Macmillan and her Sister)Caroline and Frances Macmillan; other two ladies unidentified. JWC may have intended to write “Mrs Alex” as Caroline’s husband was the publisher Alexander Macmillan. When I come in it is after our Chelsea Post time—
But better to send this evidence of a “good intention” than put off and off. And end perhaps in not writing at all
God bless you my Dear!

Give him my love and constant remembrance! I cannot write to himself with the fear of saying somehow the wrong thing before my eyes always! I never could write to direction in my life! that is to other direction than my own sense of fitness— When he is stronger, and can stand anything it comes in my head—or rather in my heart to say, I will be a good correspondent

div3.sourceNote: JWC-AW, GW, and EW [AGEW], [26 March]. Addr: Craigen villa / Morning side / Edinr. PM: London, 27 March 1866. MS: NLS 609.763. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:311–13; Bliss, JWC 329–30. Quot: Simpsons 283–84. The envelope was addressed only to “Miss Anne Welsh”; TC later wrote in blue pencil on it: “(1866,—within 4 weeks: ah me!)”; and on the back of the letter: “(1866; probably the last!).”
div3.head:
JWC
TO ANN, GRACE, AND ELIZABETH WELSH

docBody.p: It is long since I have written; and I have not leisure for a satisfactory letter even now. But I want you to have these two admissions in good time, in case you desire to hear poor Mr C’s Address, and dont know how to manage it. If you dont care about it or cant for any other reason use the admissions or either of them; please return them to me forthwith. For the thing comes off this day week and there is a great demand for them.

Mr C was too modest when asked by the University people how many admissions he wished reserved for himself and required only twenty for men, and six for women—or, as I suppose, they would say in Edinr—‘Ladies’! Four have been given away to Ladies who have shown him great kindness at one time or other. and the two left he sends to you in preference to some dozen other Ladies who have applied for them directly or indirectly—so you see the propriety of my request to have one or both returned if you are prevented from using them yourselves.

I am afraid and he himself is certain; his address will be a sad break-down to Human expectation! He has had no practice in Public Speaking—hating it with all his heart! And then he does Speak—does not merely read or repeat from memory a composition elaborately prepared—in fact, as in the case of his predecessor printed before it was “delivered”!!William Ewart Gladstone; see TC to JAC, 7 Nov.

I wish him well thro’ it, for I am very fearful the worry and flurry of the
thing will make him ill. After speculating all winter about going myself; my heart failed me as the time drew near, and I realized more clearly the nervousness and pain in my Back that so much fuss was sure to bring on— I did not dread the bodily fatigue but the mental. We were to have broken the journey into two by stopping a few days at Lord Houghtons in Yorkshire and after giving up Edinr I thought for a while I would still go as far as the Houghtons, and wait there till Mr C returned. But that part of the business I also decided against, only two days since! preferring to reserve Yorkshire till summer, and till I was in a more tranquil frame of mind.

Mr C is going to stay while in Edinr at Thomas Erskine’s, our dear old friend—not however because of liking him better than anyone else there, but because of his being most out of the way of—railway whistles!! It was worthwhile however to have talked of accompanying Mr C, to have given so much enthusiastic hospitality an opportunity for displaying itself! One of the letters of invitation I had quite pleasantly surprised me by its warmth and eagerness; being from a quarter where I hardly believed myself remembered—David Aitken and Eliza Stodart!— They had both grown into sticks I was thinking!
But I have no time to gossip—

Do send me soon some word of Robert“Her dying cousin” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:311); see also JWC to GW, 23 Jan.
—tho’ I know too well there no good news can come

div3.sourceNote:
TC-Dr. H [DRH], 27 March. MS: Hilles. Hitherto unpbd. Probably Dr. Jacob Hunter, physician, friend of John A. Carlyle; see
JWC to IC, [28 Aug. 1854].
div3.head: TC TO DR. HUNTER

docBody.p: Admit Dr Hunter to the Rector’s Installatn Address, at Edinr, April 2.

postscript.p: (Chelsea, 27 March 1866)

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TE, 28 March. Addr: 11 Gt Stuart Street / Edinburgh. PM: London, 28 March. MS: privately owned. Hitherto unpbd. Thomas Erskine noted “Mrs Carlyle’s last” on the envelope.
div3.head: JWC TO THOMAS ERSKINE

docBody.p: I want you to do something for me; which I know you will do willingly, as it is a kind action.

I want BettyBetty Braid. to be let see Mr Carlyle in some way, when in Edinr.
