He is sure to be kept in a whirl of things, all the time, which might prevent him, of himself, getting out to Greenend to see her. And it would be a grievous disappointment to the dear Soul, should he come and go, and she not so much as shake hands with him! And she will have had some disappointment already, in my failing to fulfil the expectation, I had stupidly raised in her, of seeing myself on “this (what Mr C calls) lamentable occasion.”

I might have written to her (without troubling you) to call at your House, and inquire for Mr C; but she might have happened to come at exactly the wrong moment—when he was out or engaged, and so have had her journey in vain. I at this distance couldn’t appoint a time for her. But you can, and will—won’t you?—or you might settle with Mr C to go with you to her cottage. He would with you; tho he mightn’t, have force of Will to go the unknown road by himself.Betty and Alexander Braid lived in Upper Stenhouse, S Edinburgh; see 37:157 JWC to MO, [29 April 1861] . Erskine replied, 3 April: “I hope to take him out to Betty’s tomorrow or next day.”
You will manage it for me as you see best.

Mr C started this morning for Fryston Hall, with Professor Tyndal, who will take care of him with the tenderness of a—Mother!Tyndall later wrote: “After many talks with him and his wife [about the journey], the simplest and safest solution of the difficulty seemed to be that I should take charge of him myself” (Tyndall, “Personal Recollections” 11–12). I once thought of going with them so far, and staying with Lady Houghton till their return. But the same reasons that had made me give up the thought of Edinr have kept me from Fryston also.

div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p:
I think the Postman had not rung, or had not been heard this morning! for four notes were found in the box “quite promiscuously”Coterie speech; see 10:72 TCJWC to JCA, 1 May 1838
. at twelve o’clock.
One of thanks from the Barlow moor manWilliam Henry Doeg; see TC to [WHD], 23 Jan.
One of ditto from Masson for your kindness in being to dine with them on the 5 of April—
third is an extract the value of which I cannot estimate; but it may serve you to amuse Ld Houghton with—and perhaps you may think the politeness worth a word of answer—

Fourth is on University business—JWC enclosed a letter of 27 March: “By direction of the Principal, a Meeting of the University Court will be held in the Court Room, on Tuesday next, the 3rd of April at twelve o’clock. / J. Christison / Secretary.” It was headed: “N.B. Observe change of hour.”

It is only one oclock and you seem to have been gone two days instead of two hours.TC wrote, 7 May (misdating the departure Thurs., 29 March): “about nine a.m., all was ready here (she softly regulating and forwarding, as her wont was); and Professor Tyndall, full of good spirits, appeared with a cab for King’s Cross Station,—Fryston Hall to be our lodging till Saturday and Edinburgh. I was in the saddest sickly mood, full of gloom and misery, but striving to hide it; she too looked very pale and ill, but seemed intent only on forgetting nothing that could further me. A little flask, holding perhaps two glasses, of fine brandy, she brought me as a thought of her own:—I did keep a little drop of that brandy (hers, such was a superstition I had), and mixed it in a tumbler of water in that wild scene of the Address,—and afterwards told her I had done so; thank Heaven that I remembered that in one of my hurried Notes. The last I saw of her was as she stood with her back to the Parlour-door to bid me her good-bye. She kissed me twice (she me once, I her a second time)” (Carlyle, Reminiscences 188). Tyndall also later described the parting: “I drove to Cheyne Row, and found him punctually ready at the appointed hour. On a table in a small back parlour below-stairs stood a ‘siphon,’ protected by wickerwork. Carlyle was conservative in habit, and in his old age he held on to the brown brandy which was in vogue in his young days. Into a tumbler Mrs. Carlyle poured a moderate quantity of this brandy, and filled it up with the foaming water from the siphon. He drank it off, and they kissed each other—for the last time. At the door she suddenly said to me, ‘For God’s sake send me one line by telegraph when all is over.’ This said, and the promise given, we drove away” (Tyndall, “Personal Recollections” 12).

Here has been Woolner for an hour!This is possibly the visit about which Woolner wrote to Lady Ashburton, late April or early May, on the occasion of visiting TC after JWC’s death: “The last I saw of her was a bright kind smile while passing thro’ the door to go away, one morning I called after Carlyle had gone to Scotland; how much more often I should have seen her had I thought of losing her so soon”; see Appendix 263. come to beg an admission for the man who had ordered the marble bust of you!The purchaser of another copy of Woolner’s marble bust of TC (currently on exhibition at the Royal Scottish Academy in Edinburgh) not further identified. Alice Woolner wrote to Lady Ashburton, 24 Feb.: “As Mr Carlyle is now the Lord Rector of the University it is very possible the Edinburgh people may wish to have the bust. This is only a conjecture of friends in Edinburgh but should it prove true and in the event of their being unwilling to wait till a new marble bust could be carved for them Tom bid me ask you if they might have your copy. He will anyhow carve another for himself and should you be long away from England would probably have done it by your return, but this of course will be just as you please and if you at all dislike the idea you will tell him so” (MS: NLS Acc. 11388). told him “how you were situated”Coterie speech; see 24:115 JWC to JAC, [11 July 1849] .

div3.sourceNote: MW-TC, 28 [29] March. Address: Fryston Hall / Ferry Bridge / Yorkshire. PM: London, 30 March 1866. MS: NLS 609.766. Hitherto unpbd. Maggie Welsh dated “Wednesday” in error; she wrote Thurs. 29 March, the day after TC left. JWC addressed the envelope, on which TC later wrote: “inside by Maggie ‘Wedy’ 28 March 1866 (the day I went away”; and “5a, by Magie Welsh.”
div3.head: MARGARET WELSH TO TC

docBody.p:
Cousin has asked me to write a few lines to you for her. She bids me say, that it is really only that she is very wearied that is preventing her writing herself. She quite hopes to have some good sleep tonight, & to be able to write you comfortably tomorrow. Last night as you would she feels sure imagine she had no sleep, & even the morphia which she took after a while failed of its, of late, usual good effect. She was obliged to go out early this forenoon, on a very sad errand. Last evening she heard through Mrs Ashurst,Bessie Ashurst, Emilie Venturi’s sister-in-law, wife of William Henry Ashurst (1819–79), solicitor; see 36:17 JWC to LAI, [28 November or 5 December 1859] . Madame Venturi’s sister of the death of poor Major Venturi which had happened yesterday morningThe Times reported, 5 April: “On the 27th March, at the house of Herbert Taylor, Esq., Wimbledon-common, Carlo Francesco Venturi, of Avio, Trentino, Italy, aged 36.” For Herbert Taylor, see JWC-TC, 30 March
. Venturi d. early on the morning of 28 March. quite suddenly. Cousin went to enquire about his poor wife today,
but has not seen her yet. Cousin bids me also ask you to thank Mr TyndalTyndall presumably wrote to JWC on arrival at Fryston, 28 March; he also wrote, [29 March]; see JWC to TC, 30 March
. very much for his letter which was most welcome.

Little “Kleine”TC later wrote on the letter: “‘Kleine’ (formerly called ‘Tiny’); that was the fatal little vermin of a Dog!” The dog was left to JWC by Clara Chapman; see JWC to LLA, [16 March] . After JWC’s death, TC blamed the dog for her death (see TC to JCA, 28 April
). sends her remembrances. She slept as quietly as a little mouse at home last night!
With kind love dear Mr Carlyle

postscript.p:
I only came from St Leonards yesterday,Maggie was staying in London with Agnes Baird; see JWC to TC, 30 March
. I am very glad to find Cousin looking well excepting being tired this evening.
Many thanks for so kindly remembering Walter.Maggie’s brother Rev. Walter Welsh, who was presumably sent one of the admittance cards for the rectorial address.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [30 March]. Address: care of Thomas Erskine Esq / 11 Gt Stuart Street / Edinburgh. PM: London, 30 March 1866. MS: NLS 609.765. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:314–16. Quot: Bliss, JWC 331.
div3.head:
JWC
TO TC

docBody.p:
Dearest
—what with your being on the road, and what with the regulations of Good Friday,Postal regulations. I dont know when this will reach you! Indeed I dont know anything about anything! I feel quite stupified!

I should have liked to have seen your own handwriting this morning, tho’ none the less obliged to Mr Tyndall, who makes the best of your having had a bad night.Tyndall wrote, [29 March]: “We are still here— He did not sleep over well last night. … We have ridden hard for three hours today— he is to have his dinner at 5½ instead of 7½. He is also to abstain from strong teas so that I hope to send you a bright report tomorrow.” What a dear warm-hearted Darling he is! I should like to kiss him! I did
sleep some, last night, the first wink since the night before you left! Last evening I felt quite smashed, so willingly availed myself of the feeble pen of Maggie“Maggie Welsh” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:314). See above. who had walked in “quite promiscuous.” She was back at Agnes
Baird’sAgnes Baird, an old friend of the Welsh family, possibly living at 50 Weymouth St., Portland Place; Maggie Welsh often stayed with her when in London; see 33:224 JWC to MR, [ca. 16 May 1856] , and 38:99 JWC to MR, [5 June 1862] . and had fixed to leave for LiverpoolTo visit her brother Alexander (Alick). on Saturday. For decency’s sake, I asked her to come here instead, and stay over Sunday. which she agreed to do. She will be company to James.“Aitken, now attempting business in the City” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:314). Jean Carlyle Aitken wrote to TC, 28 Jan.: “James came home to us on Thursday. … He had exhausted every chance of employment in Liverpool before deciding to leave finally. … His only plan at present seems to be—to stay here a little while and then go up to London & try to establish himself in some small office of his own as a Commission Agent in the Shipping way— It is a thing he is thoroughly at home in now after his Liverpool experience. Glasgow London & all has been in that line. Several friends in Liverpool have promised to do business with him if he shd think of beginning in that line. We are all rather inclined to think this a likely thing for him to try especially as it takes very little capital to make a beginning with— He says he knows a man in London who made a start in that line with £50 & is doing well.” He
didnt come back to sleep last night! having accepted an invitation from somebody (Mr George?)Unidentified. at Islington, with whom he was going to spend good friday out of town somewhere. He had “not quite” concluded about his office—“all but”John A. Carlyle wrote to Alexander Carlyle, 12 April: “Young James Aitken has taken an office in the central part of London, and is going to try to get business as a Shipbroker” (Marrs 749).—had failed in all attempts to find a Lodging; but this Mr George “would help him in looking,” he thought. I pressed him to keep his bed here, till he was suited, but he “would be nearer his office at Mr George’s.” He is to come on Sunday morning however to spend the day, and I promised to take him to Richmond Park or somewhere before dinner. At parting for the present, he tried to make a good little speech about “my kindness to him”— Pity he is so dreadfully inarticulate! for his meaning is modest and affectionate poor fellow!

The sudden intimation of Venturi’s death, sleepless as I was at the time, stunned me for the rest of the day like a blow on the head! He was taken ill in the night at the house of Herbert Taylor,“John Mill’s stepson-in-law” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:314). Herbert and Annie Taylor lived at Wimbledon Common. but would not allow his wife to raise anyone or to make the least disturbance and at five in the morning he was dead! There was an examination which satisfied the Drs he had died of heart-disease and that he must have been suffering a great deal; while de MusseyProbably Henri Gueneau de Mussy (1814–92), French doctor living in exile in London; he lived at 4 Cavendish Pl. and other Drs of his acquaintance had treated any complaint of illness he
made as “imaginary.” “The result of his unsatisfactory life”! Poor Emily is as you may imagine “like death.”Bessie Ashurst wrote to JWC, 30 March: “I went to see Emilie yesterday and I found her very bad more than the day before. She had had no sleep and had constantly three or four times gone into poor Carlo’s room. She comes to stop with us tomorrow after all is over at Highgate. I cannot tell you how I dread it. / I would rather see her dead than in such misery.” The Ashursts had a family plot in Highgate Cemetery.
Mr Ashurst was trying to prevent a Corner’s Inquest but he feared it would have [to] be—today.
Goodby— Keep up your heart—the first three minutes and after that—it will be all plain sailing

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 30 March. Addr: 5. Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Pontefract, 30 March 1866. MS: NLS 617.733. Quot: Froude, Carlyle 4:301–2.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p:
Dearest mine,—You got a very bad Letter yestr from the Professor; & I wrote none myself, lest it shd have been worse. Today, however, that is all changed, and I can send you good news,—thank Heaven! In fact my first night here, owing to railway and other noises all thro’, not to speak of excitatns, talkings dinnering &c, was totally sleepless;—a night of wandering, starting to (vain) tobacco, and utter misery;—and little wanted but that in the morning, I had been off, post-haste, for York & Edinr direct; uncertain Edinr too, & some wild hope of finding a noiseless bed at Auchtertool on the second night after taking wing! But all this, by my own reflexion & everybody’s kindness, was wisely overruled. I breakfasted with beautiful judiciousness, by myself, a simple egg-tea (coffee not to be relied on) and dry toast just as at home; rode 14 miles with Tyndall (horses wd gallop instead of walk, as I meant);Tyndall later wrote: “In due time we reached Freystone [Fryston], where the warmest of welcomes greeted Carlyle. … Railways had multiplied; they clasped Freystone as in a ring, and their whistles were energetically active all night. I feared the result, and my fears were only too well grounded. In the morning I found Carlyle in his bedroom, wild with his sufferings. He had not slept a wink. It ought to be noted that the day previous he had dined two or three hours later than was his wont, and had engaged in a vigorous discussion after dinner. Looking at me despairingly, he said, ‘I can stay no longer at Freystone, another such night would kill me.’… I spoke to Lord Houghton, who, though sorely disappointed, agreed that it was best to allow his guest complete freedom of action. It was accordingly arranged that we should push on to Edinburgh. … As he breakfasted our projects were discussed. Once, after a pause, he exclaimed, ‘How ungrateful it is on my part, after so much kindness, to quit Freystone in this fashion.’ Taking prompt advantage of this moment of relenting, I said, ‘Do not quit it, but stay. We will take a pair of horses and gallop over the country for five or six hours. When you return you shall have a dinner like what you are accustomed to at home, and I will take care that there shall be no discussions afterwards.’ He laughed, which was a good sign. / The animal bestrode by Carlyle was a large bony grey, with a terribly hard mouth. He seemed disposed to bolt, and obviously required a strong wrist to rein him in. Carlyle was no longer young: paralysis agitans had enfeebled his right hand—for some time my anxiety was great. But after sundry imprecations and strenuous backward pulls, the horse was at length clearly mastered by its rider, and we fleetly sped along” (Tyndall, “Personal Recollections” 12–13). dined
by myself strictly à la Warren;As provided by Mrs. Warren, the Carlyles’ cook. lay down there on my not too quiet sofa; and, by Heaven’s blessing, had for the first time an hour & half of real sleep. Continued retirement &cbrot me to pillow agn (having done the civils from the distance); & shortly after midnight I fell sound asleep, sound till abt 6 a.m., & two after hours added to boot! So that today I am a new man;Tyndall continued: “At six o’clock his simple dinner was set before him, and he was warned against discussion. … I accompanied him to his bedroom, every chink and fissure of which had been closed to stop out both light and sound. ‘I have no hope of sleep,’ he said, ‘and I will come to your room at seven in the morning.’ My reply was, ‘I think you will sleep, and if so, I will come to your room instead of your coming to mine.’… At seven o’clock, accordingly, I stood at his door. There was no sound. Returning at eight, I found the same dead silence. At nine, hearing a rustle, I opened his door and found him dressing. The change from the previous evening was astonishing. Never before or afterwards did I see Carlyle’s countenance glow with such happiness. It was seraphic. … He looked at me with boundless blessedness in his eyes and voice. ‘My dear friend, I am a totally new man; I have slept nine hours without once awaking.’ That night’s rest proved the prelude and guarantee of his subsequent triumph at Edinburgh” (Tyndall, “Personal Recollections” 13–14). & by agn riding, agn &c&c, hope to arrive in Edinr better not worse than at startg, and get thro’ my paltry busss in some tolerably harmless way. HuxleyThomas Henry Huxley; he was to be awarded an LL.D. on the same occasion as TC’s rectorial address; Thomas Erskine was also to be awarded an LL.D. came yesterday: we are to start abt 9 a.m. (that, at least is what I shd like), and arrive in Edinr 4½ p.m.; failing that, we shd go at noon, have to dine in York abt 2, & not get to Edinr till 8½ (say 9) p.m. Courage, Dearest; all will go right! Only let me have at “11. Great Stuart Street” a little bulletin (favourable) from thyself), & all is safe so far.

This place is beautiful in the spring sun, in the fine seclusion; & everybody is intent to be good & kind:—all considered, however, it was perhaps better for you not to come! As well quiet at home among yr own old objects & intimates. We are not to be called an interesting society;The other visitors at Fryston included James Kitson (1835–1911; ODNB), Leeds locomotive manufacturer and politician; Count Adolphe de Circourt (1801–79), diplomat, scholar, traveler, and journalist; John Ferguson McLennan (1827–81; ODNB), social anthropologist; and Thomas Hirst (1830–92; ODNB), mathematician. It was presumably Kitson who recalled “the almost ferocious way in which, turning upon him as though he were the incarnation of the guilt of which he had to complain, Carlyle said, ‘They tell me, sir, that the people of Leeds have set up a roaring blast furnace in the middle of the ruins of Kirkstall Abbey; is that so or is it not?’ Even the assurance that the outrage of which he spoke had not been committed hardly sufficed to calm his temper, and that first evening at Fryston was one of somewhat mingled experiences. But a good night’s rest made Carlyle a different creature. Next morning he was tolerant, amiable and good-natured to everybody” (Reid, RMM 2:148). and the House &
neighbd are rather noisy.—— Tyndall’s conduct to me has been loyalty’s own self; no adoring son cd have more faithfully watched a decrepit Father:—in fact I shall not forget it.
But here they all are, back from “Church service” so-called;—and I will abruptly close. God keep my own poor little Schatz [darling] for me; & send us soon into contact agn!—

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 30 March. Addr: Miss Orrock’s / 73. George Street / Edinburgh. PM: Pontefract, 30 March 1866. MS: NLS 526.38. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head:
TC
TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Tyndall sent you a doleful enough Letter yesterday; but thank Heaven I can send you a very difft one today!

In fact Yesterday morning, after a night of more misery (railway trains every ¼ of an hour, and not one wink of sleep had), I was within an inch of starting at once for York, in the passionate hope of catching you there, & speeding on to Edinr & finis,—tho’ what you cd have done for me there was so very uncertn!—

But instead Tyndall strengthened my hands in the course I preferred of vigorous riding, of strict dieting, absolute seclusion; & the consequence I have got back my sleep,—am all myself agn; resolute still for another ride & a strict day;—and hope to join you tomorrow in better case than you cd have hoped. Pray Heaven it be so.

What our train is I cannot yet absolutely learn,—owing to genl defect of BradshawRailway timetable. Science here:—but the course I will strive for is, To leave Castleford (say 4 miles “down” from this) abt 9 a.m. (or perhaps it is leaving this at 9?) whh brings us, it wd seem, to Edinr abt 4½ p.m.,—in the way recommended by his Lp Lord Houghton.
yesterday. But everybody is out, or just coming home from Church; & I can’t say.— Failing this plan, we may be looked for (Huxley, Tyl & I) by the Mail train 8½ p.m.— Tyndall, if I can manage, will, before 6 (post-
hour[)] this evg, announce whh is the hour really fixed on. I shall look out for yr face. Anounce me at Grt Stuart St

signed.name: T. CarlyleThomas Erskine wrote to David and Eliza Aitken, 30 March, inviting them for Mon. 2 April, “to meet your friend Mr. Carlyle” (Ritchie 327).

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MO, [31 March]. Addr: Windsor. PM: Windsor, 1 April. MS: NLS 23210, envelope only; most of the address and the London postmark are torn off. The letter presumably told Oliphant that JWC intended to visit 5 April; see JWC to MO, [4 April] .
div3.head: JWC TO MARGARET OLIPHANT

docBody.p: [Letter untraced]

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 1 April. Addr: 5. Gt Cheyne Row, Chelsea / London. PM: 1 April 1866. MS: NLS 617.732. Pbd: Bliss, TC 383–84.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Dearest, Oh my Dearest,—You see how my hand is going;TC’s writing is particularly shaky. I will write you one word,—among so many for others.

I have been terribly off for sleep; agn quite lost (night before yesterday), such a day yesterdy with Milnes escorting to York &c&c:—safe arrival here, however, & (thank God) sleep agn almost miraculously recovered; so that I hope to get over tomorrow comfortably after all, and not “in the horrors,” as I feared. Fear nothing; I really don’t fear or care.
Better have given £50 than gone by Milnes’s; won’t agn: but that is all safe behind me.

Am sitting here (fine back drawing room, with all &c) in absolute seclusn (wd not even see Tyndall who called);Tyndall wrote later: “Carlyle was lodged in the house of his gentle and devoted friend, Erskine of Linlathen. He was placed as far from the noises of the street, in other words as near the roof, as possible. I saw him occasionally in his skyey dormitory, where, though his sleep did not reach the perfection once attained at Freystone, it was never wholly bad” (Tyndall, “Personal Recollections” 14). reading my Notes: intend a long walk tho’ it rains. Bedroom is silent absolutely as that at Chelsea; I had been lost otherwise. ButlerProbably Mr. Cairns; see TC to TE, 17 April
. &c, all the servants (not to mentn both the Hosts)Thomas Erskine and his sister Christian Stirling; she wrote to John A. Carlyle, 23 March: “As the time approaches for your Brother’s visit to Edinburgh—my thoughts turn to how I can make him comfortable in regard to outward things while he is with us.— I know you will be happy to help me & I therefore write to you to ask what refreshment would suit him best after his journey?— I suppose he will arrive late, so what sort of supper would he like? or would Tea & a fresh egg suit him better? Then would he like to be allowed to break fast in his own room? & does he take Tea or Coffee, or what?— Please mention any thing that will conduce your Brother’s comfort; and dont be afraid of putting us out of our way.— I always break fast in bed, & my brother’s break fast is merely nominal, a cup of Cocoa & seldom even a morsel to eat” (MS: NLS Acc. 9086). are humanly devoted to me. Will out & walk; keep as silent as maybe, all day long.
How welcome, last night, yr bit of Autogrh after Maggie’s Quodlibet [whatsoever pleases] bad tidings. Thank Heaven, you are tasting sleep agn: ah me!—— Poor Venturi, what a tragedy.
Adieu, Dearest; be patt,—the good loaf takes baking.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, 2 April. Addr: 11 Gt Stuart Street / T Erskine Esq / Edinburgh. PM: London, 2 April 1866. MS: NLS 609.767. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:316–17; Bliss, JWC 331–32; Simpsons 285. Quot: Hansons, NE 541–52; Ashton 442; Fielding and Sorensen 310–11.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: By the time you get this, you will be out of your trouble, better or worse,—but out of it, please God! And if ever you let yourself be led or driven into such a horrid thing again, I will never forgive you! never!

What I have been suffering, vicariously, of late days, is not to be told! If you had been to be hanged, I don’t see that I could have taken it more to heart! This morning, after about two hours of off-and-on sleep, I awoke—long before daylight—to sleep no more! While drinking a glass of wine and eating a biscuit at five in the morning; it came into my mind what is He doing, I wonder, at this moment? and then instead of picturing you sitting smoking, up the stranger chimney, or anything else that was likely to be; I found myself always dropping off into details of a regular execution! now they will be telling him it is time! now they will be pinioning his arms! and saying last words! Oh mercy! was I dreaming or waking? was I mad or sane?— Upon my word I hardly know now!— Only that I have been having next to no sleep all the week—and that at the best of times I have a too “fertile Imagination,” like “oor David”!“A lying boy at Haddington, whom his mother excused in that way” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:317).

When the thing is over I shall be content—however it have gone, as to making a good “appearance” or a bad one! That you have made your “address” and are alive—that is what I long to hear, and please God shall hear in a few
hours! My “Imagination” has gone the length of representing you getting up to speak before an awful crowd of people; and what with fuss and “bad air” and confusion dropping down dead!— Why on Earth did you ever get into this galley!For TC’s previous use of the metaphor of galley slave to describe his feeling of being chained to work on Frederick, see 38:67 TC to WA, 3 March 1862
.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [3 April]. Addr: 11 Gt Stuart Street / Edinburgh. PM: London, 3 April 1866. MS: NLS 609.769. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:317–19; Bliss, JWC 332–33; Simpsons 286. Quot: Ireland, JWC 302; Wilson, Carlyle 6:54–55; Hansons, NE 543; Fielding and Sorensen 311–12.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: I made so sure of a letter this morning—from some of you! And “nothing but a double letter for Miss Welsh!”

Perhaps I should, that is, ought to have contented myself with Tyndall’s adorable Telegram,John Tyndall’s telegram, “A perfect triumph,” was sent from the telegraph office nearest to the Music Hall, George St., where the address was given; see TC to JWC, 3 April
. which reached me at Cheyne Row five minutes after six last evening! Considering the sensation it made!—

Mrs Warren and Maggie were helping to dress me for Forster’s Birth-day when the Telegraph Boy gave his double knock— “There it is!” I said. “I am afraid cousin, it is only the Postman” said Maggie. Jessie rushed up with the Telegram. I tore it open and read “from John Tyndall (Oh God bless John Tyndall in this world and the next!) to Mrs Carlyle “A perfect triumph”— I read it to myself and then read it aloud to the gaping chorus, and chorus all began to dance and clap their hands— “Eh Mr Carlyle! Eh Hear to that” cried Jessie. “I told you Mam! cried Mrs Warren; I told you how it would be!” “Im so glad, Cousin! you’ll be all right now Cousin!” twittered Maggie, executing a sort of leap-frog round me. And they went on clapping their hands, till there arose among them a sudden cry for—Brandy! “Get her some Brandy”! “do Mam swallow this spoonful of Brandy!—just a spoonful”! For you see the sudden solution of the nervous tension with which I had been holding in my anxieties for days nay weeks past, threw me into as pretty a little fit of hysterics as you ever saw.

I went to Forsters nevertheless with my Telegram in my handJohn Forster’s 55th birthday dinner; he later recalled JWC’s buoyant mood that evening: “Tyndall had told her of the triumph just before dinner. She came to us flourishing the telegram in her hand, and the radiance of her enjoyment of it was upon her all night. Among other things she gave Dickens the subject for a novel, from what she had herself observed at the outside of a house in her street; of which the various incidents were drawn from the condition of its blinds and curtains, the costumes visible at its windows, the cabs at its door, its visitors admitted or rejected, its articles of furniture delivered or carried away; and the subtle serious humour of it all, the truth in trifling bits of character, and the gradual progress into a half romantic interest, had enchanted the skilled novelist. She was well into the second volume of her small romance before she left, being as far as her observation then had taken her; but in a few days exciting incidents were expected, the denouement could not be far off, and Dickens was to have it when they met again” (Forster, Dickens 3:277). JWC was presumably basing her narrative on observations of her neighbors, 6 Cheyne Row: “It is a house full of Misteries No 6! I have thoughts of writing a novel about it” (JWC to Mary Russell, 25 Dec. 1865). and “John
Tyndall” in the core of my heart! And it was pleasant to see with what hearty good will all there, Dickens, Wilkie Collins,Wilkie Collins (1824–89; ODNB), writer. as well as Fuzz, received the news. and we drank your health with great glee! Maggie came in the evening and Fuzz in his joy over you sent out a glass of Brandy to Silvester!! Poor Silvester by the by showed as much glad emotion as anybody on my telling him you had got well thro’ it!

Did you remember Craik’s paperA copy of the rectorial address for Craik. I am going to take Maggie to the Railway for LiverpoolEuston station. I suppose I shall now calm down and get sleep again—by degrees I am smashed for the present

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 3 April. Addr: 5. Cheyne Row, Chelsea / London. PM: Edinburgh, 3 April 1866. MS: NLS 617.734. Pbd: Bliss, TC 386–87.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p:
Dearest,—Thank God all is tolerably over here; the work of this day included (all but a College Dinner, at 7 p.m.,“Sir David Brewster was requested on the part of the Senatus to invite Mr Carlyle to dine with the Senatus on Tuesday 3d April” (Senatus Minutes, 17 March; [1865–69] 129). sorrow on it!) So that you may fairly go to sleep agn; as I hope the next little note will tell me you have done: the note of this morng was very kind, but very distressing withal. You may depend on it, all is finished, rather well then, and infinitely better than I often expected. You never saw such a tempest of enthusiastic excitatn as that among the student people,—poor young souls, following me thro the streets with their vivats & vociferatns Tyndall later recalled: “The eventful day came, and we assembled in the ante-room of the hall in which the address was to be delivered—Carlyle in his rector’s robe, Huxley, Ramsay [Andrew Crombie Ramsay (1814–91; ODNB), geologist], Erskine, and myself in more sober gowns. We were all four to be doctored. The great man of the occasion had declined the honour, pleading humorously that in heaven there might be some confusion between him and his brother John, if they both bore the title of doctor. … Carlyle stood up, threw off his robe … and in his carefully-brushed brown morning coat came forward to the table. With nervous fingers he grasped the leaf, and stooping over it looked earnestly down upon the audience. ‘They tell me,’ he said, ‘that I ought to have written this address, and of deference to the counsel I tried to do so, once, twice, thrice. But what I wrote was only fit for the fire, and to the fire it was compendiously committed. You must therefore listen to and accept what I say to you as coming straight from the heart.’ He began, and the world already knows what he said. … For an hour and a half he held them spellbound, and when he ended the emotion previously pent up burst forth in a roar of acclamation. With a joyful heart and clear conscience I could redeem my promise to Mrs. Carlyle. From the nearest telegraph office I sent her a despatch of three words: ‘A perfect triumph,’ and returned towards the hall. Noticing a commotion in the street, I came up with the crowd. It was no street brawl, it was not the settlement of a quarrel, but a consensus of acclamation—cheers and ‘bravos,’ and a general shieing of caps into the air! Looking ahead I saw two venerable old men walking slowly arm-in-arm in advance of the crowd. They were Carlyle and Erskine. The rector’s audience had turned out to do honour to their hero. Nothing in the whole ceremony affected Carlyle so deeply as this display of fervour in the open air” (Tyndall, “Personal Recollections” 15–16). For the full text of the rectorial address, see Carlyle, Works 29:449–82. (till I got shelter in John’s Lodging, having appointed to find
JamieTheir brother James Carlyle; John A. Carlyle’s lodgings were at the Misses Orrock, 73 George St., Edinburgh. there, whh I did): in the finis, there came a tone into their cheering, whh for a moment actually entered my heart, with a strange feeling made up of joy & sorrow. Poor young fellows, you too will have woes & toils, & perhaps worse!—

The report, they tell me this morning, is actually very good: you had Tyndall’s telegraph yesternight; and today I have sent you a Scotsman (whh keep);The Scotsman, 3 April, pbd. a long report of the address; see JWC to TC, 4 April
. —as for myself I bargained with John & ConwayMoncure Conway. that I wd not read any report, nor hear any remark upon the matter,—at least till I got as far as Scotsbrig, safe out of all this. But I have reason to know the thing went actually not amiss;—whh is abundtly enough for me.

figure.p: Thomas Carlyle’s Installation as Lord Rector of the University of Edinburgh

docBody.p:
The tumult was prodigious: never in this world was I in such a scene.For the drawing of TC giving his address pbd. by the Illustrated London News, 14 April, see 158 above. I took yr drop of brandy with me; mixed it a tumbler for cooling of the tongue: I had privately a kind of threap the brandy shd be yours. DodsWilliam Dods. found me just as I was taking refuge into John’s: many kind things abt you as we clomb the stair (Peter Swan there too, with an &c)Patrick Don Swan (1808–89), known to family and friends as Peter, provost of Kirkcaldy 1860–86; see 10:154 TC to JWC, 26 Aug. 1838
. The “&c” is unidentified. Hy DavidsonHenry Davidson. has left a card this morn
morning;Word repeated at turn of page with a line over it; TC also wrote “2)” in the top left-hand corner.—as have yr Aunts,JWC’s paternal aunts Ann, Elizabeth, and Grace Welsh. & a dozen others. Ah me!— But I mean to cut for Scotsbrig as soon as I have got my 3 dinners done (one already, not of the 3, was here last night, only think of it,—David Aitken, Wm Stirling &c:John Campbell Shairp (1819–85; ODNB) later described the evening: “Many will still remember the wise and gracious courtesy with which [Erskine] then performed the duties of hospitality, on the one hand securing for his guest the repose he needed and desired, on the other according to as many as possible the coveted privilege of meeting the sage of Chelsea. On the day on which Mr. Carlyle addressed the students in the large Music Hall, Mr. Erskine, knowing how great was the effort for a retired man of Mr. Carlyle’s years, and anxious how he might feel after it was over, had asked no one to dinner for that day. When the address was well achieved, and Mr. Erskine found that Mr. Carlyle was none the worse, but rather the better for the deliverance, he asked two or three of his intimate friends to come and join a quiet dinner-party. That evening Sir William Stirling Maxwell sat at the foot of the table, and with nice tact gave such turn to the conversation as allowed fullest scope to the sage who has praised silence so well, but fortunately does not practise it. Released from his burden, Mr. Carlyle was in excellent spirits, and discoursed in his most genial mood of his old Dumfriesshire remembrances, of the fate of James IV., and other matters of Scottish history, and of the then Emperor Napoleon, of whom, as may be imagined, he was no admirer” (J. C. Shairp, “Reminiscence of Thomas Erskine,” Letters of Thomas Erskine of Linlathen, ed. William Hanna [Edinburgh, 1877] 2:373–74). Erskine had apparently already invited David and Eliza Aitken, 30 March (Ritchie 327). and one’s sleep considerably broken by that!)—

Everybody is kindness itself to me; & I have now (this day) presided the University CourtSee JWC to TC, [28 March] . one time;— therewith as I calculate finished off all the real business this sublime promotn will ever cause me. Courage, Dearest; & take to sleeping agn: all will be right. I have still a great deal of walking to do,— must run out at once. Adieu, Adieu

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [4 April]. Addr: 11 Gt Stuart Street / Edinr. PM: London, 4 April 1866. NLS: MS 609.771. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:319–22; Bliss, JWC 333–34 inc. Quot: Hansons, NE 543; Simpsons 287–88; Fielding and Sorensen 312–13. TC wrote later on MS, next to the address and date: “I well remember getting this (better than some of the others), & reading it by the road, on the cold morning, and walked for heat after bathing.”
div3.head:
JWC
TO TC

docBody.p: The letter I had from Tyndall yesterday might have satisfied any ordinary man—or woman; you would have said. But I dont pretend to be an ordinary man—or woman I am perfectly extraordinary; especially in the power I possess of fretting and worrying myself into one fever after another, without any cause to speak of!

What do you suppose I am worrying about now, because of the Scotsman having not come? That there may be in it something about your having fallen ill—which you wished me not to see! This I am capable of fancying at moments; tho’ last evening I saw a manAlexander Macmillan. who had seen you “smoking very quietly at Masson’s,”Prof. David Masson. and had heard your speech, and, what was more to the purpose, (his semiarticulateness taken into account) brought me what he said was as good an account of it as any he could give,—already in the Pallmall Gazette written by a hearty admirer of long standing, evidently.Moncure Conway also wrote the introductory note to the address report in the Pall Mall Gazette, 3 April: “I have never heard a speech of whose more remarkable qualities so few can be conveyed on paper. You will read of ‘applause’ and ‘laughter,’ but you will little realize the eloquent blood flaming up the speaker’s cheek, the kindling of his eye, or the inexpressible voice and look when the drolleries were coming out. When he spoke of clap-trap books exciting astonishment ‘in the minds of foolish persons,’ the evident halting at the words ‘fools,’ and the smoothing of his hair, as if he must be decorous, which preceded the change to ‘foolish persons,’ were exceedingly comical. As for the flaming bursts they took shape in grand tones, whose impression was made deeper, not by raising, but by lowering the voice. Your correspondent here declares that he should hold it worth his coming all the way from London in the rain in the Sunday night train were it only to have heard Carlyle say, ‘There is a nobler ambition than the gaining of all California, or the getting of all the suffrages that are on the planet just now!’” For the drawing of TC giving the address, see 158. It was so kind of Macmillan to come to me—before he had slept. He had gone in the morning straight from the Railway to his Shop & Work— He seemed still under the Emotion of the Thing Tears starting to his black eyes every time he mentioned any moving part!!—

Now just look at that! If here isn’t—at half after eleven when nobody looks for the Edinr post—your letter—two newspapers, and letters from my Aunt Anne Thomas Erskine,Thomas Erskine wrote, 3 April: “Your husband did his work yesterday like a good & wise man— as we had a very small party of friends at dinner I think he got over the day; with the least possible amount of trouble / I am sure, it will be a great relief to you to know that he is this morning tolerably well, although he has not yet quite got back his regular sleep. / I have not seen the Doctor this morning—but if I find that he has not sent you the Scotsman newspaper, I shall send you one. It gives a fair & just idea of the effect & the character of the address. There was something in it to my mind most touching— As he looked on these young people entering on their wonderful career—he could not but feel the deepest compassion—especially as their reception of himself was so full of enthusiasm— I hope to take him out to Betty’s tomorrow or next day—he cannot go today—as he has to go through some of the ceremonial of his office [presiding over the University Court] . … he is a thorough Scotchman & likes this town & his old memories of it— / With true love paternal & fraternal.” David Aitken besides.
I have only as yet read your letter. The rest will keep now—I had a nice letter from Henry Davidson yesterday—as good as a Newspaper Critic.

What pleases me most in this business—I mean the business of your success, is the hearty personal affection towards you that comes out on all hands. These men at Forsters, with there cheering, our own people; even old Silvester turning as white as a sheet, and his lips quivering when he tried to express his gladness over the telegraph, all that is positively delightful, and makes the success “a good joy”Coterie speech; see 10:167 JWC to TC, [9 Sept. 1838] . to me— No appearance of envy or grudging in anybody, but one general, loving, heartfelt throwing up of caps, with young and old, male and female! If we could only sleep Dear, and what you call ‘digest’; wouldn’t it be nice?

Now I must go— I promised to try and get Madame Venturi out with me for a little air. She has been at her BrothersWilliam Henry Ashurst; see MW to TC, 28 [29] March
; he lived at 7 Prince of Wales Terrace, Kensington. quite near Forsters—since the Funeral—The history she herself gave me of the night of his Death was quite excruciating.

He took these spasms which killed him, soon after they went to bed; and till five in the morning the two poor souls were struggling on, he positively forbidding her to give an alarm. Mrs TaylorAnnie, wife of Herbert Taylor, with whom the Venturis had been staying; see JWC to TC, 30 March
. had a child just recovering from scarlet fever, and sent from home for fear of infecting the others.The Taylors had two children, b. ca. 1854 and 1857 (and another b. ca. 1868), listed in the 1871 census; as JWC implies more than two children here, the child with scarlet fever may have d. When Emilie would have gone to the Taylors bedroom to tell them he said; “Consider the poor Mother! If you rouse her suddenly, she will think there has come bad news of her Child! It might do her great harm.” “and I thought, Dear, there was no danger she said to me—the Drs had so constantly said he had no ailment but indestion”— It was soon after this that he “threw up his arms as if he had been shot, and fixed his eyes with a strange wondering look, as if he saw something beautiful and surprising, and then fell to the floor dead!” I am so glad She likes me to come to her—for it shows she is not desperate—

Oh Dear I wish you had been coming straight back“Oh that I had—alas, alas!” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:322).—for it would be so quiet for you here just now— There isnt a soul left in London but Lady William—whom I havnt seen since the day you left. I am afraid she is unwell
Good by—
We have the sweeps today in the Drawingroom and elsewhere.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 4 April. Addr: 5. Grt Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Edinburgh, 4 April 1866. MS: NLS 617.735. Pbd: Bliss, TC 387.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: It is past 5 p.m., post gone (it seems, but there is another whh arrives at 2, & finds you on return from driving): I have not from first awakening had one moment to myself; but will now snatch one, & actually send one word.

I have had some sleep &c; but am like a man killed with kindness;—ah me, all the world coming tumbling on “Do me this, see me that; above all, dine, dine!”— Two days of it still remain to me; Friday morng, Friday or at latest Saturday, I am off to Scotsbrig; there to cool down, and be silent, dumb as stones.

Last night we had the Professorial:Tyndall later described the Senatus dinner as “a Symposium Academicum, got up in Carlyle’s honour. … At [which] hilarity ran high. … Till then I had thought the dinners of our Royal Society Club in London the most genial in the world; but they could not hold a candle to this Edinburgh Symposium.” Prof. Robert Christison also noted TC’s good humor at the banquet. In a letter to his son David, 15 April, he reported: “[TC] evidently greatly enjoyed our symposium, at which the new-made LL.D.’s were present. Maclagan [Sir Andrew Douglas Maclagan (1812–1900; ODNB), regius professor of forensic medicine at Edinburgh Univ.] was in great force, and very lucky in his choice of themes. Blackie [John Stuart Blackie] was just boisterous enough to carry off his peculiar species of humour. Ramsay, the geologist, sang a capital quiz of his great friend Sir Roderick [Sir Roderick Murchison], for returning to his patron the Russian Emperor, from the Ural, without finding for him any ‘coal’ in any ‘hole.’ Sir Wm. Stirling Maxwell, as Rector of St. Andrews, was also a guest, and seemed not less delighted than Carlyle. Clearly they find a congress of Edinburgh professors something very different from a conventicle; and from various quarters I hear of their surprise and pleasure” (Life of Sir Robert Christison, Bart., ed. “by His Sons” [Edinburgh, 1886] 2:305). pretty on my honr; quite a little jewel of a thing,—scotch wholly in type; cairngorm or agate cut to a hairsbreadth: Tyndall & Huxley much amused by it. Particrs at large by and by.— Today I have seen BettyBetty Braid. (along with Erskine for my escort); seen yr Aunts (all alive & cheery,—“micht ha tane to waur, my dear!”— I have seen & done, & whirled abt till this moment; and am now going to try for a half-hour of sleep, preparatory to a dinner very dull.See TC to JWC, 5 and 8 April
.
Yr Note was charming; I cd hardly get it read (to say nothing of the rest) for janner & disturbance.
Adieu my own poor Jeannie, tell me only you are sleeping agn!

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MO, [4 April]. MS: NLS 23210. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO MARGARET OLIPHANT

docBody.p: I will begin this note as my old Betty ends most of hers to me! “Oh dear Bairn / forgive all my rongs.”— I am not coming tomorrow yet! The sweeps are cleared out but a flood of other business has rolled in! D. V—(that is the right D—; for as Mr Venables says “there are two Ds—)For George Stovin Venables’s saying about the “two Ds,” see JWC to LLA, [16 March] . I will go to you by the 2 o’clock train on Friday. And if Dr TullochJohn Tulloch. comes on Friday I can return by a late train or—sleep with him—if you are short of beds—whichever you recommend.
Oh my “rongs”! I feel them deeply! But as Mr Carlyle is always saying for himself “if you knew how I am situated”!—

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MDC [MCON], 5 April. Copy: NLS 609.785. Pbd: Conway, Autobiography 2:97–98; Bliss, JWC 336 inc. Conway copied JWC’s letter and included it in his letter to TC, [25 April]; TC later wrote on the envelope: “to ‘Moncure D. Conway.’—”; and “From Conway, containg her Ansr to him.”
div3.head:
JWC
TO MONCURE D. CONWAY

docBody.p: The “disposition to write me a little note”Conway wrote, 3 April: “I cannot resist a disposition I have tonight to write you a little note. I longed yesterday when Mr. Carlyle was speaking that you should have been present not only to witness the glowing enthusiasm of the students and the eminent men who were assembled in the Music Hall—an enthusiasm which Mr. Carlyle well pronounced ‘beautiful’—but that you should have heard the address itself. At no time during its delivery could you have felt nervous; for from the first it was evident that Carlyle was not only empowered by his feeling for the occasion, but by the steady tide of sympathy from his audience which fairly floated him. Like his best talks at his own fireside when his true pupils are about him—and no higher could anyone wish him—was his long discourse.” was a good inspiration, and I thank you for it; or rather, accepting it as an inspiration, I thank Providence for it;—Providence, “Immortal Gods,” “Superior Powers,” “Destinies”Coterie speech; see 35:102 JWC to IEB, [early June 1859] .—whichever be the name you like best!

Indeed, by far the most agreable part of this flare up of success, to my feeling, has been the enthusiasm of personal affection and sympathy on the part of his friends. I haven’t been so fond of everybody, and so pleased with the world since I was a girl, as just in these days when reading the letters of his friends your own included.

I am not very well; having done what I do at every possible opportunity—gone off my sleep; so I am preparing to spend a day and night at Windsor,To stay with Margaret Oliphant. for change of atmosphere—moral as well as material. I am in a hurry, but couldn’t refrain from saying, “Thank you, and all good be with you!”

signed.name: Jane W. Carlyle.Alice Woolner wrote to Lady Ashburton about both Carlyles, 4 April: “Mr Carlyle’s Speech at Edinburgh is in today’s ‘Times’ but I have not read it yet. Very many people went down from London to be present at the Installation but Mrs Carlyle did not go. A little while ago I called on her and found her busy writing. She said her chief employment for some days had been answering invitations to Edinburgh as their friends there supposed she was to accompany her philosopher. Mr Carlyle was much troubled and nervous she said as the time drew near and doubtless he is glad enough that his speech is spoken” (MS: NLS Acc. 11388).

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, [5 and 8 April]. Addr: 5. Cheyne Row, Chelsea / London. PM: Ecclefechan, 8 April 1866. MS: NLS 617.736 and 737. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p:
Thanks, Dearest; due Letter this morng, duly read too (whh is something here!)—I wish I cd hear of your sleeping; but there is too little of definite on that importt head! Oh my Dear, there never was such an element; comparable to that of the Three Children (Shadrach Meshach &c) in in the fire before Nebuchadnezar.Cf. Dan. 3:19–20. TC repeated “in.” Thank God, I am to be out of it, Saturday at 1 p.m.; thence to Scotsbrig, with MaryMary Austin lived at The Gill; she was to stay at Scotsbrig to look after TC. & perfect solitude till I recover my wits at leisure. Yesternight, in spite of the wearisomest dinnerProbably dinner at Erskine’s, to which John A. Carlyle was invited; Christian Stirling had meant to ask him for the dinner with the Aitkens, 2 April, as she wrote to him, 3 April: “I cannot tell you how very much we both regretted your absence yesterday,— we fully expected you till Dr Aitken told us that you were not to dine with us: I thought I had told you at first that we expected the pleasure of your Company both on Sunday & Monday certain— I know you will believe, that I am very sorry for my omission, (if I did not ask you distinctly)— that you will excuse my stupidity.—— Tomorrow at 7 O’Clock we shall hope to see you, & I hope you have no engagement to prevent your coming tomorrow” (MS: NLS Acc. 9086). (to be repeated
tomorrow night), I had a long “treacle sleep”:A deep unbroken sleep; see 13:80 TC to JWC, 7 April 1841
. but since opening my eyes, no other rest. Tepid breakfast too, everything inexorably tepid: but let us say nothing, for very shame! One thing is, I saw Tyndall, & settled all morning with him,—for he paid thro’out for me;—gallant & good fellow:During their gallop over the countryside at Fryston (see TC to JWC, 30 March
) Tyndall had paid at the toll gates; he wrote later: “Before coming away I visited Carlyle in his bedroom. He was correcting the proofs of his Address. ‘Now,’ he said, ‘the tollgates at Freystone are to be settled for.’ I made light of them, and urged him to say ‘Good-bye!’ But he would not. ‘The thought of them clings to me like unwashed hands.’ He recognised as mean the cause of the discomfort, and used a congruous metaphor to express it. I still refused to make out a bill, so he put down all the items he remembered, added them together, and said, ‘I owe you so much.’ Looking over the account I retorted, with mock-sternness, ‘I beg your pardon, you owe me fourpence halfpenny more.’ He laughed heartily, produced the fourpence halfpenny, which, with an air of business-like gravity, I pocketed, and bade him ‘Good-bye’” (Tyndall, “Personal Recollections” 17). he is to call on you directly after returning; probably will call on Saturdy, & report everything viva voce.

Masson’s dinnerMasson noted at the end of his chapter on “Carlyle’s Edinburgh Life”: “Of that visit, perhaps the crowning glory of his old age, and reconnecting him so conspicuously with Edinburgh at the last, but saddened for him so fatally by the death of his wife in his absence, I have not a few intimate recollections. … Any such recollections may be reserved” (Edinburgh Sketches & Memories [London and Edinburgh, 1892] 358). will possibly be a shade less wearisome tonight; no matter if even not.

I have done with the Paton Sculptress;Amelia Robertson Hill, b. Paton; her bust of Carlyle, exhibited, 1867, at the Royal Scottish Academy and the Royal Academy, now belongs to the National Trust for Scotland. gave her the last minute of my promised “Two hours,” let her sink or swim. For you she gave me photographs of “the dowie dens of Yarrow,”Amelia Hill’s brother Joseph NoËl Paton (1821–1901; ODNB), painter, created six engravings for the Scottish border ballad “The Dowie Dens o’ Yarrow,” pbd. for members of the Royal Association for the Promotion of the Fine Arts in Scotland, The Dowie Dens o’ Yarrow (Edinburgh, 1860). Hill presumably gave TC photographs of two or more of these, or possibly photographs of the actual Yarrow valley; Yarrow Water is a tributary of Ettrick Water, which itself flows into the Tweed.—these will keep.

Finally the Speech (on Forster’s hest) is actually gone to printer;This official version of TC’s rectorial address was printed by Thomas Constable, Edinburgh (see 
  TC to TCON, [13 April]
) and was first pbd. with the title Inaugural Address by Edmonston & Douglas, Edinburgh, and by Chapman & Hall, London; for the title page, see 165. I am to send from Scotsbrig to Ecclefn P. Office for a Proof on Sunday morning: mind that, if along with it there cd be a word from you, dated before ½ past 4 on 
Saturday: yr Friday’s Note (if any) will still reach me here. God bless you, Dearest; I am staid for, & must run. Adieu my Heartkin. T.C.

figure.p: Title page of Thomas Carlyle’s Inaugural Address

p.hi: Courtesy of the National Library of Scotland

docBody.p: Scotsbrig, Sunday 5½ p.m.
Dearest,—The inclosed was actually written “on Thursday”; in the interstice of hurries,—then forgotten to be posted; and, with remorse, found here in my pocket, on arriving. Read, & wonder & pity!—
I am all safe, if you are; I have had sleep, had excellt warm coffee, had &c&c— — and, in short, have sat all day correcting for life & death; progress goodish but slow.

closer.salute: Adieu. Yrs ever (if you will only sleep)

div3.sourceNote: JWC-GC [GCMC], [5 and 7 April]. Addr: 2 Chlorine Place / Belfast. PM: Windsor, 7 April 1866. MS: Strouse. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head:
JWC
TO GEORGIANA CRAIK

docBody.p:
Nice good little Woman!
I have no time, and very little composure; the hubbub of these days being considerable; but I will fire off at you such small note as is possible; while waiting for the carriage to take me to dine with that very MarchionessLady Lothian. who excited Mrs G Craik’s spleen.Dinah Mulock Craik; Lady Lothian’s call on Mulock Craik apparently irritated her; see below. Mulock Craik was m. to Georgiana’s cousin George, and presumably she had written something in a letter to the Craik family in Belfast about her irritation. For tomorrow morning I am going to Windsor to stay a couple of days with Mrs Oliphant, with a view to getting back my sleep, which has been

Now just see! Not one moment have I had to go on with my letter since Miss Davenport Bromley broke in on me at the last word. She stayed till it was time to go to the Lothians—and when I came home I was too tired for anything but tumbling into bed. Yesterday I had my preparations for this visit to occupy me in the morning, including the daily letter to Mr C and since my arrival at Mrs Oliphants I have been every moment in the presence of fellow creatures—except while I slept—for I did sleep last night like a human creature thank god! So I shall stay another night— But tomorrow I must go home being engaged to dine with the most agreeable woman in London, in spite of her seventy three years and he r
Titl e
.Lady William Russell. By the way; Did Miss Muloch
never hear the Scotch proverb; “he’s scant o’ clash that tells his Father was hanged.” Had any one given me the slap in the face I gave her I would have kept it as private as possible. Her little flare up of vulgar affectation, was the more ridiculous to me, from my knowledge that Lady Lothian’s proposed call was no homage to her authoress merits but a little bit of sentiment towards a dearly loved sister. “Dont think me silly, running after celebrities, she had said to me—my wish to see Miss Muloch originates in no particular admiration of her. I dont care for her Books, the last one, I quite loathe but I had a beloved Sister, now dead,Lady Victoria Susan Chetwynd-Talbot (1831–56), Lady Lothian’s eldest sister. some years older than me, who read the First Book—The OgilviesDinah Mulock, The Ogilvies. A Novel (1849); for JWC on The Ogilvies, see 24:302, 304 JWC to JF, [ca. 1 Dec. 1849]
, and JWC to HW, [2 Dec. 1849]
.—and found something in it that chimed in with some mood of her own at the time, and she used to feel a great interest in Miss Muloch and for her sake, I thought of going to see her.” Miss Muloch who goes so much on the “finer sensebilities,”Coterie speech; see French Revolution, Carlyle, Works 2:56–57. would have found this motive more legitimate, it is to be hoped, than the supposed aristocratic presumption of seeking her out to lionize her!

I am heartily glad your dear Father could read Mr C’s speech and take pleasure in it. It seems to me one of the hopefulest symptoms this interest out of himself— To be sure, it is his nature to be unselfish—unselfconscious— But illness, especially this sort of illness so often changes the nature in these respects. Oh when the fine Weather comes, and he can have a change of air and scene, I feel sure the improvement will be rapid. I have reason to believe in change; when all medecine was mockery, change has never failed to do me more or less good.
I dont know when Mr C will be home— He was to leave Edinr today, but had to go among his relations next. They have been very kind to him in Edinr—

I have seen Madame Venturi a good many times last week—on Thursday I got her out to take a drive with me, which was a great step— Poor darling!— I was afraid for her at first. Now, she is quite composed, and like herself again in being unlike everybody else— The formalists of her acquaintance are dreadfully concerned that she will not wear a widow’s cap, but has her head bare, tho’ iron grey now, and all in a toozle like a nest for putting plovers eggs in. She said to me, how can I wear that odious thing that Carlo laughed at—saying it was like a placard to Let on an empty House?
Give your Father my best love and a kiss. How glad I shall be to see him again after all we have mutually suffered—

postscript.p: There are two Miss TullochsPresumably Sarah Elizabeth and Isabella Frances Tulloch; the third da., Janeanne, was only 11. here and Principal Tulloch and wife expected momentarily

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [6 April]. Addr: Scotsbrig / Ecclefechan / N.B. PM: London, 6 April 1866. MS: NLS 609.772. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:322–24. TC later wrote on the envelope: “read on the road (nr Cleughbrae!) to Scotsbrig came thither, Saty April 7 .”
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: Scotsbrig, I fancy will be the direction now.

I am just getting ready to start for Windsor, to stay a day and night—or two nights if the first be successfulTC’s nephew James Aitken wrote to JWC, 5 April: “I suppose this will find you preparing for your Windsor journey & I trust you may be the better of it.— Enclosed is a note of the Great Western Sunday trains from which you may be able to select one to suit you. … I meant to have proposed to you to take charge of ‘Kleinchen’ [Tiny] until you came back, but I presume you will take her with you. … I am glad to tell you I find my lodging here pretty good. They are rather rough kind of people in the way of cooking:—but I am afraid my stay at Chelsea rather spoiled me for appreciating lodging-cookery for some time again. … P.S I enclose also a note of the trains to Windsor.”—with Mrs Oliphant— Even that much “change of air,” and “schene”“Old grandfather Walter’s ‘varry the schane’” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:322). may perhaps break the spell of sleeplessness that has overtaken me. It is easier to go off one’s sleep than to go on to it.

I did rather better last night however, after an eight o’clock dinner with the Lothians. The American Mr MaconProbably James Murray Mason (1798–1871), commissioner of the Confederacy to Britain and France 1861–65; see 38:52 TC to LLA, 6 Feb. 1862
. Lord Lothian had sympathized with the South in the American Civil War; see TC to LLO, 16 [15] Nov. 1865
. there, a queer fine old fellow, with a touch of my grandfather Walter in him. Both Lord and Lady and the Beauty Lady AdinePresumably Lady Adelaide Chetwynd-Talbot (1844–1917), Lady Lothian’s sister, known as a great beauty; Lord and Lady Lothian were staying at Shrewsbury House, the London home of her parents; see TC to JAC, 21 Dec.
so kind to me. It made me feel like to “go off” to hear the young Marquis declaring “how much he wished he could have heard your speech.” He looked perfectly lovely yesterday, much more cheerful and brighter than I have seen him since he came to London. They seemed to take the most affectionate interest in the business.

Lady WilliamLady William Russell. too charged me with a long message I haven’t time for here.
I found her in bed in the middle of newspapers which she had been “reading and comparing all the morning, and had discovered certain variations in”! I am to dine with her on Sunday after my return from Windsor Miss Bromley is come back; she came yesterday, and I am to dine with her on Tuesday. I needn’t be dull you see unless I like!

Will you tell JamieTC’s brother James Carlyle. the astonishing fact that I have eaten up all the meal he sent me; and cannot live without cakes. Ergo!—also take good care of Betty’s table cloth!—she writes me it was her Mothers spenig.“A gift of poor Betty’s—never to arrive” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:323); Betty wrote “spenig” for “spinning”; see also TC to BB, 2 May
. She was awfully pleased at your visit “what am I. O der me to be so vesated”! Here is an exuberant letter from Charles KingsleyCharles Kingsley (1818–75; ODNB), writer and clergyman; known to TC since the late 1840s; he wrote, 5 April: “My dear Master / (For so I must call you) Let me express freely my delight at your speech at Edinburgh. I will not enter into my own feelings at seeing you installed as Rector— A proof (if I needed one) that the Heavens are just, & the Earth not yet rotten: but I will say—that your address there made me feel young again; & brought me back to the times when as a young man, I learnt from your books, was delivered by your books from phantoms & superstitions. … Amid many failings and follies, I have been at heart ever true to your teaching: & I do hope that I may do some good work with it yet, ere I leave a world wh is to me a very serious & painful place of labour & responsibility. … Let me know how Mrs Carlyle is.” — Exuberant letters more of them than I can ever hope to answer Lady Airlie offers to come and drink tea with me on Sunday night—“Cant be done”—must write in this hurry to put her off— Even I have my hurries you see— kind love to Jamie and the rest—

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady A [LAI], [6 April]. MS: NLS 20767.72. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO LADY AIRLIE

docBody.p: I am really vexed!— I am just starting for Windsor to spend two days with Mrs Oliphant, in the view of breaking a spell of sleeplessness that has proved too strong for morphia— I shall return, at latest on Sunday; but am engaged to dine with Lady William on that day. Wouldnt you come there? She receives from nine till midnight always. If you could and would come to tea with me on Monday I would be at home and so glad to see you, and would try and bring Sartorina (little Price)Maria Price. for your inspection.

Just now I am in a hurry to turn one’s brain— A LadyThe Carlyles’ neighbor at 4 Cheyne Row, Margaretta Theresa Chalmers (b. ca 1795), widow of Francis Chalmers; see JWC to TC, [6 April] . who calls once in twelve months having chosen this inauspicious moment—when I am ever so busy—to come and sit an hour

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [6 April]. MS: NLS 609.775. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p:
this is merely to say that you will find a letter at ScotsbrigJWC presumably sent this letter to TC in Edinburgh, in case he had not yet left for Scotsbrig. — In case you do not go there tomorrow, you might be vaixed Coterie speech; see 15:10 JWC to TC, [12 Aug. 1842]
. at receiving nothing.
By way of helping me thro’ my little bustle Jessie showed in Mrs Chalmers who sat half an hour.
The Carriage will be here in five minutes

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 7 [6] April. Addr: 5. Grt Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Edinburgh, 6 April 1866. MS: NLS 617.738. Hitherto unpbd. TC misdated.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p:
“Nothink from Crk today Ma’am!”Coterie speech; see 19:209 JWC to TC, [23 Sept. 1845] . But I hope there will be tomorrow,—more especially something at Scotsbrig on Sunday morng (written on Saty).— All well, Dearest; except that hurry continues, hurry of hurries. I have got sleep; in quantity, tho’ all in pieces. Such a pen, such a hand!— Masson’s dinner (thank God) went off, & is done. One other remains here to night, and never more.— Tyndall will call on you, Saty forenoon; soon after yr reading of this.JWC was in Windsor when Tyndall called; they did not meet until she called on him, 16 April; see JWC to TC, 17 April
. Butler (of New York)Charles Butler; John A. Carlyle had been acting as intermediary between TC and Butler regarding TC’s American investments; see 40:158–59 TC to JAC, 1 Aug. 1864
. Butler wrote to John A. Carlyle, 22 March: “I thought … that after so long a suspension it would be encouraging to your good brother to receive this token of revival & resumption & thus reassure him that we were not dead, but living— I do not know that I have ever thanked you for your very kind & to me most interesting letter of September last, covering the photographs of your brother & yourself then so recently taken and which were most acceptable— I have also received the last volume of Frederick which has been read with the deepest interest to the ‘Finis’—by my whole family— I beg you to present my cordial regards to your brother & his wife” (MS: NLS Acc. 9086). John A. Carlyle replied, 6 April: “I have today received your kind letter, enclosing Draft of £70–6–0 for my brother Thomas, together with a most brief & clear statement of his account, which even to him is quite intelligible. … He desires me to send kindest respects & thanks to you” (MS: EUL). sends me £70 actual money:—Courage! Only
sleep there, my little Schätzkin [Darling]; and all will be straight agn.—— Yesterday I saw Bess StoddartEliza Aitken, b. Stodart. (Aitken out, by luck). More calls today; then off & away.—

postscript.p:
Dowie Dens included; & Portraits of my Sculptures & her Husband:Amelia Robertson Hill gave TC photographs of “The dowie dens of Yarrow” for JWC; see TC to JWC, 5 and 8 April
; she presumably also gave him photographs of herself and her husband, David Octavius Hill, the photographer. day of small thingsCf. Zech. 4:10.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MP, [7 April]. Pbd: Price, “Recollections” 35. Dated by JWC’s return to Chelsea from Windsor “tomorrow,” Sun. 8 April.
div3.head:
JWC
TO MARIA PRICE

docBody.p:
Dear littl e
Woman,
—I am here, on a visit to Mrs Oliphant, for two days; but mean to be home tomorrow. I wonder if you would like to spend good part of Monday with me? I will go to you about two on Monday, and bring you back with me if you be willing.—

signed.name:
Jan e
Welsh Carlyle.The Athenaeum pbd. its report of TC’s inaugural address, 7 April: “Mr. Carlyle … delivered an elaborate address on the usual topics of study and conduct. To say that it was a strange, weird, eloquent and emphatic discourse, is only another way of saying it was spoken by Mr. Carlyle in the full ripeness of his age and thought. From twenty things in the discourse we should thoroughly dissent; especially from such doctrines as that of good government by despots, and that of an heroic peerage down to the reign of Charles the First. Over some things we smile; such as the recommendation to young men to avoid literature and to read poor old Arthur Collins. But, taking these little bits of alloy with the pure gold of the discourse, we may very warmly congratulate the University of Edinburgh on this splendid exhibition of genius” (Athenaeum, 7 April). Charles I (1600-49; ODNB), king of England, Scotland, and Ireland; Arthur Collins (1681/2–1760; ODNB), genealogist; for one of TC’s previous recommendations of Collins’s Peerage of England (first pbd. 1709; definitive edn., 9 vols. 1812), see 38:209 TC to HP, 15 Sept. 1862
.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-[OR or JF] [ORJF], [8 April]. MS: NLS 609.777. Hitherto unpbd. Recipient conjecturally identified either as Oskar von Reichenbach as he attended the tea party, 9 April, or possibly John Forster whose name is written by an unknown hand on the MS as a suggested recipient. JWC gives no indication Forster was invited in her other letters.
div3.head:
JWC
TO [OSKAR VON REICHENBACH OR JOHN FORSTER]

docBody.p:
I am returned from WindsorOliphant wrote to a friend sometime after 10 April: “I have had a little visit from Mrs Carlyle, who is looking very feeble and picturesque, and as amusing as ever, and naturally has been taking away everybody’s character, or perhaps I ought to say throwing light upon the domestic relations of the distinguished people of the period. I was remarking upon the eccentricity of the said relations, and could not but say that Mr Carlyle seemed the only virtuous philosopher we had. Upon which his wife answered, ‘My dear, if Mr Carlyle’s digestion had been stronger, there is no saying what he might have been!’” (Oliphant, Autobiography and Letters 209). within the last half hour—and must now go and dress myself to dine with “Lady William” Tomorrow I cannot go to you, having invited Sartorina Maria Price.
(Mr BrookfieldW. H. Brookfield; Forster and Brookfield moved in the same social circles, while Reichenbach may have known him through their mutual interest in education. can tell you about her) to spend the day with me—and on Tuesday I am engaged to dine with Miss Davenport Bromley. I wish you had asked me for Wednesday when I could have come—and should have liked to. But—would you come here to tea tomorrow evening (Monday) and see the queer little Sartorina, a Camberwell Tailor’s daughter, who has read more books (good ones) than any young Lady I know. Perhaps Lady Airlie may come— She offered herself for tonight and as I was engaged to Lady William I proposed to her to come tomorrow— But there has been no time for an answer— Do come—

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 9 April. MS: Wellcome Med. Hist. Soc. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Dear Brother,—Yes, Conway’s headings have struck me too as rather an obstructn, smart tho’ they are.Moncure Conway helped to prepare TC’s rectorial address for publication. John A. Carlyle wrote to TC, [8 April]: “Last night I sent off the proofs of the address to you. … I could find no errors in them as compared with the Scotsman report. But it appeared to me that the subdividings of Mr Conway rather interrupted the discourse & might have been omitted altogether, or indicated only on the margins. They want the necessary precision & rather deform the perfect symmetry of the whole. Of this however you yourself are the best judge.” Cut them out; merely put a white line where they are,—or where the main divisns ought to be.John A. Carlyle replied, 12 April: “Both Mr Douglas & I think it will be best to put those headings of Conway … opposite to the headings of ‘Inaugural Address’ at the top of the pages … ‘Inaugural Address’ on left hand pages, & Conway’s headings on right-hand pages.” The address was published in this way. David Douglas (1823–1916), Edinburgh publisher.

I have sat all day, till now 6½ p.m. (after dinner, with Jamie waiting on the slip); busier I cd not be: tomorrow I hope to finish. Then a revise, whh shall return (a slight thing) by return of post.— If the Printer find my correctns difficult,—help him; and say it is mainly his own blame, who left me no margins!
I have got immensely better here; sleep &c&c; and the air is charmingly clean & silent.

Masson’s Irish LettersJohn A. Carlyle forwarded two letters from James Rowley to David Masson, who had written, 7 April: “Here are two notes to me from a Mr Rowley, to whom Mr Carlyle was kind enough to give an autograph admission to the Address—the one acknowledging receipt of the admission & written from Ireland; the other from Glasgow on his return homewards. I rather think Mr Carlyle ought to see them—as, from them & his previous notes, Rowley seems to be a very likeable & modest man.” James Rowley’s first letter, 28 March, thanked Masson for having obtained admission to the address for him: “For, indeed, you could have done me no greater favour: Mr Carlyle has been in my eyes for many years now the foremost man in all the world. In my loneliness here his works are priceless; and I have learned to admire and reverence him beyond all living men. … If you would convey to [TC] my sincere thanks, when next you see him, you would oblige me exceedingly” (MS: NLS 1775C.36). He wrote again, 4 April: “Before leaving Scotland I wish to entreat you, if ever you should have occasion to require a service done you in Ireland, to reckon on me as at any rate most willing to do it for you to the utmost of my ability. Whatever the nature of the thing may be, you will pleasure me greatly by using my poor energies without hesitation” (MS: NLS 1775C.38). James Rowley not further identified. I have not yet read; Spedding’s of yesterday was really gratifying to me.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 10 [9] April. Addr: 5. Grt Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Ecclefechan, 9 April 1866. MS: 617.739. Pbd: Bliss, TC 387–88. TC misdated.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p:
This is the finis of my day, Dear; & I expect, in few minutes, to get out into the twilight, beautiful still grey twilight,—as I did into the do morning, and
not since. Every moment I have been busy, busy as a bee;—have still another day of it; but do calculate to end then, and be at rest.

I am well, wonderfully; can sleep, have right food; & rejoice at being out of claret, Cato,Last letter unclear; it is most like “Cato”; it is not the “cakes” that Bliss transcribed. tepidity, nonsense, noise & hurlyburly. All well, is it not? If you will only sleep;—but I still fear you don’t!—— Spedding’s LetterPresumably Thomas Spedding to TC, forwarded by JWC; Spedding wrote to John A. Carlyle, 9 April, reporting a friend’s comment on the lecture: “He says the seeing was as good as the hearing” (MS: NLS Acc. 9086). I found welcomer than any other. Not a word more, my poor little Goodykin;—young JamieTC’s nephew James Carlyle Jr. is waiting like greyhound on the Slip, and daylight itself is altogether done. Adieu

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [10 April]. Addr: Scotsbrig / Ecclefechan / N B. PM: London, 10 April 1866. MS: NLS 609.776. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:324–26. Quot: Simpsons 290; Fielding and Sorensen 313. TC wrote on the envelope: “(been 2 days at Windsor).”
div3.head:
JWC
TO TC

docBody.dateline: 5 Cheyne Row Tuesday [10 April 1866]TC later wrote “April 10, 1866” below “Tuesday.”
docBody.p:
Alas I missed Tyndalls call! See TC to JWC, 7 [6] April
.
and was “vaixed”! He left word with Jessie that you were “looking well and every body worshipping you”! and I thought to myself; a pity if he have taken the habit of being worshipped! for he may find some difficulty in keeping it up, here!—

Finding the first night at Windsor (Friday night) a great success, I gladly staid a second night, and only arrived at Cheyne Row in time for Lady William’s Sunday dinner. It couldnt be “quiet” that helped me to sleep so well at Mrs Oliphants for all day long I was in the presence of fellow creatures. The first evening, besides two Miss Tullochs,Sarah and Isabella Tulloch; see JWC to GCMC, [5 and 7 April] . living in the House, there arrived to tea and supper(!) a family of Hawtries to the number of seven! seven grown up brothers and sisters!! The eldest “Mr Stephen,” with very white hair and beard, is Master of Mathematics at Eton.Rev. Stephen Thomas Hawtrey (1808–86), M.A., master of mathematics at Eton College, Windsor, 1836–72. He was one of 13 siblings, at least five of whom died young; his surviving brothers and sisters were: Montague John Gregg (1805–87), Anna (1807–86), Harriet (1817–76), John William (1818–91), Henry Courtenay (1823–1906), and Florence (1829–1905); see also Oliphant, Jay 123. And has a pet-school of
his own—Tradesmens sons and the like—on which he lays out three hundred a year of his own money.Hawtrey founded St. Mark’s School, Windsor, ca. 1846, for the sons of the laboring classes; he initially taught them himself, and maintained links with the school until his death; in the late 1850s he raised money through subscriptions for a new building for the school, and contributed £2000 himself; see Florence Molesworth Hawtrey, The History of the Hawtrey Family
, 2 vols. (1903). He pbd. A Letter Containing An Account of St. Mark’s School, Windsor (1859), setting forth his philosophy of education.
