He complimented me on your “excellent address” which he said, “we read aloud to our Boys.” I asked Mrs Oliphant after, what Boys he meant?— She said it would be “the Boys of his Hobby school—they were the only Boys in the world for Mr Stephen”! on the following day arrived Principal Tulloch and Wife on a long visit. Mrs Oliphant seems to me to be eaten up with long visitors. He (the Principal) had been at the “address” and saw you walking in your wideawake, with your Brother, just as himself was leaving Edinr.

Frederick Elliot, and—Hayward!Thomas Frederick Elliot; Abraham Hayward (1801–84; ODNB), translator and author; both known to TC since the early 1830s.—were at Lady Williams. Hayward was raging against the Jamaica business—would have had Eyre cut into small pieces and eaten him raw— He told me women might patronize Eyre—that woman were naturally cruel, and rather liked to look on while horrors were perpetrated.Gov. Edward John Eyre; for the events of the “Jamaica business,” see TC to Lady L, 2 Dec. 1865
. In Jan. a Royal Commission had been sent to investigate the Jamaican riots and to take evidence. Their report was submitted, 9 April; it concluded that the uprising and the threat of its continuance had been severe, the initial response had been speedy and vigorous, but that the ensuing punishments were excessive, reckless, and barbarous. Hayward included a critical passage on the situation in his article, “The Reform Bill and the Government,” Fraser’s Magazine (April 1866): “No-one any longer affects to doubt that things have taken place in that unhappy island which disgrace civilization, which make us shudder for our race, which will be cited against England all the world over, to the destruction of the moral weight she has beneficially exercised wherever the great cause of humanity was at stake. For one entire month the dominant faction actually revelled and rioted in cruelty and blood. They shot, hanged, flogged, and burned down houses … they made a sport of the agonies of their victims. … They added moral and mental to bodily pain, by compelling men and women to stand by whilst their friends and relatives—their husbands, wives, and children—were hung, shot, or catted. … But these West Indian blacks did no more than any other infuriated mob or body of rioters. They cut down or shot the volunteers who had fired upon them, and then took to burning and plundering … but during the whole time the disturbed districts were at their mercy … only two men were killed by them … and not a woman or child was injured” (Fraser’s Magazine 73:490–91). But no man living could stand up for Eyre now! “I hope Mr Carlyle does, I said, I haven’t had an opportunity of asking him, but I should be surprised and grieved if I found him sentimentalizing over a pack of black brutes”!— After staring at me a moment, “Mr Carlyle! said Hayward—oh yes!
Mr Carlyle! one cannot indeed swear what he will not say! His great aim and philosophy of Life being “the smallest happiness of the fewest number”!Cf. the utilitarian philosophy of life, to act in such a way as to produce the greatest happiness for the greatest number, espoused by, among others, John Stuart Mill.—

I slept very ill again that night of my return, but last night was better, having gone to bed dead weary of such a teaparty as you will say could have entered into no human head but mine! SartorinaMaria Price. “A tailor’s daughter, in the Kensington region, a modest yet ardent admirer, whom, liking the tone of her letter, she [JWC] drove to see, and liked, and continued to like” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:326).—Count Reichenbach and James Aitken!! There should was to JWC inserted “was to” above “should.”
have been also—Lady Airlie!!! you have no idea how well Reichenbach and James suit each-other! they make each other quite animated! by the delight each seems to feel in finding a man more inarticulate than himself!Maria Price later described her afternoon with JWC, Mon. 9 April: “I was ready at the time appointed, and more than willing—eager and anxious—to compare notes with her about the great speech, and people’s ideas of Carlyle. She was bright, and even kinder to me than usual. We made some calls, or rather Mrs Carlyle did, leaving me in the carriage; and afterwards we dined together. In the drawing-room, as she lay back among the cushions, I noticed, for the first time, how frail she looked, and how languidly her fingers moved as she knitted. I sat on a low seat beside her, as she told me of her beautiful mother, and sent me for different miniatures, and a large album containing some very curious things; till some gentlemen [Reichenbach and James Aitken] joined us and we had tea. Our conversation was chiefly on the all-absorbing topic [TC’s rectorial installation], I remember. When the time came for me to leave, one of the gentlemen was commissioned to see me into an omnibus” (Price, “Recollections” 35). They got towards the end into little outbursts of laughter—of a very peculiar kind!

postscript.p:
send me a proof“Correcting to the Edinburgh printer of the Address. A London pirate quite forestalled me and it” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:326). For the pirated version, see TC to JWC, 15 April
. as soon as you can.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 11 April. Addr: 5. Grt Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Ecclefechan, 11 April 1866. MS: NLS 617.740. Pbd: Bliss, TC 388–89. Quot: Froude, Carlyle 4:309; Workman 91; Ashton 443–44.
div3.head:
TC
TO JWC

docBody.p:
A beautiful Letter, Dearest,
this that I have got today at last (nothing since Saty before): you are coming back to sleep, I see; & all will be right, or on
the way thither. Pity to have forfeited a sleep for the sake of Hayward, paltry creature. I fear his loudness indicates a bad humour in the public agt Eyre;—if they do condemn him to censure, for quenching a hideous fire of that kind, by the readiest means he had (plenty of water on it till it ceased), I shall never forgive them. Nay (privately very!) if Eyre had shot the whole Nigger populatn, & flung them into the sea, wd it probably have been much harm even to them, not to speak of us? I really calculate, from the aspects & horoscopes, not. Blockheads black, & do white!—

I have done with my correcting, or as good done,—tho’ there will be no Proof-sheet for you till probably Saty: but, next week, Chapn will be able to supply you with copies.Forster wrote to Frederic Chapman about the pamphlet, 10 April: “Have you any copies yet from Messrs Edmonston & Douglas? / There should be some understanding as to advertising—so that double outlay may not be incurred. I suppose you would leave the Scotch publishers to advertise the address ‘revised & corrected by Mr. Carlyle’—for the present in the London papers. … / I have a letter about the address & the agreet—hence this note of mine— On consideration I suppose the revised & corrected copy cannot yet be printed off” (MS: photocopy; source untraced). I have had to sit toiling all the first 3 days till 5 or 6 p.m.; today I got done much sooner,—and may still go out for exercise before dinner, if I like, instead of after. Seldom have I been better in the last 6 months; so blessed is the country stillness to me, the purity of sky and earth, & the absence of all babble and annoyance. Dinner is of chicken (stewed or boiled), with mutton (do) for change: all very nice & eatable. Tepid coffee is not known!—and poor Jean sent me the 3d day ago, a homebaked brown loaf; but that is gone wandering, we know not where!— Jamie tells me, of the meal, that never shall you want for meal, you!See JWC to TC, [6 April] .—that there is plenty here in the house of yr kind; but that, as there ought to be perhaps 6 or 8 stone, it will be better you have it new; the millerDavid Little (1787–1866), of Satur Mill, Dumfriesshire, about 2 mi. (3 km.) E of Ecclefechan; see 41:62 TC to JAC, 6 Oct. 1864
. therefore is to go ahead, and it shall be despatched to that amount, “on Saty or Monday,”— will arrive, I shd guess, early next week. I really ought to have stirred the matter practicallThus in MS. up sooner: but I read yr quizzical little acct, to Jamie junr as we came home in the gig, and in my hurries forgot, for some time, to speak of it to others. Be patient, Dear; & try to subsist on the inferior grains for a few days longer! Lucky I get porridge with such milk as never were; above a pint of cream set down every morning for half-a-gill that is really needed. Envy me!—

Nevertheless, Dearest, I have “’appened a misfortune”Coterie speech; see 17:42 JWC to TC, [13 Aug. 1843] . (to keep me in the level of common humanity, & take any undue conceit out of me): namely,
sprained my ancle the other night,—owing to darkness, in rough ground,—so that I cannot walk with convenience, to any right degree; but rejoice in an excellt Pony, almost equal to Rubbish“Rubbish,” a horse belonging to the Ashburtons, ridden by TC at The Grange and at Seaforth Lodge; see 41:191 TC to JCA, 18 March 1865
, and 200 JWC to MO, 29 March 1865
. (only frightfully dirtier). The thing is swollen; but has absolutely no pain noticeable; seems to be better, too, this morning, and I calculate will soon cease to bother me at all.—

closer.salute: Adieu, Dearest; I am ever thine,—

div3.sourceNote: JWC-SHS [SS], [11 April]. Addr: 11 Hill Street / Edinburgh. PM: London, 11 April 1866. MS: NLS 20.5.25.60. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:327–28. TC wrote in blue pencil on the envelope: “(The last of all!).” TC wrote later: “I still in Edinburgh on that fated visit. I called on Mrs. Stirling; the last time I have seen her. This letter was dated only ten days before the utter finis. / The sudden death mentioned here, minutely and sympathetically described in a letter to me, was that of Madame Venturi’s (born Ashurst’s) Italian husband, with both of whom she was familiar.—T.C.” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:326). Susan Stirling, b. Hunter (1799–1877), m. James Stirling (1802–76), living in Edinburgh; JWC’s old friend; see JWC to SS, [June or July? 1835] .
div3.head: JWC TO SUSAN H. STIRLING

docBody.p:
No change of modern Times would have surprised me more disagreeably than your addressing me in any other style than the old one. The delight of you is just the faith one has—has always had in your constancy. One mayn’t see you for twenty years, but one would go to you at the end with perfect certainty of being kissed as warmly and made as much of as when we were together in the age of enthusiasm.JWC apparently last wrote to Susan Stirling, 21 Oct. 1859 ( 35:237–39 JWC to SS, 21 Oct. [1859]
), and last saw her, Aug. 1856 ( 31:202 JWC to TC, [29 Aug. 1856] ).

I was strongly tempted to accompany Mr C to Edinr and see you all once more. But looked at near hand, my strength or rather my courage failed me in presence of the prospective demand on my “finer sensibilities”! Since my long terrible illnessJWC was ill, autumn 1863—autumn 1864; see vols. 39 and 40. I have had to quite leave off seeking emotions, and cultivating them. I had done a great deal too much of that sort of work in my time— Even at this distance I lost my sleep, and was tattered to fiddlestrings for a week by that flare-up of popularity in Edinr. To be sure the sudden death of an apparently healthy young man, husband of one of my most intimate friendsEmilie and Carlo Venturi. had shocked me into an unusually morbid mood. To say nothing of poor Craik
struck down whilst opening his mouth to reprove a pupil!George Lillie Craik had suffered a stroke in February while lecturing; see JWC to GLC, 4 March
. I had got it in my head that the previous sleeplessness, and fatigue, and the fuss, and closeness of a crowded room, and the novelty of the whole thing, would take such effect on Mr C that when he stood up to speak, he would probably—drop down dead!! when at six oclock (!) I got a Telegram from Professor Tyndall, to tell me it was over, and well over, the relief was so sudden and complete, that I (what my Cook called)—“went off”—that is; took a violent fit of crying, and had Brandy given me!— I am very busy and cannot write a long letter, but a short one containing the old love and a kiss will be better than “silence” however “golden.”Cf. Carlyle, Sartor 162.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [12 April]. Addr: Scotsbrig / Ecclefechan / NB. PM: London, 12 April 1866. MS: NLS 609.778. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:328–30 inc; Bliss, JWC 336–37 inc. Quot: Simpsons 290; Ashton 443; Fielding and Sorensen 313–14.
div3.head:
JWC
TO TC

docBody.p:
I sent you better than a letter yesterday—a charming Punch The 14 April issue (apparently available some days earlier) of Punch, weekly satirical magazine.
—which I hope you received in due course; but Geraldine undertook the posting of it, and as AnnAnne, servant at Cheyne Row 1852–58. said of her long ago, “Miss can write Books but I’m sure it’s the only thing she’s fit for”!—Well! there only wanted, to complete your celebrity, that you should be in the chief place of Punch! And there you are, cape & wideawake, making a really creditable appearance.“It came to Scotsbrig, with this letter, late at night; how merry it made us all: oh Heaven! ‘merry!’” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:328). Punch published a tribute to TC entitled “Lord Rector” accompanied by a full-page illustration, “Wisdom and Wind-bag,” by John Tenniel (1820–1914; ODNB), artist and cartoonist. The article began: “While able and unable talkers, and others of the spouting sort, are going round the shallow political puddles, and lashing them into one knows not what mud splash and dirty water storms there riseth, brethren, in the very midst, as a silver fountain, one calm voice of a wise man. … For, regard him how you may, this Thomas of Chelsea hath the root of the matter in him, while others do but wave branches, not altogether, it would seem, of olive. He goes for the Truth, when for the most part men are content to mumble truism, and not a few run jocundly away with lies. Uncomely may be the garb or outside form of his teaching, to those who love the trim gardens, but the Truth is with him.” The engraving was of TC in the forefront; the caption (taken from the Times report, 4 April, of his rectorial address) reads: “Wisdom Carlyle. ‘For if a good speaker—an eloquent speaker—is not speaking the truth, is there a more horrid kind of object in creation?’ (Loud cheers.)”; the parliamentary reformer John Bright is behind to TC’s right, addressing a crowd; his caption reads: “Wind-bag Bright. ‘The House of Commons is little better than a Sham and a Farce. Parliament is never hearty in any good work. It hated the Reform Bill, it hated the Repeal of the Corn Laws, it hates this Franchise Bill.’” See 181. I must repeat what I
said before, that the best part of this “success” is the general feeling of personal goodwill that pervades all they say and write about you. Even Punch cuddles you and purrs over you as if you were his favourite son! From Punch to Terry the green grocer,Not further identified. is a good step; but let me tell you, he (Terry) asked Mrs Warren; was Mr Carlyle the person they wrote of as Lord Rector, and Mrs Warren having answered in her stage voice “the very same”! Terry shouted out—“(quite shouted it Mam!)” I never was so glad of anything!—by George!—I am glad”!— Both Mrs Warren and Jessy rushed out and bought Punches to send to their families; and in the fervour of their mutual enthusiasm they have actually ceased hostilities—for the present. It seems to me that on every new compliment paid you, these woman run and fry something; such savoury smells reach me up stairs!

figure.p: “Wisdom and Wind-bag,” engraving by John Tenniel

Punch
, 14 April 1866

docBody.p:
Lady Lothian was here the day before yesterday, with a remarkably silly Mrs LeslieNot further identified.— I was to tell you that she (Lady L) was “very impatient for your return” “missed you dreadfully”— I was to “come some day before luncheon and then we could go—somewhere”— To Miss Evans is where we should go, still, if you would let us!“Famous ‘George Eliot’ (or some such pseudonym)” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:329). Mary Ann (later Marian) Evans, pseud. George Eliot (1819–1880; ODNB), novelist; since 1853 she had lived with G. H. Lewes (1817–78; ODNB), who was unable to annul his marriage (1841) to Agnes, b. Jervis (1822–1922). Although JWC loved Eliot’s books, they did not meet socially because TC disapproved of Evans and Lewes living together; see 29:171–72 TC to EF, 19 Oct. 1854
; 184–85 TC to JAC, 2 Nov. 1854
; and 37:195 JWC to AGI, 31 July 1861
. Eliot and Lewes lived at The Priory, Regent’s Park.

Dont forget about my oatmeal!— Edgar YorstounIsabella Edgar Yorstoun (1786–1854), sister of Margaret Yorstoun (b. 1774) and E. Yorstoun (b. 1791), neighbors of Mary Russell at Thornhill; see 42:105 JWC to TC, [4 July 1865] . died
(her family said) of having her oat cakes stopt when she went on a visit to Bath.

There is a large sheet from the Pall Mall BankRansom, Bouverie & Co., bankers, 1 Pall Mall, the bank TC used for foreign transactions; see 42:3 TC to JAC, 2 May 1865
. acknowledging the receipt
of 70 pounds “only”TC noted in his checkbook: “22 March to Jane (House, & £10 for me) / £75 .. 0 .. 0”; he noted later on the reverse: “(for the last time: ah me!— £70 from Butler of N. York (some time in April) paid in” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753); see TC to JWC, 7 [6] April
. I dont forward any nonsense letters come to you—this one inclosed has sex and youth to plead for it—soJWC enclosed a letter from Blanche Atkinson (see TC to BAT, 2 Feb.
); Atkinson wrote later: “In April … came the famous episode of Mr. Carlyle’s enthusiastic reception as Rector of the Edinburgh University; and the newspaper accounts of the ceremony and the full report of his speech were intensely interesting. The verses with which he concluded made a deep impression upon me, and I tried to find them in my German books, in order to learn the poem in the original. I could not find them, however, and after thinking of nothing but Carlyle and his speech for some days, I once more wrote. … Of course I wrote to Chelsea, not knowing his address in Scotland; and it has been interesting to me, since the publication of Mrs. Carlyle’s letters [pbd. 1883], to find that I owe the fact that Mr. Carlyle granted my (I cannot but now think, most audacious) request, to her kind and womanly sympathy. … Perhaps it was because thus commended by his wife to his notice [see Froude, LM 3:330], that Mr. Carlyle, in the midst of his engagements and business, took the trouble to answer me” (Blanche Atkinson, “My Four Letters From Carlyle,” Good Words 33 [1892]: 459). For Atkinson’s request and TC’s response, see TC to JN, 13 April
.

postscript.p:
my kindest regards to Mary “Sister” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:330); Mary Austin.
—for whom I have made a cap, you may tell her—but, couldnt get it finished before you left

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 13 April. Addr: 5. Grt Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Ecclefechan, 13 April 1866. MS: NLS 617.741. Pbd: Bliss, TC 389–90. Quot: Froude, Carlyle 4:309. TC wrote later on the envelope: “mine, from Scotland 1866: / the other 5 were put by Her into / this Pocket. (T.C. 26 july 1866).”
div3.head:
TC
TO JWC

docBody.p:
Dearest,
—I cd write nothing yesterday; kept correcting &c&ctill after 6 p.m; and only then getting out for my ride into the free air. Today the correctn is done early,—first sheet fairly off To Press, as the whole will be tomorrow:—but agn I am overwhelmed in Notes &c; and can only write you one word, to say all goes well enough & promises do.

Yr bright little Note saluted me, the first thing this morng; you say nothing of yr sleep, so I try to believe that is back agn in some endurable degree. The Punch did not come yesterday morning (good only for writing of books, that yg Lady!)Geraldine Jewsbury; see JWC to TC, [12 April] .—but it did at night by chance; and gave everybody a hearty bit of entertaint. The thing is really capital; and has been done by some thoroughly
well-wishing man.Unidentified. The Portrait too is not bad, tho’ comical a little;The cartoon was by John Tenniel. & the slap directed on Bright is perfectly suitable for that blusterous blockead, who is busy with such mischief.TC first met John Bright, 1847, when they disagreed profoundly; see 22:58 TC to JWC, 9 Sept. 1847
, and 68 TC to JWC, 13 [14] Sept. 1847
. Bright was a political radical who believed that the suffrage should be extended to all working men and was a leading proponent of the reform bill introduced, 12 March, to Parliament, and finally passed 1867. I have sent this Punch on for Jean & The Gill; you must [send]Word omitted at turn of page. another for Betty.8*Betty Braid; TC put an asterisk at the name, and then wrote down the side of the letter “(from an Annan Newspr, ill informed!” He then attached a clipping from the newspaper, which read: “Mr Thomas Carlyle left Edinburgh on Saturday afternoon at one o’clock, accompanied by his brother, Dr Carlyle, and passed through Carlisle. The Edinburgh Courant says:— ‘It is noteworthy regarding the Rector’s visit that while he refused several warm and even pressing invitations to the palaces of the nobility, he should have paid a visit to an aged woman, at one time a servant in his father’s house, whom he discovered on inquiry, to be staying at Morningside.’” TC put an asterisk after “woman” on the clipping.— How uncommonly proper in those two women, to begin “frying” something for themselves,Sarah Warren and Jessie Hiddleston; see JWC to TC, [12 April] . the instant they get any fresh good-news:—you satirical little wretch, smelling it out with your nose! On the whole, all is better than it might have been;—and I hope we shall soon be out of all that hurly-burly of sense & nonsent;Thus in MS. & quiet at our respective sides of the fire agn.

I walked, or tried it a bit, with my lame ancle, this morng for the first time,—having doubled down a shoe, & buttoned on a gaiter;—pretty successful, in spite of the rough road & the high wind. The swelling, I flatter myself, has begun to abate; there is no pain or almost none when I let it alone, or am merely riding—my exquisite bit of Pony, on the old silent preternatural road. Today I am to be out before dining. Board here is perfectly good, coffee excellt as at home, and the finest drop of porridge with as good as half-cream. This morning, not sooner, I had Jean’s loaf,—most savoury brown bread (as good as the Warren),—and a real desideratum to me for two weeks past! past!Word repeated with a line over it at turn of page. Yr meal is sure; & I hope, swift.

closer.salute: God bless thee, my little Schätzchen [darling]; & make us thankful for all good things!—

div3.sourceNote: TC-JN, 13 April. Addr: Roslyn Park / Hampstead / London. PM: Ecclefechan, 13 April 1866. MS: NLS 553.283 envelope only. Pbd: Blanche Atkinson, “My Four Letters From Carlyle,” Good Words 33 (1892): 460.
div3.head:
TC
TO JOSEPH NEUBERG

docBody.p:
Will you be so kind as look into your Goethe (index will tell you), and satisfy this good young lady’s inquiry.Blanche Atkinson pbd. the rough copy of her letter to TC, [ca. 10 April], forwarded by JWC (see JWC to TC, [12 April] ): “You answered me so kindly when I wrote to you before to ask for your autograph, that I have dared to intrude upon you again. … I want very much to know in which of Goethe’s works I can find the piece of poetry you quoted the other day at Edinburgh. I have looked through the book of his short poems, and cannot find it, and so thought perhaps you would tell me where it is, for I want to read it in German. / I know what a great deal I am asking from you, and I am quite conscious of the great difference and distance between you and me. The difference would be less if I were even a boy instead of a girl, but as it is, I know it is the utmost presumption in me to ask such a favour, and will be the utmost condescension in you to grant it, and I have only dared to ask you because I know that you are as good and kind as you are great and wise” (Good Words 459). Just write page and volume at the end of what I am now writing, and despatch it in the cover she has sent.Neuberg sent TC’s letter on to Atkinson, with the information as instructed; she later wrote: “Mr. Neuberg kindly added the name of the poem, the first verse (omitted by Mr. Carlyle), and the page and volume where it would be found” (Good Words 460). The Goethe poem TC quoted at the conclusion of the inaugural address was “Symbolum” or “Mason-Lodge” (Carlyle, Works 10:237–38); see also 9:117 TC to JOST, 17 Jan. 1837
. The poem can be found in Goethe, Werke I: Gedichte und Epen (Munich, 1996): 340–41. TC first mentioned the poem in 1830; see 5:153 TC to G, 31 Aug. 1830
.

I am busy and bothered with proof-sheets, &c., &c., but hope to be home again before many days, and see you either at Chelsea or Hampstead, after these tumultuous adventures. The country is beautifully silent, clear, and pure, above and below—no noise in it but that of the fresh winds (with here and there a nasty railway far off), and occasionally the song of birds.

signed.name: T. Carlyle.John A. Carlyle sent Neuberg a copy of the Scotsman, 3 April, with the report of TC’s inaugural address. Neuberg wrote, 12 April, thanking him for the Scotsman and for sending stamps for his sister’s children: “‘It was very kind in Dr Carlyle to think of us’ said Gertrude [Neuberg’s niece] tenderly.” Neuberg, unable to attend the inaugural because of ill-health, commented: “The Scotsman was very welcome at Hastings where we were staying for the holidays. The report in it was an improvement upon that in the Times, which had various obvious blunders, besides such German spelling as ‘Ehrfurt’ for Erfurcht! But both reports have ‘gloomy, austere, aesthetic people,’ where the spoken word evidently is ascetic.— / The address itself, with its deep-toned reality, and its appropriateness as advice to young students meant to be followed,—forms a singular contrast to Mr Gladstone’s long-winded far-fetched sophistries of last year! It is very beautiful, and was to me, in several parts, very touching. On the whole it seems to have been a satisfactory and successful ceremony: a meet scene in the evening of your Brother’s life,—and a memorable day in the Annals of the University” (MS: NLS Acc. 9086).

div3.sourceNote: TC-TC [TCON], [13 April]. Addr: 11. Thistle Street / Edinr. PM: Ecclefechan, 13 April 1866. MS: Strouse. Hitherto unpbd. Thomas Constable (1812–81; ODNB), Edinburgh printer; his publishing company, Thomas Constable & Co., established about 1847, was sold, 1860, to Edmonston & Douglas, Edinburgh publishers of the Inaugural Address. TC wrote at the top of p. 5 of the proof sheets of his rectorial address.
div3.head: TC TO THOMAS CONSTABLE

docBody.p: I am not sure but this was forgotten in the Sheet just gone? Put it so, at any rate.TC crossed out the words “the wildness and ferociousness of their nature” from the sentence, “He points out the profoundly religious nature of the Roman people, notwithstanding the wildness and ferociousness of their nature,” and substituted “their ruggedly positive, defiant, & fierce ways.”

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [13 April]. Addr: Scotsbrig / Ecclefechan / N B. PM: London, 13 April 1866. MS: NLS 609.779. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:330–31 inc. Quot: Simpsons 291; Fielding and Sorensen 314.
div3.head:
JWC
TO TC

docBody.p:
Oh what a pity, Dear,
and what a stupidity, I must say! After coming safely thro so many fatigues and dangers to go and sprain your ancle off your own feet! And such treatment the sprain will get! out you will go with it, morning and night. along the roughest roads, and keep up the swelling heaven knows how long! The only comfort is that, “Providence is kind to women, fools, and drunk people,”Proverbial; favorite epigram of JWC; cf. John Gay, Fables pt. 2, “Pan and Fortune”; see also 15:147 JWC to ABJ, [24 Oct. 1842] . and in the matter of taking care of yourself, you come under the category of “Fools,” if ever any wise man did.

There came a note for you last night, that will surprise you at this date, as much as it did me, tho’ I dare say it wont make you start and give a little scream as it did me.“A note from John Mill—response about some trifle, after long delay” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:331); for Mill’s letter, see TC to JSM, 13 March
. It—such a note—is hardly more friendly than silence but it is more polite— I wish I hadn’t sent him that kind message. Virtue (forgiveness of wrongs, “milk of human kindness”Cf. Macbeth 1.5. and all that sort of “damned
thing,” being “ever its own reward,”—“unless something particular occur to prevent,”Coterie speech; see 25:188–89 JWC to TC, 2 Sept. [1850]
.—“which is, almost invariably”!— Madame Venturi was telling me that Herbert Taylor spoke of his Sister,Helen Taylor lived with her stepfather, John Stuart Mill, at Blackheath Park, SE London. if at all, with great stiffness and apparent dislike, and as exercising great influence over Mill. Somebody, StansfieldJames Stansfeld (1820–98; ODNB), political and social reformer; m., 1844, Caroline, b. Ashurst (1816–85; ODNB), sister of Emilie Venturi. I think, had been saying Mill couldn’t come somewhere, because it would keep him too late, having to go home to Blackheath—Herbert remarked angryly—“He wouldnt dare to make Mis s Taylor
uneasy, as she would have been had he overstayed the usual Time.” Madame Venturi also said the Mill SistersJohn Stuart Mill had four surviving sisters: Clara Esther (1810–86), m., 1860, John Stephen Digweed (ca. 1811–87), lawyer; Harriet Isabella (1812–97); Jane Stuart (ca. 1816–83), m., 1847, Marcus Paul Ferraboschi (b. 1823), an Italian banker and stockbroker, living in Paris; and Mary Elizabeth (1822–1913), m., 1847, Charles Frederick Colman (1817–87). Mill fell out with most of his family on his marriage to Harriet Taylor, 1851. on the other Hand had almost nothing to do with Mill and Miss Taylor, but were excessively intimate with the Herbert Taylors and spoke of Mill as “a poor Eccentric”—calling him always “our poor Brother John”!
There—I must get ready for that blessed carriage—I have been redding up all morning

postscript.p:
It would be good to send back Mills letter that Reichenbach might tell Lowe of it“Löwe (German, unknown to me) wanted to translate something of Mill’s, and had applied, through Reichenbach, to me on the matter” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:331). For Wilhelm Löwe, see TC to JSM, 13 March
.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 15 April. Addr: 5. Grt Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Ecclefechan, 15 April 1866. MS: NLS 617.742. Pbd: Bliss, TC 390–91.
div3.head:
TC
TO JWC

docBody.p:
Dearest,
—I got yr Letter yesterday; and (by industry) will have this ready for you at breakfast tomorrow, let us hope! I entirely finished out that wretched job of correctns; & have despatched the thing with my final Apage [Away with you]:—first set of Perfect Sheets to be sent to you; Pampht to appear, I know not what day. But they will lose no time; some London shark having been attemptg to publish in the uncorrected form.John Camden Hotten pbd., mid-April, On the Choice of Books: The Inaugural Address of Thomas Carlyle, Lord Rector of the University of Edinburgh. Reprinted from “The Times,” with Additional Articles, a Memoir of the Author, and Two Portraits
. The text was from the Times, 4 April. The pamphlet included an introduction by Hotten and a memoir by Richard Herne Shepherd (1840–95; ODNB), bibliographer; see also JWC to TC, 10 April
. The Daily News reported, 21 April: “Messrs. Chapman and Hall have published an authorised report of Mr. Carlyle’s Edinburgh address. Mr. Hotten, of Piccadilly, has also republished a newspaper report of the same address, with two portraits and some prefatory matter.” For the cover of the Hotten version, see opp.; for the title page, see 207. SevalThus in MS. things have been
improved;—and it was as well I had to sit over that, as go hopping & shuffling abt with half a shoe for support.

figure.p: Cover of On the Choice of Books. An Address by Thomas Carlyle

docBody.p:
N.b. I squeezed on the whole shoe today, whh was a real success; & have been ‘revising’ my Corns to a very strict degree, the Proofs being off. Had it not been for this ‘misfortune M’m,’See TC to JWC, 11 April
.—I ought to have been thinking to lift anchor very soon: but it won’t do till I can walk at least on pavet, & don’t need to depend on “Dirty-Swift” (as I have called him)TC mentioned that the pony was like the Ashburtons’ “Rubbish,” but dirtier; see TC to JWC, 11 April
. for my exercise! Not to say that I am really well off, for the moment; and get a real nourisht from these ancient dumb scenes, with the misty winds playing orchestra!— I believe I shall have to let Mary away, abt the early middle of this week, & send for poor Jean in her stead, who is touchingly silent abt her wishes to see me: I have busss with Adamson,Samuel Adamson. too; in short I must start from Dumfries:—but all that will settle itself soon enough.

Indeed I did not ‘scream out,’ Dear at that frosty nothingness of a Mill’s Note,—reason being, my want of care abt the said Mill or what he does or forbears to do. Don’t you repent what of kindness you expressed to the poor creature:—but essentially, as old SterlingEdward Sterling (1773–1847; ODNB), journalist, father of John Sterling; Mill introduced John Sterling and TC, 1835. used to say of him, he is made of something very like sawdust;—and so are his ‘great thinkings of the age,’ too, & much else of him: things to be left lying (since he so prefers) with some mute “Good b’ye, then; and peace be with you and us evermore!”— Does Reichenbh, or does anybody, want his scrae of Note any farther? I hope not; for it is hidden in clouds of rubbish here, tho’ probably not burnt.

Yr meal, poor wretch, went off yesterday afternoon to Ecclefn Statn: I fancied I heard the Luggage trains nr midnight rushing south with it (among other things); hurrying to get across the Border before Sunday, & so speed along all day afterwards. Sunday is reckoned a good day for punctuality at English Statns: perhaps the meal may reach you on Tuesday,—that is, if it do
its very best & luckiest! Tell me of course you will.— I inclose a particle of ofWord repeated with a line over it at turn of page. half-corrected Proof, to shew you the type &c

closer.salute: Adieu poor Goodykin; blessings on thee

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 15 April. MS: NLS 518.23. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 6:64–65.
div3.head: TC TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: Dear Sister,—I have now (I trust) got totally done with my wretched Printer people;—suppose the Pampht will be out (under John’s managet of everything) some day this week, & the Copies fling abt. I shall now, therefore, be as idle as needs: and were it not for my unlucky ancle, shd be looking out towards Dumfries as the final necessary stage. My ancle is mending (not too fast); today first it was a great triumph to get it fairly squeezed into the shoe agn, in whh state I can shuffle & walk abt with it not amiss; tho’ dependt for exercise mostly upon a Pony here.— I begin to think it will be best to let MaryTC’s sister Mary Austin. go home agn one of these days, & send for you in her stead;—I have not yet spoken of it to anybody; & indeed you were the one I first of all thot of to come & meet me here; when suddenly, Jamie wanting something with Mary, named her:—spoken of to nobody yet; but I think that must be the issue soon. Ancle over, I shd see Adamson once; then let you pack me into the S. Western,The Glasgow and South Western Railway stopped at Dumfries on its way from Glasgow to Carlisle, where TC would change onto the main line train to London. & despatch me home (Monday morning, say) addressed “Glass with care.”

The bread (brown) is capital, & a real blessing to me: never got to hand, or to teeth, till Friday morng, as you heard: the careless blockheads, while others were so prompt and punctual! But it is perfectly good,—white too, tho’ not such a favourite,—and will be to the last.— — I enclose a bit of Proof half corrected. I send kindest regards to James and all the young people.—

div3.sourceNote: JWC-Lady A [LLA], [15] April. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Pbd: Hansons, NE 542 inc. Quot: Ashton 444.
div3.head:
JWC
TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p:
Dearest, Sweetest, Beautifulest!
—Oh my Darling!— How long you stay away; and Life so short!— The night before Mr C started for Edinr to deliver that dreadful ‘address,’ we were talking over people we knew, going from London to hear it. And Mr C said plaintively; “Had Lady Ashburton been in this country, as she ought to have been, She would have been for going to hear me and we might have done nice things together
!”— What did he mean? “nice things?”!—

When you come home you must make friendship with Professor Tyndall. He is a Jewel, that man! Mr C wrote to me of him from Edinr; “no adoring son ever watched more carefully and tenderly over a decrepit old Father than Tyndall has done over me! I shall never forget him!”— And myself he kept in my skin
, with a constant supply of Telegrams and letters. You should have seen the arrival of the Telegram to tell me it was all well over! For several days I had been “suffering Martyrs”Coterie speech; a saying of Etienne Paulet’s; see 31:201 JWC to TC, [29 Aug. 1856] . (as a french friend of mine used to express it);—from no over anxiety about the success of the Speech when spoken; but from a wild idea that it might never get spoken at all!—that what with previous sleeplessness and wild hubbub, and close air of the overcrowded room, and the whole unsuitability of the thing,—when he rose up to speak he might probably instead, drop down dead! I knew it was a morbid idea,—due partly to the shock I had received from the sudden death of a friends Husband (Major Venturi) but—if it was my idea, what difference, in point of feeling did it make whether it was morbid or healthy? So you may conceive how my heart leapt into my throat at the sound of the Telegraph double knock.— Mr C was still speaking at four o’clock and at Three minutes after six I had the Telegram!—
“From John Tyndall to Mrs Carlyle 5 Cheyne Row Chelsea— A perfect Triumph”

I read it to myself, then read it aloud to my CousinMaggie Welsh. staying with me, and both the maids, who all waited gaping for the contents; and forwith fell to clapping their hands and ejaculating like a Greek Chorus. “Eh the Maister! Hear Hear to that! Hurrah”! cried the Scotch Housemaid;Jessie Hiddleston. “i told you Mam! i knew how it would be”! cried the Cook;Sarah Warren. “He, he, he, tee, tee, tee, how nice!
cried the Cousin, hopping round me. And then the chorus combined in a cry for—brandy!— “Where’s the Brandy?” “Run for the Brandy” “Dont you see the mistress is going off!”—“where to
”? I asked, in the midst of my outburst of weeping; all my Life I have so hated to be thought hysterical; but I swallowed the Brandy.

Miss Bromley was here the night before last; I had a small tea party; Saffi and his bright little Patriot-Wife,Aurelio and Giorgina Saffi; they were both followers and friends of Mazzini. Geraldine Jewsbury, Mr Twisleton, George Cooke.Edward Boyd Twisleton and John George Cooke. I wanted Mr Twisleton and Miss Bromley to take to one another; I thought he would be an agreeable addition to her men. But the stupid man took to the Patriot-Wife, and had eyes and ears only for Her.

You have sent me a message by Miss AnstrutherAnnie Nairn Anstruther, niece of Lady Ashburton. and I have never received it. I shouldn’t have known she had returned, had not Miss Bromley told me the other day, and expressed surprise that she (Miss Anstruther) had not come to see me, as she had said, she had “brought things from Lady Ashburton to Mrs CarlyleLady Ashburton wrote to JWC from Menton, the Riviera, SE France, 26 March: “Will you use these little Candlesticks when you take your Bedroom Candle, for my sake? & believe how true & bright my love burns, & always will burn—/ This is a mere hurried line by Annie who takes all these things—Please ask dear Mr Carlyle to allow this piece of olive wood, to keep down the papers he has nearest to him—?” but (she had added) it wouldn’t signify when they were delivered
. Begging the young Lady’s pardon I think it signifies a good deal, for more reasons than one.
I don’t know when Mr C will return; he is now at his Brothers in Annandale—“wonderfully well” he says—

I saw Sir WalterSir Walter Calverley Trevelyan. in the Park today with CawenporeSir Walter’s nephew George Otto Trevelyan, author of Cawnpore; see JWC to LT, 16 Jan.
but couldn’t make him see me—

My Kleine “Tiny,” also known as “Kleine,” previously Clara Chapman’s terrier; see JWC to LLA, [16 March] .
says if you would come she would give you both her paws—so prettily! “if you would come”—Ah yes— /

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [15 April]. Addr: Scotsbrig / Ecclefechan / NB. PM: London, 16 April 1866. MS: NLS 609.780. Pbd: Fielding and Sorensen 315–16 inc. Quot: Bliss, JWC 337.
div3.head:
JWC
TO TC

docBody.dateline: 5 Cheyne Row SundayTC wrote on the MS after “Sunday”: “(April 15th, 1866).” [15 April 1866]
docBody.p: It is nine of the clock, and I have just finished a letter to Lady Ashburton; but I will write a few lines tonight in case of hindrances in the morning. I know of one, for certain;—SealePossibly William Seal, linen draper, 55 Leather Lane, Holborn Hill; otherwise unidentified.—to take down and repair the dining-room blinds.

It seems to me, in a vague way, that I have a good many things to tell you; if I could only bring my mind to bear on them; but my mind, I regret to say, is all “dadded abreed,”Coterie speech; see 9:335 TC to JA, 19 Oct. 1837
. at the present writing, by a horrid fit of sickness and headache which took me so soon as I rose this morning. I hadn’t slept worse than usual—nay, for the last hour my sleep had been the sleep of a stone—but so soon as I began to dress, I turned oh so deadly sick! and as you were not there to force “some breakfast” on me, I went on retching and fainting, till midday. But I went for my drive, all the same, at one; and having engaged to lunch with Lady Airlie, I turned it into breakfasting with her. My Lord was there, and speaking fervently—of your speech. After Luncheon he drove off with his whole bonnie familyLord and Lady Airlie had six children: Henrietta Blanche (1852–1925), Clementina Gertrude Helen (1854–1932), David Stanley William (1856–1900), Maude Josepha (1859–1933), Lyulph Gilchrist Stanley (1861–1947), and Griselda Johanna Helen (1865–1934). to the Zoological;London Zoological Gardens, Regent’s Park. and Blanche conducted me to her conservatory to see “poor Lady GiffordsHelen Selina Hay, b. Sheridan (1807–67; ODNB), dowager countess of Gifford; formerly Lady Dufferin and Claneboye, she m., on his deathbed, Oct. 1862, George Hay (1822–1862), earl of Gifford; see 28:201 TC to JWC, 13 July [1853]
. Monkey.” a weezened little
Devil that Huxley would take to his heart!Thomas Henry Huxley; see TC to JWC, 30 March
, and 38:135 JWC to TC, [12 Aug. 1862] . Through his work as a biologist and natural historian, Huxley had come to believe that humans were related to apes. “significant of much”!Coterie speech; see 16:245 JWC to TC, [7 and 8 July 1843] .— “But why do you say poor Lady Gifford”; I asked. The answer was sad enough; “Don’t you know? She has just had an operation for cancer; one of her breasts taken off.”— And Lady ElsmereHarriet Catherine Egerton, b. Greville (1800–1866), m., 1822, Francis Leveson-Gower (later Egerton) (1800–1857; ODNB), 1st earl of Ellesmere; she d. 17 April. underwent the same operation two weeks ago, they were saying at Lady William’s—Dying one’s hair with a cancer in one’s breast! If that isn’t a kind of Spartanism;Spartanism, courage in the face of adversity. what
is it?—

I drove from Airlie LodgeLondon home of the Airlies. to Lady William’s, to inquire for Arthur,Arthur John Edward Russell, Lady William Russell’s son who lived with her. who had been two days in bed with Influenza. Arthur hearing my voice came out of his room, and made me come in, and sent for “Madame.”Arthur had recently m. Laura de Peyronnet, artist. If I found in Madame a dash of acrobate before; today I found her all acrobate with only a dash of Lad!JWC presumably uses the French word “acrobate” because Laura was half French; her entirely respectable parents were Vicomte Jules de Peyronnet (1804–72) and Georgina Frances, b. Whitfield (1815–95; ODNB), journalist, m., 1835; she and Arthur were to have six children and she was apparently an excellent wife. She looked coarse, hard, comfortless! hands that seemed to have done much dirty work, and to have remained unwashed! hair all toozy like a Byremaid’s! face that reminded one of hoeing turnips! A Gown in the worst taste, of a sort of dirty brown, neither loose nor fitting, without a morsel of white collar or frill round the neck! Nor was her countenance such as made one overlook her details— Believe me she had the bored, somewhat illtempered look of an acrobate out of an engagement. She will flirt, that woman; and come to grief—at least Arthur will!

I had a nice little tea party the night before last; and it “passed over,” like a breakfast in Deerbrook, “pleasantly”!Cf. Harriet Martineau, Deerbrook (1839); see 30:201 JWC’s Journal, 22 Oct. 1855
.—Miss Bromley, Saffi and Madame Saffi, Geraldine Mr Twislton, and George Cooke. Mr Twisleton “was meant” to take to Miss Bromley; but, instead, he took—very decidedly too—to the bright little Patriot-Wife! really a charming bit creature—very pretty—as well as clever, and so amusingly absurd! the Patriot part of her!

Old Crawfurd (of the Athenaeum)John Crawfurd (1783–1868; ODNB), orientalist, colonial administrator, and writer; he and his second wife, m. 1820, Anne Horatia, b. Perry (1802–55), were known to the Carlyles from the mid-1830s; see 9:243 TC to JAC, 7 July 1837
. According to his ODNB entry, he “held court at the Athenaeum [Club] most afternoons.” calls and leaves two cards, every Sunday,
when I am out. Mrs Warren says “the old gentleman seems to be of a jocuous turn;“A sparkling conversationalist, genial and gregarious, he had a wide circle of friends, old and young” (John Crawfurd’s entry, ODNB). so she endeavours to meet him with the same”!

Ruskin is going off to the Continent with the Trevelyans.Ruskin left England for a holiday in Switzerland, 24 April, traveling with Sir Walter and Lady Paulina Trevelyan, Lady Trevelyan’s niece Mary Constance Hilliard (1852–1915), and Ruskin’s cousin Joan Agnew (1846–1924). I called for his motherMargaret Ruskin; see 42:181 JWC to TC, [9 Aug. 1865] . on Friday

postscript.p: Did you hear that Fryston Hall was on fire two days after you left?Several London papers carried a report from the Leeds Mercury, 7 April: “Fryston Hall, the seat of Lord Houghton, narrowly escaped total destruction by fire on Wednesday night [4 April]. As is too often the case in old mansions, the beams, which run into one of the flues, in the very centre of the house, became heated and charred, and but for the timely exertions of the household would have burst into flames, which it would have been impossible for the best engineering to extinguish. The fire was kept down, till the Pontefract fire brigade arrived, by the household, assisted by Mr. Baker, the enterprising African traveller, and other guests staying in the house.” Samuel White Baker (1821–93; ODNB), traveler and explorer in Africa.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 16 April. MS: NLS 518.24. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Dear Brother (you see how my hand is going!) TC’s handwriting was becoming increasingly shaky; Robert Christison wrote to his son David, 15 April: “I saw a good deal of Thomas Carlyle here last week, and found him a simple-hearted, straightforward man, with all the ingenious felicity and humour in conversation which one would anticipate from his writings; but I was sorry to observe that his physical powers are not retained on a level with those of the mind” (Life of Robert Christison, Bart., ed. “by His Sons” [Edinburgh, 1886] 2:305). —

Yesterday I had written to Jean that I wd let Mary go home, and she wd come instead one of these days. This morning, before Post-time, Jean had set off, however (a Letter announcing her to us); & here she now is;—“walked from Lockerby”About 8 mi. (13 km.); she had presumably taken a train from Dumfries to Lockerbie. in such a tempest of wind! Mary is to go tomorrow; & she is to take her room.

Yesterday was violent weather; I managed, however, a long ride,—thro “Poverty,” by Waterbeck on to The Craigs,“Poverty” is presumably TC’s name for a row of poor cottages nr. Scotsbrig; Waterbeck is a small village about 2 mi. (3 km.) E of Scotsbrig; The Craigs was either another small community or perhaps local cliffs (“craig” being a variant of “crag”). and thence straight back, mackintosh well wetted but nothing farther, & did well enough thro’ the day (night at first a little disturbed by a knocking window, till that got settled). The ancle is getting slowly better,—still swoln too much; I tried with cold-water pouring today. Poor Betty Smeal’sBetty Smeal or Smail (1776–14 March 1866) had been a servant of TC’s father; see 37:158 JWC to MO, [29 April 19861] ; John A. Carlyle wrote to Janet Hanning, 25 Oct.: “Poor old Betty Smail’s house is now empty. She got gradually frailer year after year, was very deaf & quite blind at last, & died rather suddenly at last” (MS: Yale). The Betty Smeal/Smail who was a servant at Craigenputtoch, 1830–32, and had been dismissed for “adultery” (see 6:205–6 TC to MAC, 21 Aug. 1832
), was presumably from a different family. Daughter,—unforte soul, she had been disconsolate, & worse in bad health, ever since her mother’s death; & this morning came news that she had got early out of bed (at “Poverty”), & drowned herself in the well!Betty Smeal’s da. was Elizabeth Jardine, b. Smeal (ca. 1811–16 April 1866); her death certificate reported that she died of “exhaustion from cold through an attempt to commit suicide by drowning herself in well”; see also 4:395 JWC to JCA, [? Aug. 1828] . I cannot get her out of ofWord repeated with a line over it at turn of page. my head, tho’ she was not known to me. Adieu; this is first of my Notes, not last yet!—

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 16 April. Addr: 5. Grt Cheyne Row, Chelsea / London. PM: Ecclefechan, 16 April 1866. MS: NLS 617.743. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p:
Dearest,—You must be content with the smallest of words; merely to say, All moderately well. Wild wind, with considerable dashes of rain, has come on us; making this, to a lame ancle, rather untowardly ground! Were it not for Dirty-
Swift,TC’s name for the pony; see TC to JWC, 15 April
.—who carried me a long sharp ride yesterday,—very pleast in the silent roads, all silent & vacant except for the howling winds (and woods where possible). Ancle is doing well enough, but will have its time, I see.

This morng, contrary to hope, Jean came (had not got my Note of yesterday, indicating perhaps Wedny or Tuesday, & not a “return ticket,” but change of guard): however, Mary is to go tomorrow, & Jean to stay since she is here.

Yesterday my ride led me thro’ “Poverty Row” (wind & rain beating very pleastly on my back): this morng very early, a poor daughter of the late Betty Smeal’s,—who had long been bedrid, but had insisted on rising for Scotsbrig when she heard her mother was dying, & then had agn taken bad, worse than ever,—“rose, went out of doors, & drowned herself in the well!” One of her boys is herd here: boys, girls & husbandElizabeth Smeal’s husband was William Jardine (ca. 1811–78); they had one da. and six sons; possibly George (b. ca. 1846) or William (b. ca. 1848) was the herdsman at Scotsbrig. are all good people; her poor heart had been broken, or her nerves poisoned. The tragedy, deep as Orestes’s,In Greek mythology Clytemnestra killed her husband, Agamemnon, because he had sacrificed their da. Iphigenia; their son Orestes then avenged the death of his father by killing his mother; the family tragedy is the subject of many plays and stories. in that poor undecorated theatre— Oh me, it will not out of my head!— —

One Hotten in Piccadilly has insisted on printing the Times Report, ‘with (laudatory) Memoir, & two Portraits,’ and sends a new Letter to me this morng (no ansr, as before):—don’t you go near him or his rubbish, the paltry little superfluous body. But he will do no ill either, I believe; perhaps good rather.— It is now time for “Dirty-Swift”; wind a tempest, but rain off for some hours.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MO, [ca. 16 April]. MS: NLS 23210.185. Hitherto unpbd. Dated approximately by the invitation to the tea party, fixed for Saturday, 21 April.
div3.head: JWC TO MARGARET OLIPHANT

docBody.p:
My Dear! I thought I should be in time to catch you before you went outPresumably Oliphant was staying in London for a few days; Oliphant’s home in Windsor, 20 mi. (32 km.) from Chelsea, was too far from London for evening visiting.— No— would you mind fixing an evening to come—all of you The Tulloch family, who were staying with Oliphant; see JWC to TC, 10 April
. to tea with me— Mr C wont be there but Mr Froude will do for the PrincipalJohn Tulloch was principal of St. Mary’s College, St. Andrews. instead, wont he?— any evening but Thursday The Froudes can come so fix quickly—in case of cross purposes and let me know

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [16 April]. Addr: Scotsbrig / Ecclefechan / NB. PM: London, 16 April 1866. MS: NLS 609.781. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p: I send this rigmarole at the cost of an additional penny; as, if I remember aright, you rather liked the ManTC noted later on MS: “‘Monday’ is April 16; enclosures gone (to the fire doubtless)”; correspondent not further identified.

Oh my goodness! The idea of “squeezing your whole (swelled) foot into a hard shoe! and calling that “a real success”!See TC to JWC, 15 April
.

div3.sourceNote: TC-TE, 17 April. Pbd: Letters of Thomas Erskine of Linlathen, ed. William Hanna (Edinburgh, 1877) 2:188; Shepherd, Carlyle 2:226–27; Wylie 277–78 inc.
div3.head:
TC
TO THOMAS ERSKINE

docBody.p:
Dear Mr. Erskine,
—This is almost the first day I have had any composure; and I cannot but write you a little word of gratitude, to Mrs. StirlingErskine’s sister Christian Stirling. and you, for your cordial reception of me in my late shipwrecked state, and your unwearied patience with me, during the whole of the late adventure. Now that is all comfortably over, and a thing to look thankfully back upon, there is no feature of it prettier to me than that your kind chamber in the wall should have been my safe lodging-place (three “chambers” or almost four, as CairnsErskine’s butler; see TC to JWC, 1 April
. well knows!), and that there, with the very clock silenced for me, I should have been so affectionately sheltered.Thomas Erskine wrote to a friend, 16 April: “I believe that the fact of Carlyle being my guest whilst he was in Edinburgh for the purpose of being installed Lord Rector of the University was the chief reason of my being honoured with the LL.D. degree. Of course nobody calls me Dr., except for fun” (Hanna 2:187). Thanks for this, as for the crown of a long series of kindnesses, precious to remember for the rest of my days.

I intend home, probably Monday next—from Dumfries, my penult and one remaining shift. I sprained my ankle a week ago, but it is mending;—and otherwise the scene altogether is touching, tender, and mournfully beautiful to me. I wrote a little word to Lady Ruthven,Mary Hamilton, b. Campbell (1789–1885), Lady Ruthven, m., 1813, James Ruthven (1777–1853), 7th Lord Ruthven of Freeland; she lived at Winton House, Pencaitland, East Lothian. Possibly TC met her at one of Erskine’s social events where he mentioned meeting one of her nieces, Lady Caroline Charteris-Wemyss-Douglas; see TC to JWC, 18 April
. as you suggested. I am still
deepish in Notes, and ought to be in the woods of SpringkellSpringkell estate, the seat of Sir John Heron-Maxwell (1808–85), 6th bart., 4 mi. (6.5 km.) E of Scotsbrig. on my solitary rides of meditation rather.
With many grateful regards to Madam and yourself,

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 17 April. Addr: 5. Grt Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Ecclefechan, 17 April 1866. MS: NLS 617.744. Pbd: Bliss, TC 391–92 inc.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Yr Note, in spite of the bad accts as to health, is all on the sparkle with satirical gaiety and malicious insight,—you little noticing gipsy! That of the acrobate in undress, and then in full-dress—alas, poor Arthur;Arthur and Laura Russell; see JWC to TC, [15 April] . I doubt he will have his trials; and will perhaps take his revenges, who knows?—

You deserve, or at least need, very few words today, having such a supply of print. The Hotten John A. Carlyle had sent TC this copy of Hotten’s edition; see TC to JAC, 17 April
. too, with the one Copy of the Speech, I send you off: whh of the two will you read first, I wonder?

Yesterday proved a mere tempest of wild winds, & dashings of rain. And I had to find my “exercise” on foot, too; think of that;—young Jamie,TC’s nephew James Carlyle. by some whirl of whim, I think, having suddenly carried off both Mary & the Pony yesterday instead of today. I was really vexed & sorry,—especially abt poor Mary: Jean she & I had all agreed upon today; and within an hour after, as I sat writing, somebody entered here, and as I didn’t look up, at once withdrew agn,—and had been poor modest self-effacing Mary just in the act of being bowled away in that tyrannous manner! Jean is writing to her, by my request; and there is to be a meeting agn, when I get to Dumfries, middle or end of this week.

My ancle is doing handsomely; not so obstinate agt the shoe, tho’ still unwilling at first; I have had it poured-upon (jug or kettle, no pump here), & use it politely; but inThus in MS. can’t get well all at once. Monday, I shd think, may possibly be the day of my coming home. Tyndall, Huxley, Froude, Fuz, these are all of London that get Edinr copies of the Address.—

div3.sourceNote: TC-JAC, 17 April. MS: NLS 526.39. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN A. CARLYLE

docBody.p: Well, dear Brother, here is the thing all finished; handsomely got done with, to a degree we cd never have expected! And we ought to be thankful,—especially you, I think, who have had such coils of incessant trouble with it (whh I don’t forget, I hope, tho’ saying nothing to you on that part of the subject.

Hotten’s thing is worth having too; and I am not sorry to have glanced over the preliminary parts, (omitting altogether the “report”), since you did send it. I send it to Jane today, along with the Edmonstn Report proper,The official publication of the address from Edmonston & Douglas. —the sale of whh, I shd suppose, it will not much hinder. Never mind the interloper more; since we cannot suppress his follies & him.—— You will still have the “despatch of Copies” to mind: J. A. Froude (5 Onslow Gardens, Brompn); Profesrs Tyndall & Huxley (“Mining College,”The School of Mines, Jermyn St., where Tyndall held the chair of natural philosophy, 1859–68, and where Huxley had been lecturing in natural history and palaeontology since 1854. or whatever the name, Jermyn Street, will find both of them daily), & Forster,—I don’t remember any other London copies special. Russell of Thornhill,Dr. James Russell. you won’t forget:— And pray try to keep some account of the heap of stamps they will cost you; these at least I may surely make some attempt to pay!—

Yesterday was a most furious tempest, of wind & fierce showers: and I had two great griefs; first, the immediate loss of Mary, on Jean’s arrival; up here we had all agreed that Mary was to stay till next day; but down-stairs Jamie (junr) perem[p]torily settled it the other way,—and poor Mary, coming up to take leave of me, & finding me writing, glided out agn, and had over the hills like a dream! Jean is to write to her a word today; & by the first opportunity at Dumfries, a return-ticket to CumertreesCummertrees station was the closest to The Gill; either TC planned to pay a final visit to his sister Mary, or more probably planned to buy her a return ticket to come and see him in Dumfries. will be in requisitn. My second grief, was that the Pony had gone off on this expeditn;Presumably Jamie needed the pony to take Mary back to The Gill, 8 mi. (13 km.) away. that I was left with my lame resources to fish for “exercise,” as I pleased, in the tempestuous day! Difficult: but I managed it, too, not amiss at all; crept down the green braes (nearest road to the burn, & there found a green quarterdeck place, & walked on it slowly near 2 hours, in mackintosh, with slippers (an old pair of yours) & stockings already dirty. Ancle is improving (was twice douched, or poured
upon, yesterday: so soon as it can fairly be walked with,—Dumfries & home! (Dfs is the way isn’t it?)

div3.sourceNote:
JWC-TC, [17 April]. Addr: Scotsbrig / Ecclefechan NB. PM: London, 17 April 1866. MS: NLS 609.782. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:331–33 inc. Quot: Bliss, JWC 337–38; Simpsons 291; Fielding and Sorensen 316. With the MS are two scraps of paper, stuck together, with TC’s notes about the letter: “cover lost; probably ‘April 10 ’;—no, this must be ‘Tuesday 17’; tuesday 10 I had hurt my foot!— / Saty April 7
(came to Scotsbrig, afternoon windy)—14; tuesday 10 (had hurt my ancle that very night, I think.)—17.” TC then noted on the back of the envelope: “The right cover this; inclosures all gone.”
div3.head:
JWC
TO TC

docBody.dateline: 5 Cheyne Row TuesdayTC wrote later under Tuesday: “17 April 1866.” [17 April 1866]
docBody.p:
Oh my Dear!
These women are too tiresome! Time after time I have sworn to send on none of their nonsense, but to burn it or let it lie; as I do all about ‘Christ’! and there is always “a something” that touches me on their behalf. Here is this Trimnell!Possibly Fanny Trimnell (ca. 1834–97), a schoolmistress living in Dower Place, Bristol; otherwise unidentified. she was doomed! and should have been cast into outer darkness (of the cupboard) but for that poor little phrase; “as much as my weak brains will permit.”—

And the Caroline Charteris;Lady Caroline Charteris-Wemyss-Douglas (1816–91), da. of Francis Charteris Wemyss Douglas (1772–1853), 8th earl of Wemyss. who the deuce is she, that writes such a scratchy illegible hand, neglects to put two stamps on her letter, sends her love to Mrs Carlyle, and proposes to “talk to her about Aimsfield & Haddington.”Amisfield House, Haddington, belonged to the Charteris family. Can she be an Aunt of Lord Elcho’sCaroline was the youngest sister of Francis Charteris Wemyss (1796–1883), 9th earl of Wemyss, and aunt of his son Francis Richard Charteris (1818–1914), Lord Elcho.—I don’t recollect a Caroline among them. “Encouraged by your Brother to beg &c&c,” complicates the question still further!—Yes—it is the mixing up of things that is the great Bad.“Reichenbach’s phrase” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:332); coterie speech; see 30:224 JWC’s Journal, 26 Nov. 1855
.

I called at the Royal Institution yesterday to ask if Tyndall had returned. He was there; and I sat some time with him in his room, hearing the minutest details of your doings and sufferings in the journey. It is the event of Tyndall’s Life!Tyndall later wrote of this meeting as having occurred “immediately after my arrival in London” although JWC had been in Windsor at the time; see TC to JWC, 7 [6] April
. He continued: “It was a bright welcome that she gave me. A deep and settled happiness had taken possession of her mind; though she still could afford a flash of sarcasm for one of the Edinburgh audience who had visited her the day before. The glow of pride in her husband was obvious enough. Not before a select few, but before the world at large, he had won for himself renown, and for her choice of him, justification. … We chatted long over the occurrences in the north, which I thought would give her a new lease of happy life. Referring to her anxiety about the Address she said she had never entertained the thought of his breaking down. As long as he had life there was no fear of that. But she thought it quite possible that life itself might snap, and that he might fall down dead before the people. It must have been her lithe fingers, and her high-strung nerves, that gave to the pressure of her hand an elastic intensity which I have not noticed elsewhere” (Tyndall, “Personal Recollections” 17–18).—Crossing the Hall I noticed, for the first time, that officials
were hurrying about, and asked the one nearest me; “is there to be Lecturing here today”? The Man gave me such a look! as if I was ‘deeranged’; and people going up the stairs turned and looked at me as if I was deeranged; Neuberg whose complexion has become that of a lobster (boiled) ran down to me and asked “wouldn’t I hear the Lecture?The lecture was “Muscular Contraction” by Prof. du Bois-Reymond at 3 p.m. (Daily News, 16 April). Emil du Bois-Reymond (1818–96), German physician and physiologist, known for his explorations of electric phenomena in living beings.—and by simply going out when everyone else was going in, I made myself an object of general interest. As I looked back from the carriage window I saw all heads in the Hall and on the Stairs turned toward me! I called at Miss Bromleys after. She had dined at the MarochettisBaron Carlo Marochetti (1805–67; ODNB), Italian sculptor, m., 1835, Camille de Maussion (ca. 1817–93); they lived at 34 Onslow Sq., S. Kensington. on Saturday, being to go with them to some spectacle after—the Spectacle she saw, without any going, was a great fire—of Marochetti’s StudioThe Pall Mall Gazette reported, 16 April: “A fire occurred on Saturday evening in the modelling rooms of Baron Marochetti, which are situate in the Fulham-road. The workmen were then engaged in casting a part of one of the colossal lions in bronze which are intended to adorn the base of the Nelson column in Trafalgar-square, when a part of the building caught fire from the overheating, or from sparks from a furnace flue, and before the fire could be extinguished the roofs of the modelling room were in great part destroyed, and the movable property within the building seriously damaged.” Trafalgar Sq. was laid out in the early 1840s, with Nelson’s Column in the center, flanked by two large fountains; the lions were added in 1867.—Furnaces overheated in casting Landseer’s ‘Great Lion’Edwin Henry Landseer (1802–73; ODNB), artist; a friend, he was using Marochetti’s studio to work on the lions for Nelson’s Column.—

I do entreat you not to cramm your foot into a shoe, till the swelling is quite fallen, sprains are one of many things that cant and wont be made well par vive force [by main force]!Coterie speech; see 10:170 JWC to TC, [9 Sept. 1838] .

How dreadful that poor womans suicide!“A poor neuralgic woman, near Scotsbrig—a daughter of old Betty Smails’s (mentioned already?—lsquo;head like a mall,’ &c)” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:333). For Betty’s saying, see 37:158 JWC to MO, [29 April 1861] . For her da., Elizabeth Jardine, see TC to JAC, 16 April
. what a deal of misery it must
take to drive a working [woman]Word omitted in MS. to make away with her life! What does Dr Carlyle make of such a case as that? no idleness nor luxury nor novel reading to make it all plain!“Alas! that was a blind, hasty, and cruel speech of poor, good John’s!” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:333). TC’s brother John told JWC, July 1864, that “no poor woman with work to mind” would suffer from nervous illness; see 40:147 JWC to TC, [23 July 1864] .

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MO, [ca. 17 April]. MS: NLS 23210.182. Hitherto unpbd. Dated the day after JWC to MO, [ca. 16 April].
div3.head: JWC TO MARGARET OLIPHANT

docBody.p: Oh, yes dear.— Saturday will do quite well— I dont suppose Mr Froude can have gone and engaged himself since I saw him yesterday—

About Friday I am dreadfully sorry— I had just posted a note for my Aunt in-lawMargaret Welsh. —at Richmond whom I have behaved monstrously to, having utterly forgotten she existed actually!—to tell her to expect me on Friday forenoon. I dont like to unsay it having affronted her already. “The troubles that afflict the just &c&c.”Cf. Ps. 34:19.

postscript.p: not later than seven on Saturday if you can help it—Froude wont come till between eight and nine however

div3.sourceNote: TC-JBB, 18 April. MS: Strouse. Hitherto unpbd. John Bernard Burke (1814–92; ODNB), genealogist and herald; author, initially with his father, John Burke (1786–1848; ODNB), of various genealogical and heraldic dictionaries.
div3.head: TC TO SIR JOHN BERNARD BURKE

docBody.p: I am very much obliged by yr kind and useful Gift; whh, I hear, has arrived safe at Chelsea. I shall be well pleased to add it to the other series of yr BooksBurke probably sent TC his Dormant and Extinct Peerages (1866). TC presumably had more than one edn. of Burke’s Genealogical and Heraldic Dictionary of the Peerage and Baronetage of the British Empire, an annual publication, although Carlyle’s House (88) lists only Peerage and Baronetage (1857) and Dormant and Extinct Peerages (1866). whh I have there; and always in consulting it henceforth, it will have a new value to me.
With many thanks & good wishes, I remain,

postscript.p: To Sir J. Bernard BurkeTC apparently knew that Burke used his middle name, Bernard, rather than John.
&c&c

div3.sourceNote: TC-JHS, 18 April. Pbd: A. H. Stirling, James Hutchison Stirling, His Life and Work (1912) 175–76. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 6:64. James Hutchison Stirling (1820–1909; ODNB), physician and philosopher; he lived in Edinburgh, where TC and John A. Carlyle visited him together, Aug. 1865; see TC to JWC, 11 Aug. 1865 .
div3.head: TC TO JAMES H. STIRLING

docBody.p: Dear Sir,—I have written you a small testimonial;Stirling was applying for the chair of moral philosophy at Glasgow Univ. and shall be very glad if it can help you,—it or anything else in my power; but there is nothing else I can think of.

Professor LushingtonEdmund Law Lushington (1811–93; ODNB), prof. of Greek, Glasgow Univ., 1838–75; he m., 1842, Cecilia, b. Tennyson (1817–1909), Alfred Tennyson’s sister. is a frank, loyal kind of man: if you don’t know him, my brother does, and will present you to him, which might have good effects, or tend that way. Did you controvert John Mill, or take his side, in your late pamphlet?James H. Stirling, Sir William Hamilton: Being the Philosophy of Perception. An Analysis (1865), an idealist critique of Sir William Hamilton (1788–1856; ODNB); Mill’s recently pbd. work on Hamilton, Examination of Sir William Hamilton’s Philosophy (1865), challenged Hamilton from an empiricist perspective. TC knew and admired Hamilton in the 1820s and 1830s. I fear, the former. John Mill is grown very whimsical latterly (I hear); but you might write to him, and perhaps his generosity would prompt him favourably.— Professor Masson has come nearer the scene,David Masson had recently moved from London, and was now prof. of rhetoric and English literature at Edinburgh Univ.; see TC to JAC, 28 [27] Nov. 1865
. and may now, also, have a word to say: he is a thoroughly kind-hearted man.

On the whole, use your best diligence; and succeed if possible. It will give me real pleasure to learn that you do; it seems the career of all others fitted for you.Stirling was unsuccessful; the chair went to Edward Caird (1835–1908; ODNB), philosopher.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, [18 April]. Addr: 5. Grt Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Ecclefechan, 18 April 1866. MS: NLS 617.745. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: My dear Jeannie, I am really driven nearly mad, with all the nonsense that has come on me today,—not only yours of the foolish silly women; but a great lot from John too, of Copies to be addressed &c:For example, John A. Carlyle wrote, 19 April, to Alexander Gibson, chair of TC’s election committee: “My brother, not knowing your address, has sent me the enclosed to be forwarded to you. … He was greatly pleased with the kind & warm reception he found in Edinburgh, & I am sure will always look back to it with much satisfaction, though the effort of coming so far & speaking in public was not without pain to him in his delicate state of health at the time” (MS: EUL). four of them to America (Butler, Emerson; Brr Alick & Sistr Jenny)Charles Butler and Ralph Waldo Emerson in the U.S. and TC’s brother Alexander and sister Jenny Hanning in Canada.—oh me, oh me, with testimonials, autographs, photographs, scrubby notes on nothing at all! However, it is now done (near 3½ p.m.), & in 20 minutes more, I shall be out riding, please Heaven!—

The Lady Caroline Charteris is the now Ld Wemyss’s Sister,Francis Charteris Wemyss, 9th earl of Wemyss; see JWC to TC, 17 April
. a broad-faced oldish Dame, with glaring eyes,—of no interest to me in the world, except that at Erskine’s by way of a topic I began speaking to her abt you, & her Aunts & ancestors,Lady Caroline Charteris-Wemyss-Douglas had four paternal aunts, all deceased, and five maternal aunts, one of whom was Lady Ruthven; see TC to TE, 17 April
. for the three minutes necessary. She might as well have bot her own “Photos,”That is, photographs of TC were readily available for buying. one wd say; but preferred making you do it,—had written to John too for that object, as you may see (if not too tired of the unintelligible, as I was). I inclosed her 2 “Photos” (merely saying on the flap of the cover, Here they are from mrs C.) to her address in Charlotte square, and so ended that adventure.
My heel & ancle are gradually lessening; you may depend, I don’t irritate or injure them, poor members, & they are in “a friend’s hand.”Unexplained. Adieu my own Goodykin; I am out at last!

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [19 April]. Addr: Scotsbrig / Ecclefechan / N B. PM: London, 19 April 1866. MS: NLS 609.783. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:333–35 inc. Quot: Hansons, NE 545; Fielding and Sorensen 316–17. TC later wrote on the envelope: “Friday 19.” 19 April was Thursday. Where TC’s later notes in Froude, LM 3:333–35, are identical to his notes on MS, we have printed only the latter.
div3.head: JWC TO TC

docBody.p:
Nothing to trouble you with today Dear. but an invitation to a Fortnightly Dinner.A dinner hosted by the Fortnightly Review, the invitation apparently coming from Anthony Trollope, one of the founders of the magazine; see TC to JWC, 20 April
. I am not sure whether to direct to you at Dumfries or at Scotsbrig still; if indeed there were anything worth directing, at all!—and what there is of not worth, I have no Spirits just at present, to give any amusing turn to; being always more or less sick in these mornings. Today I am going out an hour earlier, to call for Mrs George WelshTC later wrote on the MS above “Mrs George Welsh”: “(day of the ‘Picture’ of Frh (now here): ah me!).” For the picture, see JWC to TC, 21 April
. at Richmond. She has had an ugly accident which I heard of for the first time yesterday; Altho’ it happened three weeks ago. A heavy wooden shutter fell down on her head.

I read the Memoir TC later wrote on the MS above “Memoir”: “(by London Pirate: ‘Hotten’ his name.” “first” yesterday morning: having indeed read the “Address” the evening before, and read it some three times in different Newspapers. If you call that “Laudatory” you must be easily pleased! I never read such stupid vulgar janners TC later wrote on the MS above “janners”: “(capital Scotch word).” The last of calumnies that I should ever have expected to hear uttered about you, was this of your going about “filling the laps of dirty children with comfits”!— Idiot! My half pound of barley-sugar made into such a legend!In his “Preliminary,” On the Choice of Books, Hotten began: “The general belief that Carlyle is a gloomy misanthrope, scarcely ever seen outside his own door, is quite an error” and that TC had “no disinclination to accept an invitation to a good dinner” (5). Hotten noted: “Though it is rare indeed that he is ever seen to stop and to speak to a grown person in the street—probably because he knows but one or two personally in his own neighbourhood—he is always ready to recognise little children. The keeper of a small confectioner’s shop near the river-side tells with delight how he will call upon her for extravagant quantities of cheap sweetmeats, with which he will sometimes stop and load the laps of a little group of poor children in some of the purlieus of Lawrence-street” (7). Hotten noted that the Cheyne Row garden was “strangely neglected … and exhibiting all the ‘rank luxuriance’ of the jungle” and then concluded “we hope, we may be pardoned for this brief, but not irreverent glance at the far-famed Lord Rector of the University of Edinburgh” (8). The wretch has even failed to put the right number to the sketch of the house. “No 7”!A sketch of 5 Cheyne Row was included on the title page, misnumbered “7”; see opp. Rodger L. Tarr’s reproduction of the title page must come from a 2d printing, as the number there is correct (Tarr 199). a luck,—since he was going to blunder,—that
he didnt call it No 6—with its present traditions!For the current occupants of 6 Cheyne Row and their habits, see JWC to MC, 28 Nov. 1865
, and JWC to BB, [10 Dec. 1865] . It is prettily enough done, the House! I recollect looking over the blind one morning, and seeing a young man doing it— “What can he be doing?” I said to Jessy. “Oh! counting the windows for the taxes”; she answered, quite confidently, and I was satisfied!Window tax had been introduced in 1696 but abolished in 1851.

figure.p: Title page of On the Choice of Books. The Inaugural Address of Thomas Carlyle

docBody.p:
I saw Frederick Chapman yesterday, and he was very angry. He had “frightened the fellow out of advertising he said;Hotten apparently did not advertise his edition in the press. The Examiner advertised, 14 April: “Chapman & Hall / INAUGURAL ADDRESS AT EDINBURGH APRIL 2, 1866 / On being Installed as Rector of the University there. / (Authorised Report) / Revised and Corrected by MR CARLYLE.” and he had gone round all the Booksellers—who had subscribed largely for the spurious address, and required them to withdraw their orders! By what right I wonder? Difficulty of procuring it will only make it the more sought after I should think! “By making it felony Mam, yourselves have raised the Price of getting your dogs back”!“London dog-stealers pleaded so, on the Act passed against them” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:334). JWC’s dog Nero was stolen and returned for ransom several times; see 25:35 JWC to MR, 27 [Feb. 1850]
, 26:24 TC to JCA, 23 Jan. 1851
, 84 JWC to HW, [5 June 1851] , and 88 TC to MAC, 11 June 1851
.

I didn’t write yesterday because in the first place I was very sick, and in the second place I got a moral shockTC later wrote on the MS under “moral shock”: “What? I cd never guess.” that stunned me pro tempore [for the time]! No time to tell you about that just now—but another day— I have put the women to sleep in your bed to air it! It seems so long since you went away!

Imagine the teaparty I am to have on Saturday night TC later wrote on the MS under “Saturday night ”: “(Oh, Heaven!).” Mrs Oliphant Principal Tulloch and wife and two grown up daughters!
