Mr & Mrs Froude Mr and Mrs Spottiswood!!!!JWC’s tea party was to have included Margaret Oliphant; John and Jane Tulloch and their two eldest das., Sara and Isabella; James and Henrietta Froude; Geraldine Jewsbury; and William Spottiswoode (1825–83; ODNB), mathematician, partner in the printing firm of Eyre & Spottiswoode, queen’s printers, and his wife (m. 1861), Eliza Taylor, b. Arbuthnot (1837–94).

Did you give Jane the things I sentTC later wrote on the MS next to “sent”: “I did: & told her so, in the Letter she never recd.— — Why shd I ever read this agn!” In Froude, LM 3:335, TC added “(Note of 1866 ).” —when one sends a thing one likes to know if it have been received safe

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 19 April. Addr: 5. Grt Cheyne Row / Chelsea / London. PM: Ecclefechan, 19 April 1866. MS: 617.746. Pbd: Froude, Carlyle 4:309–10 inc; Bliss, TC 392–93. TC wrote later on the envelope: “(The last she ever read from me.).”
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.p: Nothing from Goody today at all;—took to reading, I suppose, immediately, yesterday morng? Well, you have been handsomely diligt of late; and have given me at least one sunny blink among the great dreary mass I got on awakening to a new day.— I only hope it is no sleepless fit, or the like; for one has always to be apprehensive of that.

closer.salute: No more, Dearest, except my blessing & adieu.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JWC, 20 April. Addr: 5. Grt Cheyne Row, Chelsea / London / S.W. PM: Ecclefechan, 20 April 1866. MS: 617.747. Pbd: Bliss, TC 394–95. TC later wrote on the envelope: “Never read (ah me!)—” and “My last Note to her (written at Scotsbrig, Friday morg April 20 ): oh that I had myself posted it,—or that my messenger had been exact!”
div3.head: TC TO JWC

docBody.dateline: Scotsbrig, 20 April, 1866 TC wrote later on MS: “never read,—alas, alas!—.” The Carlyles’ servant Jessie later recalled: “a letter … from Mr. Carlyle to Mrs. Carlyle … had arrived that afternoon from Scotland, after Mrs. Carlyle had gone out for her drive. I remember how annoyed she was she did not get it, as she expected, in the early morning; and Mr. Carlyle himself was so grieved she had not got it—his last letter to her—then; for, he said, he had written it that she might have it in the morning” (Blunt, “CHH” 464–65). —
docBody.p: Dearest,—I shd like much to hear what the “moral shock” was (as soon as possible!)—also to hear better news of yr morning’s appetite, if you cd send me any. Yesterday I had said, It is nothing, this silence of hers: but abt 1 a.m. soon after going to bed, my first operatn was a kind of dream, or actual introduction to the sight of you in bitterly bad circs; and I started broad awake with the thot, “Ah, this was her silence, then, poor soul!” Send better news; don’t reduce me to dream.

The weather is all dried up agn today; & I am for a fine little ride, before setting out for Dumfries & a pedestrian life. The ancle is nearly well, but not quite (quite will take abt a week yet perhaps); swelling well fallen, walking fairly possible, especially on pavements.— I was fairly shocked by yr inquiry abt “Jean’s things,” and cd not at first recollect what you meant at all,—such tides of things have gone raging over the top of that; and since Edinr my portmanteau has lain only half unpacked! All was soon found still correct at the bottom (where all is agn repointed),—and was recd by the Donee That is, Jean Aitken. with real pleasure & the due JapanMeaning unclear; for other gifts of Japanese ware, see JWC to MR, 25 Dec. 1865
. admiratn too. This evg I hope to post out there my flat neighbrs forever & a day.— By the bye, tell me distinctly whether you have recd yr meal or not? I will bring a few pounds of the same sort with me, if you haven’t.

Pray write to “trollope”Anthony Trollope. too (or tell Fr Chapman) that I can’t dine anywhere, and must not;—“Fortnightly review” people, what a charming set! Fr Chapn may hunt Hotten to the death, if he will & can; I have totally ignored him (silent as a stone), & care nothing abt his balderdash at all. Here is a Scotsman Paragraph inclosed, for warning“The address—so noble, homely, kindly, wise, and characteristic—delivered by Mr Carlyle on his inauguration as Rector, has now been issued … by Edmonston & Douglas. … It is the only authorised report, which it is the more necessary to state that an unauthorised and uncorrected one has also appeared” (Scotsman, 19 April). of the Edinr people. Basta [Enough]. I only
add Erskine’s Letter too, whh arrived this morng. Lady Caroline Wemyss,Lady Caroline Charteris-Wemyss-Douglas. it appears, is reckoned hardly sane; sails abt the world (kindly borne with, being kind & good), “seeking a baying she cd love!”Coterie speech; see 5:56–57 TC to JAC, 5 Jan. 1830
.—

We are to leave a little before 5 (train starts from Ecclefn, 5.27 in reality; in 38 minutes, due at Dumfries!)—and ought, witht delay to get forward upon my riding or packaging. Adieu, my Dearest; send me better news, clearer any way. What a Party is that of Saty Evg; unexampled in modern society, or nearly so! My regards to Froude.

div3.sourceNote: JWC-TC, [21 April]. Addr: The Hill / Dumfries / N.B. PM: London, 21 April 1866. MS: NLS 609.784. Pbd: Froude, LM 3:336–38; Bliss, JWC 338–39 inc; Simpsons 291–92 inc. Quot: Ashton 445; Hansons 545; Fielding and Sorensen 317–18. TC wrote later on the envelope: “(April 21 (the day of her death! Ah me!) T.C. Dfs 22 April.” After writing this letter, JWC went for lunch with the Forsters; she then took her usual drive in Hyde Park; Tiny the dog, after being let out for a run, was hit by another carriage, and JWC jumped out to take her into the carriage. Silvester became concerned when he heard nothing from her; he asked a passerby to check, and JWC was found to be dead. Her body was then driven to the nearest hospital, St. George’s. For TC’s description of JWC’s death in his journal, see Appendix 249. For further details, see following letters and Appendix. TC later wrote an introduction to this letter: “The last words her hand ever wrote. Why should I tear my heart by reading them so often? They reached me at Dumfries, Sunday, April 22, fifteen hours after the fatal telegram had come. Bright weather this, and the day before I was crippling out Terregles way, among the silent green meadows, at the moment when she left this earth. / Spottiswoodes, King’s Printer people. I durst never see them since. Miss Wynne, I hear is dead of cancer six months ago. / ‘Very equal,’ a thrifty Annandale phrase. / ‘Scende da carrozza’ [descending from the carriage] (Degli Antoni). / ‘Picture of Frederick.’ I sent for it on the Tuesday following, directly on getting to Chelsea. It still hangs there; a poor enough Potsdam print, but to me priceless. / I am at Addiscombe in the room that was long ‘Lady Harriet’s;’ day and house altogether silent. Thursday, August 5, 1869, while I finish this unspeakable revisal (reperusal and study of all her letters left to me). Task of about eleven months, and sad and strange as a pilgrimage through Hades.—T.C.” (TC’s note in Froude, LM 3:335). Terregles, parish W of Dumfries; see JWC to TC, [18 Aug. 1831]; for “scende da carrozza,” see JWC to TC, [14 Aug. 1842].
div3.head:
JWC
TO TC

docBody.p:
Dearest—it seems just a “consuming of Time”See 7:285TC to MAC, 1 Sept. 1834. to write today, when you are coming the day after tomorrow. But—“if there were nothing else in it”—(your
phrase) such a piece of liberality, as letting one have letters on Sunday if called for, should be honoured, at least by availing oneself of it! All long stories however may be postponed till next week.

Indeed I have neither long stories nor short ones to tell this morning. Tomorrow, after the Teaparty, I may have more to say; provided I survive it! Tho’, how I am to entertain, on “my own base” eleven people, in a hot night, “without refreshment” (to speak of) is more than I “see my way” thro’! Even as to cups!—there is only ten cups of company-china, and eleven are coming; myself making 12! “After all, said Jessie; you had once eight at tea! three mair won’t kill us”!— I’m not so sure of that!— Let us hope the motive will sanctify the end, being “the welfare of others”!—an unselfish desire to “make two Baiings [Beings] happy”!See TC to JWC, 20 April . Principal Tulloch and Froude who have a great liking for one another! The Spottiswoods were added in the same philanthropic spirit. We met in a shop, and they begged permission to come again; so I thought it would be clever to get them over (handsomely,—with Froude and Mrs Oliphant) before you came. They couldn’t “ask for more” for a long time! Miss WynnCharlotte Williams Wynn. The other guest, unmentioned by JWC, was Geraldine Jewsbury, who, according to Froude, “was to assist in entertaining us” (Froude, Carlyle 4:311). offered herself, by accident, for that same night.

The MarchionessLady Lothian. was here yesterday twice; called at four when I hadn’t returned,JWC had been visiting Maria Price; Price later recalled: “On the … Friday I was surprised and delighted to see her again, accompanied by Count R[eichenbach], the father of the young German lady I had seen. Mrs Carlyle was radiant, and had brought ‘Punch’ for me to see. The cartoon for the week was ‘Wisdom and Windbag’: on the one side Bright lampooned as ‘Windbag’; Carlyle, with grave dignity, on the other side, was ‘Wisdom,’ and an extract from his speech was given. She was full of wifely pride and triumph, and was anxious for me to share in her pleasure. My father talked with her a great deal that afternoon, and after she had gone, told me Mrs Carlyle had promised him a copy of ‘Past and Present.’ / To the end of time I shall remember that bright little visit, for it was the last. On the next day she died, suddenly, and swiftly departed. … / [T]he sun of my little world had gone” (Price, “Recollections” 35). For the cartoon, see JWC to TC, [12 April] , and 181. and called again at five. She brought with her yesterday a charming old Miss Talbot,Possibly Mary-Anne Talbot (1794–1885) or her sister, Georgina Charlotte Talbot (1796–1870), philanthropist who established schools and almshouses; they were the only children of Sir George Talbot (1763–1850), 3rd bart. and Anne, b. Preston, and had inherited their father’s estates; they lived at 21 Grosvenor Sq.; or possibly a relative of Lady Lothian who was a Chetwynd-Talbot. with a palsied head but the most loveable Babyish old face! She seemed to take to me as I did to her;Jewsbury apparently called on JWC after this visit, as she wrote to Lady Lothian, Sat. 22 [21] April, from 5 Cheyne Row, telling her of JWC’s death: “I know Mrs Carlyle wd not have wished you to hear the sorrowful news from any chance report—for I know the high regard she had for you—you were here yesterday she told me—she spoke of you and the Lady you brought to see her—it had pleased her so much—nobody will ever see her again Mrs Carlyle is dead—she died this afternoon quite suddenly in her Brougham— I know no details for I couldn’t bear them yet—but she is gone— We have sent a telegram to Mr Carlyle who was to return on Monday” (MS: Berg). Jewsbury also wrote to Charlotte Southam, 22 April (see Appendix 259), and to Lady Amberley with news of JWC’s death, 23 [22] April 1866: “To prevent yr hearing accidentally of the terrible sorrow that has fallen on us I write to tell you that Mrs Carlyle is dead—she died yesterday quite suddenly in her Brougham— Mr Carlyle is expected home tomorrow morning early—it will be a sorrowful coming home for him” (MS: NLS 20767.82). and Lady Lothian staid behind a
minute, to ask if I would go with her some day, to see this Miss Talbot who had a Houseful of the finest Pictures.
You should have sent the address to Lord Lothian or Lady— I see several names on the List less worthy of such attention—

Chapman is furious at Hotten—no wonder! When he went round to the Booksellers he found that everywhere Hotten had got the start of him. Smith & Elder had bought five hundred copies from Hotten! and poor Frederick did not receive his copies from Edinr till he had “telegraphed” six and thirty hours after I had received mine!— I saw in an old furniture shop-window at RichmondJWC was in Richmond visiting Margaret Welsh, 19 April. a copy of the Frederich picture that was lent you.TC had been lent a portrait, April 1858, of Frederick the Great by Heinrich Francke (1738–92), by William Warren Vernon (1834–1919); TC returned the portrait Feb. 1860; see 33:208–10
TC to WWV, [21 April 1858] , and TC to WWV, 22 April 1858 . not
bad—coarsely painted; but the likeness well preserved. Would you like to have it? I will, if so, make you a present of it—being to be had “very equal”— I “descended from” the carriage, and asked: “what was that?” (meaning what price was it—)— The Broker told me impressively; “that Mam, is Peter the Great.” “Indeed! and what is the price?”—“seven & sixpence” I offered five shillings on the spot. but he would only come down to six shillings. I will go back for it if you like, and can find a place for it on my wall—

signed.name: JWCTC wrote later: “She lived nineteen days after that Edinburgh Monday; on the nineteenth (April 21, 1866, between three and four p.m., as near as I can gather and sift), suddenly as by a thunderbolt from skies all blue, she was snatched from me: a ‘death from the gods,’ the old Romans would have called it; the kind of death she many a time expressed her wish for” (Carlyle, Reminiscences 191).

div3.sourceNote: TC-JF, 22 April. MS: FC. Quot: Kaplan 472.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN FORSTER

docBody.p:
Yr saddest of messagesTC recalled later that he received two telegrams (see Appendix 249 TC’s Journal Entry ), presumably one from Forster and one from John A. Carlyle. There are several versions of that afternoon; Jessie Hiddleston later wrote: “I was going to identify the body. I gave … Mr. Blunt a letter I had with me from Mr. Carlyle to Mrs. Carlyle, which had arrived that afternoon from Scotland. … The letter was lying on the lobby table when Silvester came for me; and I just took it in my hand, as I knew it would say where Mr. Carlyle was, and that information would be wanted” (Blunt, “CHH” 464–65). Reginald Blunt recalled his father’s dilemma: “When my father arrived at Cheyne Row he found a situation of sad anxiety. No one knew definitely where Carlyle was. Should they open Carlyle’s letter? And would it be possible to avoid an inquest? With some hesitation it was decided to open the letter. He remembers that it was dated from Dumfries, and began with the one word ‘Dearest.’ No more was read; the letter was replaced and the envelope closed; telegrams were sent to John Carlyle and Dr. John Brown [both in Edinburgh] asking them to break the news as best they could at Dumfries” (Blunt, “CHH” 465). Froude later wrote that he was called on by a Cheyne Row servant, and, collecting Geraldine Jewsbury, they drove to the hospital. He then went on to Cheyne Row, where he “found Forster half-distracted, yet, with his vigorous sense, alive to what must immediately be done. Mr. Blunt, the Rector of Chelsea, was also there; he, too, dreadfully shaken, but collected and considerate. Two points had to be considered: how to communicate the news to Carlyle; and how to prevent an inquest and an examination of the body, which Forster said would kill him” (Froude, Carlyle 4:312–13). Froude did not mention TC’s letter in his account of the scene: “As to Carlyle, we did not know precisely where he was, whether at Dumfries or Scotsbrig. In that uncertainty a telegram was sent to John Carlyle at Edinburgh, another to Dr. John Brown, should John Carlyle be absent” (Froude, Carlyle 4:314). For John Brown, see TC to JAC, 22 Nov. 1865
. John A. Carlyle wrote to David Aitken, [22 April] : “Late last night a few minutes after my return from Fife Dr John Brown called with a telegram … stating that Mrs Carlyle had died suddenly in the afternoon; & at a still later hour I myself had one to the effect that she had died in her carriage in the Park” (MS: EUL). came to me last night abt 10. The stroke that has fallen on me is immense; my heart is as if broken.— Tomorrow morng I set out for what can never more be a home to me;—may expect to arrive abt 11 p.m.—my Brother, I can guess (but Edinr has no posts)As there was no postal service in Edinburgh on Sundays, TC could not hear again from John A. Carlyle until Monday. In his letter to David Aitken, John A. Carlyle wrote: “I sent on the sad tidings to my brother at Dumfries, & had a reply, asking me to join him there, as he starts by the Express tomorrow for London—there being no train today— I go off at 9.30 to Lockerbie tonight, hoping to be in Dfrs early enough to catch him tomorrow” (MS: EUL). will accompany or soon follow.

Funeral must be at Haddington; with my best power of computing, I have named Wednesday morning as the date of our leaving London; arrive at Haddington perhaps 9 p.m.;—Funeral to be next day Thursday 26. That in my bewildert is the best I can settle.

Pray, therefore, lose not a moment; go down to Chelsea, and commence the necessary preparatns:For the transfer of JWC’s body north to Haddington. I am told they can be easily completed in the course of Tuesday. Do this for me, dear F,—and for her.Reginald Blunt later described Forster’s meeting with his father, Sat. 21 April: “John Forster … came on to see my father at the rectory. He was in a state of uncontrolled distraction and excitement as to how an inquest, which he knew would be a cruel aggravation of Carlyle’s sufferings, but which, from what had been said at the hospital, seemed inevitable, might be avoided. My father agreed that an effort should be made, and any influence brought to bear on the authorities, to obviate this, and Forster went off at once to Dr. Quain, Mrs. Carlyle’s physician, and thence to St. George’s Hospital, where, armed with the doctor’s certificate, he was able to arrange for the removal of the body to Cheyne Row” (Blunt, “CHH” 465). An inquest was normally demanded in cases of sudden death but Richard Quain, who attended JWC in her illness, 1863–64, and had seen her socially, early Jan., certified JWC’s “spinal disease as the cause of death under the circumstances” (Marrs 753); Froude wrote later: “Forster … was a lunacy commissioner, and had weight with official persons. Dr. Quain had attended Mrs. Carlyle in her illness, and from him I believe Forster obtained a certificate of the probable cause of her death, which was received as sufficient” (Froude, Carlyle 4:313–14). She is to lie beside her Father (promise 39 years old); and I must come and convey in person,—or forever suffer for it. As my Brother is to be with me, there is no need of your taking such a journey.— I have, just now, a Letter from her hand, written in the most perfect spirits, date “Saturday” 21st!—
On Monday night, then, there will lie some Note from you at Chelsea. Adieu, my friend & hers.

div3.sourceNote: TC-SW [SWA], [22 April]. MS: Hornel. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: TC TO SARAH WARREN

docBody.p: Good Mrs Warren I hope & believe you are using all yr prudence and good sense in this terrible catastrophe that has come upon us! Telegram reached me here at 10 p.m. yesternight. Monday morng I set out for Chelsea (my Brother probably with me, or near at hand); we can expect to arrive abt 11 p.m.;—have the rooms ready. We calculate to go away agn, Wednesday morning on our sad errand.To Haddington, for JWC’s funeral.
If Mr Forster begin anything to morrow (Monday morng), you will be sure to forward him all you can.
No more, at this moment.

div3.sourceNote: TC-WD [WDO], 22 April. MS: Strouse. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 6:68.
div3.head: TC TO WILLIAM DODS

docBody.p: There has come to me, last night, the saddest of all earthly message: My dear & noble Wife suddenly reft away from me; “Died yesterday afternoon” (Saty 21 April ,) “in her carriage in the Park,” says one of the two Telegrams; and I have yet no other details. Half an hour ago, there is of date also “Saty” a Letter in her own hand to me, longish & writen in perfect spirits! Judge of my situatn.

Long ago it was her covenant with me that she was to lie beside her Father in Haddington Churchyard; and, within these two years, she repeatedly made me promise that I shd write at once to you,William Dods had known JWC from childhood and was one of her last friends in Haddington. She had probably last seen him when he and his wife visited Chelsea Oct. 1861; see 38:70 JWC to JAD, 8 March 1862
. For a photograph of him(wrongly captioned), see 39:63 JWC to MR, [17 Feb. 1863] .—who whoRepeated at top of new page. wd immediately, for her sake, undertake all the arrangts. In perfect faith I write accordingly.

The day of Funeral at Haddington ought to be Thursday next (Thursday 26th): I calculate that I must leave London, with my sacred burden (my Brother probably escorting) on Wedny morning, from King’s Cross by the mail train: that brings us to Haddingtn (or as near it as we can get) probably abt 8 p.m.? But you shall hear more precisely from London: or perhaps you can yrself instruct me precisely as to place and hour. We will calculate on seeing yr friendly face, with the necessary conveyance &c, & the sympathy whh is so valuable to the overwhelmed

div3.sourceNote: JAC-WD [WDO], 24 April. MS: NLS 1797.116. Written on black-edged paper. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JOHN A. CARLYLE TO WILLIAM DODS

docBody.p: I hold the pen for my brother who is not himself able to write at present.
He telegraphed to you this morning the intention which I now describe in detail.

My brother & myself, with our friend Mr Forster, will leave by the Express from King’s Cross at 10 a.m., bringing the coffin with us. The Railway authorities have given an order by which the Express will be specially stopped for us at Longniddry.Longniddry, village and nearest main line stn., about 7 mi. (11 km.) W of Haddington. This will be, it is calculated, at or near eight o’clock tomorrow (Wednesday) night.

We wish therefore that you will have the great kindness to have a hearse in attendance to receive the coffin—and a carriage that will convey us three—from Longniddry to Haddington. It is my brother’s wish that the coffin should be taken to a private hotel or house, as you may find it possible to arrange; as he could on no account bear that the funeral should proceed from a railway station.

If it be practicable to obtain a lodging in a hotel or private house for the night—for Mr Forster & myself—you will yourself perhaps, if your house is in a quiet locality,Jane and William Dods lived in Court St., Haddington’s main thoroughfare. be able kindly to receive & lodge my brother for that night at Haddington.

You will be so good as to appoint the funeral for twelve o’clock on Thursday. The undertaker at HaddingtonProbably Thomas Ormiston (b. 1825). will have to make arrangements & provision for everything that is necessary in taking the coffin from Longniddry Station to Haddington, & from thence the next day to the place of burial.
What we bring with us is simply the coffin which encloses a leaden coffin within, (the outer one being of Oak); & the dimensions outside are two feet wide by six feet four inches long.
My brother desires to have the funeral as quiet as possible, so that you will please to invite only those whom it is absolute necessary to invite as old friends or acquaintances of my sister-in-law

closer.salute: I am, / Dear Sir, / yours sincerely,

postscript.p: W. Dods Esq

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 28 April. MS: NLS 518.25. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NL 2:235–36.
div3.head:
TC
TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p:
You will read these Three Letters with a very melancholy interest;—especially the one of them I wrote from Scotsbrig the morning we left for Dumfries; and will regret with me to the end of yr life that she did not see it; alas, no, no; it was not posted at Ecclefn by 6 p.m. in time for the morng mail of London; wd come abt 2 p.m. by whh time she was gone out, never to return more— Oh why didn’t I post it myself at BackburnBackburn, nearest post office, ½ mi. (1 km.) E of Scotsbrig. as I rode past; why did I wait for anything,—why did Jamie ‘junr’ make any delay in posting! But alas what is the use of such reflexion:—was not her own death caused by the hurt toe of a miserable little scraping of a dog hardly even hers? That wretched animalcule has done me more mischief than all the men and animals that have ever lived in the world in my time!Tiny, left to JWC by Clara Chapman (see JWC to LLA, [16 March] ), was consistently blamed by TC for JWC’s death; see his note to MW to TC, 28 [29] March
. According to Jessie Hiddleston, Tiny was never brought back to Cheyne Row and was probably taken from the hospital by Count von Reichenbach; when Reichenbach later asked to keep her, TC replied: “Tell him to take it, and never let me set eyes on it again!” (Blunt, “CHH” 467). We must take these paltrinesses to us, also; they were part of our bitter cup.

The Letter she wrote after that of Scotsbrig shd have arrived you will never forget reading with me last Sunday; after writing so, she lunched with the Forsters (old friends), was never seen more brilliantly cheerful, well beyond wont, and seemed to eat better than usual: “my Friend coming home to me, day after tomorrow!”—and within ½ or ¾ of an hour, she sat dead. Oh, that monday night, oh this week in genl; the black week of my poor life.— But she died happy & victorious, in the way she had always wished to do.— — No more; this is my first writing, & my hand is as you see.

In a few days I will write agn. Day by day I am getting bits of order introduced into this great overturn of my past existence; that is the only thing she wd have wished as a consolatn to me. I saw her dead face twice: beautiful as Eternity, soft as an angel’s or as a babe’s.Froude described seeing JWC in the hospital: “There, on a bed in a small room, we found Mrs. Carlyle, beautifully dressed, dressed as she always was, in quietly perfect taste. Nothing had been touched. Her bonnet had not been taken off. It was as if she had sate upon the bed after leaving the brougham, and had fallen back upon it asleep. But there was an expression on her face which was not sleep, and which, long as I had known her, resembled nothing which I had ever seen there. The forehead, which had been contracted in life by continued pain, had spread out to its natural breadth, and I saw for the first time how magnificent it was. The brilliant mockery, the sad softness with which the mockery alternated, both were alike gone. The features lay composed in a stern majestic calm. I have seen many faces beautiful in death, but never any so grand as hers” (Froude, Carlyle 4:312–13). Jewsbury wrote to TC, 26 May: “Those who saw her at the hospital speak of the beautiful expression on her face” (Froude, LM 3:340). D. A. Wilson criticized Froude’s passage in particular: “The mention of a great change in the face by Froude is palpable fiction. He goes far beyond Miss Jewsbury’s fanciful statement, and is discredited not only by the silence of Blunt, who saw her at the same time and knew her better, and by the general probabilities arising from the facts beyond dispute” (Wilson, Carlyle 6:67). Put in these 4 Letters into the Miss
W’sProbably the Misses Welsh, JWC’s aunts in Edinburgh. cover,—and despatch despatchWord repeated with a line over it at turn of page. to them by Monday’s mail, that you may have time for reading them (yourself only).— I will walk all day; my sleep only half come back: well otherwise. God bless you, dear Sister, & reward yr sympathy & kindness for me.

signed.name: T.C.Moncure Conway wrote, 25 April: “I cannot, and will not, try to say how deeply I mourn at the heavy sorrow that has come upon you,—upon you and how many others that have recognised the worth of her who was so truly a help meet for you. Every heart knoweth its own bitterness and a stranger intermeddleth not therewith.”

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], 28 [30?] April. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Written on black-edged paper. Hitherto unpbd. TC wrote that it was nine days since JWC d. and Lady Ashburton’s letter from Italy, dated 26 April, had arrived; he probably misdated.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: I cannot write even to you:Lady Ashburton wrote to TC, 26 April, as soon as she heard the news of JWC’s death: “Oh! my Beloved friend— What can I say to you in this desolation? only weep with you—over one we love so well— Can it be true we shall never again be cheered, & encouraged, by her bright & tender spirit?— How different Earth will always seem to us both, now she has left it. To me, there can never come such another friend— to you, what can be before you, but Desolation? & oh! Well so I know, what that word means— May God support, & comfort you.” silence (in the utmost seclusion I can get) can alone express to myself or others the state I am in since Saty 21st. Sudden, like a bolt from the skies all shining bright, the stroke fell; and has shattered my whole existence into immeasurable ruin. Since that Saty (10 p.m. at Dumfries, perhaps abt 3½ p.m. in Hyde Park), the nine days that have passed are like no other I ever had since I was born. My heart feels as if broken; overwhelmed, in mean wrecks of things secular & prosaic, and in deluges of sacred sorrow, to whh, except slowly from time & reflexion, there is no alleviation possible.

Thursday last, she was committed to her Father’s Grave, in the Abbey Kirk at Haddington, and now sleeps there,—as was the covenant between us, 40 years ago or nearly so. Her death was swift, (as had always been her prayer); swift, I am led to think, almost as lightning from the skies; and she passed
away as in a blaze of splendour, victory (late, but bright & complete to her) crowning her whole noble life & her. For her life from the time we met was and continued all mine; and she had fought and toiled for me, valiantly at all moments up to that last,—how loyally, lovingly and bravely, & thro’ what sore paths and difficulties, is now known only to God and one living mortal. Sixteen hours after the fatal telegram at Dumfries, there came to me a Letter written on the Saty morning (perhaps two hours before her death), in the cheeriest spirits any had yet been (and they were all cheerful, prosperous, even joyful, after “April 3”), and I think, the longest of all,—in bright hope that we shd meet “the day after tomorrow.” Indeed for a fortnight before, all testimony is, That she looked brighter, gayer, and felt better, than for years past. That is the last value I shall ever get of my poor bits of “successes,” whh, for her sake, were and now are really precious to me, but had otherwise the character mainly of mere confusions, and can henceforth have no value to me.

Maggie Welsh is here, unraveling the dismal chaos to meGeraldine Jewsbury reported to Lady Amberley, 29 April: “Miss Welsh asked me to assist her in making an Inventory of all her things & it has occupied us a good deal to get it done before his return” (MS: NLS 20767.84); Maggie Welsh then continued sorting JWC’s possessions after TC’s return, 27 April. For the rest of Jewsbury’s letter, see Appendix 260–61. (for I did not even know a key in the house); my Brother too has attended me throughout; and I am gradually recovering my sleep;—day after day, since Friday morng last, endeavouring slowly to settle the wreck of my existence into some incipiency of order; and to see round me me,Word repeated with a line over it at turn of page. instead of a gloomy confusion, something of regulatn, whh is as yet not less gloomy, but almost more. Except Froude yesterday I have admitted nobody;TC had been visited by John Tyndall, Mon. 23 April; he had read the notice of JWC’s death in the Times, 23 April, at Southampton railway stn. and “sped to London, and … found a note from Miss Jewsbury. … ‘For Heaven’s sake … come and see the old man; he is utterly heart-broken.’… I drove forthwith to Chelsea. The door was opened by Carlyle’s old servant, Mrs. Warren, who informed me that her master was in the garden. I joined him there, and we immediately went up-stairs together. It would be idle, perhaps sacrilegious on my part, to attempt any repetition of his language. In words, the flow of which might be compared to a molten torrent, he referred to the early days of his wife and himself—to their struggles against poverty and obstruction; to her valiant encouragement in hours of depression; to their life on the moors, in Edinburgh, and in London—how lovingly and loyally she had made of herself a soft cushion to protect him from the rude collisions of the world. … Three or four times during the narrative he utterly broke down. I could see the approach of the crisis and prepare for it. After thus giving away, a few sympathetic words would cause him to rapidly pull himself together, and resume the flow of his discourse. … While he thus spoke to me, all that remained of his wife lay silent in an adjoining room” (Tyndall, “Personal Recollections” 18–19). one very kind little note from Miss Bromley I kept, one and abt two others; the rest I cd not myself read: signature & subject were all they contained of tolerable to me.

By no means think of coming hither on my acct, kind Lady;Lady Ashburton wrote: “would my presence in England be any consolation to you? if so, I will gratefully hasten to your side— Will you let us each, be legacies to one another, during the remainder of our mortal pilgrimage? I left by him, & You by her— Let me be of some use to you—you don’t know how tenderly I will try.” nobody can help me here: I must dree my wierd, & the one help will be that I have faithfully done it. My Brothr yesterday came in with some report (from Miss Farrar,Annie Louisa Farrer (1818–1910), old friend of the Ashburtons’; see 38:279 38:biographical notes . I think) that you had quitted Mentone and were probably now in England: the thot of that was, I confess, as a spark of light for moments; but reflexion even then ansd, No! It is true, too, all thro’ the Winter, while writing nothing I thot much of you; and to both of us it was a very disappointing and regretful consideratn that you had quitted English life, or seemed to be quitting it:—and to myself still, when you do come to Engld for good, it will be a bit of real consolatn; but not before that, not before!—
I send my kindest regards to yr precious little DarlingLady Ashburton’s da., Mary Florence. & you;—the thanks due from me I feel to be boundless.

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady AS [LAS], 1 May. Copy: NLS 1776.139; the copy of TC’s letter was by John A. Carlyle. Pbd: Froude, Carlyle 4:321.
div3.head: TC TO LADY Augusta STANLEY

docBody.p: This gracious mark of her Majesty’s sympathyLady Augusta Stanley, at the Queen’s request, wrote to John A. Carlyle, 30 April: “I was here when the news of the terrible calamity with which your Brother has been visited reached Her Majesty—and was received by Her with feelings of sympathy and regret all the more keen from the lively interest with which the Queen has so recently followed the proceedings in Edinburgh— / Her Majesty expressed a wish that … I should convey to Mr Carlyle the expression of these feelings, and the assurance of Her sorrowful understanding of a grief, which she herself alas! knows too well.— / It was with heartfelt interest that the Queen heard yesterday that Mr Carlyle has been able to make the effort to return to his desolate home & that you are with him” (MS: NLS 1776.135). touches me with many feelings, sad & yet beautiful & high.
Will you, in the proper manner, with my humblest respects, express to her Majesty my profound sense of her great goodness to me in this the day of my calamity.
I can write to nobody; it is best for me, at present, when I do not even speak to anybody.

closer.salute: Believe me, / yours with many grateful regards, /

postscript.p: the Lady Augusta StanleyLady Augusta Stanley continued: “I dare not intrude any words of my own, but I long to say to you what a source of infinite pleasure & benefit I felt it to be to have made Mrs Carlyle’s acquaintance … when two years since I got to know her personally, I felt indeed what a privilege it was—and I think I can in some measure comprehend what utter desolation your Brother’s must be” (MS: NLS 1776.135). TC wrote to JWC about meeting, 25 Sept. 1864, Lady Augusta Stanley, who was “really interested in you” and would call on her return to London, Nov. 1864 (41:53); she presumably met JWC then.

div3.sourceNote: TC-TE, 1 May. Pbd: Froude, Carlyle 4:317–18; Friedrich Althaus, “Thomas Carlyle,” Two Reminiscences of Thomas Carlyle, ed. John Clubbe (Durham, NC, 1974) 5 inc. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 6:80.
div3.head:
TC
TO THOMAS ERSKINE

docBody.p: Your little word of sympathyErskine wrote, 26 April: “What can man say to you, but; that not a sparrow falleth to the ground without your Father— That underlies all things & surely has endless consolation in it, if we can take hold of it— / I write this to you, because I feel that I have nothing else to write, & yet that I ought to express my sympathy with you in this great sorrow— My sister joins me in kindest regards. … / I had hoped to be with you on thursday at the funeral—but when I went to the station, I found it filled by a dense crowd, which I could not penetrate.” went to my heart, as few of the many others could do. Thanks for it. Thanks also, and many of them, for your visit to poor Betty,Erskine ended his note: “I have seen Mrs Braid, as I know she herself would have wished me to do.” to whom I have yet written nothing, though well aware that of all living hearts but one, hers is the saddest on this occasion. Pray go out to her again after a time, and say that so long as I live in the world, I wish and propose to keep sight of her, and in any distress that may fall on her, to ask myself what I can do to be of help to that good soul.

Hitherto I write to nobody, see nobody but my brother and Maggie Welsh, of Auchtertool. Indeed, I find it is best when I do not even speak to anybody. The stroke that has fallen on me is immeasurable, and has shattered in pieces my whole existence, which now suddenly lies all in ruins round me. In her name, whom I have lost, I must try to repair it, rebuild it into something of order for the few years or days that may remain to me, try not to waste them further, but to do something useful with them, under the stern monition I have had. If I but can, that should be my way of honouring her, whose history on earth now lies before me, all bathed in sorrow, but beautiful exceedingly, nay, of a kind of epic grandeur and heroic nobleness, known only to one heart
now. God bless you, dear Mr. Erskine. You will not forget me, Mrs. Stirling and you; nor will I either of you.

signed.name: T. Carlyle.Erasmus Darwin wrote, 2 May: “I cannot refrain from writing you one word to say how much I feel your great loss. / My intercourse with your dear wife had been one of the great pleasures of my life & I shall never cease thinking of her with gratitude & affection. / Of the loss to you I can say absolutely nothing.”

div3.sourceNote: TC-BB, 2 May. MS: NLS 3278.137. Written on black-edged paper. Quot: Kaplan 476.
div3.head: TC TO BETTY BRAID

docBody.p: I cannot write to you, not even to you,—tho’ I am aware that, except my own heart, there is no heart living more sad than yours, under this great misery that has suddenly come.Both Geraldine Jewsbury (22 [21] April; see Appendix 259) and John A. Carlyle (24 April, see below) wrote to Betty Braid to tell her of JWC’s death; John ended his letter: “My brother who is not fit for writing any letters at present bids me send you his kindest remembrances.” I send you the Inclosed to buy you a suit of mourning for her;TC noted in his checkbook: “2 May 1866 / to Elizth Braid (poor old Betty; poor old me!) / £25 .. 0 .. 0.” TC also sent money to his sister Mary, noting in his checkbook: “4 May 1866 / to Sister Mary (‘Dress,’—ah me!) / £25 .. 0 .. 0.” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). she loved you, as you know, right well;—and there are Two, as I reckon, from whose memory she will never pass while they are in this world.

Yr “table-cloth of yr mother’s spinning,”For the tablecloth, see JWC to TC, 6 April
. Betty’s mother was Christian Pringle, b. Hay (b. 1776). I was bidden “take special care” of it;—and it is now here where there is none to own the Address. You will let me keep it; in memory of yr faithful love to one whose loss is the loss of all that was of value to me in this world. My life looks desolate, lonely, as sad as it can be: but we must endeavour to say, God’s will be done.

My Brother is with me, & Miss Welsh of Auchtertool: Mr Erskine said, he called on you;John A. Carlyle wrote to Betty Braid, 24 April: “I saw Mr Erskine on Sunday [23 April] before leaving Edinburgh, & I hope he will soon make another visit to you as he spoke of doing” (MS: NLS 3278.135). by and by he will call again, I expect, with something I bade him tell you.

Do not write to me at present; merely take that Newspaper (N. York Tribune, sent herewith); put the inclosed cover round it; and that will be sign enough.Newspapers were delivered free of charge, so Betty could acknowledge receipt of the check without paying for a stamp. Blessings be on you, dear Betty.—

div3.sourceNote: MW-EA, [2 May]. MS: EUL. Written on black-edged paper. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: MARGARET WELSH TO ELIZA AITKEN

docBody.p:
Mr Caryle has asked me to write to thank you very much for your most kind letter to him. You can well believe that he is unable to do or to think of any thing but what he absolutely must do. So he thinks you will forgive his not writing to you himself. He is on the whole, poor man, as well as one could almost have hoped to see him, (or indeed in some ways better) when one thinks of all the fearful suddenness & the sad circumstances of poor Cousin’s death for him. His being away from her at the time, & she herself being so very cheerful (& really well for her) writing each day to him in such good spirits & so much pleased with all that took place in Edinburgh, all this naturally only made the blow come more severely. Dr Carlyle as you know is with him; I had been spending two months in London this Spring, & had been staying
with dear Cousin for a few days while he Mr C was away.For Maggie Welsh’s visit, see MW to TC, 28 [29] March
, and JWC to TC, 30 March
. I only left her the day after the Installation took place, & went to visit my brother in Liverpool. Though she has looked to me very frail ever since that severe illness she had two years ago, she has been so cheerful & so happy these last few months, that one knew she must be feeling better & I had fain hoped she might have yet been spared to poor Mr Carlyle & us all for some time to come. You can believe what a sad shock to me it was, when only a fortnight after they telegraphed for me to come, but alas! it was too late to do any thing for her. She did so dread another long illness poor thing, that one feels as if for herself her sudden, & truly apparently painless death had been granted her in mercy. But for those she has left to grieve for her it was very sad. I am glad to feel as if I were of some little help to poor Mr Carlyle at this sad time though it is little real comfort that any one can give him poor man. I have been very busy with little things & sad ones too, that I feel as if I had not yet taken in the sad fact that poor Cousin will come back to us no more! She was speaking of you to me only the last time I saw her, & seemed to be looking forward with so much real pleasure to seeing you again. From her Mother & from herself I have heard so often of you dear Mrs Aitken that though I have never seen you, I do not feel as if I were writing to a stranger. All my life I have heard of you & of your Uncle,Eliza Aitken’s uncle was John Bradfute (1764–1837), Edinburgh bookseller; see 1:204 JBW to EA, [early Oct. 1819] . Eliza lived with him before her marriage, and JBW stayed with them often at 22 George Sq., Edinburgh. For the plaque commemorating JWC on the wall of no. 22, see above. so you will forgive my writing to you as I have done.

figure.p: Plaque commemorating Jane Welsh Carlyle, 22 George Sq., Edinburgh

docBody.p: Mr Carlyle begged me to give his kindest regards to Dr Aitken & to yourself.
With my own kind regards / Believe me / Dear Mrs Aitken

div3.sourceNote: JAC-WD [WDO], 4 May. MS: NLS 1797.124. Written on black-edged paper. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head:
JOHN A. CARLYLE
TO WILLIAM DODS

docBody.p:
I have this morning received your kind letter together with the Accts of the undertaker &c. which have been paid by you. My brother desires me to enclose cheque for the amount, together with his sincerest thanks for all the Trouble you have taken in the matter.TC recorded in his checkbook: “5 May 1866 / (to Wm Dodds Esqr Haddington: ah me!) / £9 .. 19 .. 3” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). The plan with dimensions of the Grave
Stone & the Inscription on it, he will take some time to consider & then write to you himself on the subject of Inscription to be added.

He continues as well as could be expected,TC was writing about his last months with JWC, interjecting dated comments about his feelings and activities, some of which are incorporated into the notes at appropriate points: “(But I will give over; no end to paltry interruptions; and poor trivialities bursting in upon my most sacred thoughts (Monday, 7th May, 2.30 p.m.))” (Carlyle, Reminiscences 188). & gets out every day for some exercise, the weather being now fine.
With kind respects to Mrs Dods,

signed.name: JA CarlyleTC also wrote a check for Silvester: “2 May 1866 / to Silvester (brougham:—done, alas, forever! 11 days ago) / £20 .. 13 .. 9” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753).

div3.sourceNote: MW-MO, [8 May]. MS: NLS 23210. Written on black-edged paper. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: MARGARET WELSH TO MARGARET OLIPHANT

docBody.p: Mr Carlyle has asked me to write for him to thank you very gratefully for your most kind note to him. Some time by & bye, he bids me say, he hopes to see you to thank you himself. As you can believe at present, for now, he feels little able for anything but what he absolutely must do. He seems to think with great interest, & even comfort almost, if he can feel that in any thing just now, of those two or three happy days that she spent with you only so lately.JWC visited Margaret Oliphant in Windsor 6–8 April. She wrote to him so cheerfully about the little visit & seemed so to have enjoyed it. One can hardly re-alizeThus in MS. to oneself that she is really gone & not to come back to us, for all things about one look as if they were only waiting for her. Truly one cannot re-alize what a desolate home it must feel to her poor husband, & one knows that as days & weeks go by the terrible, & sudden, loneliness will only be the more sadly felt by him.

He is almost better, to outward appearance, than one might have hoped to see him, but he does look so sad & heartbroken almost. It is touching to see the patience & gentleness with which he bears his sorrow.TC wrote, 9 May: “My foot still pains and lames me; I am going today (the second time after some interval to try her black mare (awkward big stalking creature), whom she called ‘Bellona,’—ah that ‘Bellona,’ how it cuts me to the heart what a world of pathos, of melting sorrow and tenderness over her noble gratitude for the small, small gift which was all I had for her!)—to follow her counsel in that; and at least rest my ancle for a day. Brougham and mare offered in vain to her Aunts in Edinburgh, are to go to Walter Welsh of Auchtertool, her Cousin, who is lame,—whose Father [John Welsh] at least she much loved. Sell it I could not, on second thoughts; how could I ever think of doing so!— My one solace and employment hitherto is that of sorting up, and settling as I judge she would have wished, all that pertained to her beautiful existence and her: her advice on it all, how that wish starts out on me strangely at many a turn; and the sharp twinge that reminds me, ‘No!’ One’s first awakening in the morning, the reality all stript so bare before one, and the puddle of confused dreams at once gone, is the ghastliest half-hour of the day;—as I have heard others remark. On the whole there is no use in writing here. There is even a lack of sincerity in what I write (strange but true). The thing I would say, I cannot. All words are idle. (Here comes Forster;—this day fortnight was her Burial-day!)” (Carlyle, Reminiscences 194–95). God grant they
may not fail him, for to him at his years & after the many many years they have gone through life together, the loss must ever be a most sore one. He almost dreads the days that are coming, only it is a mercy to see him able to bear up at all at the present time & one can but have trust for the future.
With kind regards dear Mrs Oliphant / Believe me /

div3.sourceNote: TC-JR [JRU], 10 May. MS: Yale. Pbd: Ruskin’s Works 18:xlvii—xlviii; Cate 117–18. Quot: W. G. Collingwood, Life of Ruskin (1893) 2:62; Wilson, Carlyle 6:81–82.
div3.head: TC TO JOHN RUSKIN

docBody.p: Dear Ruskin,—Your kind words from Dijon were welcome to me:Ruskin noted in his diary that he wrote to TC, 6 May; letter untraced. Ruskin called at Cheyne Row on the afternoon of 21 April and was told of JWC’s death; he did not tell the friends he was traveling with (see JWC to TC, [15 April] ) until the news reached them in Paris; see Collingwood, Life of Ruskin 2:261–62. thanks. I did not doubt your sympathy in what has come; but it is better that I see it laid before me. You are yourself very unhappy, as I too well discern—heavy-laden, obstructed and dispirited; but you have a great work still ahead, and will gradually have to gird yourself up against the heat of the day, which is coming on for you,—as the Night too is coming.Cf. John 9:4. Think valiantly of these things.

I cannot write to you; I do not wish yet even to speak to anybody; find it more tolerable to gaze steadily in silence on the blackness of the abysses that have suddenly opened round me, and as it were swallowed up my poor little world. Day by day the stroke that has fallen, like a thunderbolt out of skies all blue (as I often think), becomes more immeasurable to me; my life all laid in ruins, and the one light of it as if gone out. And yet there is an inexpressible beauty, and even an epic greatness (known only to God and me), in the Life of my victorious little Darling whom I shall see no more.TC was probably looking at JWC’s photograph albums at this time as he wrote, 9 or 10 May: “I have no Portrait of my lost Darling; nothing but a miniature (taken by Macleay, in Edinburgh) shortly before our marriage; it has the fine sunny smile of her face, but wants the sharp delicacy of featuring; represents a much heavier and less seriously spiritual countenance. The Photographs are old, and one and all completely unjust, and have abolished the finer traits. Some one of them I must select as the bad-best, and treasure it. She was so anxious about my poor portrayings; and wholly neglected her own” (Carlyle, Reminiscences 194). For JWC’s miniature by Kenneth Macleay (1802–78; ODNB), see 32:16 JWC to MR, [24 Oct. 1856] . TC began writing comments 7 Oct. 1867 underneath many of the photographs (Thomas Carlyle Photograph Albums, Columbia Univ.); under two recent photographs of JWC, both taken in 1865, he wrote, “My own Jane (a distorted Likeness),” see frontis., and “My own Jane (very recognizable, an unfavourable Likeness),” see 42:48 TC to JWC, 29 May 1865
. For another, possibly also 1865, “this the worst,” according to TC; see Kaplan 453. Silence about all
that; every word I speak or write of it seems to desecrate it,—so unworthy of the Fact now wrapt in the Eternities, as God has willed.
Come and see me when you get home; come oftener and see me, and speak more frankly to me (for I am very true to your highest interests and you) while I still remain here.

You can do nothing for me in Italy; except come home improved. If you pass through or near Montey (in the Valais, not far from Vevey, I think) you might call on (Dowager) Lady Ashburton,Monthey, Valais, on the N shore of Lake Geneva, Switzerland; Lady Ashburton was now in Nice; see TC to LLA, 20 May
. and bring me some report of her.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 14 May. MS: NLS 518.26. Written on black-edged paper. Pbd: A. Carlyle, NL 2:236–37 inc. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 6:79.
div3.head:
TC
TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p: It is no want of kindness or grateful affectn that prevents my writing to you. But I write to nobody,—literally so. There is but one topic, that lies in all my thots by day and night, in all forms high and low;—and on that, all mortals but myself are comparatively little concerned (however kindly sympathetic they may feel); and it is better, and more tolerable for me, that I keep that locked in my own sad mind. Universal overturn has tumbled all my little world to ruins for me; into this I am drawn & driven to look steadily, and see by degrees what there is that I can do with it.

My ancle is getting at last nearly well; I rode thrice, on her poor Horse she was so proud of;Bellona; TC wrote, 11 May: “Yesterday, paid off the last of the accounts; no desecrating intermixtures farther. I have twice ridden her poor ‘Bellona’ (never would while she bade me) with many thoughts,—for relief of my foot. See nobody; think of nothing but her, in the bustle of the Parks now all tragic to me” (Carlyle, Reminiscences 195). TC presumably referred to the check he wrote, 10 May: “To Callow,—(messenger of Fate, ah me!) / £48 .. 3 .. 0” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). George Callow (1815–85), undertaker, “Black Horse,” 7 Abbey St. E., London; the undertaker’s costs presumably included the railway transport to Longniddry. and the rest to sinew & bone had good effects. In genl, my health is not worse; rather otherwise perhaps, for I do nothing, but wander abt in the solitary air, whenever there is good possibility: indeed all this is of smaller concernt than usual to me. Carriage & Horse are to go to Walter Welsh (son of one whom she loved much, & who is lame, & needs such a thing), I believe, next week.Rev. Walter Welsh, minister at Auchtertool, Fife, son of JWC’s maternal uncle John Welsh; see also MW to MO, [8 May] , and TC to GEJ, 22 May
.

The Dr seems well & comfortable; is prompt as possible to do any service to me; but there is not now much in his power. Maggie Welsh & he keep the House from being so ghastly to me, as in its emptiness it wd otherwise be. Maggie is an active orderly polite creature, with a certn truth of sympathy in my sorrow,—and will go at any moment, or stay longer, as I like. Everything is catalogued, and arranged (I believe), in the House;Maggie did the inventory of JWC’s belongings when TC was in Haddington at JWC’s funeral, 26 April, and then continued with sorting them; see TC to LLA, 28 [30?] April
. but I have not yet had the heart to take it any way in hand.

James junr comes hither from time to time; and is always modest, quiet & eager to be of use. Some faint symptoms of busss in his new enterprise, too,
seem to be opening for him.Jean’s son James, living at 59 Elinore St., Islington, was trying to establish a business as a shipbroker; see JWC to TC, [30 March] .— This is all at prest, dear Sister. Don’t trouble yrself writing to me, unless you feel an impulse otherwise: in genl, you know I cannot ansr by return.

signed.name: T. CarlyleTC noted the death of JWC’s cousin Robert Welsh who d. of consumption; his callers, 13 May, included Henry Taylor, “Arthur Russell, and his young French Wife,” and “Forster to ‘walk’ me”; Froude and Emilie Venturi called, 15 May (Carlyle, Reminiscences 196). Venturi had apparently also called earlier soon after TC returned from Scotland: “Mr. Carlyle was in Scotland when his wife died. He returned immediately to London and I went to see him at once. The servant told me she had orders to admit no visitors, but I well knew he would not refuse to see one as unhappy as himself. He was quite alone; he looked up as the door opened and seeing me, said very gently: ‘Ah! is it you?’ He rose and came forward with both hands stretched towards me, his wonderful eyes filled with tears as he put his arms round me, saying: ‘Sister in sorrow! sister in sorrow.’ We both wept silently for some minutes, then looking very pitifully at me, he said: ‘poor thing, poor thing; your hair has gone grey. Well, well; my heart is as grey as it’” (Emilie Venturi, “A Memory of Thomas Carlyle,” Paternoster Review, 2 [1890]: 125–26).

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], 20 May. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Written on black-edged paper. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head:
TC
TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p:
Yr letter came 3 days ago; the voice of yr kindness, be sure, is always precious to me; you too have had a real loss in Her who is gone, tho’ not a loss like mine,Lady Ashburton wrote from Nice, 13 May: “I wish I cd tell you how grateful I was for that letter— how constantly I am with you in thought— It is a kind of consolation to know how tenderly she was loved wherever she was known— that her memory will ever be a precious possession to all there— / For myself I can indeed say—that is gone with her, which can never come back— I never look to have such a friend again in my life, & I miss the consciousness of her truth & devotion, even at this distance—in very daily life. I am always feeling for her, & she is not there—if so, with me—what must it be to you—whose whole life was encompassed by her love?” whh transcends all my arithmetic, and has stript my poor existence here, and as if blotted out any light there still was in my decaying days. I have nothing new to tell you; I am very quiet, as much as may be, silent; a dreary leaden sky of sorrow lying over me, whh will not abate, or soften into calm, for a long time. A pious and heavenly remembrance I have, too, of the Forty years that are gone; nothing to remember of her but cheerful magnanimity in all fortunes, a noble constancy of valour, graceful truth, good sense; and such a loyalty and love to me, at all times, as is grand to me to think of,—me all
un
worthy of such beautiful heroism, and now first measuring the real extent of it when it is gone from me forevermore! Thank God for the balm of such a memory as she has left me, amid so many sorrows!— I am doing nothing, except as heretofore, all little things whh I can consider as of her silent bidding: by and by, I shall either rally into something of new activity; and find work of a useful kind for my final days, or soon rejoin her in the place where no farther work is required of us.— Enough of all this; too much of it. Miss Welsh and my Brr are still likely to continue here some time; my health is coming round to the poor old point it was at, whh I was used to;—and I have nothing more to say abt my insignificant self at prest.

Baillie,James Bailey (b. ca. 1809), butler at The Grange; see 42:4 JWC to LLA, [2 May 1865] . when he called here, had given me to understand you were at Montey [Monthey] in the Valais (so I made it out, from the Dictionnaries & him); and I directed Ruskin to ask for you there, if he passed thro’ Vevay, & to bring me word. He is gone to Italy, for a Tour with two Young friends;See JWC to TC, [15 April] . and will return I know not at what time of the season, or whether by Switzerland or not. I am very well pleased to hear of yr projected return “to England for good”; and only wished it had been, by good accidt, earlier;—but you will do well to keep yr engagts with yrself, and we will be content with Septr, if better be not. My Dr Brother, asking abt yr dear little Mary, seemed to think the chief danger to her health (such a vivid little creature as I described her) might very possibly be the too much excitet attached to change of scene, of company, & of habits, if carried too far; and that the favourable state for her wd be quietude and steady regularity in outward things. I know not what truth may be in this: but it is very certain, she was meant to be an Englishwoman, and cannot too early learn to love her native place, and strike life-roots into it with all the opulence of her good little heart.Lady Ashburton wrote: “God willing, I hope in Septr to turn my steps to England—going now to Vichy, (Grand Hotel du Parc,) for 5 weeks for my own pains— after that, to Switzerland for Mary—who grows so fast that she needs all the strengthening I can give her.”

I very well conceive the gloomy solitary look of MelchetFor Melchet Court, see TC to Lady A, 7 Nov. 1865
. to yr imaginatn, after all that has come & gone (of avoidable and unavoidable); but surely you must boldly go into it, plant yrself down there,—and never doubt but good & blessed fruit will grow there, for you & yours, as, by faithful husbandry, it does everywhere under God’s blessed sky! This is indisputable; and this is all I will venture to say in the way of advising (little or nothing more being perfectly clear to me) in this complex matter.

For the rest, you need have no doubt but that, if I live some years in the
world, and you settle into regularity within reach of me, yr affectionate regard will be a comfort to me in my loneliness, and yr power to be of real help to me will not be small, if wisely administered betwn us. That is an evidt fact: and another is, that so long as I live, all my poor faculty, in every strait or uncertainty of yours, is at yr disposal always.Lady Ashburton wrote: “How much circumstances (of these last 5 years!) have made us to each other! For his sake, & for hers, I hope to be something to you of comfort yet.”

This is all I can write at prest— I will wish you well at Vichy, well at Montey; above all things, well home. Let us hear agn from you soon. I wd send my blessing to yr little jewel of a Mary,—if it cd avail anything;Lady Ashburton wrote: “Little one, who finds I am writing to you, sends you ‘her Best love— a kiss.’” whh I know well it cannot.

signed.name:
T. CarlyleRalph Waldo Emerson wrote, 16 May: “I must think her fortunate … in this gentle departure, as she had been in her serene & honored career. We would not for ourselves count covetously the descending steps, after we have passed the top of the mount, or grudge to spare some of the days of decay. And you will have the peace of knowing her safe, & no longer a victim. … I rejoice that she stayed to enjoy the knowledge of your good day at Edinburgh, which is a leaf we would not spare from your book of life. It was a right manly speech to be so made.” For Robert Browning’s letter to Isa Blagden, 22 April, about JWC’s death, see Appendix 257 RB to IBL, 22 April 1866
; he then wrote, 19 May: “Poor Mrs Carlyle’s death was sad and strange,—but by no means ‘shook’ me rudely;—after all, there are people to take care of her husband,—and she might be considered fairly as entitled to go: I have not seen C.,—he talks much about her, and shows more deep feeling than is usual with him: I dined with them both, and saw her for the last time, when he completed his seventieth year” (Browning, Dearest Isa 239); for the dinner at the Forsters’, see TC to JAC, 5 Dec. 1865
.

div3.sourceNote:
TC-GEJ, 22 May. MS: NLS 532. Pbd: Carlyle, Reminiscences 66; Wilson, Carlyle 6:83 inc. Quot: Kaplan 478. TC wrote the letter in Jewsbury’s notebook, “In Memoriam / J. W . C. /
Ob. April 21. 1866” (MS: NLS 532). It followed Jewsbury’s conclusion: “I end here these ‘stories told by herself’—not because there are no more. They give some slight indication of the courage and nobleness and fine qualities which lay in her who is gone. … Those who were her friends will only go on feeling their loss and their sorrow more and more every day of their own lives. / Chelsea May 20. 1866” (Carlyle, Reminiscences 65–66).
div3.head:
TC
TO GERALDINE E. JEWSBURY

docBody.p:
Dear Geraldine,
—Few or none of these Narratives are correct in all the details; some of them, in almost all the details, are incorrect. I have not read carefully beyond a certn point whh is marked on the margin. Yr recognitn of the character is generally true and faithful; little of portraiture in it that satisfies me. On the whole, all tends to the mythical; it is very strange how much of mythical there already here is!—

As Lady Lothian set you on writing, it seems hard that she shd not see what
you have written: but I wish you to take her word of honour that none else shall; and my earnest request to you is that, directly from her Ladyship, you will bring the Book to me, and consign it to my keeping.TC later wrote on a scrap of paper: “Early in May 1866, in the first weeks of my irreparable calamity, Miss Geraldine Jewsbury, who long had been a familr here, sent me this little Book half written out, in her hasty and flowing hand, with a very kind Note (whh unhappily I have lost), explaining That the Marchss of Lothian, who had a little begun to know, and much to esteem, my departed Dearest, had requested to have Miss jewsy’s recollectns of her, especially of what in their many dialogues togr Miss Jy had come to know of her life; and that here was what she had written: wd I permit the kind Marchss, herself a sorrow laden woman, to have it? My ansr, I believe, is given in the little Book;—restricting, on certn consideratns, the sight of it rigorously to Lady Lothian alone. Miss Jy, with a perfect sense of propriety, did not use even the permissn given her; but directly returned me the little Book to burn or do with what I liked.— — After some days, I began writing down my own corrections &c, whh gradually swelled into additions,—day by day, all that I cd most brightly remember of Her bright Life beside me. This, with the pious sorting of her Letters, & of all that had belonged to her, and made her lovely to me, in our Pilgrimage together,—formed my one solacet all that summer. And this may sufft Preface to the little Book (or Book-and-half), whh I have never dared to open since. (19 Feby 1869)” (MS: Berg).

No need that an idle gazing world shd know my lost Darling’s History or mine;—nor will they ever, they may depend upon it! One fit service, and one only, they can do to Her or to Me: cease speaking of us, through all Eternity, as soon as they conveniently can.—

signed.name: T. CarlyleBellona was sent N to Auchtertool, 22 May, according to TC’s checkbook: “23 May 1866 / To Silvester (finis of Horse &cgone yesterday) / £3 .. 12 .. 6” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753).

postscript.p: (Chelsea, 22 May 1866.)Charles Dickens wrote from 6 Southwick Pl., Hyde Park W., 30 May: “I have not written to you from any part of the country where I have lately been employed (and I have been working hard in many parts), for a reason that I instinctively felt you would understand. Even now I touch your hand with mine in the spirit, hardly venturing to press it. / My dear friend my thoughts have been much with you, for I truly love and honor you. To your great heart and mind little can come out of mine but sympathy.— That has been with you from the first, and ever will be while I live. / Your truly affectionate friend.”

div3.sourceNote: TC-CAW, 16 June 1866. Addr: 1 Chapel Street, Curzon Street / Mayfair. PM: London, 16 June 1866. MS: NLS Acc. 9086. Hitherto unpbd. The letter follows TC to GEJ, 22 May 1866 ; see also JAC to WDO, 19 June 1866 . [This letter, pbd. at CL 44:237, is now placed at its proper chronological location.]
div3.head: TC TO CHARLES A. WARD

docBody.p:
Thanks for yr kind bit of attention: the Strawberries Charles Augustus Ward regularly sent the Carlyles presents of food; see, for instance, 43:19 TC to CAW, 21 Oct. 1865
. were of very good quality;—do the criticism on Ruskin; Ruskin had just pbd., late May, The Crown of Wild Olive (1867) (see 43:123 TC to JRU, 14 Feb. 1866
), and Ward may have written a review of the book. whh I agreed in wholly, except when you seem to question not his strength alone, but his sincerity a little too; whh latter I can testify to be complete, and even vehement and painful to him. If he live, there will be mission enough for him in the next 20 years. You too,—tho’ I wd not have you take up “literature,” to hurt of yr real employt, Ward was a wine merchant, but wanted to be a writer; see TC to CAW, 1 Aug. 1866
. —must actually prepare to help him a little in that huge but sacredly needful enterprise. The harvest so great, the labourers so few.

div3.sourceNote: JAC-WD [WDO], 19 June. MS: NLS 1797.132. Written on black-edged paper. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head: JOHN A. CARLYLE TO WILLIAM DODS

docBody.p:
Since I last wrote my brotherTC wrote, 31 May: “This morng her poor will (in my favr, before our marriage) abt Craigenputtoch, is at last reported ‘found at Dumfries.’ Nobody to inherit, after me. Shall I bequest it in bursaries to Edinr College? Consider maturely” (TC’s journal; privately owned). TC then wrote, 11 June: “Have read the (Dumfries) Copy of her Will, too; a beautiful Letter to her mother [written 19 July 1825; see 3:252–53 JBW to EA, 18 Jan. (1825)
], and other Deed (‘of Life-rent’ [for Craigenputtoch]),—all gone, gone into the vacant Past:—and have reposited both Documents” (Carlyle, Reminiscences 108). TC did leave Craigenputtoch to Edinburgh Univ. to provide student bursaries. & all the rest of us here have been pretty
well, & his sprained anckle is now quite right again.TC continued noting visitors, the weather, and his feelings in his reminiscences of JWC: “(june 4, Monday 1866) Yesterday all spent, against my will, in foreign talk: ‘National Portrait Exhibition’ (Tyndall’s kindness), American Pike (Belgian Minister), Mazzini (kind and sad) etc. etc.: at midnight, alone upon the streets, I felt only gloomier and sorer than ever,—as if she had been defrauded of my thoughts every instant they had been away from her.) Perge [pause] here”; “(june 7; hot weather come; no shift etc)”; “(Sunday june 10 ; weather fiercely hot; health suffering visibly last week; must take new courses; form new resolutely definite plans,—which requires (or would require) a great deal more of strength and calmness than I have at present! Quiet I am, avoiding almost everybody, and far preferring silence to most words I can hear: but clear of vision, calm of judgment I am far from being!— Ought I to quit this ‘work’ here, which I feel to be very idleness? I sit in great gloom of heart, but it is gloom all drenched in soft pity (as if she were to be ‘pitied’!) in benign affection: really it is like a kind of religious course of worship to me, this of ‘sitting by her Grave,’ as I daily do. Oh my Loved One, must I quit even that, then? Dost thou, as if it were thou, bid me Rise, go hence, and work at something? Patience; yet a little, yet a little!— At least I will quit these vague provinces; and try to write something more specifically historical, on this Paper of her providing!— Stop to-day.)” (Carlyle, Reminiscences 89, 101, 107–8). James Shepherd Pike (1811–82); for his last recorded visit, 1864, see 41:32 TC to JWC, 19 Sept. 1864
. For Mazzini’s visit, see TC to JRU, 10 May
. Miss Welsh is still staying with us.Maggie Welsh continued to sort JWC’s belongings; TC wrote, 11 June: “Very mournful little hour: ‘Parting of her raiment’ (I somehow call it) sad sanction of what Maggie Welsh had done in it!”; and, 22 June: “Her clothes (Maggie dividing) are all gone their several roads, I myself know little whither;—and there remains to me vacancy and silence, nothing vocal but memory now. Had to be so; who can contend against the everlasting Law!” (Carlyle, Reminiscences 108, 135).

The new Inscription on marble for the gravestone, of which my brother spoke when in Haddington, is now ready & will be forwarded to you this week. It will require to be inserted & fastened under the old inscription, & he would like to have this done as soon as possible, & begs you will have the kindness to seek out some proper person who could do it well & would be ready as soon as it arrives. He will himself write to you on the subject after seeing the marble which has not yet come from the workshop.See TC to WDO, 21 June
. TC noted: “(june 6: Surely this is very idle work,—the rather if it is all to be burnt! But nothing else yields me any solace at all, in these days. I will continue it to-morrow. Poor Tablet or memorial due to me from the lapidary, this day fortnight, at farthest, surely.)”; and “june 11 . … Little Tablet is not due for ten days yet; feel it too sad to quit my daily companionship, idle though it be, and almost blameable—no, it is not blameable, no!)” (Carlyle, Reminiscences 97–98, 108).

figure.p: Jane Welsh Carlyle’s memorial tablet

docBody.p:
He would have preferred having the inscription merely cut on the stone
itself below the old one; but there was not nearly room enough left, so the marble with smaller letters than can be cut on stone was indispensible. The letters on it are filled with “imperishable lead,” fastened in such a way as to remain in them, & looking simply like black paint.

figure.p: John Welsh’s tombstone

docBody.p: I am going to see the thing today, & will tell you, if I can, in a postscript when it may be sent off.
I trust you are all well, in spite of the stormy & wet weather. Please give my best respects to Mrs Dodds, & believe me,

div3.sourceNote: TC-WD [WDO], 21 June. MS: Strouse. Written on black-edged paper. Pbd: Glasgow Herald, 13 July 1901.
div3.head:
TC
TO WILLIAM DODS

docBody.p:
The lapidary peopleEdward Gaffin (1819–69), sculptor and marble mason, Regent Quadrant and 17 Kensington Place. undertook to me yesterday that the Tablet, of whh my Brother wrote,See JAC to WDO, 19 June
. shd be punctually despatched, with packing &cunquestionable, on Friday evg,—to yr Address. I can believe, therefore, that it will reach you, safe & right, some time on Saturday; and that if yr MasonAndrew Beatson (1811–92), master mason, Haddington. is ready, he can, on Monday, conclude the operatn,—perhaps still in time for a word by post from you; the rather, if you have not written on Saturday to say that all is safe; as I suspend payment of my Lapidaries till that report come.

Yr Mason, if he is faithful and expert, will have no difficulty or uncertainty: he fixes the marble into the centre of what vacant space there is in the flat Tombstone (whh seemed to me to be of excellent firm sandstone, and will yield a margin on all the four sides): the thickness of the marble I judge to be abt half that of the sandstone; and there were to be (yesterday) two thick copper studs let into the back of it,—whh of course will need corresponding holes in the bed, and the best kind of fixing he can give (lead, I suppose, is impossible there).TC had written in his journal, 31 May: “After a good deal of paltry mechanical bother (whh poor John, with all his good will, had not the art of keeping off me), they are cutting (in marble with lead) the poor little memorial Tablet whh is to go into her Father’s Tombstone. Not to be done for about 3 weeks yet. Feebly, but correctly so far expresses my feeling towards her,—as it were, in part, my last word to her. Oh, as I often think, what wd not I give for only 5 minutes more of her, to say what I never knew till now, how peerless I esteemed her, what a Heroine and brightest Benefactress she was to me; and fill her dear heart with noble joy! She never fairly knew it either. And now— Alas, alas: forever hidden from my eyes” (TC’s journal; privately owned). On 22 June, he wrote: “Occupied for the last two; going to Lapidary to see,—yesterday, moreover, writing letters, and then with Forster to Lapidary for the last time. Poor little Memorial Tablet, all properly finished, leaden letters, etc., is to go off tonight to Haddington; will probably be fixed-in Monday next. I reflect with a livelier twinge of sadness, that it is now the last service I can ever do her in this world! A kind of second parting with her: ‘Go, thou ever-dearest, thou are of Eternity now, I of dim Time’” (Carlyle, Reminiscences 135–36). The inscription on JWC’s tombstone reads: “Here likewise now rests JANE WELSH CARLYLE, spouse of Thomas Carlyle, Chelsea, London. She was born at Haddington, 14th July 1801: only child of the above John Welsh, and of Grace Welsh, Caplegill, Dumfriesshire, his wife. In her bright existence she had more sorrows than are common; but also a soft invincibility, a clearness of discernment, and a noble loyalty of heart, which are rare. For forty years she was the true and ever-loving helpmate of her husband; and, by act and word, unweariedly forwarded him, as none else could, in all of worthy that he did or attempted. She died at London, 21st April 1866; suddenly snatched away from him, and the light of his life as if gone out.” It is now covered by a metal plate with the same inscription; see above. But he himself will know far better than I what manner of
cement
, of manipulatn and management is the necessary and the best:—and from you, dear Sir, it will be a never-forgotten favour if you will see, instead of
me, with yr own eyes and judgt, that everything is verily correct and complete. Thereupon pay the faithful man, with my thanks superadded; & report hither.

I send many grateful regards to Mrs Dods, and yr young Gentn.William Dods’s son Charles Shirrif (b. 1840); for the rest of his children, see 37:265 37:biographical notes . I will write agn so soon as yr report arrives.

signed.name: T. CarlyleGeraldine Jewsbury wrote to Lady Amberley, 18 June: “Mr Carlyle said last night that he wd be very glad to see you whenever you liked to come and see him—he spoke as tho’ he wd be as glad as he can be of any thing now— I thought you wd like to know—he looks decidedly better within the last fortnight but you will find him looking very shaken” (MS: NLS 20767.84).

div3.sourceNote: TC-Lady A [LLA], 21 June. MS: NLS Acc. 11388. Written on black-edged paper. Quot: Surtees, Ludovisi 123–24.
div3.head: TC TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: We are now at the Summer Solstice, and there still comes no word from yr locality,—a locality itself uncertain to me.Lady Ashburton wrote to TC from Vichy, central France, 18 June: “I am getting quite hungry for tidings of you— beg you to send me a few lines.” A good many weeks ago, directly on the morrow of yr last Letter (still dated Nice) I wrote to you at some length, addressing “Vichy Hôtel du Parc,” as bidden; but whether that missive came to hand, or was lost, as others have been since yr flight from us, I do not yet know.

Please do send me a little word of indication, or prediction if you can: How little Marykin and yrself are,Lady Ashburton wrote: “I am better than I have been for many a long day owing to these wonderful waters & little Mary too is perfectly well.” Vichy was famous for its thermal baths. and where,—also whether the prediction of “September” still holds, as I hope?
