Your movements are not witht importance and influence for my own: I may as well confess; I have always, for above a year back (still more, for eight weeks back), had a kind of eye on that traditionary “Farmhouse” in Melchet Park, and some “Apartt” I might build myself there (with yr permission), as a covert from the rolling of railways, and the other noisy horrors of London, when they become intolerable to me;—but this, as you may suppose, is more and more fading into a dream; and indeed radically, I suppose, was never much other.During their last visit to Lady Ashburton’s house, Seaforth Lodge, in Devon, the Carlyles had considered buying a country house nearby; see 41:201 JWC to MO, 29 March 1865
. That you were coming to
Melchet, however, with fixed purpose to settle there, wd undoubtedly be an increase to my now small resources, and limited field of planning.

I am keeping very quiet here; not seeking society or talk; but shunning it;—unraveling, with all my faculty, the gloomy imbroglio whh my life has suddenly become, and endeavouring to extract from it something whh may still be cosmic and feasible. Endeavouring; or I shd rather say, faintly hoping, for I have little strength to endeavour that or any way. I sit silent, working a little (if it can be called work) over things that belong to the inexorable Past;TC was waiting for information from Walter Welsh about the Welsh family, having already been sent some dates and names from the family Bible by Grace Welsh, 12 June (see Carlyle, Reminiscences 113–15); he wrote, 18 June: “day wet and muddy; Tablet ‘near ready’; Brother John going off to Jersey on visit of a few days; from reverend Walter of Auchtertool still nothing. Sad, quiet and sad; ‘drowned in soft regrets and loving sorrow,’ so I define my common mood at present,—and sometimes estimate it as a kind of religious worship (course of devotional exercises) I have got into;—driven by Fate, at the long last!). … june 22nd. … Let me continue): What I can recollect of the London years, to come now” (Carlyle, Reminiscences 131–32, 135–36). I walk abt, a good deal, silent,—especially on long walk towards midnight, along a range of solitary streets, “Cremorne”Pleasure gardens nr. Cheyne Row; see 41:29 TC to JWC, 16 Sept. 1864
. and its nauseous uproars heard only faintly in the distance. All people are kind to me, some markedly so; but nobody can do me much or any good. The sombre gloom of my own thots is less affliction to me, in general, than anything I can hear or speak. Public topics are disgusting to me, and I am apt to speak of them words that I repent; of private there is only one, and that is not permitted me. On the whole, I am full of sadness; but it is a sorrow as if drowned in tenderness, and with hues in it, here and there, beautiful inexpressibly; sacred, soft, religious in a sort,—and I almost believe, salutary to my too hardened, heavy-laden old heart, more used to silent rages and suppressed execrations than to better exercises, in this dull impious & perverse world.— Miss Welsh is still here, a fine cheerful well-mannered girl; but I think, intends home now in a little. Yesterday my Brother went off on a visit to somebody in Jersey;TC noted, 22 June: “Brother John off to Jersey the night before last: probably good for both of us” (Carlyle, Reminiscences 136); see TC to JCA, 23 June
. and probably will not continue long with me on his return. I must acquaint myself with Solitude; that, I have all along perceived, must mainly be my lot henceforth.

Miss Bromley is at Ripple-Court, with a Child-NephewRipple Court, Kent, about 5 mi. (8 km.) NE of Dover; see JWC to Lady Am, 7 and 8 Nov. 1865
. Caroline Davenport Bromley’s nephew was her brother William’s son, Walter Arthur Davenport Bromley; he and his wife, Augusta, had two children, with a third due in Sept. for chief company, till July begin, when she returns to Town for two or 3 weeks. In August, if the windless heat, and baked pavements of London become too unendurable,
I am under promise to try for shelter under her kind roof for a little:TC visited Caroline Davenport Bromley, Aug. 1866. I shall, possibly enough, go;— intend, if so, to have “Rubbish”A horse belonging to Lady Ashburton; see TC to JWC, 11 April
. with his galloping talent sent for, if you continue to allow such liberty.

What a loss to you, the death of poor Lady Trevillian!Lady Paulina Trevelyan d., 13 May, in Switzerland; Lady Ashburton wrote: “I dread the returning to Seaton, without the hope of a visit from her, I loved so truly, & also without my almost sister, Lady Trevelyan.” Ruskin wrote to a friend, 11 June: “the deaths of Mrs. Carlyle and of Lady Trevelyan take from me my two best women friends of older power” (Ruskin’s Works 36:509). I need not say how it rang upon my sad existence here; and awoke memories that are so recent, and yet that are gone into the Eternities, like the years beyond the Flood! Somebody said, He had seen Sir Walter sitting in the Athenaeum one day, handling papers, & looking inexpressibly sorrowful. Poor man, I can right well believe it.— Lord RusselLord John Russell, prime minister 1865–66. will be at BalmoralBalmoral, Queen Victoria’s Scottish home in Deeside, Aberdeenshire. this morning, resting on some sofa, let us hope,—after his 600 miles of railway, with the broken shards of that beautiful Reform Bill (“maddest thing I have seen out of Bedlam”) on his sorrowful back;Lord Russell had gone to tender his resignation to the queen after his government’s reform bill was defeated, 18 June; see TC to JWC, 13 April
. let him rest, and it.— — Adieu, dear Lady; be good & write.

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 23 June. MS: NLS 518.27. Quot: Wilson, Carlyle 5:85.
div3.head:
TC
TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p:
There has nothing more of evil happened to me; bodily nothing at all: my bodily health is not worse than it used to be, sometimes, I almost think (tho never quite), a slight degree better; my ancle got altogether well agn;—and the weather never much disagreeable hitherto, the reverse rather. For the rest, I am sad and sombre, my heart wholly wae, wae; and occupied with one object, whh none can be expected to share with me,—nor cd in the least help me if they did. But I keep very quiet; fully best, I think, when nobody is speaking to me, and I walk silent with my thots & memories for company. Plenty of people come, too many rather; I do not, except it be to leave a card for mere civility, go to almost anyone.TC wrote: “(23 june 1866, Saturday hot, and weary of heart)”; “(24 june: morning silently quasi-wasted; the Sabbath stillness, and the brisk breeze amid the sunshine and the solitude (Brother John away in Jersey, Maggie out to Church) being a temptation to idle sad musings.— Tablet ought to have arrived yesterday in Haddington (nine weeks exact!); in the course of this week I expect to have final account. ‘Wae, wae,’ that is the mood I am in,—sad very, but soft also)”; “(june 25 Interruption
; nothing else, all day!)” (Carlyle, Reminiscences 139, 141, 142).

The Doctor went off Wedny Evg last, for Jersey (Island of Jersey, 150 miles off); on a visit to one “Mr Smith,” of whom I never heard before, & cd learn on inquiry nothing but that the acquaintance had been “made in Berwickshire.” Putting things together, I guess this Smith, or his Daughter, to be concerned in the youngest Snaffle of a Watt,—who is home from India just now;—and that his worthy marriage (or want of do) is possibly enough the topic on hand.William Watt, John A. Carlyle’s youngest stepson, was to marry Mary Smith, da. of E. H. Smith, living in Grouville, Isle of Jersey. John A. Carlyle wrote to Alexander Carlyle, 4 July: “I have to go once to Jersey again to be present at the marriage of my youngest ward or stepson Wm Watt, who is an officer of Dragoons, and has been four or five years engaged to the young lady whom he is to be wedded next week. It is with her father and mother that I staid on my first visit, and mean to stay again, till after the wedding” (Marrs 755). William and Mary were m. 18 July.
Good, good. I send you the Dr’s Note of this morng, to assure you also of his safe arrival. Of his time of return hither there was no talk; nor of what he intended for himself after that cd he say anything when I have incidentally asked.John A. Carlyle continued: “I … shall most likely go straight to Dumfries from Jersey along the west coast of England. Tom himself thinks he will be quite as well or perhaps better without me for a time” (Marrs 755) but TC noted: “(june 30; hot and windless; John suddenly returned from Jersey)” (Carlyle, Reminiscences 150). Poor well-intending, practically not unaffectionate soul, I wish I cd help him to some good settlet, good for us both!— —

figure.p: Choir of St. Mary’s Church, Haddington
Moncure Daniel Conway, Thomas Carlyle (1881)

p.hi: Courtesy of Edinburgh University, Special Collections Department

docBody.p:
Today the poor little Tablet of memorial (a little bit of marble to be let into her Father’s Tombstone) shd have arrived in Haddingtn!The tablet did not arrive until 27 June; TC noted, 28 June: “Note from Dods yesterday that the Tablet was not come, nor indeed had been expected; note to-day that it did come yesterday: at this hour probably the Mason is hewing out a bed for it; in the silence of the Abbey Kirk yonder, as completion of her Father’s Tomb” (Carlyle, Reminiscences 145); JWC’s tablet was placed beneath John Welsh’s inscription of 1819: “Sacred to the memory of John Welsh of Craigenputtock, Surgeon in Haddington: who died the 19th of September 1819. Aged Forty four years”; see 240. For JWC’s inscription, see TC to WDO, 21 June
, and 236. For the choir of the Abbey Church (St. Mary’s Church, Haddington), at that time unroofed, see 241.

postscript.p:
No
Newspr this time; I ansr John’s Note by it

div3.sourceNote: TC-JCA, 25 June. MS: EUL. Hitherto unpbd.
div3.head:
TC
TO JEAN CARLYLE AITKEN

docBody.p:
Dear Sister,
—I return you the dirty little clipping, Printing corrected;—as you may wish to have the poor bit of Inscriptn even in that form.Jean Aitken presumably sent TC the report from the Scotsman, 23 June, about “the following affectionate and touching tribute … by her bereaved husband”; the Scotsman printed the inscription correctly, but introduced it by saying that the tablet “is to be placed beneath a stone, which records the death of her parents at Haddington, Dumfriesshire”; JWC’s mother was buried in Crawford graveyard, Lanarkshire. The inscription, with some errors, was also pbd. in the Pall Mall Gazette, 22 June, and the Times, 23 June. TC commented: “Hungry Penny-a-liner (long since) had stolen through Gaffin’s window a copy, incorrect Copy, of the Sculpture; and has that circulating far and wide, in newspapers” (Carlyle, Reminiscences 162).

My
“plans” do not need to be “waited for” by the Dr; they are, and have all along been, to live quiet in my own house here, and silently set myself and it in order,TC noted his financial dealings of this week: “18 june 1866 / to Dr Carlyle / for myself; House &c; rent paid to june 22d ; next term (£16 .. 17) is Decr 22.) / £58 .. 2 .. 0”; JWC previously took care of household expenses, including the rent; see 40:211 JWC to TC, [26 Aug. 1864] ; 217 TC to JWC, 30 Aug. 1864
; and 222 JWC to TC, [31 Aug. 1864] . Forster was helping with some of TC’s arrangements, handling the transfer of money left by JWC in her bank account; he wrote, 22 June: “The Bank people made no difficulty—and everything is now as you wish— / The 125£ principal—together with £3 .. 1 .. 4 interest—(£128 .. 1 .. 4 in all)—has been transferred to your account; and to your account has also been paid today the cheque for 100£ that I gave them”; TC noted the transactions: “22 june 1866 / Paid in (by Forster for me; Hers &c!) / £128 .. 1 .. 4 (alas, alas!) / £100 .. .. 0 from Dumfries on whh day, so far as I can count, the Balance in my favr now is / £186 .. 3 .. 10” (TC’s checkbook; MS: NLS 20753). for the time that may remain. If he were residing near me,
in like fashion, I have told him, I shd like it; but that is the thing we “wait for” (if for anything),—and may long “wait”!— — Much rubbish of Letters this morng,—several of whh I have burnt witht reading.— In haste /

postscript.p: The London Library. / 12, St. JAMES’S SQUARE.The letter is written on a small piece of paper with this address printed on it.

div3.sourceNote: TC-SA, 28 June. Pbd: Janet Ross, Three Generations of Englishwomen (1888) 2:159–60.
div3.head:
TC
TO SARAH AUSTIN

docBody.p: Thanks for your kind inquiry after me; I feel it all the kinder knowing too well that you are yourself so weary and heavy-laden.Sarah Austin suffered from heart trouble and gout; widowed in 1859, she had since lost a sister and two brothers; her only child, Lucie Duff Gordon, suffered from tuberculosis and lived abroad.

In respect of bodily health I seem not to be worse than I was six months ago, which, indeed, is not saying a great deal. As to my instantaneous and incalculable loss, otherwise. I felt, and more and more feel it to be, the sudden extinction of all that remained of humanly cheerful in my sombre existence, and had better not speak of it at present—much and continually as it insists on being thought of, and thought to the bottom if I can. How I understand what you say about letters of condolence! I have burnt some scores of them, unread except the first line and the signature.

Mr. IrvingJoseph Irving (1830–91; ODNB), journalist and antiquary. did not call even in passing—out of polite and considerate motives. Please tell him, if you write, that I yesterday morning received his letter enclosing yours, and along with it his Notes upon Tobias Smollett and the Smolletts,Irving, Some Account of the family of Smollett of Bonhill; with a series of letters hitherto unpublished, written by Dr. Tobias Smollett, author
(Dumbarton, 1859); TC’s copy was signed, “With J. Irvings Compts / June 25/66”; TC made various corrections and elucidations to the text (MS: NLS 3786). which I read with interest and care, and will keep with thanks.
Smollett’s house stood within a gunshot of me here, and only vanished within the last twenty years.Tobias George Smollett (1721–71; ODNB), writer, lived in a wing of Monmouth House, Lawrence St., parallel and to the W of Cheyne Row, 1749–63; see 7:173 TC to JWC, 21 May 1834
; it was razed in 1834; see 7:238 .
May peace more and more be with you, dear old friend! Accept my grateful remembrances and continuance of affectionate wishes.

div3.sourceNote: TC-MC [MCR], 29 [28] June. Addr: 2. Chlorine Place / Belfast. PM: London, 28 June 1866. MS: Strouse. Written on black-edged paper. Hitherto unpbd. Recipient identified as Mary Craik, George Craik’s elder da., who helped JWC during her illness, May–July 1864, rather than the younger da., Georgiana. TC misdated.
div3.head: TC TO MARY CRAIK

docBody.p:
With a sad and solemn emotion I received yr tidings of last night.The death of her father, George Lillie Craik, 25 June. TC noted: “News of Craik’s death, at Belfast 27 ult. came last night” (Carlyle, Reminiscences 148). — I know, by painful experience, how idle are words: I will say nothing, therefore, except That yr Father’s memory, by all that knew him, is & will be held in honourable regard here;TC also wrote in different terms about Craik in his reminiscences, Craik having offended JWC deeply when he looked at one of her notebooks; TC wrote about her notebooks and his self-imposed task, around 27 May: “Why do I write at all, for that matter? Can I ever forget? And is not all this appointed by me rigorously to the fire? Somehow it solaces me to have written it;—and tomorrow, probably, I shall fill out these two remaining pages. Ah me.— She had written at one time something of her own early life; but she gave up, and burnt it,—some disgusting fellow having got his eye on a bit of it, ‘unable to resist the temptation, such the charm, the’—Unforgiveable coarse soul! She wrote at various times in Notebooks; refusing all sight of them even to me: but she has destroyed nearly every vestige of them;—one little Book, consisting of curious excerpts and jottings not biographic (in which she would often look practically for Addresses (Street and number) as one item), is all that remains,—that I do not mean to burn” (Carlyle, Reminiscences 72–73); forsee also JWC’s Notebook, 1845–52
, see 30:157–72. TC added more, 3 July: “in 1856, too evidently, to whatever owing, my poor little Darling was extremely miserable! Of that year there is a bit of Private Diary, by chance, left unburnt; found by me since her death, and not to be destroyed, however tragical and sternly sad are parts of it. She had written, I sometimes knew (though she would never shew to me or to mortal any word of them), at different times, various bits of Diary; and was even, at one time, upon a kind of Autobiography (had not Craik, the poor Craik, now just gone, stept into it with swine’s foot, most intrusively, though without ill intention,—finding it unlocked, one day;—and produced thereby an instantaneous burning of it, and of all like it which existed at that time). Certain enough, she wrote various bits of Diary and private record, unknown to me: but never anything so sore, downhearted, harshly distressed and sad as this (right sure am I!)—which alone remains as specimen! The rest are all burnt; no trace of them, seek where I may. The place for inserting it is now arrived at; and it shall stand here, very mournful to me while I live” (Carlyle, Reminiscences 157–58); forsee also JWC’s Journal, Oct. 1855–July 1856
, see 30:197–262.—that yr own gentle ways and modest worth are personally known to some of us; and that yr Sister and you will not want for
helpful friends, willing and able, in any essential matter,—least of all, for all the help I can give you, now or henceforth, shd a difficulty rise.

My hand refuses (as is now sometimes its wont), or makes great objectn, to write farther. I pray for blessings on yr bereaved Household; bid you, in the depths of yr sorrow, still be of courage unshaken;—and am always

div3.sourceNote: TC-ES [EMI], 30 June. MS: EUL. Written on black-edged paper. Hitherto unpbd. Eliza Snowden, b. Miles, with whose family the Carlyles lodged in Ampton St., London, 1831–32 (see TC to MAC, 10 Nov. 1831 , and JWC to EMI, 16 June 1832), and with whom JWC remained on friendly terms (see JWC to TC, [ca. 10 July 1841]); their last recorded contact was in 1856; see JWC’s Journal, 25 March 1856.
div3.head:
TC
TO ELIZA SNOWDEN

docBody.p: Your words are full of tenderness and truth;Snowden wrote to TC, [ca. 28 June]: “I cannot express the grief I felt when informed of your sudden bereavement, yet much as I desired to express my sympathy, knew your sorrow was too sacred to be hastily intruded upon. / May I now be allowed to do so. … It is 34 years since I first knew and loved your gifted wife, and although she became surrounded by this world’s admiration and prosperity, she continued uncontaminated by its applause, and retained a reality of character and warmth of heart, seldom seen in one so situated. / I can never forget or cease to love her, but shall treasure in my inmost heart, all her loving words and kind deeds.” they evidently come from yr heart, and cannot be refused admission into mine. I know how loyally you loved her from the first day;TC wrote on the MS: “This is poor Eliza Miles, the Daughter of our first Lodging-House people; who took an enthusiastic affection for my Darling, almost at first sight, and has continued it, with more & more perfect discernt, to the last. Snowden is grown, from a Londn Shopman, gradually a prosperous upholsterer; this Eliza a thoroughly good wife, housewife & mother:—her poor Letter has now a value to me; from the heart gone to the heart. T.C. / 1 july 1866.” and how she constantly returned it;—and I find the feeling to be good and beautiful, on both sides. Retain it, you who are left; it will do you nothing but good;—indeed I know you cannot altogether part with it so long as you live.

As to me— But it is better that I say nothing of me. I ask myself ever since,
What is there left for me henceforth of any value in this world?—and the ansr does not become more apparent hitherto.TC wrote, 29 June: “Sometimes the image of Her, gone in her car of victory (in that beautiful death), and as if nodding to me with a smile, ‘I am gone, loved one; work a little longer, if thou still canst; if not, follow! There is no baseness, and no misery here. Courage, courage to the last!’—that, sometimes, as in this moment, is inexpressibly beautiful to me, and comes nearer to bringing tears than it once did. (Stop for today)” (Carlyle, Reminiscences 150).

Miss Welsh, a Cousin who used to wait on her sometimes, of whom you have probably heard, is to send you some poor little memorial token,Maggie Welsh sent Eliza Snowden a “boa & little cuffs”; see MW to EMI, [6 July] (vol. 44). whh I know you will accept & keep.
With true good wishes and much regard, I remain

signed.name: T. CarlyleTC wrote about Snowden and her letter: “The Daughter of the house, a fine young Cockney specimen, fell quite in love with her; served like a fairy; was, next year long after we were gone, for coming to us at Craigenputtock to be ‘maid of all work’ (an impossible suggestion!)—and did, in effect, keep up an adoring kind of intercourse till the fatal day of April last; never changing at all in her poor tribute of love. A fine outpouring of her grief and admiring gratitude, written after that event, (Letter to me, signed ‘Eliza Snowden,’—Miles was her maiden name. ‘Snowden,’ once a clerk with her uncle, is, now himself, for long years back, a prosperous Upholsterer; and the Sylph-like Eliza, grown fat enough of shape, is the mother of six or seven prosperous children to him), was not thrown into the fire, half-read or unread, but is still lying in a drawer at Chelsea, or perhaps adjoined to some of the things I was writing there, as a genuine human utterance, not without some sad value to me” (Carlyle, Reminiscences 336).

div3.sourceNote: JWC-MC, 4 March 1866. MS: Univ. of California Santa Cruz Lib. Hitherto unpbd. JWC wrote to George Lillie Craik (1798–1866), 4 March 1866, expressing sympathy for his illness (see JWC to GLC, 4 March [1866]); he had had a stroke in Feb. and was to die 25 June 1866. Mary Craik (1827–1909), his eldest da., helped nurse JWC May–July 1864. JWC then wrote this letter in answer to one from Mary with news of her father.
div3.head: JWC TO MARY CRAIK

docBody.p: Oh! don’t I too wish I had my arms about you! and that I could comfort you with wise, kind words; even as you comforted me, in my dark time!For Mary Craik’s nursing of JWC in St. Leonards, Sussex, see 40:93TC to GEJ, 8 May 1864, 110JWC to MR, [ca. 31 May 1864], and 128JWC to GLC, [9 July 1864].

See! I am well now! alive and well. And was there a more suffering, more despairing creature than I was then?—my outlook continually wavering between Death, and Madness!JWC wrote, March 1864, expressing the fear that she was dying; see 40:42JWC to WDO, [25 March 1864], and 43JWC to AGEW, [25 March 1864]. Maggie Welsh referred to the “terrible depression that from which she suffers & the almost constant nervous pain which she has for so long complained of” [8 April 1864]; see 40:60MW to LLA, [8 April 1864]. You did not know, no one knew how desperate I was, all that time; even when crushing down complainings under an iron weight of silence!

That I recovered—after all—when to others there seemed no probability of it—and to myself no possibility—has made such an impression on me, that I should feel it now a kind of impiety to despair of any one living!

Indeed I have good hopes of your Father! His illness has been in so many
of its features exactly like my Uncle’s—who recovered!John Welsh; see 43:129TC to RMM, 10 March 1866. – And this beautiful Calm in which he awaits his fate,—is it not the state most favourable for recovery, as well as most prophetic of it? Oh my Dear! My Dear! I think of you allMary, her father, and Mary’s sister Georgiana (1831–95). unceasingly!
I fear you will think my note to Him too long—and perhaps injudicious. But—I could only write just what came to me! And with so much in my heart for him, it was, to my thinking little to write.

A word now and then, when you can spare me a minute?– My love to your Sister— Ah! when we were bothering about Reviews,Georgiana Craik was a novelist; for JWC’s responses to and Jewsbury’s reviews of Georgiana’s early works, see 33:113–14JWC to DD, 5 Nov. [1857], and 35:23–25JWC to GMC, [8 Feb. 1859]; for Jewsbury’s critical review of one of her works, 1860, see 36:139–40JWC to GCMC, 18 June [1860]; for JWC’s response to Winifred’s Wooing, Craik’s 1862 novel, and a review of it, see 38:239JWC to GMC, 20 Oct. [1862]. how little He or She, or I foresaw this!
God comfort and strengthen you both

div3.sourceNote: JWC-JT, 3 April [1866]. MS: Royal Institution RI JT/2/10.410 (Tyndall’s Journal 1858–71). Hitherto unpbd. John Tyndall’s letter to JWC, 2 April, presumably arrived after JWC expressed her disappointment at not receiving a letter from “some of you” (see JWC to TC 3 April). It was probably written before TC to JWC, 3 April 1866.
div3.head: JWC TO JOHN TYNDALL

docBody.p: The Scotch HousemaidJessie Hiddleston / Hiddlestone (1835–1904; see 44:35TC to JCA, [ca. 10 Aug. 1866]), from Thornhill, one of the Carlyles’ maids, July 1865–Aug. 1866. was perfectly right, when she pronounced you “The very nicest gentleman that came to this House! Just rale charming, in HER opinion”! God bless you! Yes!—I never saw anybody so “charming” in all my life! Even Mr C is charmed! He writes to me;
“Tyndall’s conduct to me has been Loyalty’s own Self; no loving Son could have more faithfully watched a decrepit Father: in fact I shall not forget it.”–

Nor shall I forget it dear kind friend! thank you, thank you, for all you have done to relieve my anxieties.Tyndall wrote, 2 April: “I have time to do little more than confirm my telegram. He spoke without faltering for an hour and a half unassisted by notes of any kind. His audience was breathlessly attentive, except at intervals when it burst into irrepressive applause. He ended by quoting with exceeding power that brave and beautiful poem of Goethe’s / “Choose well your choice is / Brief but yet endless” / and here the audience rose as one man and burst into a universal roar of acclamation. When he quitted the house with his friends he was followed into the street and when I last saw him there was a crowd at his heels battering their hats together in the open air, and cheering the Hero. / Now are you content? ”
I was horribly afraid yesterday, till the Telegram came; I had got it in my head that He was to drop down dead at the outset! I should certainly have done so in his place.

The relief your Two cleverly chosen words“A perfect triumph”; see 43:155JWC to TC, [3 April 1866]. sent thro’ me from head to foot could only express itself in a violent fit of crying! But I didn’t begin to cry till I had read the words to a gaping audience comprising every body in the house, Cook,Sarah Warren. Housemaid, young-Lady CousinMaggie Welsh, staying at Chelsea early March–3 April 1866. —who all fell to dancing and clapping their hands, and exclaiming in their several ways—Jessie the housemaid’s way was— “Eh!– Hear to that! Hurrah!” and above her rose the voice of the Cook, crying “goodness gracious! some Brandy for the Mistress!– Don’t you see she is going off!!! and a tablespoonful of brandy was administered and was, I dare say, useful.

The Telegram was in my hand at three minutes after six! and I took it in my hand to John Forsters Birthday dinner, where was Dickens and Wilkie Collins,Wilkie Collins (1824–89; ODNB), writer. and again there was hurrahing and again on my part a tendency to “go off” (suppressed)–“fine fellow that Tyndall! said Forster, a dear warm-hearted fellow—you can see that from the way he throws himself into the thing”!

I had several letters from persons who had been present, along with yours, but none of them put the scene before the eyes of my heart as yours did. Since the letters one eye witness has been here Mr MacmillanAlexander Macmillan. but dreadfully inarticulate with the best intentions.

docBody.dateline: 5 Cheyne Row / Chelsea S. W April 22 [21]—1866—
docBody.p: dear Bettyn—Mrs Carlyle has talked to me about you so often that I feel to know you quite well— I write to you at once that you may not hear my sorrowful tidings from any chance person—

Mrs Carlyle was as well as usual yesterday when I saw her— this morning she was in her usual health & went out to drive and she died quite suddenly in her carriage this afternoon about four o’clock— I have seen he r— it has quieted me I shall have all my life long to be sorry but now I am comforted to have seen her so calm & placid & out of all pain & sorrow— She loved you so much & I know she will be glad I shd write to you She complained of being very sick but that she has been so long we thought little of it but now she will suffer no more.

Dear Betty do please write to me—here I am stopping here. She wished to be laid by her mother in Scotland so we hope Mr Carlyle will stay there to receive her— I have not heard any particulars yet—I cannot bear them—but I will write to you again
I love you because you loved her—
GERALD BLUNT’S DESCRIPTION OF JOHN SILVESTER’S RETURN TO CHEYNE ROW. Pbd: Blunt, “CHH” 464.

Reginald Blunt later described the scene when John Silvester returned to 5 Cheyne Row from the hospital: “About five o’clock my father met the empty brougham returning from St. George’s Hospital to Cheyne Row. Poor old Silvester, the coachman, pulled up on seeing him, and, terribly upset, told him what had happened: the drive first to Mr. Forster’s house at Palace Gate; then to the park; Mrs. Carlyle’s getting out near Queen’s Gate, and giving her little dog a run as far as the Serpentine; and again putting him out near the Victoria Gate, when he was almost run over by a carriage, and his paw slightly hurt; her jumping out almost before he could pull up, lifting the dog into the carriage and getting in herself; then the drive twice round the park, and his growing alarm at receiving no order from her; finally, his appeal to a passing lady, who at once gave her verdict, ‘Dead,’ which was confirmed by another bystander; and the drive to St. George’s Hospital, where the worst was confirmed, and where he had just left his mistress.”

I shall tell you a sad piece of news. Yesterday Mrs Carlyle lunched with Mrs Forster,—was in particularly good spirits: she afterwards went to drive in the Park: when there, she stopped the carriage to put down her little dog for a run,—a dog bequeathed her by poor Mrs Chapman a few weeks ago: no sooner out in the road, than the little thing’s foot was run over by a carriage-wheel,—the creature screamed, & Mrs Carlyle got out and took it in again,—no doubt, much startled by the accident: the Coachman continued his drive round the park,—repeated it,—then began to wonder at getting no order, looked round, and could not see his mistress: he stopped, and asked a passer-by to look in at the door,—the person, a lady cried “Drive to St George’s Hospital.”— He did so,—they took her out dead. Forster was sent for,—and was at immense pains to get the body removed,—the authorities insisting that an inquest must be held: he put forth all his admirable energy and managed the matter—not before midnight. (I little guessed as I passed the Hospital at eleven, returning from Ld Belper’s close by, who was lying there.) Carlyle is away in Scotland,—one can hardly venture to fancy the shock to him,—at the end of his pleasant little triumph there. Forster, who had a deep affection for her, is in a paroxysm of grief,—yet, strange to see, I have had no message to prevent my dining with him today, as was arranged: he may want me for some purpose, to be sure: otherwise, what a “dinner!”— I met her the last time on the occasion of Carlyle’s completing his seventieth year—not very long ago.
[Isabella Blagden (1816/17–73; ODN B), novelist and poet. Edward Strutt (1801–80; ODN B), 1st Baron Belper; politician; his house was at 75 Eaton Sq., London.]

div3.head: SDI TO CHARLOTTE CUSHMAN AND EMMA STEBBINS

docBody.p: 22 April 1866. MS: Charlotte Cushman Papers, Library of Congress. Pbd: Carlyle Studies Annual 24 (2008):148–49; text from pbd. source.

Sunday April 22nd 1866 / My dear friends, you will be surprized [sic] to hear from me again so soon, and you will be very sorry for the news I have to send you— On Thursday, ten days after I wrote to you, I went to see Mrs Carlyle as I had promised her I would do during this week.— She was going out to Richmond to see an Aunt there, and I went with her—and we took with us a little dog that was left to her care by Mrs Frederick Chapman, who died some short time ago. Once or twice on our way she put the little dog down to run by the carriage as she did not know how to give it excercise [sic], and she found this answer so well she said she should sometimes drive in the park and let it run there— She was as well as I have seen her for many months—very feeble, of
course, and complaining of suffering from the warmer weather—but just herself. She was interesting herself about a nephew [James C. Aitken] of Mr Carlyle who has come up to London. She wanted Stauros [Dilberoglue, Sarah’s husband] to know him, and it was arranged that he and I should have tea with her to-night and meet this nephew before Mr Carlyle’s return (who is to be here tomorrow) as in his uncle’s presence the young man is over awed, and it is difficult to know anything about him. [Two illegible words] matters—well—last night I had gone to bed between 11 & 12 & Stauros was still up reading, when I heard a loud strange rapp at the door & a talking—and Lizzie rushed up to tell me it was a nephew of Mrs Carlyle’s who brought us the news that she was dead. I have just come in from Chelsea where Geraldine Jewsbury & the nephew are [sto]pping in the house— And poor Mr Carlyle is looked for at ½ past 4 or 10 o’clock in the morning—as his arrangements stood he was to return home by a train to-night[.] Yesterday it seems she lunched at Mr Forster’s and in her return home drove in the Park to give that hapless little dog a run—it got hurt by a carriage and she had to get out and take it in with her, & was flurried and excited by this— The old coachman says that for a time he heard the crying of the dog as she was turning it about to find where it was hurt—then there was stillness, & he kept driving up and down as ordered— Wondering at last she did not tell him to go home as it was getting late, he looked into the carriage, and seeing there was something wrong asked a lady who was passing to look in— She did and said “I dare not open this door, for I am afraid the lady is dead”—then a gentleman got into the carriage and ordered the coachman to drive to St George Hospital— She was taken in and found to be quite dead—the coachman said also she was, and of course all care was taken— Dr Quain was either there or was sent for,—and late last night she was removed home— / Monday morning.—— I went to Chelsea again last night—through the exertions of John Forster the pain of an inquest will be spared. Dr Quain has called the cause of death paralysis—but we all believe it was an apoplexy— To me this change from Thursday to last night when I saw her lying in her bed in that mournful house has been a great shock— We are to hear from the nephew to-day how Mr Carlyle is— He will feel as if life were [word crossed out] indeed ended—his work done, its acknowledgment received, and his wife gone from him—and may talk now of that “rest for Evermore” I once heard him speak of— We feel unspeakably sorry for him— I must finish, for Stauros will take my letter with him to put in the city, that you may hear as soon as possible— Dear love from all to you both.
[For Charlotte Cushman (1816–76), see 37:224–25 JWC to [CCU], [6 Sept. 1861] , and 264–65 37:biographical notes ; for Emma Stebbins (1815–82), see 37:265 37:biographical notes .]
22 April 1866. Pbd: Blunt, “CLC” 420.
Dear Charlotte,
This little bit of paper is large enough to hold the heavy tidings I have to tell you.

Mrs. Carlyle is dead—she died yesterday quite suddenly whilst out driving— Dr. Quain says it was Paralysis— Mr. Carlyle is not at home but he may come back to-morrow—it will be a terrible coming home for him. She was in her usual health and spirits and we none of us dreamed of danger. /

docBody.dateline: 5 Cheyne Row Chelsea / S W Monday April 23–1866
docBody.p: My dear Bettyndash;I wrote to you yesterday but I fear my letter did not bear a quite correct address so I write again to tell you the sorrowful news is true we shall never see her or hear her speak again in this world— Mrs Carlyle is dea d—she died quite suddenly on Saturday in her carriage whilst she was driving in the Park— Mr Carlyle is still in Scotland—but he would hear the heavy news yesterday. She always wished to lie beside her father— so she will go once more to Scotland to stay there always.

Poor Mr Carlyle it will be a sore sorrow to him & there is no one to comfort him now— She used to talk of you & love you so much that I feel to know you quite well We are both of us growing old & so we shall not be long left behind her—
Miss M. Welsh came here last night— we are here to meet Mr Carlyle

I will write to you again when I have more to tell you— Mrs Carlyle always when she was alarmed or agitated had a great sudden pain in her Bac k wh took her breath for the moment she used to say her mother had it & that some day it would kill her—well on Saturday she had put her little dog out of the carriage to run by the side a little A carriage drove over it poor thing & she sprang out of the carriage to take it up— took it in her arms & got in again— then in a little while the driver of the carriage was surprised not to have orders to go home as it was her time— then they found she was dea d— now she lies in her Coffin upstairs looking as tho’ she were asleep

closer.salute: Miss Welsh sends you her love & so do I

p.hi: HADDINGTONSHIRE COURIER'S DESCRIPTION OF THE FUNERAL CEREMONY,

docBody.p: THE LATE MRS CARLYLE

Mrs Carlyle,
the wife of the great writer, died on Saturday under very peculiar circumstances. She was taking her usual drive in Hyde Park about four o’clock, when her little favourite dog, which was running by the side of the brougham, was run over by a carriage. She was greatly alarmed, though the dog was not seriously hurt. She lifted the dog into the carriage, and the man drove on. Not receiving any call or direction from his mistress, as was usual, he stopped the carriage, and discovered her, as he thought, in a fit or ill, and drove to St George’s Hospital, which was near at hand. When there it was discovered that she must have been dead some little time. Mrs Carlyle’s health had been for some months feeble, but not in a state to excite anxiety or alarm. / The late Mrs Carlyle, the Star says, was a woman of much intelligence and culture. She, as well as her distinguished husband, corresponded
with Goethe and other foreign authors of renown. In the full collections of Goethe’s poems will be found two or three poetical scraps addressed to “Madame Carlyle, Scotland.” One of these was originally written on a visiting card, which Goethe sent to the wife of his friend and admirer, and the lines, roughly translated, run somewhat in this fashion:— / “Messengers like this we send / To tell the coming of a friend; / This poor card can only say / That the friend is far away.” / The Daily Telegraph,
in noticing the death of Mrs Carlyle, says that of few English [sic] wives could it more truly have been said that “she lived unknown,” than of the wife of Thomas Carlyle. Gentle, affectionate, and retiring; contented to remain in the studious shade by her husband’s home that she might look forth from it upon the gladsome sunshine of his world-wide fame; seeing through his eyes, hearing through his ears, yet never surrendering her own autonomy of thought and independence of judgment—it is to Mrs Carlyle that in no slight degree the world is indebted for many of those grand prose epics, which are songs to humanity and martial music to working men for all future time. … [ellipses in H C
] / Wherever the English tongue is spoken—wherever noble thoughts clad in nervous, sinewy language, and illustrated by matchless imagery of thought and expression—can be read and appreciated, there will arise a cry of commiseration for the death of her who so ministered to the greatest living teacher of his countrymen. From every corner of the earth will come words of comfort and support—from the home of Longfellow, whence all light and hope passed when his wife was snatched away, and from the home of Emerson—from Germany and Australia, no less than from England, Scotland, and Ireland. And we are but anticipating the universal sentiment, when we say that, in the name of every class—from those who stand the most exalted in station or in literature, to those of his humble and unknown brethren who have also found in his words an inspiration and a passion—we offer to Mr Carlyle a respectful tribute of heart-felt sympathy.

The deceased lady, to whom these parting tributes of affectionate respect and admiration have been paid by our London contemporaries, was born in Haddington in 1801, and was thus in her 66th year. She was the only child of the late Dr Welsh, one of the most successful practitioners of the medical art that our burgh ever possessed and a man of great force and originality of character, in which respect his daughter much resembled him. Her education was, for the most part, received in the burgh schools here—the celebrated Edward Irving, who was at that time one of the masters, having been for a considerable period her tutor. Of her early compeers at the burgh schools, Mr W. Dods, banker, is, so far as we are aware, among the few now resident in Haddington, and it was to his house that the remains of his old class-fellow were removed from London by train on Wednesday, previous to interment
in the parish church-yard, where her father lies buried. Mr Carlyle, accompanied by his brother Dr Carlyle and Mr John Forester [Forster], left the metropolis in the same train, and arrived in Haddington late on Wednesday—Mr Carlyle being the guest of Mr Dods for the evening. The interment took place at one o’clock yesterday afternoon, from the house of Mr Dods. The Rev. Dr Cook, who along with a few of the older citizens, had been invited to accompany the remains to the grave, offered up a deeply impressive prayer previous to the melancholy procession taking its way to the burying ground. On arriving at the church-yard, the body, enclosed in a coffin of polished mahogany, was removed from the hearse, and carried shoulder high to the grave, within the centre of the old aisle. Mr Carlyle took his place as chief mourner, the pall-bearers being Dr Carlyle, the Hon. Mr Twisleton, Mr John Foster [Forster], the Rev. Mr [Walter] Welsh, Mr Binnie (Seton Mains), Mr W. Dods, and Dr Howden, senr. Several of those present, who had enjoyed the friendship of the deceased, were bathed in tears as dust was being consigned to dust, but Mr Carlyle himself, though evidently by a strong effort, maintained wonderful composure, and manifested few external indications of emotion. What the nature of his feelings were could be known from the long, sad, sorrowful look that he cast into the open grave, and the tenderness of the gesture with which he stooped down, and flung the first handful of earth over the remains of her who had shared so long with him the joys and sorrows of life. / Mr Carlyle and the friends who had accompanied him from England left Haddington by the afternoon train for the south.

[Henry Wadsworth Longfellow (1807–82), U.S. poet and translator; after his 2d wife, Frances Appleton, d. 1861, Longfellow found it difficult to write poetry; he met JWC and TC in 1840 (12:379) and 1842 (15:126). Rev. Dr. John Cook (1807–74), minister of St. Mary’s, Haddington. Thomas Binnie (b. 1824), son of JWC’s second cousin Mary Binnie (1794–1866; see 37:262 37:biographical notes ), farmer at Seton Mains, Longniddry. Dr. Thomas Howden (1787–1868), JWC’s father’s partner; see 32:251 32:biographical notes .]

docBody.dateline: THE TIMES’S DESCRIPTION OF THE FUNERAL CEREMONY, 28 April 1866.
docBody.p:
The remains of Mrs. Carlyle were conveyed from London on Wednesday to Haddington for interment there, and the funeral took place on Thursday afternoon. Mr. Carlyle was accompanied from London by his brother, Dr. Carlyle, Mr. John Forster, and the Hon. Mr. Twisleton. The funeral cortège consisted of a hearse and two carriages, and was followed on foot by a large number of gentlemen who had known Mrs. Carlyle and her father, Dr. Welsh, who was held in high estimation in the town, where he had practised medicine till his death in 1819. The grave, which is the same as that occupied by Dr.
Welsh, lies in the centre of the ruined choir of the old cathedral at Haddington, known as the Lucerna Loudoniensis or “Lamp of Lothian.” The pall-bearers were, in addition to the gentlemen who accompanied Mr. Carlyle from London, the Rev. Mr. Welsh, Mr. Dods, banker, Haddington; Mr. Binnie, Seton Mains; and Dr. Thomas Howden, the last-named gentleman having been the business partner of Mrs. Carlyle’s father. The body was encased in a handsome coffin of polished wood with brass mountings. In accordance with the Scottish practice there was no service read, and Mr. Carlyle threw a handful of earth on the coffin after it had been lowered into the grave. A number of ladies and gentlemen had assembled in the churchyard to witness the funeral.

docBody.dateline: 43 Markham Square Chelsea S. W. / April 29 1866 Sunday night
docBody.p:
You asked me to give you any early intelligence about Mr Carlyle—he returned on Friday morning. very much broken & shaken— This sorrow has made him quite an old man all at once he is “feeble & sore broken” & it is enough to break ones heart to see him—he cannot talk yet. I saw him yesterday but only very brief words were spoken.—walking seems to soothe him & he went out yesterday in all that pouring rain but he cd not bear the weight
of either cape or great Coat— I think he will remain in the house where all is as she left it— His brother is with him also Miss Welsh— the two servants watch him with great care & thoughtfulness—
I mentioned to Miss Welsh about the little table—but if he remains it is a thing he [is] used to seeing, & he sits down beside it on the floor when he smokes.

Miss Welsh asked me to assist her in making an Inventory of all her things & it has occupied us a good deal to get it done before his return. Now that I am alone & in my own room again all the occupation of my life seems over. for she has been for many years the main interest I have had—all my employments were made with a view to her
I hope you will keep your kind promise or rather the pleasant hop e you gave me that you wd sometimes let me see you.
I am dear Madam
1 May 1866. MS: NLS Acc. 9086.

You have been very kind in letting us hear of your Brother, and we thank you heartily for both your letters. It is not to be expected that Mr Carlyle should get over his loss for many a day: but I am thankful to hear that he is now getting a little sleep; which is the best restoration for his nervous system which must have received a great shock. Both your brother and your self know how deeply we are interested in him, and how earnestly we desire that he may be comforted & supported under his sorrow——so I think I may venture to say—what his Mother would have said to him under present circumstances,—that I trust he may find God a present help in this—his time of trouble; and be kept safely under the care of the Almighty. / I hope when the weather improves,—he will go abroad,— perhaps Professor Tyndall may go with him. He should not remain too long in London: where he will find it difficult to avoid seeing visitors;—and even the kindness of friends,—is very overpowering in sorrow. … /

div3.sourceNote: GEJ-KST, 1 May 1866. MS: NLS 1797.120.
div3.head: GEJ TO LADY AMBERLEY,

docBody.dateline: 43 Markham Square Chelsea S. W. / May 1–1866
docBody.p: I am extremely obliged by your very kind letter— I need not tell you that it wd be a great pleasure if you were good enough to come to see me at any time. & I only hope that nothing will occur to prevent it.
I gave Mr Carlyle your letter to read and when he laid it down he said mournfully— “She is a dear good child—but I cannot see her yet”——

But I think the experience of the love & reverence with wh she was regarded soothes him—he seems to feel so bitterly that she shd have been taken away just at the moment when she had seen the end, crown his life’s work, after she had borne with him the struggle & burden of the day He has become a very old man all at once. broken & frail & very worn—last night there was a letter from Lady Augusta Stanley, conveying a very gracious message from the Queen;—an expression of her sympathy— also a reference to the interest she had taken in his Speech at Edinbro—but he did not seem to care for it—only to feel that nothing cd bring her back again— If ever any one deserved sorrow & regret she does—as yet we do not feel it; it is a sorrow that will grow heavier as time goes on. Mr Carlyle is not well & he has a very bad cold. I think the only consoling thought he has—is that their separation will but [sic] for a very little while.—of course! I wish your husband long success for your sake & I think he will have success in life tho’ it may not come yet. the affirmation that is to last seldom comes early— I have had no heart to read newspapers for many days past—but I think that now if I can get an admission to the Lady’s Gallery I cd listen to a good tough debate with interest— I am dear Madam

div3.sourceNote: TWO-LLA, Apri / May 1866. MS: NLS Acc. 11388 inc.
div3.head: TWO TO LADY ASHBURTON

docBody.p: He spoke of the coming back and finding the little edifice in which he had hoped to spend the rest of his days all shattered; and how hard it was to believe it true, and all the time its being an invincible reality! He talked for a long time of her who had been such a true and faithful mate for forty years; and that thinking of her thorough nobleness made him feel proud to have been partner of such a woman.

Dr Carlyle and his niece Miss Welsh are with him, and the sitting room looked much the same to a rude glance, but how vacant looked that corner of the sofa!— How I missed the the little silver knick-knack ornaments there!
The last I saw of her was a bright kind smile while passing thro’ the door to go away, one morning I called after Carlyle had gone to Scotland; how much more often I should have seen her had I thought of losing her so soon. She often spoke to me of what a loss it was to her missing your Ladyships society, and how she wished you would return; poor dear creature how little she thought you were never to meet again.
He came a walk with me and on parting asked me to go and see him again: when I do I will write again and say how he is and what doing.

On Saturday 21st April I was in Edinburgh, and Tom at Dumfries, when a piece of very sad news came to me from London, late in the evening by telegraph, which I had to forward to him at once. A second telegram came the same night at a still later hour, and it too had to be forwarded. The two joined together announced that Mrs Carlyle had died suddenly in the afternoon of that day while driving in her little carriage alone in Hyde Park. A small terrier, left to her care by a friend (Mrs Chapman) who died lately (in March) of consumption, had been running alongside the carriage and had got itself either kicked or trampled on by the horses of another carriage and was left
lying on the road. Jane got out, took it up, and spoke a few words to the lady of that other carriage who had got out to make an apology; then entered her own carriage again, and the driver went on as before noticing nothing particular about her and seeing that the dog had got very little if any injury. There was a string close to her by pulling which she could at once have stopped him. He first became uneasy at her not pulling it after he had gone on as far as usual; looked down through the front window, saw her hands lying quiet and open on her lap; went round the Park again, and on returning to the place (again) of which she used to pull the string, he stopt and saw her hands in exactly in the same position—which of course gave him great alarm—and not being able to quit the horse he asked the nearest lady and gentleman to look into the carriage and see if aught had happened. They found her quite gone, reclining backwards with face looking placid in death and relieved of all sorrow. I joined Tom at Dumfries by the earliest train from Lockerbie, having come so far by the only Sunday train from Edinburgh; and we started together for London the same day (Monday), arriving here about half past ten at night. He had written to a friend on the Sunday from Dumfries, to make preparations for the funeral, and we found every thing in a state of forwardness. In the coffin her face still retained the expression of earnest placidity and relief from sorrow. / On wednesday went to Haddington with the coffin in next compartment of railway carriage before us, two friends from London accompanying us; on the Thursday the funeral took place from the house of Mr Dods, banker, an old friend and schoolfellow of hers. It was attended by many other old friends and acquaintances of the neighbourhood and passed off very quietly indeed, the weather being quite beautiful. She lies buried in the same grave as her Father, in the ruined choir of the old Abbey church. She had written to Mr Dods about her burial more than twelve months ago; and she had told Tom before he went to Edinburgh, that she durst not go with him owing to some disease of the spine which sometimes took away her breath and stopped the action of the heart when aught agitated her suddenly; and the physician who attended her before, certified this spinal disease as the cause of death under the circumstances. She had talked of it to Tom as slight and so he had felt little or no alarm beforehand. He has felt the shock most severely of course, especially since we got back from Haddington on Friday, but he is quite calm and has had pretty good sleep for the last three nights. I intend staying here sometime with him. I will put three strokes on the newspaper address, if all goes well next week, as a signal. I could get no time to write earlier, or even to send off the newspaper last week. / We hear today from Dumfries, Gill, and Scotsbrig that all was well there. From the Queen downward there have been condolences, if any good were possible from them. Tom is as well as usual in body. Let us hope he may soon be able to adjust himself patiently to his great loss. I have not time to write more today. Please either send this on
to Jenny without delay, or write her the substance of it, for I feel quite worn by writing.

postscript.p: The kind of death which I have described, from that disease of the spine or brain, would be as sudden and as free from all pain as a simple fainting fit. The position in which the body was found reclining also shewed that there had been no struggle or suffering. She had written a letter to Tom, in excellent spirits, on the Saturday just before going out for her drive, and reached him at Dumfries on the Sunday. She had lunched with Mrs Forster too and been in high spirits only some 20 minutes before her death. Ever since her illness in 1864 she had been frail as possible, but had kept driving out daily and had never complained to any one; so that none of us felt alarmed about her. I did not hear of her spinal disease at all, or it might have alarmed me, as it did her physician whom I don’t know personally and who had said nothing to Tom about it. She had suffered much from want of sleep all along, though she made no complaints. To herself such a gentle death would be a real benefit, though it has left our brother desolate and without his main stay in life. / The Edinburgh Address you would get from himself, as well as the first report of it from me, by post. It was as successful as anything of the kind could be, and poor Jane of course was glad as if some great victory had been gained. / I will write two words after all by this mail to Jenny, referring her to you for particulars. / J A C / The infinite number of letters of condolence has been most troublesome to me especially as I have had to acknowledge most of them.

docBody.p: TC’S JOURNAL ENTRY ON JWC’S DEATH AND FUNERAL.
MS: privately owned. Pbd: Froude, Carlyle 4:314–16.

Saturdy night, about 9½ p.m., I was sitting in sister Jean’s at Dumfries, thinking of my railway to Chelsea on Monday, and perhaps of a sprained ancle I had got at Scotsbrig two weeks or so before—when the fatal telegrams (two of them in success) came; it had a kind of stunning effect on me; not for above two days cd I estimate the immeasurable depth of it, or the infinite sorrow whh had peeled my life all bare, and, in a moment, shattered my poor world to universal ruin. They took me out next day, to wander (as was medically needful) in the green sunny Sabbath fields; and ever and anon there rose from my sick heart the ejaculatn, “my poor little woman!” but no full gust of tears came to my relief, nor has yet come; will it ever? A stony “Woe’s me, woe’s me!” sometimes with infinite tenderness, & pity not for myself, is my habitl mood hitherto. I had been hitching lamely abt in the Teregles quarter, my company the green solitudes and fresh spring breezes,—quietly but far from happily, abt the hour she died. Sixteen hours after the telegram (Sunday abt 2 p.m.) there came to me a Letter from her, written on Saty before going out; the cheeriest & merriest of all her several prior ones;—a Note for her written at Scotsbrig, Friday morning, & whh shd have been a pleasure to her at breakfast this morning was not put in till after 6 at Ecclefn (negligence of my nephew Jamie, excusable but unforgettable); had not left Ecclefn till 10 p.m., nor arrived till 2 p.m. next day, and lay u nopened here. / Monday morning, John set off with me for London;—never, for a 1,000 years shd I forget that arrival here of ours,—my first u nwelcomed by her;—She lay in her coffin, lovely in death, I kissed her cold brow next night before the Maggie Welsh here & Pale death and things not mine or ours had possession of our poor dwelling. Very kind very helpful to me if to no other,—everybody was. For, as I learnt ultimately, had it not been for their John Forster & Dr. Quain’s and everybody’s mercy to me, there must have been, by rule, a Coroner’s Inquest held, whh wd have been a blotch upon my memory, intolerable then, and discordantly ugly for all time coming. It is to Forster’s unwearied and invincible efforts, that I am indebted for escape from this sad defilet of my feelings. Indeed his kindness then, and all thro’, in every particular & detail, was u nexampled, of a cordiality & assiduity almost painful to me. Next day wander over the fatal localities in Hyde Park; Forster & Br John settling, apart from me, everything for the morrow. Morrow, Wedny morning, we were under way with our sacred burden; John & F. kindly did not speak to me (good Twisleton too was in the train witht consulting me): I looked out upon the spring fields, the everlasting skies, in silence; and had for most part a more endurable day,—till Haddington where friends Dods &cwere waiting, with hospitalities, with &c&cwhh almost drove me openly wild. I went out to walk in the
moonlit silent streets, not suffered to go alone: I looked up at the windows of the old room where I had first seen her,—1820, I believe, on a summer eveg after sunset,—six and forty years ago. Edwd Irving had brot me out, walking, to Haddington; she the first thing I had to see there. The beautifullest young creature I had ever beheld; sparkling with grace and talent, tho’ sunk in sorrow (for loss of her Father), and speaking little. I noticed her once looking at me.— Oh Heaven, to think of that now!— / The Dodses (excellt people in their honest homely way) had great pity for me, patience with me; I retired to my room, slept none all night,—little sleep to me since that telegram night;—but lay silent in the great Silence. Thursday (26th April 1866) wandered out into the churchyd &c: at 1 p.m. came the funeral; silent, small only 12 old friends, and 2 volunteer, besides us three, very beautiful and noble to me: and I laid her head in the grave of her Father (accord to covenant of 40 years back); and all was ended. In the nave of the old Abbey Kirk, long a ruin, now being saved from further decay, with the skies looking down on her, there sleeps my little Jeannie, and the light of her face will never shine on me more. One other time,—after the Inscriptn is put on,—I have promised my self to be in Haddington. We withdrew, that afternoon; posted up (by Edinr with its many confusions) towards London all night, and abt 10 or 11 a.m. were shovelled out here; where I am hitching and wandering abt, best off in strict solitude (were it only possible); my one solace and employment that of doing all whh I can imagine she wd have liked me to do. [TC wrote similarly about this time in Carlyle, Reminiscences (194) where he concluded:] I suppose it to be useless to continue these jottings (Book probably to be burnt from all other eyes, and to myself painful!)—but perhaps will add something to-morrow still. (May 8 1866; 9th, I find!).
26 May 1866. Pbd: Froude, Carlyle 4:338–41.

Dear Mr. Carlyle,—I think it better to write than to speak on the miserable subject about which you told me to inquire of Mr. Silvester. I saw him to-day. He said that it would be about twenty minutes after three o’clock or thereabouts when they left Mr. Forster’s house; that he then drove through Queen’s Gate, close by Kensington Gardens, that there, at the uppermost gate, she got out, and walked along the side of the Gardens very slowly, about two hundred paces, with the little dog running, until she came to the Serpentine Bridge, at the southern end of which she got into the carriage again, and he drove on till they came to a quiet place on the Tyburnia side, near Victoria Gate, and then she put out the little dog to run along. When they came opposite to Albion Street, Stanhope Place (lowest thoroughfare of Park towards Marble Arch), a brougham coming along upset the dog, which lay on its back screaming for a while, and then she pulled the check-string; and he turned round and pulled
up at the side of the footpath, and there the dog was (he had got up out of the road and gone there). Almost before the carriage stopped she was out of it. The lady whose brougham had caused the accident got out also, and several other ladies who were walking had stopped round the dog. The lady spoke to her; but he could not hear what she said, and the other ladies spoke. She then lifted the dog into the carriage, and got in herself. He asked if the little dog was hurt; but he thinks she did not hear him, as carriages were passing. He heard the dog squeak as if she had been feeling it (nothing but a toe was hurt); this was the last sound or sigh he ever heard from her place of fate. He went on towards Hyde Park Corner, turned there and drove past the Duke of Wellington’s Achilles figure, up the drive to the Serpentine and past it, and came round by the road where the dog was hurt, past the Duke of Wellington’s house and past the gate opposite St. George’s. Getting no sign (noticing only the two hands laid on the lap, palm uppermost the right hand, reverse way the left, and all motionless), he turned into the Serpentine drive again; but after a few yards, feeling a little surprised, he looked back, and, seeing her in the same posture, became alarmed, made for the streetward entrance into the Park a few yards westward of gatekeeper’s lodge, and asked a lady to look in; and she said what we know, and she addressed a gentleman who confirmed her fears. It was then fully a quarter past four; going on to twenty minutes (but nearer the quarter); of this he is quite certain. She was leaning back in one corner of the carriage, rugs spread over her knees; her eyes were closed, and her upper lip slightly, slightly opened. Those who saw her at the hospital and when in the carriage speak of the beautiful expression upon her face. / On that miserable night, when we were preparing to receive her, Mrs. Warren came to me and said, that one time, when she was very ill, she said to her, that when the last had come, she was to go upstairs into the closet of the spare room and there she would find two wax candles wrapt in paper, and that those were to be lighted and burned. She said that after she came to live in London she wanted to give a party; her mother wished everything to be very nice, and went out and bought candles and confectionary, and set out a table, and lighted the room quite splendidly, and called her to come and see it when all was prepared. She was angry; she said people would say she was extravagant, and would ruin her husband. She took away two of the candles and some of the cakes. Her mother was hurt and began to weep. She was pained at once at what she had done; she tried to comfort her, and was dreadfully sorry. She took the candles and wrapped then up, and put them where they could be easily found. We found them and lighted them, and did as she desired. /

Carlyle let me in yesterday, and talked about her (Mrs. Carlyle) for near an hour. How I wish I could have taken down what he said word for word! “She wrapped me round like a cloak, to keep all the hard and cold world off me.” “When I came home, sick with mankind, there she was on the sofa, always with a cheerful story of something or somebody, and I never knew that she, poor darling! had been fighting with bitter pains all day.” “To think that little dog should have been the instrument to take the light of life away from me.” “What would it be for me now to have the fame of Trismegistus [see 42:114 TC to JN, 8 July 1865
], without her to be glad at it?” “She had never a mean thought or word from the day I first saw her looking like a flower out of the window of her mother’s old brick house, my Jeanie, my queen;” and so on.

div1.p: Notes on the Carlyles’ contemporaries referred to more than once in the present volume are given below, cross-referenced to earlier information. Some relatives or old friends who died before the starting date of this volume are retained because of frequent references to them. Otherwise, individuals are accounted for in headnotes and footnotes when they appear in the letters.

Adamson, Samuel (1831–80), of British Linen Co., Dumfries, where TC had an account; son of Robert Adamson (1787–1861; see 10:23 TC to JA, 14 Feb. 1838
, and 37:261 37:biographical notes ).

Airlie, Henrietta Blanche, b. Stanley (1829–1921; see 26:302 26:biographical notes ), 5th countess; m., 1851, David Graham Drummond Ogilvy, Lord Airlie (1826–81; see 26:289 26:biographical notes ), 5th earl; for their children, see JWC to TC, [15 April 1866] . They lived at Cortachy Castle, Forfarshire (now Angus).

Aitken, David (1796–1875; see 4:192 TC to DA, [17 Feb. 1827] ), minister of Minto, Teviotdale, resigned 1864; m., 1836, JWC’s childhood friend Eliza, b. Stodart (ca. 1794–1869; see 1:199 JBW to EA, [26? Sept. 1819] ); see 39:23 JWC to JRS, [31 Dec. 1862] . Living at 4 Charlotte Sq., Edinburgh.

Aitken, Jean (“Craw”) Carlyle (1810–88), TC’s sister; m., 1833, James Aitken (1809–87) from Troqueer, housepainter of English St., Dumfries; they moved from Assembly St., Dumfries, to their new house, The Hill, Lochmaben Rd., Dumfries, 1863. They had two sons who d. in infancy (1834–36 and 1855–56), both named Alexander; their surviving sons were James or Jamie (1836–71), who worked in a mercantile house in London 1858—ca. 1864, then moved to work in Liverpool, and from early 1866 was living in London trying to establish himself as a shipbroker; Thomas (1841–69), who had been at an inst. for the deaf in Glasgow (see 29:186 TC to JAC, 4 Nov. 1854
), but was apparently now living at home; and John (1843–1911). Their das. were Anne (1839–1919), Margaret (1845–1932), and Mary (1848–95), who m., 1879, her cousin Alexander Carlyle.

Amberley, Katherine (Kate) Louisa (1842–74; ODNB), viscountess, radical, and suffragist; m., 1864, John Russell (1842–76; ODNB), viscount, politician, and writer; son of John Russell (1792–1878; ODNB), 1st Earl Russell, politician, and Frances Anna Maria, b. Kynynmound (1815–98). Their son, John Francis (Frank) Stanley, was b. 12 August 1865.

Anstruther, Mary Frances, b. Stewart-Mackenzie (1819–1913), sister of Lady Louisa Ashburton, m., 1838, Philip Anstruther (1802–63). For their 11 children, including Annie Nairn (1841–1931), see 38:273–74 38:biographical notes . The family lived at 17 Norfolk St., Park Lane, London.

Ashburton, Lady Louisa Caroline, b. Stewart-Mackenzie (1827–1903), m., 1858, William Bingham Baring (1799–1864; ODNB; see 11:40 TC to MAC, 8 March 1839
, and later vols.), 2d baron, politician, and partner in Baring Bros., bankers. They had one da., Mary Florence (1860–1902). Lady Louisa was the da. of Mary Elizabeth Frederica, b. Mackenzie (1783–1862; ODNB), chief of Clan Mackenzie, and James Alexander Stewart (1784–1843); on their marriage (1817) the name Mackenzie was added to that of Stewart. Her sister-in-law, widow of her brother George Augustus Stewart-Mackenzie (1824–52), m. 1850, was Maria Louisa, b. Marriott (b. ca. 1826), always referred to as “Mrs. George.” JWC expected not to like Louisa but was swiftly won over. Lady Ashburton lived at Melchet Court (see 38:8 JWC to LLA, [11 Nov. 1861] ), a country house 6 mi. (9.5 km.) W of Romsey, Hampshire, on the border between Hampshire and Wiltshire; she also owned a farm at Addiscombe, near Croydon, and Seaforth Lodge, Devon. Lord Ashburton’s first wife, m. 1823, was Harriet, b. Montagu (1805–57; ODNB; see 11:40 TC to MAC, 8 March 1839
, and 26:ix–xv 26:introduction ); they met the Carlyles in 1839 and became close friends. Lord Ashburton’s brother Francis Baring (1800–68; see 36:276 36:biographical notes ) became 3d Baron Ashburton; his sisters were Louisa (1804–88) and Lydia Emily (1814–68). Where necessary for clarity, we refer in notes to Lord Ashburton’s first and second wives as Lady Harriet Ashburton and Lady Louisa Ashburton respectively, although these are not the correct forms.
Atkinson, Blanche (1847–1911), writer and naturalist, da. of a prosperous Liverpool soap manufacturer.

Austin, Mary Carlyle (1808–88), TC’s sister, m., 1831, James Austin (1805–78), farmer of The Gill, 6 mi. (9.5 km.) SW of Ecclefechan. They had eight das.: Margaret (see Stewart); Grace (b. 1833), who m., 1856, William Yeoward (b. ca. 1824), of Toronto, Ontario; Jessie (b. 1836), who m., 1859, George Grierson (b. 1835); Jane (b. 1840); Mary Anne (b. 1842); Catherine (1844–1908), who m., 18 Sept. 1866, her cousin James Carlyle; Isabella (b. ca. 1846); and Mary Carlyle (b. 1851); and one surviving son, James (b. 1848).

Austin, Sarah, b. Taylor (1793–1867; ODNB), writer and translator, widow of John Austin (1790–1859; ODNB); known to the Carlyles since 1831; see 5:379 TC to JWC, 29 Aug. 1831
. She lived in Weybridge, Surrey. Her da. Lucie (1821–69; ODNB), writer and translator, m., 1840, Alexander Cornewall Duff Gordon (1811–72); she suffered from tuberculosis and lived abroad.
Baring; see Ashburton.

Barnes, Dr. Alfred Brooke (ca. 1802–67), physician, living at 182 King’s Rd., Chelsea; JWC’s doctor in Chelsea until he became ill (see 40:123 TC to LLA, 28 June 1864
, and 198 TC to JWC, 22 Aug. 1864
); m. Susannah (ca. 1804—ca. 1855); their children were Laura Susannah (b. 1829, now dead); Rev. Brooke Cremer (b. 1833); Dr. Herbert Sedgwick (ca. 1835–26 Sept. 1865), JWC’s doctor; and Isabella Emily (b. 1837,
d. by 1899; see 35:188 JWC to JGCO, [2 Sept. 1859] ), m., 1862, John Simmonds (b. 1829), still alive in 1899, barrister; they lived at 82A Oakley St., Chelsea; their children were Ethel Jane (1863–65) and Amy Constance (b. Sept. 1865).
Barnet; see Blakiston.
Blackie, John Stuart (1809–95; ODNB), scholar and author, professor of Greek at Edinburgh Univ. from 1852; m., 1842, Eliza, b. Wyld (ca. 1819–1908).

Blakiston, Bessy, b. Barnet (ca. 1810–91), m., 1862, Peyton Blakiston (1801–78), M.D.; they lived at St. Leonards-on-Sea, Sussex. Blakiston’s first wife, m., 1825, was Frances, b. Powell (d. 1858); their sons were John Richard (1829–1917), Peyton (see below), Douglas Yeoman (1832–1914), and Matthew Folliott (1835–1906).

Blakiston, Peyton (1831–66), Commander, RN, m., 1862, Annie, b. Bally (1843–97), da. of Dr. William Ford Bally (1813–71) and Sarah Ellen, b. Hewlett (b. 1815); their children were William Graham (1864–1919), Evelyne Frances (Jan. 1865–1929), and Peyton (20 Dec. 1865–1883).

Blunt, Abel Gerald Wilson (1827–1902), m., 1851, Frances Mary, b. Forssteen (1820–99); they had seven children, including Reginald (1857–1944). Gerald Blunt was appointed rector of St. Luke’s, Chelsea, in 1860.

Braid, Betty, b. Pringle (1795–1875), Grace Welsh’s Haddington servant, close to JWC (see 21:82 JWC to SS, [29 Oct. 1846] , and 24:221 JWC to TC, [5 Sept. 1849] ); b. in Prestonkirk, E. Lothian; m. Alexander (1792–1874), stonemason and shopkeeper. Three sons d. in infancy: Alexander (b. 1826), James (b. 1829), and James (b. 1831); their son George (1827–65) survived into adulthood but suffered ill-health. Previously living at 15 Adam St. (see 17:127 TC to JWC, 12 Sept. 1843
), they moved in 1858 to Upper Stenhouse, Greenend, Liberton, S Edinburgh.
Brewster, Sir David (1781–1868; ODNB), principal and vice-chancellor of Edinburgh Univ. 1859–68.

Bright, John (1811–89; ODNB), politician, parliamentary reformer; he and TC had met and argued in 1847; see 22:68 TC to JWC, 13 [14] Sept. 1847
.

Bromley, Caroline Davenport (1820–91), da. of Rev. Walter Davenport Bromley (1787–1862) of Wootton Hall, Staffordshire, and his first wife, m., 1818, Caroline Barbara, b. Gooch (1791–1827). A friend of Lady Louisa Ashburton, she became a close friend of JWC’s. The Carlyles called her “Lark,” “Die Lerche,” or “Flight of Skylarks.” Her London home was at 32 Grosvenor St. Her brother was William Davenport Bromley (1821–84), m., 1858, Augusta Elizabeth, b. Campbell (d. 1916); by 1866 they had two children, Evelyn Caroline (1859–1931) and Walter Arthur (1863–1942); there were to be three more.
Brookfield, William Henry (1809–74; ODNB), Church of England clergyman, m., 1841, Jane Octavia, b. Elton (1821–96; ODNB), literary hostess and writer.

Browning, Robert (1812–89; ODNB), poet, TC’s friend since the mid-1830s
(see 30:74 TC to JAC, 26 Sept. 1855
, and 133 TC to RB, 4 Dec. 1855
). His wife, m. 1846, was Elizabeth Barrett, b. Moulton Barrett (1806–61), poet. Robert Wiedemann Barrett (“Pen”) (1849–1912) was their only child.

Butler, Charles (1802–97; see 28:314 TC to JCA, 18 Nov. 1853
), U.S. lawyer, financier, land speculator, entrepreneur, and philanthropist; welcome in Britain for his part in handling the threat by some U.S. states in the 1840s to default on their bonds; met TC in Nov. 1853 and looked after his Illinois bonds and other American investments. He m., 1825, Eliza, b. Ogden (1803–78); they had five children: Abraham Ogden Butler (1832–56), two other sons who d. in infancy, and two das., Emily (b. 1840) and Anna (d. 1877).

Carlyle, Alexander (Alick) (1797–1876), TC’s brother; emigrated with his family to Canada, 1843; settled at the Bield, 4½ mi. (7 km.) W of Brantford, Ontario. He m., 1830, Janet, b. Clow (1809–91); they had six surviving sons: Thomas (1833–1921), John (1839–1924), Alexander (see below), James (1846–1924), William (1849–1935), and Robert (1851–1932); and three surviving das.: Jane Welsh (1831–84), who m., 1852, Robert Sims; Janet (1836–1916); and Margaret (1847–1935); see 1:166 TC to AC, 23 Feb. 1819
. An unidentified son (1832–33), Margaret (1835–36), James (b. 1840), and Euphemia (1853–54) all d. in infancy; see 32:4 TC to AC, 3 Oct. 1856
.

Carlyle, Alexander (1843–1931; see 16:153 TC to AC, 4 May 1843
), Alexander and Janet’s son; m., 1879, his cousin Mary Aitken; lived with TC from 1879 and ed. various collections of the Carlyles’ letters and TC’s writings.

Carlyle, James (Jamie) (1805–90), TC’s brother, farmer at Scotsbrig; m., 1834, Isabella, b. Calvert (ca. 1813–1859). Their children were James (Jr., the younger) (1835–71), who had been working in Glasgow as a clerk but was now back home; m., 18 Sept. 1866, his cousin Catherine Austin; John (1836–1901); Thomas (1839–41); and Janet (Jessie or Jenny) (1843–74), m., 1864, William Scott (b. ca. 1829), draper from Birmingham; their son John James Carlyle was b. July 1865.
Carlyle, Margaret Aitken (1771–1853), TC’s mother; she had lived with James and Isabella Carlyle at Scotsbrig. TC’s father was James Carlyle (1758–1832); they m. 1795.

Chapman, Edward (1804–80; ODNB), senior partner in Chapman & Hall, retired 1864. TC’s publisher since 1842 (see 14:37 TC to JF, 5 Feb. 1842
); he m., 1841, Mary, b. Whiting (b. ca. 1820).

Chapman, Frederic (1823–95; ODNB), Edward Chapman’s cousin and partner in Chapman & Hall; took over the management of the company 1864; he m., 1861, Clara, b. Woodin (1842–28 Feb. 1866); they had one surviving son, Frederic, and a baby who d. early 1866.

Christison, Robert (1797–1882; ODNB), Edinburgh physician, toxicologist, professor of medicine at Edinburgh Univ., member of the University Court 1858–82; m., 1827, Henrietta Sophia, b. Brown (d. 1849); they had three sons: Alexander, an army doctor; David (1830–1912), Edinburgh physician and archaeologist, already known to TC as Lord Ashburton’s doctor; see 39:18 JWC to BB, [25 Dec. 1862] , and 170 ; and John, Writer to the Signet, and secretary of the Edinburgh University Court.

Clough, Blanche Mary Shore, b. Smith (1828–1904), m. 1854, Arthur Hugh Clough (1819–61; ODNB), poet, known to TC since the mid-1840s; see 20:76 TC to AHC, 7 Dec. 1845
, and 24:6–7 TC to JWC, 3 April 1849
. They had at least four children.

Conway, Moncure Daniel (1832–1907), Virginia-born American Unitarian minister, abolitionist, and author; friend of Ralph Waldo Emerson’s, who introduced him to TC. He m., 1858, Ellen, b. Dana (d. 1897); they had two sons, Eustace (b. 1858) and Emerson (1861–64). They came to Britain 1863 and lived at 28 Notting Hill Sq., London. Conway was pastor at South Place Chapel, 11 South Pl., Finsbury, London, 1864–84.

Cooke, John George (known as George Cooke) (1819–80), stockbroker; he had met JWC in 1856 (see 30:252 JWC’s Journal, 18 May 1856
) and became a close friend. She described him in 1864: “a man between thirty and forty; tall, strong, silent, sincere; has been a sailor, a soldier, a New Zealand settler, ‘a Man about Town,’ and a Stock Broker!!!” ( 41:65–66 JWC to MR, [10 Oct. 1864] ). He lived at 18 Pelham Place, Brompton. He had five sisters, including Charlotte (b. 1811, Margaretta (b. 1815), and Louisa (b. 1817).
