Craik, Dinah Maria, b. Mulock (1826–87; ODNB), writer, known to JWC since 1852; see 27:387 JWC to HW, [30 Dec. 1852] . She m., 29 April 1865, George Lillie Craik (1837–1905), an accountant, son of Rev. James Craik (1802–70) and Margaret,
b. Grieve; nephew of the Carlyles’ friend George Lillie Craik (see below). George Lillie Craik was a partner in Alexander Macmillan’s publishing company, 1865–1905.
Darwin, Erasmus Alvey (1804–81), friend of the Carlyles since 1835; brother of Charles Darwin (1809–82; ODNB).

Davidson, Henry (1807–84), sheriff-clerk of East Lothian. His brother David (1811–1900; see 38:277 38:biographical notes ) was a childhood friend of JWC’s; their aunt was Janet Davidson (1782–1869); see 39:42 JWC to JAD, [29 Jan. 1863] .

Delepine, Elizabeth Marie Louise, b. Jäger (b. ca. 1831), known as Madame Elise, milliner and dressmaker at 170 Regent St.; she inherited the business from her aunt, Jane Clarke (d. 1859, milliner (see also 33:141 JWC to DD, 29 Dec. 1857
). TC noted on a photograph of her: “‘Madame Elise’ I think a fashionable Dressmaker, whom she [JWC] thot a real artist, and who valued her approval in a marked manner” (see 41:130 JWC to MR, [19 Dec. 1864] ; Thomas Carlyle Photograph Albums, vol. 2; Rare Book and Manuscript Lib., Columbia Univ.). She m., 1857, Frederick Wooton Isaacson (1836–98), silk merchant; they had three children: Frederick (b. ca. 1858), Violet Elise Marie Louise (ca. 1861–1910), and Rudolph (b. ca. 1863). They lived at Hill House, Acton.

Dickens, Charles (1812–70; ODNB), novelist; friend of the Carlyles since the early 1840s; m., 1836, Catherine Thomson, b. Hogarth (1816–79); separated from her in 1858; see 33:233 TC to RWE, 2 June 2858
.

Dilberoglue, Sarah, b. Coxon (ca. 1827–69; see 28:21–22 JWC to KS, [28 Jan. 1853] ), actress (her stage name had been Anderton); she m., 1859, Stauros Dilberoglue (1818–78), Greek businessman, philanthropist, and art collector; they lived at 13 Barnsbury Park, Islington. Stauros lived in England from the mid-1830s; he was a partner in Cavafy & Co., which traded from 31 Threadneedle St., London (see 40:227 40:biographical notes ).

Dixon, Thomas, cork cutter from Sunderland; working-class activist and educator; he had first written to TC Aug. 1862; see 38:168 JWC to TC, [27 Aug. 1862] , and 175 TC to JWC, 29 Aug. 1862
.

Dods, William (1795–1873; see 33:79 JWC to LAI, [11 Sept. 1857] ), Haddington bank agent; childhood admirer of JWC’s. He m., first, Harriet, b. Shirreff (ca. 1804–53), with whom he had seven sons and two das.; see 37:265 37:biographical notes . He m., second, 1854, Jane, b. Wilkie (ca. 1809–85); they lived on Court St., Haddington. His photograph, For his photograph, see
39:63 JWC to JAD, 21 Feb. [1863]
, is incorrectly captioned . His brother was Thomas Dods (1800–1878; see 33:88 JWC to WDO, [19? Sept. 1857] ).
Elise, Madame; see Delepine.

Emerson, Ralph Waldo (1803–82; see 6:425 TC to JAC, 27 Aug. 1833
), philosopher, essayist, poet, and transcendentalist. He first met TC in Aug. 1833; in spite of their differences they had close ties; he introduced many Americans to TC and played a leading part in arranging the publication of TC’s works in the U.S.

Erskine, Thomas (1788–1870; ODNB; see 10:18 TC to JAC, 1 Feb. 1838
), theologian and retired advocate, living at Linlathen, Dundee; known to the Carlyles since the mid-1830s. He had two widowed sisters who lived with him: Christian (1789–1866), who m., 1817, Charles Stirling; and David (1791–1867), who m., 1821, Capt. James Paterson. During the winter they mainly lived at 11 Gt. Stuart St., Edinburgh.
Ewart, Alicia, b. Yorstoun or Yorston (ca. 1789–1882), widow of Thomas Ewart (d. 1831), m. 1828; friend of Mary Russell, living at Nithbank, Thornhill; see 40:193–94 JWC to TC, [19 Aug. 1864] .
Eyre, Edward John (1815–1901; ODNB), governor of Jamaica 1862–65.

Forster, John (“Fuz”) (1812–76; ODNB; see 6:118 TC to JHLH, 8 Feb. 1832
, and 11:7 TC to JF, [25? Jan. 1839] ), historian, journalist, and biographer; ed. of the Examiner 1847 –55; sec. to the Lunacy Commission 1855–61, and a commissioner from Feb. 1861; friend of the Carlyles since the late 1830s and TC’s literary adviser. He m., 1856, Eliza Ann, b. Crosbie (ca. 1819–94), widow of the publisher Henry Colburn (ca. 1784–1855; ODNB); from late 1863 they lived at Palace Gate House, Kensington.

Froude, James Anthony (1818–94; ODNB), journalist and historian, ed. of Fraser’s Magazine 1860 –74; he m., first, 1849, Charlotte Maria, b. Grenfell (1812–60); they had two das., Georgina Margaret (1850–1935) and Rose Mary (b. 1852), and a son, Pascall Grenfell (1854–79). He m., second, 1861, Henrietta Elizabeth, b. Warre (1824–74); they had a son, Ashley Anthony (1863–1949), and a da., May (b. 1867). They lived at 5 Onslow Gdns., Fulham Rd. Henrietta’s father, John Ashley Warre (1787–1860), had m., as his third wife, Charlotte Froude’s sister Caroline (1809–86).
Gladstone, William Ewart (1809–98; ODNB), politician, chancellor of the exchequer 1859–66; m., 1839, Catherine, b. Glynne (1812–1900; ODNB).

Graham, Agnes, b. Veitch (b. 1801), m., 1822, Thomas Graham; see 33:36 JWC to TC, [18 Aug. 1857] ; sister of Hamilton Veitch (1804–65), soldier, JWC’s schoolfellow and admirer; see 32:210 JWC to TC, [30 July 1857] ; for his death, see 42:190–91 JWC to TC, 15 Aug. [1865]
.

Hanning, Janet Carlyle (1813–97), TC’s sister; m., 1836, Robert Hanning (1796–1878), who had emigrated to Canada in mysterious disgrace in 1841; she joined him in Hamilton, Ontario, Aug. 1851, with their two das., Margaret (b. 1838) and Mary (b. 1840), who m., 1864, Charles Coates Holden (b. 1836). In Canada they had two more das., Catherine (b. ca. 1852) and Jane.

Hiddleston/Hiddlestone, Jessie (1835–1904), the Carlyles’ maid 1865–66; she
m., 1866, Robert Broadfoot (ca. 1833–90), butler to Archibald Watson Goldie (1793–1872), Writer to the Signet, and his second wife, Henrietta Townsend, b. Hare (d. 1904), m. 1860. Her mother was Margaret (ca. 1800–4 May 1865), widow, m. 1830, of William Hiddleston, tailor; maid to JWC’s mother at Templand; see 14:160 TC to JWC, 21 April 1842
; and her sister was Margaret (1831–1904), m., 1855, Joseph McCaig (1829–76), cabinetmaker, living at 62 W. Morton St., Thornhill.

Hill, Amelia Robertson, b. Paton (1820–1904; ODNB), sculptor; second wife, m. 1862, of David Octavius Hill (1802–70; ODNB), painter and photographer. Her bust of Carlyle (1866–67) was exhibited at the Royal Scottish Academy (1867) and at the Royal Academy.
Hotten, John Camden (1825–73; ODNB), publisher and writer.

Houghton, Richard Monckton Milnes (1809–85; ODNB), 1st baron, author, and politician; see 9:8 TC to JAC, 14 July 1836
, and 12:9–10 TC to RWE, 6 Jan. 1840
; lived at 16 Upper Brook St., London, and Fryston Hall, Yorkshire; the Carlyles’ friend since the late 1830s despite political differences; Milnes supported religious and civil liberties and championed progressive causes, such as education for the working class and prison reform; M.P. for Pontefract 1837–63; 1st baron, 20 Aug. 1863. He m., 1851, Annabella, b. Hungerford Crewe (1814–74); they had two das. and a son; see 37:270 37:biographical notes .

Howard, Rosalind Francis, b. Stanley (1845–1921; ODNB), m., 1864, George James Howard (1843–1911; ODNB), artist and politician, only son of the Hon. Charles Wentworth George Howard (1814–74) and Mary Priscilla Harriet, b. Parke (1822–43). Their first da. was Mary Henrietta Howard (20 July 1865–1956).
Huxley, Thomas Henry (1825–95; ODNB), biologist and science educationist.

Inglis, Henry (1806–85), Writer to the Signet, Edinburgh lawyer at 16 Queen St., whom the Carlyles had known since the late 1820s; see 5:12 TC to HI, 31 March 1829
. He m. Marianne (b. 1816), and they had four children: Andrew (b. 1832), Kate (b. ca. 1836), Fanny (b. 1838), and William (b. 1840); they lived at Torsonce House, Stow, Midlothian.

Irving, Edward (1792–1834; ODNB; see 1:92 TC to RM, 12 Feb. 1817
, later vols., and Carlyle, Reminiscences), the Carlyles’ great friend; religious leader and preacher.

Jewsbury, Geraldine Endsor (1812–80; ODNB; see 12:103–4 TC to GEJ, 12 April 1840
), novelist, reviewer, and misc. writer; friend of the Carlyles, particularly JWC, since 1841. She lived at 41 Markham Sq., London.
Kelland, Philip (1808–79; ODNB), professor of mathematics at Edinburgh Univ. 1838–79, secretary of the Senatus Academicus from the 1840s until 1867.
Kerr; see Lothian.

Laing, David (1793–1878; ODNB), antiquary; librarian of the Signet Lib., Edinburgh, 1837–78. When TC became rector of Edinburgh Univ. he
chose Laing as his assessor on the Senatus Academicus. Laing’s youngest sister, Euphemia (1808–96), lived with him as his housekeeper after the death of their mother, Helen, b. Kirk (1767–1837); since 1845 they had lived in East Villa, 12 James St., Portobello.

Larkin, Henry (1820–99), collector or cashier for the Chelsea Steamboat Co.; partner in an engineering business; wrote Carlyle and the Open Secret of His Life (1886). For TC’s early contacts with him, see 25:322 TC to HL, 29 Dec. 1850
, and 27:78 TC to HL, 29 March 1852
. He worked on TC’s indexes and maps from 1856; see 34:57 JWC to TC, 19 July 1858
. For their disagreements over his final work on Frederick, see vol. 41. He m., 1862, Louisa, b. Wagstaff (b. 1837); they had a son, Alfred Edward (b. 1863), and a da., Nora, who d. at birth (1864). They lived at 6 Cheyne Row until 1864, when they moved to 6 Torriano Cottages, Leighton Rd., NW London.

Lothian, Lady Constance Harriet Mahonesa, b. Chetwynd-Talbot (1836–1901), marchioness, da. of Henry John Chetwynd-Talbot (1803–68), 18th earl of Shrewsbury, and Lady Sarah Elizabeth, b. Beresford (1807–84), m. 1828. She m., 1854, William Schomberg Robert Kerr (1832–70), 8th marquess, a noted bibliophile, and an invalid for much of his life. They lived at Blickling Hall, Norfolk, and Newbattle Abbey, Dalkeith.
McCaig; see Hiddleston.

Maccall, William (1812–88; ODNB), impoverished writer, Unitarian preacher, lecturer, and author; m., 1842, Alice, b. Haselden (1813–78); they had one da., Elizabeth (b. 1843). They lived at Fountain Villa, Woolwich, Rd., Bexley Heath, Kent. See K. J. Fielding, “Carlyle, Charles Dickens, and William Maccall,” Notes and Queries n.s. 1 (1954): 488–90.

Macmillan, Alexander (1818–96; ODNB), publisher, m., 1851, Caroline, b. Brimley (1824–71). They had five children, Malcolm Kingsley (1852–1889), George Augustin (1855–1936), Margaret (b. 1857), Olive (b. 1859), and William Alexander (1864–1966). After the death of Alexander’s brother and business partner, Daniel Macmillan (1813–57; ODNB), his sister-in-law, Frances Eliza, b. Orridge (1821–67), and her four children, Frederick Orridge (1851–1936), Maurice Crawford (1853–1936), Katherine (b. 1855), and Arthur (1857–1876), came to live in his household. They lived at The Elms, Streatham Lane, Tooting.

Masson, David (1822–1907; ODNB; see 16:312 JWC to TC, 24 July 1843
); writer and editor, prof. of English lang. and lit., University Coll., London, 1853–65, and of rhetoric and English lit., Edinburgh Univ., 1865–95. He m., 1853, Emily Rosaline, b. Orme (1835–1915); they had four children; they lived at 3 Roseberry Terr., Edinburgh. He was also ed. of Macmillan’s Magazine 1859 –68.

Mazzini, Giuseppe (1805–72; see 11:225 TC to JSM, 6 Dec. 1839
, and 28:xiii–xiv 28:acknowledgments ), Italian revolutionary; friend of the Carlyles since the late 1830s. He was usually based in London, although he continued to agitate for a united Italian republic. His photograph, 39:64, is incorrectly captioned.
Milnes, Richard Monckton; see Houghton.
Muir, John (1810–82; ODNB), Sanskritist; he was appointed as an assessor to the General Council of Edinburgh Univ. in 1863.
Mulock; see Craik.

Oliphant, Margaret Oliphant, b. Wilson (1828–97; ODNB), novelist, biographer, reviewer, and misc. writer; she m., 1852, her cousin Francis Wilson Oliphant (1818–59; ODNB); their children were Margaret Wilson (1853–64), Marjorie (1854–55), a son who d. at birth (1855), Cyril Francis (“Tids”) (1856–90), and Francis Romano (“Cecco”) (1859–94). Her parents were Margaret Oliphant Wilson (ca. 1789–1854) and Francis W. Wilson (ca. 1788–1858). Friend of JWC since 1860; see 37:62 JWC to MO, [12 Dec. 1860] .

Orrock, Agnes (b. 1817), and her sister Elizabeth (b. 1819), Edinburgh lodging house keepers, previously at 67 Hanover St., now at 73 George St.; John A. Carlyle lodged with them for many years (see 42:147 TC to JAC, 25 July 1865
).
Paterson; see Erskine.

Pollock, William Frederick (1815–88; ODNB), lawyer and author, m., 1844, Juliet, b. Creed (1818–99); they lived at 59 Montagu Sq. His father was Sir Jonathan Frederick Pollock (1783–1870; ODNB), 1st baronet, judge, lord chief baron of the exchequer 1844–66; he m., first, 1813, Frances,
b. Rivers (ca. 1787–1827); m., second, 1834, Sarah Anne, b. Langslow (1815–95); see 29:33 TC to JAC, 17 Feb. 1854
.

Price, Maria Ann (1839–1910), lived with her father, Joseph Price (ca. 1800–1872), widower, master tailor, in Camberwell, S London. She had three sisters, Ellen (b. ca. 1840), a governess, Martha (b. ca. 1842), and Mary (b. ca. 1844). The 1861 census recorded that Price employed three men, and that his four das. lived with him at 10 Church St., Lambeth (also in S London). Maria m., 12 Nov. 1868, Henry Henshaw (1845–80), corn merchant; they had four children, Beatrice (b. ca. 1870), Henry Maurice Carlyle (b. ca. 1872), Helen Mabel (b. ca. 1873), and Harry Edwards (b. ca. 1875); they lived in Biggleswade, Bedfordshire. The 1881 census recorded her as Maria A. Henshaw, corndealer, Market Sq., Biggleswade. The 1891 census recorded her as a “visitor” to Islington, “living on her own means.” Her “Recollections of Thomas Carlyle” (which included material on her friendship with JWC) was pbd. in Blackwood’s Edinburgh Magazine (Jan. 1896) 31–37.

Quain, Richard (1816–98; ODNB), physician, specializing in heart diseases, and with many wealthy and influential patients; he lived at 67 Harley St., London. He m., 1854, Isabella Agnes, b. Wray (1828–91); they had four das. He treated the Ashburtons and JWC.

Reichenbach, Oskar von (1815–93), Silesian landowner, liberal deputy to the Frankfurt Parliament 1848–49, exiled to London in 1850. Friend of the Carlyles since the 1840s. His wife, m. 1842, was Friederika or Fredrike (called Hedwig in error before vol. 39), b. Plattnauer (b. 1817), sister of Richard Eduard Plattnauer (b. 1814; see 41:234 41:biographical notes ); and their children were Elisabeth (b. 1843), Hedwig (1844–92), and Oskar (b. 1845). They emigrated to the U.S. in 1853 but returned to London in 1863. In 1866 Reichenbach visited Prussia to assist Otto von Bismarck in the drafting of a constitution for the North German Confederation, which formed the political basis of the later empire.

Ruskin, John (1819–1900; ODNB), author, artist, and social reformer; m., 1848, Euphemia Chalmers, b. Gray (1828–97); marriage annulled 1854 (she then m., 1855, John Everett Millais [1829–96; ODNB], artist). Ruskin lived in the family home at 163 Denmark Hill, S London, with his mother, Margaret, b. Cock (1781–1871). His father, John James Ruskin (1785–1864), had been a wine merchant.

Russell, Elizabeth Ann, b. Rawdon (1793–1874), widow of Lord George William Russell (1790–1846; ODNB), soldier and diplomat; she had three sons: Francis Charles Hastings (1819–91), M.P. for Bedfordshire 1847–72; Arthur John Edward (1825–92), M.P. for Tavistock 1857–85, with whom she lived at 2 Audley Sq., London; and Odo Leopold William (1829–84; ODNB), diplomat. She was always known as Lady William
Russell; see Carlyle, Reminiscences 187. Arthur Russell m., Oct. 1865, Laura, b. de Peyronnet (1837–1910); for her parents see JWC to TC, [15 April] ; Arthur and Laura were to have six children.
Russell, John; see Amberley.

Russell, Mary, b. Dobbie (1802–75; see 6:145 TC to AC, [7 April 1832] ), close friend of JWC and her mother. She m., 1829, Dr. James Russell (ca. 1796–1878); they had moved to Holmhill, nr. Thornhill, by Oct. 1859. Her father was Rev. Edward Dobbie (1773–1857; see 14:65 TC to JWC, 9 March 1842
).

Saffi, Aurelio (1819–90), count, poet, and politician, supporter of Mazzini; see 33:280 33:biographical notes ; friend of the Carlyles since 1851; see 26:231 JWC to JAC, [15 Nov. 1851] . Returning to Italy, he was elected to the new Italian Parliament, 1861, then returned to London, 1864. He m., 1857, Scottish-born Giorgina Janet, b. Craufurd (1827–1911), da. of Sir John Craufurd (1780–1867), Scottish nobleman, magistrate, and deputy lieutenant of Ayr, and Sophia-Marianna, b. Churchill (ca. 1785–1865), m. 1814. Raised in Florence, Giorgina returned to Britain in 1849; a feminist, she was a devoted follower and close friend of Mazzini. The Saffis had four sons: Attilio Joseph (1858–1923), Emilio John (1861–1930), Charles Balilla Louis (1863–1896), and Rinaldo Arthur (1868–1929).
Silvester, John (b. ca. 1799), livery stable owner, Upper Church St., Chelsea. His wife was Phoebe (ca. 1800–1865); they had a son John (b. ca. 1829) and a grandson William (b. ca. 1857).

Snowden, Eliza Jane, b. Miles (1808–71?); the Carlyles lodged with her family in Ampton St., London, 1831–32; see 6:40 TC to MAC, 10 Nov. 1831
, and 172–73 JWC to EMI, 16 June 1832
. Her father was an upholsterer; he d. 1834, and her mother had remarried by 1841. Eliza m. James Wilde Snowden (b. 1806), upholsterer, and they had six children: James (b. ca. 1837), William (b. ca. 1839), Eliza (b. ca. 1840), Athol (b. 1842), Shenstone (b. 1845), and Ada (b. 1847). They lived at 2 Park Cres., Church St., Stoke Newington.

Southam, Charlotte, b. Watson (1842–1905), the Carlyles’ maid until June 1861; see 37:273 37:biographical notes ; then housemaid at the Kent home of George Charles Pratt (1799–1866), 2d marquis of Camden; see 39:103 JWC to CSO, 29 March 1863
. She continued to visit and correspond with both Carlyles. She m., 1866, Adolphus James Mills (b. 1842), a carpenter; they had five sons: Adolphus Berby (b. 1869), Thomas (b. 1871), Alfred George (b. 1875), Ernest (b. 1876), and Edward (b. 1880). Orphaned in childhood, she had been adopted by her uncle and aunt, Thomas (1806–64), a waterman, and Elizabeth (b. ca. 1805) Southam, whose surname she took; Elizabeth and Thomas are often referred to as Charlotte’s mother and father; they lived on Lawrence St., near Cheyne Row.

Stanley, Arthur Penrhyn (1815–81; ODNB), dean of Westminster 1864–81. He m., 1863, Lady Augusta Bruce (1822–1876; ODNB), da. of Thomas Bruce (1766–1841; ODNB), 7th earl of Elgin; former lady of the bedchamber and secretary to Queen Victoria. He was 1st cousin to Edward John Stanley.

Stanley, Henrietta Maria, b. Dillon (1807–95; ODNB), m., 1826, Edward John (1802–69; ODNB; see 12:59 TC to JAC, 27 Feb. 1840
), 2d Baron Stanley of Alderley, Whig politician; living at Alderley Park, Cheshire; their London home was at 40 Dover St. Both were friends of the Carlyles. Lord Stanley was nicknamed Lord Ben after Sir Benjamin Backbite, a character in Richard Brinsley Sheridan’s School for Scandal (ca. 1780 (see 35:264 35:biographical notes ). They had nine surviving children: Henry Edward John (1827–1903; ODNB); Alice Margaret (1828–1910), m., 1853, Augustus Henry Lane Fox-Pitt-Rivers; Henrietta Blanche (see Airlie); Maude Alethea (1833–1915; ODNB); John (Johny) Constantine (1837–78); Edward Lyulph (1839–1925; ODNB); Katherine (Kate) Louisa (see Amberley); Algernon Charles (1843–1928); and Rosalind Francis (see Howard).

Stephen, James Fitzjames (1829–94; ODNB), lawyer and writer; he was to be the executor of TC’s will; see 41:24 TC to JWC, 14 Sept. 1864
. He had two brothers, Herbert (ca. 1822–1846) and Leslie (1832–1904; ODNB), and two sisters, one d. in infancy (1825) and Caroline Emelia (1834–1909; ODNB); their father was Sir James Stephen (1789–1859; ODNB; see 8:197 JWC to JCA, [mid-Aug. 1835] ), lawyer and civil servant, under-secretary for the colonies 1836–48; friend of TC’s since the early 1840s; see 15:194 TC to RWE, 17 Nov. 1842
.

Sterling, Sir Anthony Coningham (1805–71; ODNB; see 9:103 TC to JAC, 2 Dec. 1836
, and later vols.), soldier; m., 1829, Charlotte, b. Baird (d. 1863), who suffered attacks of insanity and was jealous of JWC (see 18:266–67 JWC to HW, 12 Nov. 1844
, and 19:9 JWC to HW, 9 Jan. 1845
); he lived at 3 South Pl., Knightsbridge. His brother John (1806–44; ODNB), writer, had been a particular friend of TC’s; see CL vols. 8–18 and Carlyle’s Life of Sterling (1851); for John Sterling’s children, see 35:264–65 35:biographical notes .

Stewart, Margaret, b. Austin (1831–74), m., 1859, Thomas Stewart (1832–69), farmer from Hollybush, now living at Ernhirst (Ironhirst), about 5½ mi. (9 km.) SW of Dumfries; see 38:19 TC to JAC, 1 Dec. 1861
; they had a da., Mary (b. ca. 1861) and a son, William (b. 1863).
Stirling, Christian; see Erskine.

Stirling, Sir William Maxwell (1818–78; ODNB), art historian, book collector, and politician; known to TC since 1848. On the death of his uncle Sir John Maxwell of Pollock (1791–1865), 6 June 1865, he succeeded to the title and became Sir William Stirling Maxwell, 9th bart. He m., 26 April 1865, Anne Maria, b. Leslie-Melville (ca. 1825–74), da. of David Leslie-Melville (1785–1860), 10th earl of Leven, and Elizabeth Anne, b. Campbell (1804–63). They had two sons, John (6 June 1866–1956) and Archibald (1867–1931). They lived at Keir, 3 mi. (5 km.) NW of Stirling.

Stodart, John Riddle (1793–1871), Writer to the Signet and notary public; JWC’s old suitor; cousin of Eliza Aitken (see above); see 24:222 JWC to TC, [5 Sept. 1849] , and 39:23 JWC to JRS, [31 Dec. 1863] .
Sylvester; see Silvester.

Symington, Andrew James (1826–98; see 34:240 TC to JCA, 13 Nov. 1858
), Glasgow merchant, poet, and biographer; old acquaintance of the Carlyle family; he m., 1860, Mary Sanderson, b. Edmonston (1832–1917) from Shetland; they had a son, Andrew James (b. 1863). They lived in Govan, Lanarkshire.

Taylor, Herbert (1827–1903), Algernon (1830–1903), and Helen (1831–1907; ODNB), children of John Taylor (1796–1849) and Harriet Taylor Mill (see above), m. 1826; Herbert lived with his wife, Annie (b. ca. 1826), at Wimbledon Common; by 1871 they had three children: Herbert (b. ca. 1854), Elenor (b. ca. 1858), and Geoffrey (b. ca. 1868). Helen lived with her stepfather, John Stuart Mill, in Blackheath.

Tennyson, Alfred (1809–92; ODNB), poet; poet laureate from 1850. Friend of the Carlyles since the early 1840s. He m., 1850, Emily Sarah, b. Sellwood (1813–96); they had two sons, and they lived at Farringford, Freshwater, Isle of Wight.

Trevelyan, Sir Walter Calverley (1797–1879; ODNB), naturalist; m., 1835, Paulina, b. Jermyn (1816–13 May 1866; ODNB), art patron; they lived at Wallington Hall in Northumberland. Lady Trevelyan was a close friend of Lady Louisa Ashburton.

Trollope, Anthony (1815–82; ODNB), novelist and post office surveyor; see 37:183 TC to JAC, 9 [8] July 1861
.

Tulloch, Jane Anne, b. Hindmarsh (ca. 1826–87), m., 1845, John Tulloch (1823–86; ODNB), Church of Scotland minister and principal of St. Mary’s College, St. Andrews; they had three das., Sarah Elizabeth (b. 1848), Isabella Frances (b. 1850), and Janeanne (b. 1855), and several sons. Close friends of Margaret Oliphant.

Twisleton, Hon. Edward Turner Boyd (1809–74; ODNB), close and respected friend of the Carlyles’ (see 28:184 TC to JWC, 5 July 1853
); he m., 1852, Ellen, b. Dwight (1828–62), from Boston, Mass., JWC’s close friend and confidante; she wrote, 1855, an account of JWC’s early married life at Craigenputtoch (see 30:267–74 Ellen Twistleton’s Account ). He lived at 3 Rutland Gate, London.

Tyndall, John (1820–93; ODNB), physicist, professor of natural philosophy at the Royal Institution from 1853; TC’s admirer and friend from the mid-1850s; see 31:1–2 TC to JF, 2 Jan. 1856
.
Veitch; see Graham.
Venables, George Stovin (1810–88; ODNB), lawyer and journalist; contributor to the Saturday Review from its founding, 1855, and to the Times, 1857–88.

Venturi, Emilie (ca. 1819–93; ODNB), da. of William Henry Ashurst (ca. 1791–1855; ODNB; portrait painter), supporter of Italian independence and campaigner for women’s rights; unhappily m. to Sydney Hawkes, whom she divorced 1861; see 30:215 JWC’s Journal, 13 Nov. 1855
and 235
27 March 1856
. She m., 1861, Carlo Venturi (ca. 1830–27 March 1866). A strong supporter of Mazzini and the Young Italy movement, she published various English editions of his writings and Joseph Mazzini: A Memoir (1875).

Ward, Charles Augustus (1828–1914), vintner, author, antiquarian, and book collector; see 29:123–4 TC to CAW, 6 July 1854
, and TC to CAW, 7 July 1854 . He lived at 1 Chapel St., Mayfair. His mother was Eliza, b. Wade (1796–1864), and his father, Charles Ward (b. ca. 1791). He often wrote under the pseudonym Feltham Burghley; see 36:262–64 TC to CAW, 24 Sept. 1860
.

Warren, Sarah (b. ca. 1812 in Norfolk), a widow with adult children (see 41:96 TC to JAC, 7 Nov. 1864
), cook and housekeeper at Cheyne Row from Nov. 1864 until at least 1871, as she was listed in the 1871 census as still at 5 Cheyne Row. Mrs. Warren was previously wrongly identified as Eliza Warren (ca. 1816–1905) in vols. 41 and 42.
Watkins, John (1823–74), photographer, originally from Raglan in Monmouthshire; he and his brother Octavius Charles Watkins (1836–82) had a studio at 34 Parliament St., Westminster, 1851–65.
Watt; see John. A. Carlyle.

Welsh, Alexander (Alick) (b. 1816), son of JWC’s maternal uncle John; m., ca. 1849, Sophy, b. Martin (b. ca. 1824). Their children were John (Jackie) (ca. 1853–64), Isabella Helen (b. 1856; see 31:201 JWC to TC, [29 Aug. 1856] ), Margaret (b. 1858), and Jean (b. 1860); they lived at Sandown Park, Wavertree, Liverpool.

Welsh, Ann (1799–1877), Elizabeth (1792–1877), and Grace (1801–67), JWC’s paternal aunts (see 14:67 TC to JWC, 10 March 1842
, and 16:219 JWC to JW, [ca. 26 June 1843] ), living at Craigen Villa, Morningside, Edinburgh.

Welsh, Grace, b. Welsh (1782–1842), JWC’s mother; m., 1800, John Welsh (1776–1819; see 1:202–3 JBW to EWE, 5 Oct. 1819
), JWC’s father, doctor in Haddington.

Welsh, Jeannie (ca. 1798–1828), JWC’s maternal aunt; for her death, see 4:358 TC to JAC, 16 April 1828
, and Carlyle, Reminiscences 127–29.

Welsh, Margaret, b. Kissock (1803–88; see 13:44 JWC to MW, [late Feb. 1841] , and 20:128 JWC to MW, Feb.–March 1846
), widow of JWC’s paternal uncle George (1793–1835), living at 19 St. Johns Grove, Richmond, nr. London. Her son was John Welsh (1824–59; ODNB; see 15:37JWC to MW, [ca. 20 Aug. 1842]), F.R.S., meteorologist, whom JWC described as “worth all my cousins tied up in one bundle!” (35:58).
Welsh, Margaret (Maggie) (b. 1821), da. of JWC’s maternal uncle John; lived in Auchtertool with her brother Walter; was JWC’s nurse, Dec. 1863–May 1864.
Welsh, Mary (1823–79), da. of JWC’s maternal uncle John; lived in Auchtertool with her brother Walter.

Welsh, Rev. Walter (1815–1879; see 16:12 JWC to JW, [8 Jan. 1843] ), son of JWC’s maternal uncle John; minister at Auchtertool, Fife, since 1842. His sisters Margaret (Maggie) and Mary lived with him.

Woolner, Thomas (1825–92; ODNB; see 26:37 TC to TWO, [21 Feb. 1851] , and 29:176–77 TC to LA, 20 Oct. 1854
), sculptor and poet; he lived at 29 Welbeck St., London. He m., 1864, Alice Gertrude, b. Waugh (b. 1845, da. of George and Mary Waugh. Their da. Amy was b. 21 Aug. 1865.

Wynn, Charlotte Williams (1807–69; ODNB), diarist; see 19:102 TC to JAC, 17 July 1845
